[OEBcw - Mark 15:41] all of whom used to accompany Jesus when he was in Galilee, and attend on him — besides many other women who had come up with him to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Mark 15:42] The evening had already fallen, when, as it was the Preparation day — the day before the Sabbath —
[OEBcw - Mark 15:43] Joseph from Ramah, a Councillor of good position, who was himself living in expectation of the kingdom of God, came and ventured to go in to see Pilate, and to ask for the body of Jesus.
[OEBcw - Mark 15:44] But Pilate was surprised to hear that he had already died. So he sent for the officer, and asked if he were already dead;
[OEBcw - Mark 15:45] and, on learning from the officer that it was so, he gave the corpse to Joseph.
[OEBcw - Mark 15:46] Joseph, having bought a linen sheet, took Jesus down, and wound the sheet round him, and laid him in a tomb which had been cut out of the rock; and then rolled a stone up against the entrance of the tomb.
[OEBcw - Mark 15:47] Mary of Magdala and Mary, the mother of Joseph, were watching to see where he was laid.
[OEBcw - Mark 16 - start] 
[OEBcw - Mark 16:1] When the Sabbath was over, Mary of Magdala, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought some spices, so that they might go and anoint the body of Jesus.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:2] And very early on the first day of the week they went to the tomb, after sunrise.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:3] They were saying to one another: “Who will roll away the stone for us from the entrance of the tomb?”
[OEBcw - Mark 16:4] But, on looking up, they saw that the stone had already been rolled back; it was a very large one.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:5] Going into the tomb, they saw a young man sitting on their right, in a white robe, and they were dismayed; But he said to them:
[OEBcw - Mark 16:6] “Do not be dismayed; you are looking for Jesus, the Nazarene, who has been crucified; he has risen, he is not here! Look! Here is the place where they laid him.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:7] But go, and say to his disciples and to Peter ‘He is going before you into Galilee; there you will see him, as he told you.’”
[OEBcw - Mark 16:8] They went out, and fled from the tomb, for they were trembling and bewildered; and they did not say a word to anyone, for they were frightened;
[OEBcw - Mark 16:9] after his rising again, early on the first day of the week, Jesus appeared first of all to Mary of Magdala, from whom he had driven out seven demons.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:10] She went and told the news to those who had been with him and who were now in sorrow and tears;
[OEBcw - Mark 16:11] yet even they, when they heard that he was alive and had been seen by her, did not believe it.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:12] Afterwards, altered in appearance, he made himself known to two of them, as they were walking, on their way into the country.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:13] They also went and told the rest, but they did not believe even them.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:14] Later on, he made himself known to the Eleven themselves as they were at a meal, and reproached them with their want of faith and their stubbornness, because they did not believe those who had seen him after he had risen from the dead.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:15] Then he said to them: “Go into all the world, and proclaim the good news to all creation.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:16] ​He who believes and is baptized will be saved; but he who refuses to believe will be condemned.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:17] ​Moreover these signs will attend those who believe. In my name they will drive out demons; they will speak with ‘tongues’;
[OEBcw - Mark 16:18] ​they will take up snakes in their hands; and, if they drink any poison, it will not hurt them; they will place their hands on sick people and they will recover.”
[OEBcw - Mark 16:19] So the Lord Jesus, after he had spoken to them, was taken up into heaven, and sat at the right hand of God.
[OEBcw - Mark 16:20] But they set out, and made the proclamation everywhere, the Lord working with them, and confirming the message by the signs which attended it.But all that had been revealed to them they reported briefly to Peter and his companions. Afterwards Jesus himself sent them out, from east to west, the sacred and imperishable proclamation of eternal salvation.
[OEBcw - Luke 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 1:1] To his Excellency, Theophilus. Many attempts have been already made to draw up an because of those events which have reached their conclusion among us,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:2] just as they were reported to us by those who from the beginning were eye-witnesses, and afterwards became bearers of the message.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:3] And, therefore, I also, since I have investigated all these events with great care from their very beginning, have resolved to write a connected history of them for you,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:4] in order that you may be able to satisfy yourself of the accuracy of the story which you have heard from the lips of others.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:5] In the reign of Herod, king of Judea, there was a priest named Zechariah, who belonged to the division called after Abijah. His wife, whose name was Elizabeth, was also a descendant of Aaron.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:6] They were both righteous people, who lived blameless lives, guiding their steps by all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:7] But they had no child, Elizabeth being barren; and both of them were advanced in years.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:8] One day, when Zechariah was officiating as priest before God, during the turn of his division,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:9] it fell to him by lot, in accordance with the practice among the priests, to go into the Temple of the Lord and burn incense;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:10] and, as it was the Hour of Incense, the people were all praying outside.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:11] And an angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing on the right of the Altar of Incense.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:12] Zechariah was startled at the sight and was awe-struck.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:13] But the angel said to him: “Do not be afraid, Zechariah; your prayer has been heard, and your wife Elizabeth will bear you a son, whom you will call by the name John.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:14] He will be to you a joy and a delight; and many will rejoice over his birth.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:15] For he will be great in the sight of the Lord; he will not drink any wine or strong drink, and he will be filled with the Holy Spirit from the very hour of his birth,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:16] and will reconcile many of the Israelites to the Lord their God.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:17] He will go before him in the spirit and with the power of Elijah, ‘to reconcile fathers to their children’ and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous, and so make ready for the Lord a people prepared for him.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:18] “How can I be sure of this?” Zechariah asked the angel. “For I am an old man and my wife is advanced in years.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:19] “I am Gabriel,” the angel answered, “who stand in the presence of God, and I have been sent to speak to you and to bring you this good news.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:20] And now you will be silent and unable to speak until the day when this takes place, because you did not believe what I said, though my words will be fulfilled in due course.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:21] Meanwhile the people were watching for Zechariah, wondering at his remaining so long in the Temple.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:22] When he came out, he was unable to speak to them, and they perceived that he had seen a vision there. But Zechariah kept making signs to them, and remained dumb.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:23] And, as soon as his term of service was finished, he returned home.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:24] After this his wife, Elizabeth, became pregnant and lived in seclusion for five months.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:25] “The Lord has done this for me,” she said, “he has shown me kindness and taken away the public disgrace of childlessness under which I have been living.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:26] Six months later the angel Gabriel was sent from God to a town in Galilee called Nazareth,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:27] to a maiden there who was engaged to a man named Joseph, a descendant of David. Her name was Mary.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:28] Gabriel came into her presence and greeted her, saying: “You have been shown great favour - the Lord is with you..”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:29] Mary was much disturbed at his words, and was wondering to herself what such a greeting could mean,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:30] when the angel spoke again: “Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favour with God.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:31] And now, you will conceive and give birth to a son, and you will give him the name Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:32] The child will be great and will be called ‘Son of the Most High,’ and the Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:33] and he will reign over the descendants of Jacob for ever; And to his kingdom there will be no end.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:34] “How can this be?” Mary asked the angel. “For I have no husband.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:35] “The Holy Spirit will descend on you,” answered the angel, “and the Power of the Most High will overshadow you; and therefore the child will be called ‘holy,’ and ‘Son of God.’
[OEBcw - Luke 1:36] And Elizabeth, your cousin, is herself also expecting a son in her old age; and it is now the sixth month with her, though she is called barren;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:37] for no promise from God will fail to be fulfilled.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:38] “I am the servant of the Lord,” exclaimed Mary; “let it be with me as you have said.” Then the angel left her.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:39] Soon after this Mary set out, and made her way quickly into the hill-country, to a town in Judah;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:40] and there she went into Zechariah’s house and greeted Elizabeth.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:41] When Elizabeth heard Mary’s greeting, the child moved within her, and Elizabeth herself was filled with the Holy Spirit,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:42] and cried aloud: “Blessed are you among women, and blessed is your unborn child!
[OEBcw - Luke 1:43] But how have I this honour, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
[OEBcw - Luke 1:44] For, as soon as your greeting reached my ears, the child moved within me with delight!
[OEBcw - Luke 1:45] Happy indeed is she who believed that the promise which she received from the Lord would be fulfilled.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:46] And Mary said: “My soul exalts the Lord,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:47] my spirit delights in God my Saviour;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:48] for he has remembered his humble servant girl; And from this hour all ages will count me happy!
[OEBcw - Luke 1:49] Great things has the Almighty done for me; And holy is his name.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:50] From age to age his mercy rests On those who honour him.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:51] Mighty are the deeds of his arm; He scatters the proud with their own devices,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:52] he casts down princes from their thrones, and the humble he uplifts,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:53] the hungry he loads with gifts, and the rich he sends empty away.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:54] He has stretched out his hand to his servant Israel, Ever mindful of his mercy
[OEBcw - Luke 1:55] (As he promised to our forefathers) For Abraham and his race for ever.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:56] Mary stayed with Elizabeth about three months, and then returned to her home.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:57] When Elizabeth’s time came, she gave birth to a son;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:58] and her neighbours and relations, hearing of the great goodness of the Lord to her, came to share her joy.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:59] A week later they met to circumcise the child, and were about to call him ‘Zechariah’ after his father,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:60] when his mother spoke up: “No, he is to be called John.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:61] “You have no relation of that name!” they exclaimed;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:62] and they made signs to the child’s father, to find out what he wished the child to be called.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:63] Asking for a writing-tablet, he wrote the words — ‘His name is John.’ Everyone was surprised;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:64] and immediately Zechariah recovered his voice and the use of his tongue, and began to bless God.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:65] All their neighbours were awe-struck at this; and throughout the hill-country of Judea the whole story was much talked about;
[OEBcw - Luke 1:66] and all who heard it kept it in mind, asking one another — ​“What can this child be destined to become?” For the Power of the Lord was with him.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:67] Then his father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit, and, speaking under inspiration, said:
[OEBcw - Luke 1:68] “Blessed is the Lord, the God of Israel, Who has visited his people and wrought their deliverance,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:69] and has raised up for us the Strength of our salvation In the house of his servant David —
[OEBcw - Luke 1:70] As he promised by the lips of his holy prophets of old —
[OEBcw - Luke 1:71] salvation from our enemies and from the hands of all who hate us,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:72] showing mercy to our forefathers, And mindful of his sacred covenant.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:73] This was the oath which he swore to our forefather Abraham —
[OEBcw - Luke 1:74] That we should be rescued from the hands of our enemies,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:75] and should serve him without fear in holiness and righteousness, In his presence all our days.
[OEBcw - Luke 1:76] And you, child, will be called prophet of the Most High, For you will go before the Lord to make ready his way,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:77] to give his people the knowledge of salvation In the forgiveness of their sins,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:78] through the tender mercy of our God, Whereby the Dawn will break on us from heaven,
[OEBcw - Luke 1:79] to give light to those who live in darkness and the shadow of death, And guide our feet into the way of peace.”
[OEBcw - Luke 1:80] The child grew and became strong in spirit; and he lived in the Wilds until the time came for his appearance before Israel.
[OEBcw - Luke 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 2:1] About that time an edict was issued by the Emperor Augustus that a census should be taken of the whole Empire.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:2] (This was the first census taken while Quirinius was Governor of Syria).
[OEBcw - Luke 2:3] And everyone went to his own town to be registered.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:4] Among others Joseph went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Bethlehem, the town of David, in Judea — because he belonged to the family and house of David —
[OEBcw - Luke 2:5] To be registered with Mary, his engaged wife, who was about to become a mother.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:6] While they were there her time came,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:7] and she gave birth to her first child, a son. And because there was no room for them in the inn, she swathed him round and laid him in a manger.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:8] In that same country-side were shepherds out in the open fields, watching their flocks that night,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:9] when an angel of the Lord suddenly stood by them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them; and they were seized with fear.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:10] “Have no fear,” the angel said. “For I bring you good news of a great joy in store for all the nation.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:11] This day there has been born to you, in the town of David, a Saviour, who is Christ and Lord.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:12] And this will be the sign for you. You will find the infant swathed, and lying in a manger.”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:13] Then suddenly there appeared with the angel a multitude of the heavenly Host, praising God, and singing —
[OEBcw - Luke 2:14] “glory to God on high, And on earth peace among those in whom he finds pleasure.”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:15] Now, when the angels had left them and gone back to heaven, the shepherds said to one another: “Let us go at once to Bethlehem, and see this thing that has happened, of which the Lord has told us.”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:16] So they went quickly, and found Mary and Joseph, and the infant lying in a manger;
[OEBcw - Luke 2:17] and, when they saw it, they told of all that had been said to them about this child.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:18] All who heard the shepherds were astonished at their story,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:19] while Mary treasured up all that they said, and thought about it often in her thoughts.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:20] And the shepherds went back, giving glory and praise to God for all that they had heard and seen, as it had been told them.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:21] Eight days after the birth of the child, when it was time to circumcise him, he received the name Jesus — the name given him by the angel before his conception.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:22] When the period of purification of mother and child, required by the law of Moses, came to an end, his parents took the child up to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:23] in compliance with the law of the Lord that ‘every first-born male will be dedicated to the Lord,’
[OEBcw - Luke 2:24] And also to offer the sacrifice required by the law of the Lord — ‘a pair of turtle-doves or two young pigeons.’
[OEBcw - Luke 2:25] There was at that time in Jerusalem a man named Simeon, a righteous and devout man, who lived in constant expectation of the Consolation of Israel, and under the guidance of the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:26] It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he should not die until he had seen the Lord’s Christ.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:27] Moved by the Spirit, Simeon came into the Temple Courts, and, when the parents brought in the child Jesus, to do for him what was customary under the law,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:28] Simeon himself took the child in his arms, and blessed God, and said:
[OEBcw - Luke 2:29] “Now, Lord, you will let your servant go, According to your word, in peace,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:30] for my eyes have seen the salvation
[OEBcw - Luke 2:31] Which you have prepared in the sight of all nations —
[OEBcw - Luke 2:32] A light to bring light to the Gentiles, And to be the glory of your people Israel.”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:33] While the child’s father and mother were wondering at what was said about him,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:34] Simeon gave them his blessing, and said to Mary, the child’s mother: “This child is appointed to be the cause of the fall and rise of many in Israel, and to be a sign much spoken against —
[OEBcw - Luke 2:35] Yes, the sword will pierce your own heart — and so the thoughts in many minds will be disclosed.”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:36] There was also a Prophetess named Hannah, a daughter of Phanuel and of the tribe of Asher. She was far advanced in years, having lived with her husband for seven years after marriage,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:37] and then a widow, until she had reached the age of eighty-four. She never left the Temple Courts, but, fasting and praying, worshiped God night and day.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:38] At that moment she came up, and began publicly to thank God and to speak about the child to all who were looking for the deliverance of Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:39] When the child’s parents had done everything required by the law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee to their own town of Nazareth.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:40] The child grew and became strong and wise, and the blessing of God was on him.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:41] Every year the child’s parents used to go to Jerusalem at the Passover Festival.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:42] When Jesus was twelve years old, they went according to custom to Jerusalem,
[OEBcw - Luke 2:43] and had finished their visit; but, when they started to return, the boy Jesus remained behind in Jerusalem, without their knowing it.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:44] Thinking that he was with their fellow travellers, they went one day’s journey before searching for him among their relations and acquaintances;
[OEBcw - Luke 2:45] and then, as they did not find him, they returned to Jerusalem, searching everywhere for him.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:46] It was not until the third day that they found him in the Temple Courts, sitting among the teachers, now listening to them, now asking them questions.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:47] All who listened to him marvelled at his intelligence and his answers.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:48] His parents were amazed when they saw him, and his mother said to him: “My child, why have you treated us like this? Your father and I have been searching for you in great distress.”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:49] “What made you search for me?” he answered. “Did not you know that I must be in my Father’s house?”
[OEBcw - Luke 2:50] His parents did not understand what he meant.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:51] However he went down with them to Nazareth, and submitted himself to their control; and his mother treasured all that was said in her heart.
[OEBcw - Luke 2:52] And Jesus grew in wisdom as he grew in years, and ‘gained the blessing of God and people.’
[OEBcw - Luke 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 3:1] In the fifteenth year of the reign of the Emperor Tiberius, when Pontius Pilate was Governor of Judea, Herod Ruler of Galilee, his brother Philip Ruler of the territory comprising Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias Ruler of Abilene,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:2] and when Annas and Caiaphas were high priests, a command from God came to John, the son of Zechariah, while he was in the wilderness.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:3] And John went through the whole district of the Jordan, proclaiming baptism on repentance, for the forgiveness of sins.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:4] This was in fulfilment of what is said in the writings of the prophet Isaiah — ‘The voice of one crying aloud in the wilderness: “Make ready the way of the Lord, Make his paths straight.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:5] Every chasm will be filled, Every mountain and hill will be levelled, The winding ways will be straightened, The rough roads made smooth,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:6] and everyone will see the salvation of God.”’
[OEBcw - Luke 3:7] And John said to the crowds that went to be baptized by him: “You children of snakes! Who has prompted you to seek refuge from the coming judgment?
[OEBcw - Luke 3:8] Let your lives, then, prove your repentance; and do not begin to say among yourselves ‘Abraham is our ancestor,’ for I tell you that out of these ​stones God is able to raise descendants for Abraham!
[OEBcw - Luke 3:9] Already, indeed, the axe is lying at the root of the trees. Therefore every tree that fails to bear good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire.”
[OEBcw - Luke 3:10] “What are we to do then?” the people asked.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:11] “Let anyone who has two coats,” answered John, “share with the person who has none; and anyone who has food do the same.”
[OEBcw - Luke 3:12] Even tax-gatherers came to be baptized, and said to John: “Teacher, what are we to do?”
[OEBcw - Luke 3:13] “Do not collect more than you have authority to demand,” John answered.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:14] And when some soldiers on active service asked “And we — what are we to do?” he said: “Never use violence, or exact anything by false accusation; and be content with your pay.”
[OEBcw - Luke 3:15] Then, while the people were in suspense, and were all debating with themselves whether John could be the Christ,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:16] John, addressing them all, said: “I, indeed, baptize you with water; but there is coming one more powerful than I, and I am not fit even to unfasten his sandals. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:17] His winnowing-fan is in his hand so that he may clear his threshing-floor, and store the grain in his barn, but the chaff he will burn with a fire that cannot be put out.”
[OEBcw - Luke 3:18] And so with many different appeals John told his good news to the people.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:19] But Prince Herod, being rebuked by John respecting Herodias, the wife of Herod’s brother, and for all the evil things that he had done,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:20] crowned them all by shutting John up in prison.
[OEBcw - Luke 3:21] Now after the baptism of all the people, and when Jesus had been baptized and was still praying, the heavens opened,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:22] and the Holy Spirit descended, in a visible form, like a dove, on him, and from the heavens came a voice — “You are my dearly loved son; you bring me great joy.”
[OEBcw - Luke 3:23] When beginning his work, Jesus was about thirty years old. He was regarded as the son of Joseph, whose ancestors were — Eli,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:24] Mattith, Levi, Melchiah, Janna, Joseph,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:25] Mattithiah, Amos, Nahum, Azaliah, Nogah,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:26] Mattith, Mattithiah, Shimei, Joseph, Josheh,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:27] Johanan, Rhesa, Zerubbabel, Shealtiel, Neriah,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:28] Melchiah, Addi, Cosam, Elmodam, Er,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:29] Joshua, Eliezer, Joram, Mattith, Levi,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:30] Simeon, Judah, Joseph, Jonam, Eliakim,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:31] Meleah, Menan, Mattithiah, Nathan, David,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:32] Jesse, Obed, Boaz, Salah, Nahshon,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:33] Amminadab, Arni, Hezron, Perez, Judah,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:34] Jacob, Isaac, Abraham, Terah, Nahor,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:35] Serug, Reu, Peleg, Eber, Shelah,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:36] Kenan, Arpachshad, Shem, Noah, Lamech,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:37] Methuselah, Enoch, Jared, Mahalalel, Kenan,
[OEBcw - Luke 3:38] Enosh, Seth and Adam the son of God.
[OEBcw - Luke 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 4:1] On returning from the Jordan, full of the Holy Spirit, Jesus was led by the power of the Spirit through the wilderness for forty days, tempted by the devil.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:2] All that time he ate nothing; and, when it was over, he became hungry.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:3] So the devil said to him: “If you are God’s Son, tell this stone to become a loaf of bread.”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:4] And Jesus answered him: “Scripture says — ‘It is not on bread alone that a person is to live.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:5] And the devil led Jesus up, and showing him in a single moment all the kingdoms of the earth, said to him:
[OEBcw - Luke 4:6] “I will give you all this power, and the splendour of them; for it has been given into my hands and I give it to whom I wish.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:7] If you worship me, it will all be yours.”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:8] And Jesus answered him: “Scripture says — ‘You should worship the Lord your God, and worship him only.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:9] The devil next led him into Jerusalem, and, placing him on the parapet of the Temple, said: “If you are God’s Son throw yourself down from here,
[OEBcw - Luke 4:10] for scripture says — ‘He will give his angels commands about you, to guard you safely,’
[OEBcw - Luke 4:11] And ‘On their hands they will lift you up, otherwise you might strike your foot against a stone.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:12] But Jesus answered him: “It is said — ‘You must not tempt the Lord your God.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:13] When he had tried every kind of temptation, the devil left Jesus, until another opportunity.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:14] Moved by the power of the Spirit, Jesus returned to Galilee. Reports about him spread through all that neighbourhood;
[OEBcw - Luke 4:15] and he began to teach in their Synagogues, and was honoured by everyone.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:16] Coming to Nazareth, where he had been brought up, Jesus, as was his custom, went on the Sabbath into the Synagogue, and stood up to read the scriptures.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:17] He was given the book of the prophet Isaiah; and Jesus opened the book and found the place where it says —
[OEBcw - Luke 4:18] ​‘The Spirit of the Lord is on me, For he has consecrated me to bring good news to the poor, He has sent me to proclaim release to captives and restoration of sight to the blind, To set the oppressed at liberty,
[OEBcw - Luke 4:19] ​to proclaim the accepted year of the Lord.’
[OEBcw - Luke 4:20] Then, closing the book and returning it to the attendant, he sat down. The eyes of all in the Synagogue were fixed on him,
[OEBcw - Luke 4:21] and Jesus began:  “This very day this passage has been fulfilled in your hearing.”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:22] All who were present spoke well of him, and were astonished at the beautiful words that fell from his lips. “Is not he Joseph’s son?” they asked.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:23] ​“Doubtless,” said Jesus, “you will remind me of the saying — ​‘Doctor, cure yourself;’ and you will say ‘Do here in your own country all that we have heard that has been done at Capernaum.’
[OEBcw - Luke 4:24] ​I tell you,” he continued, “that no prophet is acceptable in his own country.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:25] ​There were, doubtless, many widows in Israel in Elijah’s days, when the heavens were closed for three years and six months, and a severe famine prevailed throughout the country;
[OEBcw - Luke 4:26] ​and yet it was not to one of them that Elijah was sent, but to a widow at Zarephath in Sidonia.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:27] ​And there were many lepers in Israel in the time of the prophet Elisha, yet it was not one of them who was made clean, but Naaman the Syrian.”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:28] All the people in the Synagogue, as they listened to this, became enraged.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:29] Starting up, they drove Jesus out of the town, and led him to the brow of the hill on which their town stood, intending to hurl him down.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:30] But he passed through the middle of the crowd and went on his way.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:31] Then Jesus went down to Capernaum, a city in Galilee. On the Sabbath he taught the people.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:32] They were amazed at his teaching, because his words were spoken with authority.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:33] In the Synagogue there was a man with the spirit of a foul demon in him, who called out loudly:
[OEBcw - Luke 4:34] “Stop! What do you want with us, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are — the Holy One of God!”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:35] But Jesus rebuked the demon. “Be silent! Come out from him,” he said. The demon flung the man down in the middle of the people, and then came out from him, without causing him further harm.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:36] And they were all lost in amazement, and kept saying to one another: “What words are these? For he gives his commands to the foul spirits with a marvellous authority, and they come out.”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:37] And rumours about Jesus traveled through every place in the neighbourhood.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:38] On leaving the Synagogue, Jesus went into Simon’s house. Now Simon’s mother-in-law was suffering from a severe attack of fever, and they asked Jesus to cure her.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:39] Bending over her, he rebuked the fever; the fever left her, and she immediately got up and began to take care of them.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:40] At sunset, all who had friends suffering from various diseases took them to Jesus; and he placed his hands on everyone of them and cured them.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:41] And even demons came out from many people, screaming ‘You are the Son of God.’ Jesus rebuked them, and would not allow them to speak, because they knew that he was the Christ.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:42] At daybreak, Jesus went out and walked to a lonely spot. But crowds of people began to look for him; and they came to where he was and tried to detain him and prevent his leaving them.
[OEBcw - Luke 4:43] Jesus, however, said to them: “I must take the good news of the kingdom of God to the other town also, for that was why I was sent.”
[OEBcw - Luke 4:44] And he continued to make his proclamation in the Synagogues of Judea.
[OEBcw - Luke 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 5:1] Once, when the people were pressing round Jesus as they listened to God’s message, he happened to be standing by the shore of the Lake of Gennesaret, and saw two boats close to the shore.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:2] The fishermen had gone away from them and were washing the nets.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:3] So, getting into one of the boats, which belonged to Simon, Jesus asked him to push off a little way from the shore, and then sat down and taught the people from the boat.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:4] When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon: “Push off into deep water, and throw out your nets for a haul.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:5] “We have been hard at work all night, Sir,” answered Simon, “and have not caught anything, but, at your bidding, I will throw out the nets.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:6] They did so, and enclosed such a great shoal of fish that their nets began to break.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:7] So they signalled to their partners in the other boat to come and help them; and they came and filled both the boats so full of fish that they were almost sinking.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:8] When Simon Peter saw this, he threw himself down at Jesus’ knees, exclaiming: “Master, leave me, for I am a sinful man!”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:9] For he and all who were with him were lost in amazement at the haul of fish which they had made;
[OEBcw - Luke 5:10] and so, too, were James and John, Zebedee’s sons, who were Simon’s partners. “Do not be afraid,” Jesus said to Simon; “from today you will catch people.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:11] And, when they had brought their boats to shore, they left everything, and followed him.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:12] On one occasion Jesus was staying in a town, when he saw a man who was covered with leprosy. When the leper saw Jesus, he threw himself on his face and implored his help: “Master, if only you are willing, you are able to make me clean.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:13] Stretching out his hand, Jesus touched him, saying as he did so: “I am willing; become clean.” Instantly the leprosy left the man;
[OEBcw - Luke 5:14] and then Jesus impressed on him that he was not to say a word to anyone, “but,” he added, “set out and show yourself to the priest, and make the offerings for your cleansing, in the manner directed by Moses, as evidence of your cure.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:15] However, the story about Jesus spread all the more, and great crowds came together to listen to him, and to be cured of their illnesses;
[OEBcw - Luke 5:16] but Jesus used to withdraw to lonely places and pray.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:17] On one of those days, when Jesus was teaching, some Pharisees and Doctors of the law were sitting near by. (They had come from all the villages in Galilee and Judea, and from Jerusalem; and the power of the Lord was on Jesus, so that he could work cures.)
[OEBcw - Luke 5:18] And there some men brought on a bed a man who was paralysed. They tried to get him in and lay him before Jesus;
[OEBcw - Luke 5:19] but, finding no way of getting him in owing to the crowd, they went up on the roof and lowered him through the tiles, with his pallet, into the middle of the people and in front of Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:20] When he saw their faith, Jesus said: “Friend, your sins have been forgiven you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:21] The teachers of the law and the Pharisees began debating about this. “Who is this man who speaks so blasphemously?” they asked. “Who can forgive sins except God?”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:22] When Jesus became aware of the way in which they were debating, he turned to them and exclaimed: “What are you debating with yourselves?
[OEBcw - Luke 5:23] ​Which is the easier? — to say ‘Your sins have been forgiven you’? Or to say ‘Get up, and walk’?
[OEBcw - Luke 5:24] ​But so that you may know that the Son of Man has power on earth to forgive sins” — ​he spoke to the paralysed man — “To you I say, Get up, and take up your pallet, and go to your home.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:25] Instantly the man stood up before their eyes, took up what he had been lying on, and went to his home, praising God.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:26] The people, one and all, were lost in amazement, and praised God; and in great awe they said: “We have seen marvellous things today!”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:27] After this, Jesus went out; and he noticed a tax-gatherer, named Levi, sitting in the tax office, and said to him: “Follow me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:28] Levi left everything and got up and followed him.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:29] And Levi gave a great entertainment at his house, in honour of Jesus; and a large number of tax-gatherers and others were having dinner with them.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:30] The Pharisees and the teachers of the law belonging to their party complained of this to the disciples of Jesus.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:31] In answer Jesus said: “It is not those who are well who need a doctor, but those who are ill.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:32] ​I have not come to call the religious, but the outcast, to repent.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:33] “John’s disciples,” they said to Jesus, “Often fast and say prayers, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees, while yours are eating and drinking!”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:34] But Jesus answered them: “Can you make the groom’s friends fast while the groom is with them?
[OEBcw - Luke 5:35] ​But the days will come — a time when the groom will be taken away from them; and they will fast then, when those days come.”
[OEBcw - Luke 5:36] Then, as an illustration, Jesus said to them: “No one ever tears a piece from a new garment and puts it on an old one; for, if they do, they will not only tear the new garment, but the piece from the new one will not match the old.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:37] ​And no one puts new wine into old wine-skins; for, if they do, the new wine will burst the skins, and the wine itself will run out, and the skins be lost.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:38] ​But new wine must be put into fresh skins.
[OEBcw - Luke 5:39] ​No one after drinking old wine wishes for new. ‘No,’ they say, ‘the old is excellent.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 6:1] One Sabbath Jesus was walking through cornfields, and his disciples were picking the ears of wheat, and rubbing them in their hands, and eating them.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:2] “Why are you doing what it is not allowable to do on the Sabbath?” asked some of the Pharisees.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:3] Jesus’ answer was: “Have not you read even of what David did, when he was hungry, he and his companions —
[OEBcw - Luke 6:4] ​That he went into the house of God, and took the consecrated bread and ate it, and gave some to his companions, though only the priests are allowed to eat it?”
[OEBcw - Luke 6:5] Then Jesus added: “The Son of Man is lord even of the Sabbath.”
[OEBcw - Luke 6:6] On another Sabbath Jesus went into the Synagogue and taught; and there was a man there whose right hand was withered.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:7] The teachers of the law and the Pharisees watched Jesus closely, to see if he would work cures on the Sabbath, so that they might find a charge to bring against him.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:8] Jesus, however, knew what was in the their minds, and said to the man whose hand was withered: “Stand up and come out into the middle.” The man stood up;
[OEBcw - Luke 6:9] and Jesus said to them: “I ask you, is it allowable to do good on the Sabbath — or harm? To save a life, or let it perish?”
[OEBcw - Luke 6:10] Then, looking round at them all, he said to the man: “Stretch out your hand.” The man did so; and his hand had become sound.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:11] But the teachers of the law and the Pharisees were goaded to madness, and consulted together what they could do to Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:12] Now about that time, Jesus went out, up the hill, to pray, and spent the whole night in prayer to God.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:13] When day came, he summoned his disciples, and chose twelve of them, whom he also named ‘apostles.’
[OEBcw - Luke 6:14] They were Simon (whom Jesus also named Peter), and his brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew,
[OEBcw - Luke 6:15] Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Simon known as the Zealot,
[OEBcw - Luke 6:16] Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who proved a traitor.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:17] Afterwards Jesus came down the hill with them and took his stand on a level place. With him were a large crowd of his disciples, and great numbers of people from the whole of Judea, Jerusalem, and the coast district of Tyre and Sidon,
[OEBcw - Luke 6:18] who had come to hear him and to be restored to health. Those, too, who were troubled with foul spirits were cured;
[OEBcw - Luke 6:19] and everyone in the crowd was trying to touch him, because a power went out from him which restored them all.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:20] Then, raising his eyes and looking at his disciples, Jesus said:  “Blessed are you who are poor, for yours is the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:21] Blessed are you who hunger now, for you will be satisfied. Blessed are you who weep now, for you will laugh.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:22] Blessed are you when people hate you, and when they expel you from among them, and insult you, and reject your name as an evil thing — because of the Son of Man.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:23] Then indeed you may be glad and dance for joy, for be sure that your reward in heaven will be great; for that is what their ancestors did to the prophets.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:24] ​But ‘alas for you who are rich,’ for you have had your comforts in full.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:25] Alas for you who are sated now, for you will hunger. Alas for you who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:26] Alas for you when everyone speaks well of you; for this is what their ancestors did to the false prophets.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:27] But to you who hear I say — love your enemies, show kindness to those who hate you,
[OEBcw - Luke 6:28] ​bless those who curse you, pray for those who insult you.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:29] ​When someone gives one of you a blow on the cheek, offer the other cheek as well; and, when anyone takes away your cloak, do not keep back your coat either.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:30] ​Give to everyone who asks of you; and, when anyone takes away what is yours, do not demand its return.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:31] ​Do to others as you wish them to do to you.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:32] If you love only those who love you, what thanks will be due to you? Why, even the outcast love those who love them!
[OEBcw - Luke 6:33] ​For, if you show kindness only to those who show kindness to you, what thanks will be due to you? Even the outcast do that!
[OEBcw - Luke 6:34] ​If you lend only to those from whom you expect to get something, what thanks will be due to you? Even the outcast lend to the outcast in the hope of getting as much in return!
[OEBcw - Luke 6:35] ​But love your enemies, and show them kindness, and lend to them, never despairing. Then your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High, for he is kind to the thankless and the bad.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:36] Learn to be merciful — even as your Father is merciful.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:37] ​Do not judge, and you will not be judged; do not condemn, and you will not be condemned. Forgive, and you will be forgiven.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:38] ​Give, and others will give to you. A generous measure, pressed and shaken down, and running over, will they pour into your lap; For The standard you use will be the standard used for you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 6:39] Then, speaking in parables, Jesus said: “Can one blind person guide another? Will they not both fall into a ditch?
[OEBcw - Luke 6:40] ​A scholar is not above their teacher; yet every finished scholar will be like their teacher.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:41] ​And why do you look at the speck of sawdust in someone’s eye, while you pay no attention at all to the plank of wood in your own?
[OEBcw - Luke 6:42] ​How can you say to your friend ‘Friend, let me take out the speck in your eye,’ while you yourself do not see the plank in your own? Hypocrite! Take out the plank from your own eye first, and then you will see clearly how to take out the speck in your friend’s.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:43] ​There is no such thing as a good tree bearing worthless fruit, or, on the other hand, a worthless tree bearing good fruit.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:44] ​For every tree is known by its own fruit. People do not gather figs off thorn bushes, nor pick a bunch of grapes off a bramble.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:45] ​A good person, from the good stores of their heart, brings out what is good; while a bad person, from their bad stores, brings out what is bad. For what fills someone’s heart will rise to their lips.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:46] ​Why do you call me ‘Master! Master!’ and yet fail to do what I tell you?
[OEBcw - Luke 6:47] ​Everyone who comes to me and listens to my teaching and acts on it — I will show you to whom they may be compared.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:48] ​They may be compared to a person building a house, who dug, and went deep, and laid the foundation on the rock. Then, when a flood came, the river swept down on that house, but had no power to shake it, because it had been built well.
[OEBcw - Luke 6:49] ​But those who have listened and not acted on what they have heard may be compared to a person who built a house on the ground without any foundation. The river swept down on it, and the house immediately collapsed; and great was the crash that followed.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 7:1] When Jesus had brought to a conclusion all that he had then had to say to the people, he entered Capernaum.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:2] A captain in the Roman army had a slave whom he valued, and who was seriously ill — almost at the point of death.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:3] And, hearing about Jesus, he sent some Jewish councillors to him, with the request that he would come and save his slave’s life.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:4] When they found Jesus, they earnestly implored him to do so. “He deserves the favour from you,” they said,
[OEBcw - Luke 7:5] “For he is devoted to our nation, and himself built our Synagogue for us.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:6] So Jesus went with them. But, when he was no great distance from the house, the captain sent some friends with the message — ​“Do not trouble yourself, Sir; for I am unworthy to receive you under my roof.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:7] That was why I did not even venture to come to you myself; but speak, and let my manservant be cured.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:8] For I myself am a man under the orders of others, with soldiers under me; and if I say to one of them ‘Go,’ he goes, and to another ‘Come,’ he comes, and to my slave ‘Do this,’ he does it.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:9] Jesus was surprised to hear these words from him; and, turning to the crowd which was following him, he said: “I tell you, nowhere in Israel have I met with such faith as this!”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:10] And, when the messengers returned to the house, they found the slave recovered.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:11] Shortly after, Jesus went to a town called Nain, his disciples and a great crowd going with him.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:12] Just as he approached the gate of the town, there was a dead man being carried out for burial — an only son, and his mother was a widow. A large number of the people of the town were with her.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:13] When he saw her, the Master was moved with compassion for her, and he said to her: “Do not weep.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:14] Then he went up and touched the bier, and the bearers stopped; and Jesus said: “Young man, I am speaking to you — Rise!”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:15] The dead man sat up and began to talk, and Jesus restored him to his mother.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:16] Everyone was awe-struck and began praising God. “A great prophet has arisen among us,” they said; “and God has visited his people.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:17] And this story about Jesus spread all through Judea, and in the neighbouring countries as well.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:18] All these events were reported to John by his disciples.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:19] So he summoned two of them, and sent them to the Master to ask — “Are you ‘the coming one,’ or are we to look for some one else?”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:20] When these men found Jesus, they said: “John the Baptist has sent us to you to ask — ‘Are you ‘the coming one,’ or are we to look for somebody else?’”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:21] At that very time Jesus had cured many people of diseases, afflictions, and wicked spirits, and had given many blind people their sight.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:22] So his answer to the question was: “Go and report to John what you have witnessed and heard — the blind recover their sight, the lame walk, the lepers are made clean, and the deaf hear, the dead are raised to life, the good news is told to the poor.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:23] ​And blessed is the person who finds no hindrance in me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:24] When John’s messengers had left, Jesus, speaking to the crowds, began to say with reference to John:
[OEBcw - Luke 7:25] ​“What did you go out into the wilderness to look at? A reed waving in the wind? If not, what did you go out to see? A man dressed in rich clothing? Why, those who are accustomed to fine clothes and luxury live in royal palaces.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:26] ​What then did you go to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and far more than a prophet.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:27] ​This is the ​man of whom scripture says — ‘I am sending my messenger ahead of you, and he will prepare your way before you.’
[OEBcw - Luke 7:28] There is, I tell you, no one born of a woman who is greater than John; and yet the least in the kingdom of God is greater than he.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:29] (All the people, when they heard this, and even the tax-gatherers, having accepted John’s baptism, acknowledged the justice of God.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:30] But the Pharisees and the students of the law, having rejected John’s baptism, frustrated God’s purpose in regard to them.)
[OEBcw - Luke 7:31] “To what then,” Jesus continued, “should I compare the people of the present generation? What are they like?
[OEBcw - Luke 7:32] ​They are like some little children who are sitting in the marketplace and calling out to one another — ‘We have played the flute for you, but you have not danced; We have wailed, but you have not wept!’
[OEBcw - Luke 7:33] ​For now that John the Baptist has come, not eating bread or drinking wine, you are saying ‘He has a demon in him’;
[OEBcw - Luke 7:34] ​and now that the Son of Man has come, eating and drinking, you are saying ‘Here is a glutton and a wine-drinker, a friend of tax-gatherers and outcasts.’
[OEBcw - Luke 7:35] ​And yet wisdom is vindicated by all her children.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:36] One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to dine with him, so Jesus went to his house and took his place at the table.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:37] Just then a woman, who was an outcast in the town, having heard that Jesus was eating in the Pharisee’s house, brought an alabaster jar of perfume,
[OEBcw - Luke 7:38] and placed herself behind Jesus, near his feet, weeping. Then she began to make his feet wet with her tears, and she dried them with the hair of her head, repeatedly kissing his feet and anointing them with the perfume.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:39] When the Pharisee who had invited Jesus saw this, he said to himself: “Had this man been ‘The prophet,’ he would have known who, and what sort of woman, this is who is touching him, and that she is an outcast.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:40] But, addressing him, Jesus said: “Simon, I have something to say to you.” “Pray do so, teacher,” Simon answered; and Jesus began:
[OEBcw - Luke 7:41] ​“There were two people who were in debt to a moneylender; one owed five hundred silver coins, and the other fifty.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:42] ​As they were unable to pay, he forgave them both. Which of them, do you think, will love him the more?”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:43] “I suppose,” answered Simon, “it will be the man to whom he forgave the greater debt.”  “You are right,” said Jesus,
[OEBcw - Luke 7:44] and then, turning to the woman, he said to Simon: “Do you see this woman? I came into your house — you gave me no water for my feet, but she has made my feet wet with her tears and dried them with her hair.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:45] ​You did not give me one kiss, but she, from the moment I came in, has not ceased to kiss my feet.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:46] ​You did not anoint even my head with oil, but she has anointed my feet with perfume.
[OEBcw - Luke 7:47] ​And for this, I tell you, her sins, many as they are, have been pardoned, because she has loved greatly; but one who has little pardoned him, loves but little.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:48] Then he said to the woman: “Your sins have been pardoned.”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:49] The other guests began to say to one another: “Who is this man who even pardons sins?”
[OEBcw - Luke 7:50] But Jesus said to the woman: “Your faith has delivered you; go, and peace be with you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 8:1] Shortly afterwards, Jesus went on a journey through the towns and villages, proclaiming the good news of the kingdom of God. With him went the Twelve,
[OEBcw - Luke 8:2] as well as some women who had been cured of wicked spirits and of infirmities. They were Mary, known as Mary of Magdala (from whom seven demons had been expelled),
[OEBcw - Luke 8:3] and Joanna (the wife of Herod’s steward, Chuza), and Susannah, and many others — all of whom provided for Jesus and his apostles out of their own resources.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:4] Once, when a great crowd was collecting, and, when the people of town after town were flocking to Jesus, he spoke to them in the form of a parable:
[OEBcw - Luke 8:5] ​“The sower went out to sow his seed; and, as he was sowing, some of the seed fell along the path and was trodden on; and the wild birds ate it up.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:6] ​Other seed fell on rock, and, as soon as it began to grow, having no moisture, withered away.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:7] ​Other seed fell in the middle of brambles, but the brambles grew up with it and choked it entirely.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:8] ​Other seed fell into rich soil, and grew, and gave a hundredfold return.” After saying this, Jesus cried aloud: “Let those who have ears to hear with hear.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:9] His disciples asked Jesus the meaning of this parable.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:10] ​“To you,” he said, “the knowledge of the hidden truths of the kingdom of God has been imparted, but to others in parables only, so that ‘though they have eyes they may not see, and though they have ears, they may not understand.’
[OEBcw - Luke 8:11] ​This is the parable — The seed is God’s message.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:12] ​By the seed which fell along the path are meant those who hear the message; but then comes the devil and carries away the message from their minds, to prevent their believing it and being saved.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:13] ​By the seed which fell on the rock are meant those who, as soon as they hear the message, welcome it joyfully; but they have no root, and believe it only for a time, and, when the time of temptation comes, they draw back.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:14] ​By that which fell among the brambles are meant those who hear the message, but who, as they go on their way, are completely choked by this world’s cares and wealth and pleasures, and bring nothing to perfection.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:15] ​But by that in the good ground are meant those who, having heard the message, keep it in the good, rich soil of their hearts, and patiently yield a return.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:16] No one sets light to a lamp and then covers it with a bowl or puts it underneath a couch, but they put it on a lamp-stand, so that anyone who comes in may see the light.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:17] ​Nothing is hidden which will not be brought into the light of day, not ever kept hidden which will not some day become known and come into the light of day.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:18] ​Take care, then, how you listen. For, to all those who have, more will be given; while, from all those who have nothing, even what they seem to have will be taken away.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:19] Presently Jesus’ mother and brothers came where he was, but they were not able to join him because of the crowd.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:20] So word was brought to him — ‘Your mother and your brothers are standing outside, wanting to see you.’
[OEBcw - Luke 8:21] His reply, spoken to them all, was: “My mother and my brothers are those who listen to God’s teaching and do what it says.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:22] One day about that time, Jesus got into a boat with his disciples and said to them: “Let us go across the lake.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:23] So they put off. While they were sailing, Jesus fell asleep. A squall swept down on the lake, and their boat was filling and they were in danger.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:24] So the disciples came and roused him. “Sir, Sir,” they cried, “we are lost!” Jesus rose and rebuked the wind and the rushing waves, and they fell, and a calm followed.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:25] ​“Where is your faith?” he exclaimed. But in great awe and amazement they said to one another: “Who can this be, who commands even the winds and the waves, and they obey him?”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:26] And they reached the country of the Gerasenes, which is on the opposite side to Galilee;
[OEBcw - Luke 8:27] and, on getting ashore, Jesus met a man, who had demons in him, coming out of the town. For a long time this man had worn no clothing, and he had not lived in a house, but in the tombs.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:28] Catching sight of Jesus, he shrieked out and threw himself down before him, and in a loud voice exclaimed: “What do you want with me, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you not to torment me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:29] For Jesus was commanding the foul spirit to come out from the man. On many occasions it had seized him, and, even when secured with chains and fetters, and watched, he would break through anything that bound him, and be driven by the demon into the Wilds.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:30] “What is your name?” Jesus asked. “Legion,” he answered (for many demons had taken possession of him);
[OEBcw - Luke 8:31] and the demons begged Jesus not to order them away into the bottomless pit.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:32] There was a drove of many pigs close by feeding on the hill-side; and the demons begged Jesus to give them leave to enter into them. Jesus gave them leave.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:33] They came out from the man and took possession of the pigs; and the drove rushed down the steep slope into the lake and were drowned.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:34] When the men who tended them saw what had happened, they ran away, and carried the news to the town, and to the country round.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:35] The people went out to see what had happened, and, when they came to Jesus, they found the man from whom the demons had gone out, sitting, clothed and in his right mind, at Jesus’ feet; and they were awe-struck.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:36] Those who had seen it told them how the possessed man had been delivered.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:37] Then all the people in the neighbourhood of the Gerasenes asked Jesus to leave them, for they were terrified. Jesus got into a boat and returned.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:38] The man from whom the demons had gone out begged Jesus to let him be with him; but Jesus sent him away.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:39] ​“Go back to your home,” he said, “and relate the story of all that God has done for you.” So the man went through the whole town and proclaimed, as he went, all that Jesus had done for him.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:40] On his return, Jesus was welcomed by the people; for everyone was looking out for him.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:41] And a man named Jaeirus, who was a President of the Synagogue, came to Jesus, and threw himself at Jesus’ feet, with entreaties that he would come to his house,
[OEBcw - Luke 8:42] because his only daughter, who was about twelve years old, was dying. As Jesus was going, the people were pressing closely round him.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:43] And a woman, who had suffered from haemorrhage for twelve years, and whom no one could cure,
[OEBcw - Luke 8:44] came up behind and touched the tassel of his cloak. Instantly the haemorrhage ceased.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:45] “Who touched me?” Jesus asked; and, while everyone was denying having done so, Peter exclaimed: “Why, Sir, the people are crowding round you and pressing against you!”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:46] “Somebody touched me,” said Jesus; “for I felt that power had gone out from me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:47] Then the woman, when she saw that she was discovered, came forward trembling, and threw herself down before him; and, in the presence of all the people, she told him her reason for touching him, and that she had been cured instantly.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:48] “Daughter,” he said, “your faith has delivered you. Go, and peace be with you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:49] Before he had finished speaking, some one came from the house of the President of the Synagogue and said: “Your daughter is dead! Do not trouble the teacher further.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:50] But Jesus, hearing this, spoke to the President: “Do not be afraid; only have faith, and she will yet be delivered.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:51] When he reached the house, he did not allow anyone to go in with him, except Peter, John, and James, and the child’s father and mother.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:52] And everyone was weeping and mourning for her.  “Do not weep,” Jesus said, “she is not dead; she is asleep.”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:53] They began to laugh at him, for they knew that she was dead.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:54] But, taking her by the hand, Jesus said in a loud voice: “Child, rise!”
[OEBcw - Luke 8:55] The child’s spirit returned to her, and she instantly stood up; and Jesus ordered them to give her something to eat.
[OEBcw - Luke 8:56] Her parents were amazed, but Jesus impressed on them that they were not to tell anyone what had happened.
[OEBcw - Luke 9 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 9:1] Jesus called the Twelve together, and gave them power and authority over all demons, as well as to cure diseases.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:2] He sent them out as his messengers, to proclaim the kingdom of God, and to work cures.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:3] ​“Do not,” he said to them, “take anything for your journey; not even a staff, or a bag, or bread, or any silver, or a change of clothes with you.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:4] ​Whatever house you go to stay in, remain there, and leave from that place.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:5] ​If people do not welcome you, as you leave that town, shake even the dust off your feet, as a protest against them.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:6] Then they set out and went from village to village, telling the good news and curing people everywhere.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:7] Prince Herod heard of all that was happening, and was perplexed, because it was said by some that John must be risen from the dead.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:8] Some again said that Elijah had appeared, and others that one of the old prophets had risen again.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:9] But Herod himself said: “John I beheaded; but who is this of whom I hear such things?” And he endeavoured to see him.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:10] When the apostles returned, they related to Jesus all that they had done. Then Jesus went privately to a town called Bethsaida, taking the apostles with him.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:11] But the people recognised him and followed him in crowds; and Jesus welcomed them and spoke to them about the kingdom of God, while he cured those who were in need of help.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:12] The day was drawing to a close, when the twelve came up to him, and said: “Send the crowd away, so that they may make their way to the villages and farms round about, and find themselves lodgings and provisions, for we are in a lonely spot here.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:13] But Jesus said: “It is for you to give them something to eat.” “We have not more than five loaves and two fishes,” they answered; “unless indeed we are to go and buy food for all these people.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:14] (For the men among them were about five thousand.) “Get them seated in companies,” was his reply, “about fifty in each.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:15] This they did, and got all the people seated.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:16] Taking the five loaves and the two fishes, Jesus looked up to heaven and said the blessing over them. Then he broke them in pieces, and gave them to his disciples to set before the people.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:17] Everyone had sufficient to eat, and what was left of the broken pieces was picked up — twelve baskets.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:18] Afterwards, when Jesus was alone, praying, his disciples joined him, and he asked them this question — “Who do the people say that I am?”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:19] “John the Baptist,” was their answer; “others, however, say that you are Elijah, while others say that one of the old prophets has risen again.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:20] “But you,” he went on, “who do you say that I am?” And to this Peter answered: “The Christ of God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:21] Jesus, however, strictly charged them not to say this to anyone;
[OEBcw - Luke 9:22] he told them that the Son of Man must undergo much suffering, and be rejected by the councillors, and chief priests, and teachers of the law, and be put to death, and rise on the third day.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:23] And to all present he said: “If any one wishes to walk in my steps, let them renounce self, and take up their cross daily, and follow me.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:24] ​For whoever wishes to save their life will lose it, and whoever, for my sake, loses his life — that person will save it.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:25] ​What good does it do someone if, when they has gained the whole world, they has lost or forfeited themselves?
[OEBcw - Luke 9:26] ​Whoever is ashamed of me and of my teaching, the Son of Man will be ashamed of them, when he comes in his glory and the glory of the father and of the holy angels.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:27] ​Indeed, I tell you, some who are standing before me will not know death, until they have seen the kingdom of God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:28] About eight days after speaking these words, Jesus went up the mountain to pray, taking with him Peter, John, and James.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:29] As he was praying, the aspect of his face was changed, and his clothing became of a glittering whiteness.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:30] And all at once two men were talking with Jesus; they were Moses and Elijah,
[OEBcw - Luke 9:31] who appeared in a glorified state, and spoke of his departure, which was destined to take place at Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:32] Peter and his companions had been overpowered by sleep but, suddenly becoming wide awake, they saw Jesus glorified and the two men who were standing beside him.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:33] And, as Moses and Elijah were passing away from Jesus, Peter exclaimed: “Sir, it is good to be here; let us make three tents, one for you, and one for Moses, and one for Elijah.” He did not know what he was saying;
[OEBcw - Luke 9:34] and, while he was speaking, a cloud came down and enveloped them; and they were afraid, as they passed into the cloud;
[OEBcw - Luke 9:35] and from the cloud came a voice which said — “This is my Son, the Chosen One; him you must hear.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:36] And, as the voice ceased, Jesus was found alone. The apostles kept silence, and told no one about any of the things that they had seen.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:37] The next day, when they had come down from the mountain, a great crowd met Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:38] And just then a man in the crowd shouted out: “Teacher, I entreat you to look at my son, for he is my only child;
[OEBcw - Luke 9:39] all at once a spirit will seize him, suddenly shriek out, and throw him into convulsions until he foams, and will leave him only when he is utterly exhausted.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:40] I entreated your disciples to drive the spirit out, but they could not.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:41] “Faithless and perverse generation!” Jesus exclaimed; “how long must I be with you and have patience with you? Lead your son here.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:42] While the boy was coming up to Jesus, the demon dashed him down and threw him into convulsions. But Jesus rebuked the foul spirit, and cured the boy, and gave him back to his father.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:43] And all present were struck with awe at the majesty of God. In the midst of the general astonishment at all that Jesus was doing, he said to his disciples:
[OEBcw - Luke 9:44] ​“Listen carefully to my words. For the Son of Man is destined to be betrayed into the hands of his fellow men.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:45] But the disciples did not understand the meaning of this; it had been concealed from them so that they did not see it, and they were afraid to question him as to what he meant.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:46] A discussion arose among the disciples as to which of them was the greatest;
[OEBcw - Luke 9:47] and Jesus, knowing of the discussion that was occupying their thoughts, took hold of a little child, and placed it beside him,
[OEBcw - Luke 9:48] and then said to them: “Anyone who, for the sake of my name, welcomes even this little child is welcoming me; and anyone who welcomes me is welcoming him who sent me as his messenger. For whoever is least among you all — that person is great.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:49] John said: “Sir, we saw a man driving out demons by using your name, and we tried to prevent him, because he does not follow you with us.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:50] “None of you must prevent him,” Jesus said to John; “whoever’s not against you is for you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:51] As the days before his being taken up to heaven were growing few, Jesus set his face resolutely in the direction of Jerusalem; and he sent on messengers in advance.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:52] On their way, they went into a Samaritan village to make preparations for him,
[OEBcw - Luke 9:53] but the people there did not welcome him, because his face was set in the direction of Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:54] When James and John saw this, they said: “Master, do you wish us to call for fire to come down from the heavens and consume them?”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:55] But Jesus turned and rebuked them.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:56] ​And they made their way to another village.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:57] And, while they were on their way, a man said to Jesus: “I will follow you wherever you go.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:58] “Foxes have holes,” he replied, “and wild birds their nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:59] To another man Jesus said: “Follow me.” “Let me first go and bury my father,” said the man.
[OEBcw - Luke 9:60] But Jesus said: “Leave the dead to bury their dead; but go yourself and carry far and wide the news of the kingdom of God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:61] “Master,” said another, “I will follow you; but first let me say goodbye to my family.”
[OEBcw - Luke 9:62] But Jesus answered: “No one who looks back, after putting their hand to the plough, is fitted for the kingdom of God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 10:1] After this, the Master appointed seventy-two other disciples, and sent them on as his messengers, two and two, in advance, to every town and place that he was himself intending to visit.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:2] “The harvest,” he said, “is abundant, but the labourers are few. Therefore pray to the owner of the harvest to send labourers to gather in his harvest.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:3] ​Now, go. Remember, I am sending you out as my messengers like lambs among wolves.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:4] ​Do not take a purse with you, or a bag, or sandals; and do not stop to greet anyone on your journey.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:5] ​Whatever house you go to stay at, begin by praying for a blessing on it.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:6] ​Then, if anyone there is deserving of a blessing, your blessing will rest on him; but if not, it will come back on yourselves.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:7] ​Remain at that same house, and eat and drink whatever they offer you; for the worker is worth their wages. Do not keep changing from one house to another.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:8] ​Whatever town you visit, if the people welcome you, eat what is set before you;
[OEBcw - Luke 10:9] ​cure the sick there, and tell people ‘The kingdom of God is close at hand.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:10] ​But, whatever town you go to visit, if the people do not welcome you, go out into its streets and say
[OEBcw - Luke 10:11] ​‘We wipe off the ​dust of your town which has clung to Our feet; still, be assured that the kingdom of God is close at Hand.’
[OEBcw - Luke 10:12] ​I tell you that the doom of Sodom will be more bearable on ‘that day’ than the doom of that town.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:13] ​Alas for you, Chorazin! Alas for you, Bethsaida! For, if the Miracles which have been done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon, they would have sat in sackcloth and ashes and repented long ago.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:14] ​Yet the doom of Tyre and Sidon will be more bearable at the judgment than yours.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:15] ​And you, Capernaum! Will you ‘exalt yourself to heaven’? ‘You will go down to the place of death.’
[OEBcw - Luke 10:16] ​Anyone who listens to you is listening to me, and anyone who rejects you is rejecting me; while the person who rejects me is rejecting him who sent me as his messenger.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:17] When the seventy-two returned, they exclaimed joyfully: “Master, even the demons submit to us when we use your name.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:18] And Jesus replied: “I have had visions of Satan, fallen, like lightning from the heavens.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:19] ​Remember, I have given you the power to ‘trample on snakes and scorpions,’ and to meet all the strength of the Enemy. Nothing will ever harm you in any way.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:20] ​Yet do not rejoice in the fact that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names have been enrolled in heaven.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:21] At that same time, moved to exultation by the Holy Spirit, Jesus said:  “I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that, though you have hidden these things from the wise and learned, you have revealed them to the childlike! Yes, Father, I thank you that this has seemed good to you.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:22] Everything has been committed to me by my Father; nor does anyone know who the Son is, except the Father, or who the Father is, except the Son and those to whom the Son may choose to reveal him.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:23] Then, turning to his disciples, Jesus said to them alone: “Blessed are the eyes that see what you are seeing;
[OEBcw - Luke 10:24] ​for, I tell you, many prophets and kings wished for the sight of the things which you are seeing, yet never heard them.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:25] Just then a Student of the law came forward to test Jesus further. “Teacher,” he said, “what must I do if I am to ‘gain eternal life’?”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:26] “What is said in the law?” answered Jesus. “What do you read there?”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:27] His reply was — “‘You must love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your strength, and with all your mind; and your neighbour as you love yourself.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:28] “You have answered right,” said Jesus; “do that, and you will live.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:29] But the man, wanting to justify himself, said to Jesus: “And who is my neighbour?”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:30] To which Jesus replied: “A man was once going down from Jerusalem to Jericho when he fell into the hands of robbers, who stripped him of everything, and beat him, and went away leaving him half dead.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:31] ​As it chanced, a priest was going down by that road. He saw the man, but passed by on the opposite side.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:32] ​A Levite, too, did the same; he came up to the spot, but, when he saw the man, passed by on the opposite side.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:33] ​But a Samaritan, traveling that way, came upon the man, and, when he saw him, he was moved with compassion.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:34] ​He went to him and bound up his wounds, dressing them with oil and wine, and then put him on his own mule, and brought him to an inn, and took care of him.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:35] ​The next day he took out two silver coins and gave them to the innkeeper. ‘Take care of him,’ he said, ‘and whatever more you may spend I will myself repay you on my way back.’
[OEBcw - Luke 10:36] ​Now which, do you think, of these three men,” asked Jesus, “proved himself a neighbour to the man who fell into the robbers’ hands?”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:37] “The one that took pity on him,” was the answer; on which Jesus said: “Go and do the same yourself.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:38] As they continued their journey, Jesus came to a village, where a woman named Martha welcomed him to her house.
[OEBcw - Luke 10:39] She had a sister called Mary, who seated herself at the Master’s feet, and listened to his teaching;
[OEBcw - Luke 10:40] but Martha was distracted by the many preparations that she was making. So she went up to Jesus and said: “Master, do you approve of my sister’s leaving me to make preparations alone? Tell her to help me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 10:41] “Martha, Martha,” replied the Master, “you are anxious and trouble yourself about many things;
[OEBcw - Luke 10:42] ​but only a few are necessary, or rather one. Mary has chosen the good part, and it will not be taken away from her.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 11:1] One day Jesus was at a certain place praying, and, when he had finished, one of his disciples said to him: “Master, teach us to pray, as John taught his disciples.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:2] “When you pray,” Jesus answered, “say — ‘Father, May your name be held holy, your kingdom come.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:3] Give us each day the bread that we will need;
[OEBcw - Luke 11:4] and forgive us our sins, for we ourselves forgive everyone who wrongs us; and take us not into temptation.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:5] Jesus also said to them: “Suppose that one of you who has a friend were to go to him in the middle of the night and say ‘Friend, lend me three loaves,
[OEBcw - Luke 11:6] ​for a friend of mine has arrived at my house after a journey, and I have nothing to offer him;’
[OEBcw - Luke 11:7] ​And suppose that the other should answer from inside ‘Do not trouble me; the door is already fastened, and my children and I are in bed; I cannot get up and give you anything’;
[OEBcw - Luke 11:8] ​I tell you that, even though he will not get up and give him anything because he is a friend, yet because of his persistence he will rouse himself and give him what he wants.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:9] And so I say to you — Ask, and your prayer will be granted: search, and you will find; knock, and the door will be opened to you.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:10] ​For the person who asks receives, everyone who searches finds, and to the person who knocks the door will be opened.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:11] ​What father among you, if his son asks him for a fish, will give him a snake instead,
[OEBcw - Luke 11:12] ​or, if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?
[OEBcw - Luke 11:13] ​If you, then, naturally wicked though you are, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more will the Father in heaven give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him!”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:14] Once Jesus was driving out a dumb demon, and, when the demon had gone out, the dumb man spoke. The people were amazed at this;
[OEBcw - Luke 11:15] but some of them said: “He drives out demons by the help of Beelzebul, the chief of the demons”;
[OEBcw - Luke 11:16] while others, to test him, asked him for some sign from the heavens.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:17] Jesus himself, however, was aware of what they were thinking, and said to them: “Any kingdom wholly divided against itself becomes a desolation; and a divided house falls.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:18] ​So, too, if Satan is wholly divided against himself, how can his kingdom last? Yet you say that I drive out demons by the help of Beelzebul.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:19] ​But, if it is by Beelzebul’s help that I drive out demons, by whose help is it that your own sons drive them out? Therefore they will themselves be your judges.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:20] ​But, if it is by the hand of God that I drive out demons, then the kingdom of God must already be upon you.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:21] ​When a strong man is keeping guard, fully armed, over his own mansion, his property is in safety;
[OEBcw - Luke 11:22] ​but, when one still stronger has attacked and overpowered him, he takes away all the weapons on which the other had relied, and divides his spoil.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:23] ​Whoever who is not with me is against me, and the person who does not help me to gather is scattering.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:24] ​No sooner does a foul spirit leave someone, than it passes through places where there is no water, in search of rest; and finding none, it says ‘I will go back to the home which I left’;
