[OEBcw - Luke 11:25] ​but, on coming there, it finds it unoccupied, swept, and put in order.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:26] ​Then it goes and brings with it seven other spirits more wicked than itself, and they go in, and make their home there; and the last state of that person proves to be worse than the first.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:27] As Jesus was saying this, a woman in the crowd, raising her voice, exclaimed: “Happy was the mother who bore you and nursed you!”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:28] But Jesus replied: “Rather, happy are those who listen to God’s message and keep it.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:29] As the crowds increased, Jesus began to speak: “This generation is a wicked generation. It is asking a sign, but no sign will be given it except the sign of Jonah.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:30] ​For, as Jonah became a sign to the people of Nineveh, so will the Son of Man be to this generation.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:31] ​At the judgment the Queen of the South will rise up with the people of this generation, and will condemn them, because she came from the ​ends of the earth to listen to the wisdom of Solomon; and here is more than a Solomon!
[OEBcw - Luke 11:32] ​At the judgment the men of Nineveh will stand up with this generation, and will condemn it, because they repented at Jonah’s proclamation; and here is more than a Jonah!
[OEBcw - Luke 11:33] ​No one sets light to a lamp, and then puts it in the cellar or under a basket, but he puts it on the lamp-stand, so that anyone who comes in may see the light.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:34] ​The lamp of the body is your eye. When your eye is unclouded, your whole body, also, is lit up; but, as soon as your eye is diseased, your body, also, is darkened.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:35] ​Take care, therefore, that the inner light is not darkness.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:36] ​If, then, your whole body is lit up, and no corner of it darkened, the whole will be lit up, just as when a lamp gives you light by its brilliance.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:37] As Jesus finished speaking, a Pharisee asked him to breakfast with him, and Jesus went in and took his place at the table.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:38] The Pharisee noticed, to his astonishment, that Jesus omitted the ceremonial washing before breakfast.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:39] But the Master said to him: “You Pharisees do, it is true, clean the outside of the cup and of the plate, but inside you yourselves are filled with greed and wickedness.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:40] ​Fools! Did not the maker of the outside make the inside too?
[OEBcw - Luke 11:41] ​Only give away what is in them in charity, and at once you have the whole clean.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:42] ​But alas for you Pharisees! You pay tithes on mint, rue, and herbs of all kinds, and pass over justice and love to God. These last you ought to have put into practice without neglecting the first.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:43] ​Alas for you Pharisees! You delight to have the front seat in the Synagogues, and to be greeted in the markets with respect.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:44] ​Alas for you! You are like unsuspected graves, over which men walk unawares.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:45] Here one of the students of the law interrupted him by saying: “Teacher, when you say this, you are insulting us also.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:46] But Jesus went on: “Alas for you, too, you students of the law! You load people with loads that are too heavy to carry, but do not, yourselves, touch them with one of your fingers.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:47] ​Alas for you! You build the monuments of the prophets whom your ancestors killed.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:48] ​You are actually witnesses to your ancestors’ acts and show your approval of them, because, while they killed the prophets, you build tombs for them.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:49] ​That is why the wisdom of God said — “I will send to them prophets and apostles,
[OEBcw - Luke 11:50] ​some of whom they will persecute and kill, in order that the ‘blood’ of all the prophets ‘that has been spilt’ since the creation of the world may be exacted from this generation —
[OEBcw - Luke 11:51] ​From the blood of Abel down to the blood of Zechariah, who was slain between the altar and the house of God.” Yes, I tell you, it will be exacted from this generation.
[OEBcw - Luke 11:52] ​Alas for you students of the law! You have taken away the key of the door of knowledge. You have not gone in yourselves and you have hindered those who try to go in.”
[OEBcw - Luke 11:53] When Jesus left the house, the teachers of the law and the Pharisees began to press him hard and question him closely on many subjects,
[OEBcw - Luke 11:54] laying traps for him, so as to seize on anything that he might say.
[OEBcw - Luke 12 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 12:1] Meanwhile the people had gathered in thousands, so that they trod on one another, when Jesus, addressing himself to his disciples, began by saying to them: “Be on your guard against the leaven — that is, the hypocrisy — of the Pharisees.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:2] ​There is nothing, however covered up, which will not be uncovered, nor anything kept secret which will not become known.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:3] ​So all that you have said in the dark will be heard in the light, and what you have spoken in the ear, within closed doors, will be proclaimed on the housetops.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:4] ​To you who are my friends I say, Do not be afraid of those who kill the body, but after that can do no more.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:5] ​I will show you of whom you should be afraid. Be afraid of him who, after killing you, has the power to fling you into Gehenna. Yes, I say, be afraid of him.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:6] ​Are not five sparrows sold for two copper coins? Yet not one of them has escaped God’s notice.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:7] ​No, even the hairs of your head are all numbered. Do not be afraid; you are of more value than many sparrows.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:8] ​Everyone, I tell you, who publicly acknowledges me, the Son of Man, also, will acknowledge before God’s angels;
[OEBcw - Luke 12:9] ​but the person who publicly disowns me will be altogether disowned before God’s angels.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:10] ​Everyone who will say anything against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but for the person who slanders the Holy Spirit there will be no forgiveness.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:11] ​Whenever they take you before the Synagogue Courts or the magistrates or other authorities, do not be anxious as to how you will defend yourselves, or what your defence will be, or what you will say;
[OEBcw - Luke 12:12] ​for the Holy Spirit will show you at the moment what you ought to say.”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:13] “Teacher,” a man in the crowd said to Jesus, “tell my brother to share the property with me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:14] But Jesus said to him: “Man, who made me a judge or an arbiter between you?”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:15] And then he added: “Take care to keep yourselves free from every form of covetousness; for even in the height of their prosperity a person’s true life does not depend on what they have.”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:16] Then Jesus told them this parable — “There was once a rich man whose land was very fertile;
[OEBcw - Luke 12:17] ​and he began to ask himself ‘What will I do, for I have nowhere to store my crops?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:18] ​This is what I will do,’ he said; ‘I will pull down my barns and build larger ones, and store all my grain and my goods in them;
[OEBcw - Luke 12:19] ​and I will say to myself, Now you have plenty of good things put by for many years; take your ease, eat, drink, and enjoy yourself.’
[OEBcw - Luke 12:20] ​But God said to the man ‘Fool! This very night your life is being demanded; and as for all you have prepared — who will have it?’
[OEBcw - Luke 12:21] ​So it is with those who lay by wealth for themselves and are not rich to the glory of God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:22] And Jesus said to his disciples: “That is why I say to you, Do not be anxious about the life here — what you can get to eat; nor yet about your body — what you can get to wear.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:23] ​For life is more than food, and the body than its clothes.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:24] ​Think of the ravens — they neither sow nor reap; they have neither storehouse nor barn; and yet God feeds them! And how much more precious are you than birds!
[OEBcw - Luke 12:25] ​But which of you, by being anxious, can prolong your life a moment?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:26] ​And, if you cannot do even the smallest thing, why be anxious about other things?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:27] ​Think of the lilies, and how they grow. They neither toil nor spin; yet, I tell you, even Solomon in all his splendour was not robed like one of these.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:28] ​If, even in the field, God so clothes the grass which is living today and tomorrow will be thrown into the oven, how much more will he clothe you, you of little faith!
[OEBcw - Luke 12:29] ​And you — do not be always seeking what you can get to eat or what you can get to drink; and do not waver.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:30] ​These are the things for which all the nations of the world are seeking, and your Father knows that you need them.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:31] ​No, seek his kingdom, and these things will be added for you.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:32] ​So do not be afraid, my little flock, for your Father has been pleased to give you the kingdom.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:33] Sell what belongs to you, and give in charity. Make yourselves purses that will not wear out — an inexhaustible treasure in heaven, where no thief comes near, or moth works ruin.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:34] ​For where your treasure is, there also will your heart be.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:35] ​Make yourselves ready, with your lamps alight;
[OEBcw - Luke 12:36] ​and be like servants who are waiting for their Master’s return from his wedding, so that, when he comes and knocks, they may open the door for him at once.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:37] ​Happy are those servants whom, on his return, the Master will find watching. I tell you that he will make himself ready, and have them take their places at the table, and will come and serve them.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:38] ​Whether it is late at night, or in the early morning that he comes, if he finds all as it should be, then happy are they.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:39] ​This you do know, that, had the owner of the house known at what time the thief was coming, he would have been on the watch, and would not have let his house be broken into.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:40] ​You must also prepare, for when you are least expecting him the Son of Man will come.”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:41] “Master,” said Peter, “are you telling this parable with reference to us or to everyone?”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:42] “Who, then,” replied the Master, “is that trustworthy steward, the careful man, who will be placed by his master over his establishment, to give them their rations at the proper time?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:43] ​Happy will that servant be whom his master, when he comes home, will find doing this.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:44] ​His master, I tell you, will put him in charge of the whole of his property.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:45] ​But should that servant say to himself ‘My master is a long time coming,’ and begin to beat the menservants and the maidservants, and to eat and drink and get drunk,
[OEBcw - Luke 12:46] ​that servant’s master will come on a day when he does not expect him, and at an hour of which he is unaware, and will flog him severely and assign him his place among the untrustworthy.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:47] ​The servant who knows his master’s wishes and yet does not prepare and act accordingly will receive many lashes;
[OEBcw - Luke 12:48] ​while one who does not know his master’s wishes, but acts so as to deserve a flogging, will receive but few. From everyone to whom much has been given much will be expected, and from the man to whom much has been entrusted the more will be demanded.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:49] ​I came to cast fire on the earth; and what more can I wish, if it is already kindled?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:50] ​There is a baptism that I must undergo, and how great is my distress until it is over!
[OEBcw - Luke 12:51] ​Do you think that I am here to give peace on earth? No, I tell you, but to cause division.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:52] ​For from this time, if there are five people in a house, they will be divided, three against two, and two against three.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:53] ‘Father will be opposed to son and son to father, mother to daughter and daughter to mother, mother-in-law to her daughter-in-law and daughter-in-law to her mother-in-law.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 12:54] And to the people Jesus said: “When you see a cloud rising in the west, you say at once ‘There is a storm coming,’ and come it does.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:55] ​And when you see that the wind is in the south, you say ‘It will be burning hot,’ and so it proves.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:56] ​Hypocrites! You know how to judge of the earth and the sky; how is it, then, that you cannot judge of this time?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:57] ​Why do not you yourselves decide what is right?
[OEBcw - Luke 12:58] ​When, for instance, you are going with your opponent before a magistrate, on your way to the court do your best to be quit of him; otherwise he might drag you before the judge, then the judge will hand you over to the bailiff of the court, and the bailiff throw you into prison.
[OEBcw - Luke 12:59] ​You will not, I tell you, come out until you have paid the very last cent.”
[OEBcw - Luke 13 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 13:1] Just at that time some people had come to tell Jesus about the Galileans, whose blood Pilate had mingled with the blood of their sacrifices.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:2] ​“Do you suppose,” replied Jesus, “that, because these Galileans have suffered in this way, they were worse sinners than any other Galileans?
[OEBcw - Luke 13:3] ​No, I tell you; but, unless you repent, you will all perish as they did.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:4] ​Or those eighteen men at Siloam on whom the tower fell, killing them all, do you suppose that they were worse offenders than any other inhabitants of Jerusalem?
[OEBcw - Luke 13:5] ​No, I tell you; but, unless you repent, you will all perish in the same manner.”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:6] And Jesus told them this parable — “A man, who had a fig tree growing in his vineyard, came to look for fruit on it, but could not find any.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:7] ​So he said to his gardener ‘Three years now I have come to look for fruit on this fig tree, without finding any! Cut it down. Why should it rob the soil?’
[OEBcw - Luke 13:8] ​‘Leave it this one year more, Sir,’ the man answered, ‘until I have dug round it and manured it.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:9] ​Then, if it bears in future, well and good; but if not, you can have it cut down.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:10] Jesus was teaching on a Sabbath in one of the Synagogues,
[OEBcw - Luke 13:11] and he saw before him a woman who for eighteen years had suffered from weakness owing to her having an evil spirit in her. She was bent double, and was wholly unable to raise herself.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:12] When Jesus saw her, he called her to him, and said: “Woman, you are released from your weakness.”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:13] He placed his hands on her, and she was instantly made straight, and began to praise God.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:14] But the President of the Synagogue, indignant that Jesus had worked the cure on the Sabbath, intervened and said to the people: “There are six days on which work ought to be done; come to be cured on one of those, and not on the Sabbath.”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:15] “You hypocrites!” the Master answered him. “Does not everyone of you let your ox or your ass loose from its manger, and take it out to drink, on the Sabbath?
[OEBcw - Luke 13:16] ​But this woman, a daughter of Abraham, who has been kept in bondage by Satan for now eighteen years, ought not she to have been released from her bondage on the Sabbath?”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:17] As he said this, his opponents all felt ashamed; but all the people rejoiced to see all the wonderful things that he was doing.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:18] So Jesus said: “What is the kingdom of God like? And to what can I liken it?
[OEBcw - Luke 13:19] ​It is like a mustard seed which a man took and put in his garden. The seed grew and became a tree, and ‘the wild birds roosted in its branches.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:20] And again Jesus said: “To what can I liken the kingdom of God?
[OEBcw - Luke 13:21] ​It is like some yeast which a woman took and covered in three pecks of flour, until the whole had risen.”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:22] Jesus went through towns and villages, teaching as he went, and making his way towards Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:23] “Master,” some one asked, “are there but few in the path of salvation?” And Jesus answered:
[OEBcw - Luke 13:24] ​“Strive to go in by the small door. Many, I tell you, will seek to go in, but they will not be able,
[OEBcw - Luke 13:25] ​when once the master of the house has got up and shut the door, while you begin to say, as you stand outside and knock, ‘Sir, open the door for us.’ His answer will be — ‘I do not know where you come from.’
[OEBcw - Luke 13:26] ​Then you will begin to say ‘We have eaten and drunk in your presence, and you have taught in our streets,’ and his reply will be —
[OEBcw - Luke 13:27] ​‘I do not know where you come from. Leave my presence, all you who are living in wickedness.’
[OEBcw - Luke 13:28] ​There, there will be weeping and grinding of teeth, when you see Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets, in the kingdom of God, while you yourselves are being driven outside.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:29] ​People will come from East and West, and from North and South, and take their places at the banquet in the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:30] ​there are some who are last now who will then be first, and some who are first now who will then be last!”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:31] Just then some Pharisees came up to Jesus and said: “Go away and leave this place, for Herod wants to kill you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 13:32] But Jesus answered: “Go and say to that fox ‘Look you, I am driving out demons and will be completing cures today and tomorrow, and on the third day I will have done.’
[OEBcw - Luke 13:33] ​But today and tomorrow and the day after I must go on my way, because it cannot be that a prophet should meet his end outside Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Luke 13:34] ​Jerusalem! Jerusalem! You who slays the prophets and stones the messengers sent to you — Oh, how often have I wished to gather your children round me, as a hen takes her brood under her wings, and you would not come!
[OEBcw - Luke 13:35] ​Verily your house is left to you desolate! And never, I tell you, will you see me, until you say — ‘Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 14 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 14:1] On one occasion, as Jesus was going, on a Sabbath into the house of one of the leading Pharisees to dine, they were watching him closely.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:2] There he saw before him a man who was suffering from dropsy.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:3] ​“Is it allowable,” said Jesus, addressing the students of the law and the Pharisees, “to work a cure on the Sabbath, or is it not?”
[OEBcw - Luke 14:4] They remained silent. Jesus took hold of the man and cured him, and sent him away.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:5] And he said to them: “Which of you, finding that your son or your ox has fallen into a well, will not immediately pull them out on the Sabbath day?”
[OEBcw - Luke 14:6] And they could not make any answer to that.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:7] Observing that the guests were choosing the best places for themselves, Jesus told them this parable —
[OEBcw - Luke 14:8] ​“When you are invited by anyone to a wedding banquet, do not seat yourself in the best place. Someone of higher rank might have been invited by your host;
[OEBcw - Luke 14:9] ​and the host who invited you both will come and say to you ‘Make room for this person,’ and then you will begin in confusion to take the lowest place.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:10] ​No, when you are invited, go and take the lowest place, so that, when the host who has invited you comes, he may say to you ‘Friend, come higher up’; and then you will be honoured in the eyes of all your fellow guests.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:11] ​For everyone who exalts themselves will be humbled, and everyone who humbles themselves will be exalted.”
[OEBcw - Luke 14:12] Then Jesus went on to say to the man who had invited him: “When you give a breakfast or a dinner, do not ask your friends, or your brothers or sisters, or your relations, or rich neighbours, because they might invite you in return, and so you should be repaid.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:13] ​No, when you entertain, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, the blind;
[OEBcw - Luke 14:14] ​and then you will be happy indeed, since they cannot reward you; for you will be rewarded at the resurrection of the good.”
[OEBcw - Luke 14:15] One of the guests heard what he said and exclaimed: “Happy will be the person who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!”
[OEBcw - Luke 14:16] But Jesus said to him: “A man was once giving a great dinner. He invited many people,
[OEBcw - Luke 14:17] ​and sent his servant, when it was time for the dinner, to say to those who had been invited ‘Come, for everything is now ready.’
[OEBcw - Luke 14:18] ​They all with one accord began to ask to be excused. The first said to the servant ‘I have bought a field and am obliged to go and look at it. I must ask you to consider me excused.’
[OEBcw - Luke 14:19] ​The next said ‘I have bought five pairs of bullocks, and I am on my way to try them. I must ask you to consider me excused’;
[OEBcw - Luke 14:20] ​while the next said ‘I am just married, and for that reason I am unable to come.’
[OEBcw - Luke 14:21] ​On his return the servant told his master all these answers. Then in anger the owner of the house said to his servant ‘Go out at once into the streets and alleys of the town, and bring in here the poor, and the crippled, and the blind, and the lame.’
[OEBcw - Luke 14:22] ​Presently the servant said ‘Sir, your order has been carried out, and still there is room.’
[OEBcw - Luke 14:23] ​‘Go out,’ the master said, ‘into the roads and hedgerows, and make people come in, so that my house may be filled;
[OEBcw - Luke 14:24] ​for I tell you all that not one of those people who were invited will taste my dinner.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 14:25] One day, when great crowds of people were walking with Jesus, he turned and said to them:
[OEBcw - Luke 14:26] ​“If any one comes to me and does not hate their father, and mother, and wife, and children, and brothers, and sisters, yes and even their life, he can be no disciple of mine.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:27] ​Whoever does not carry their own cross, and walk in my steps, can be no disciple of mine.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:28] ​Why, which of you, when you want to build a tower, does not first sit down and reckon the cost, to see if you have enough to complete it? —
[OEBcw - Luke 14:29] ​Otherwise, if you have laid the foundation and are not able to finish it, everyone who sees it will laugh at you,
[OEBcw - Luke 14:30] ​and say ‘Here is a person who began to build and was not able to finish!’
[OEBcw - Luke 14:31] ​Or what king, when he is setting out to fight another king, does not first sit down and consider if with ten thousand men he is able to meet one who is coming against him with twenty thousand?
[OEBcw - Luke 14:32] ​And if he cannot, then, while the other is still at a distance, he sends envoys and asks for terms of peace.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:33] ​And so with everyone of you who does not bid farewell to all you have — you cannot be a disciple of mine.
[OEBcw - Luke 14:34] ​Yes, salt is good; but, if the salt itself should lose its strength, what will be used to season it?
[OEBcw - Luke 14:35] ​It is not fit either for the land or for the manure heap. People throw it away. Let those who have ears to hear with hear!”
[OEBcw - Luke 15 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 15:1] The tax-gatherers and the outcasts were all drawing near to Jesus to listen to him;
[OEBcw - Luke 15:2] but the Pharisees and the teachers of the law found fault. “This man always welcomes outcasts, and takes meals with them!” they complained.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:3] So Jesus told them this parable —
[OEBcw - Luke 15:4] ​“Who among you who has a hundred sheep, and has lost one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine out in the open country, and go after the lost sheep until he finds it?
[OEBcw - Luke 15:5] ​And, when he has found it, he puts in on his shoulders rejoicing;
[OEBcw - Luke 15:6] ​and, on reaching home, he calls his friends and his neighbours together, and says ‘Come and rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep which was lost.’
[OEBcw - Luke 15:7] ​So, I tell you, there will be more rejoicing in heaven over one outcast who repents, than over ninety-nine religious people, who have no need to repent.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:8] ​Or again, what woman who has ten silver coins, if she loses one of them, does not light a lamp, and sweep the house, and search carefully until she finds it?
[OEBcw - Luke 15:9] ​And, when she has found it, she calls her friends and neighbours together, and says ‘Come and rejoice with me, for I have found the coin which I lost.’
[OEBcw - Luke 15:10] ​So, I tell you, there is rejoicing in the presence of God’s angels over one outcast who repents.”
[OEBcw - Luke 15:11] Then Jesus continued: “A man had two sons;
[OEBcw - Luke 15:12] ​and the younger of them said to his father ‘Father, give me my share of the inheritance.’ So the father divided the property between them.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:13] ​A few days later the younger son got together all that he had, and went away into a distant land; and there he squandered his inheritance by leading a dissolute life.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:14] ​After he has spent all that he had, there was a severe famine through all that country, and he began to be in actual want.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:15] ​So he went and engaged himself to one of the people of that country, who sent him into his fields to tend pigs.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:16] ​He even longed to satisfy his hunger with the bean-pods on which the pigs were feeding; and no one gave him anything.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:17] ​But, when he came to himself, he said ‘How many of my father’s hired servants have more bread than they can eat, while here am I starving to death!
[OEBcw - Luke 15:18] ​I will get up and go to my father, and say to him “Father, I sinned against heaven and against you;
[OEBcw - Luke 15:19] ​I am no longer fit to be called your son; make me one of your hired servants.”’
[OEBcw - Luke 15:20] ​And he got up and went to his father. But, while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and was deeply moved; he ran and threw his arms round his neck and kissed him.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:21] ​‘Father,’ the son said, ‘I sinned against heaven and against you; I am no longer fit to be called your son; make me one of your hired servants.’
[OEBcw - Luke 15:22] ​But the father turned to his servants and said ‘Be quick and fetch a robe — the very best — and put it on him; give him a ring for his finger and sandals for his feet;
[OEBcw - Luke 15:23] ​and bring the fattened calf and kill it, and let us eat and make merry;
[OEBcw - Luke 15:24] ​for here is my son who was dead, and is alive again, was lost, and is found.’ So they began making merry.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:25] ​Meanwhile the elder son was out in the fields; but, on coming home, when he got near the house, he heard music and dancing,
[OEBcw - Luke 15:26] ​and he called one of the servants and asked what it all meant.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:27] ​‘Your brother has come back,’ the servant told him, ‘and your father has killed the fattened calf, because he has him back safe and sound.’
[OEBcw - Luke 15:28] ​This made him angry, and he would not go in. But his father came out and begged him to do so.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:29] ​‘No,’ he said to his father, ‘look at all the years I have been serving you, without ever once disobeying you, and yet you have never given me even a young goat, so that I might have a merrymaking with my friends.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:30] ​But, no sooner has this son of yours come, who has eaten up your property in the company of prostitutes, than you have killed the fattened calf for him.’
[OEBcw - Luke 15:31] ​‘Child,’ the father answered, ‘you are always with me, and everything that I have is yours.
[OEBcw - Luke 15:32] ​We could but make merry and rejoice, for here is your brother who was dead, and is alive; who was lost, and is found.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 16 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 16:1] Jesus said to his disciples: “There was a rich man who had a steward; and this steward was maliciously accused to him of wasting his estate.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:2] ​So the master called him and said ‘What is this that I hear about you? Give in your accounts, for you cannot act as steward any longer.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:3] ​‘What am I to do,’ the steward asked himself, ‘now that my master is taking the steward’s place away from me? I have not strength to dig, and I am ashamed to beg.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:4] ​I know what I will do, so that, as soon as I am turned out of my stewardship, people may welcome me into their homes.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:5] ​One by one he called up his master’s debtors. ‘How much do you owe my master?’ he asked of the first.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:6] ​‘Four hundred and forty gallons of oil,’ answered the man. ‘Here is your agreement,’ he said; ‘sit down at once and make it two hundred and twenty.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:7] ​And you, the steward said to the next, ‘how much do you owe?’ ‘Seventy quarters of wheat,’ he replied. ‘Here is your agreement,’ the steward said; ‘make it fifty-six.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:8] ​His master complimented this dishonest steward on the shrewdness of his action. And indeed men of the world are shrewder in dealing with their fellow men than those who have the light.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:9] ​And I say to you ‘Win friends for yourselves with your dishonest money,’ so that, when it comes to an end, there may be a welcome for you into the Eternal Home.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:10] ​The person who is trustworthy in the smallest matter is trustworthy in a great one also; and the person who is dishonest in the smallest matter is dishonest in a great one also.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:11] ​So, if you have proved untrustworthy with the ‘dishonest money,’ who will trust you with the true?
[OEBcw - Luke 16:12] ​And, if you have proved untrustworthy with what does not belong to us, who will give you what is really our own?
[OEBcw - Luke 16:13] ​No servant can serve two masters, for, either they will hate one and love the other, or else they will attach themselves to one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and Money.”
[OEBcw - Luke 16:14] All this was said within hearing of the Pharisees, who were lovers of money, and they began to sneer at Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:15] “You,” said Jesus, “are the ones who justify themselves before the world, but God can read your hearts; and what is highly esteemed among people may be an abomination in the sight of God.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:16] ​The law and the prophets sufficed until the time of John. Since then the good news of the kingdom of God has been told, and everybody has been forcing their way into it.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:17] ​It would be easier for the heavens and the earth to disappear than for one stroke of a letter in the law to be lost.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:18] ​Everyone who divorces his wife and marries another woman is an adulterer, and the man who marries a divorced woman is an adulterer.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:19] ​There was once a rich man, who dressed in purple robes and fine linen, and feasted every day in great splendour.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:20] ​Near his gateway there had been laid a beggar named Lazarus, who was covered with sores,
[OEBcw - Luke 16:21] ​and who longed to satisfy his hunger with what fell from the rich man’s table. Even the ​dogs came and licked his sores.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:22] ​After a time the beggar died, and was taken by the angels to be with Abraham. The rich man also died and was buried.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:23] ​In the place of death he looked up in his torment, and saw Abraham at a distance and Lazarus at his side.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:24] ​So he called out ‘Pity me, Father Abraham, and send Lazarus to dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am suffering agony in this flame.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:25] ​‘Child,’ answered Abraham, ‘remember that you in your lifetime received what you thought desirable, just as Lazarus received what was not desirable; but now he has his consolation here, while you are suffering agony.
[OEBcw - Luke 16:26] ​And not only that, but between you and us there lies a great chasm, so that those who wish to pass from here to you cannot, nor can they cross from there to us.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:27] ​‘Then, Father,’ he said, ‘I beg you to send Lazarus to my father’s house —
[OEBcw - Luke 16:28] ​For I have five brothers to warn them, so that they may not come to this place of torture also.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:29] ​‘They have the writings of Moses and the prophets,’ replied Abraham; ‘let them listen to them.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:30] ​‘But, Father Abraham,’ he urged, ‘if some one from the dead were to go to them, they would repent.’
[OEBcw - Luke 16:31] ​‘If they do not listen to Moses and the prophets,’ answered Abraham, ‘they will not be persuaded, even if some one were to rise from the dead.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 17 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 17:1] Jesus said to his disciples: “It is inevitable that there should be temptations but sorrow awaits the person who does the tempting!
[OEBcw - Luke 17:2] ​It would be good for them if they had been flung into the sea with a millstone round their neck, rather than that they should prove a trap even one of these little ones.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:3] ​Be on your guard! If your brother or sister does wrong, rebuke them; but if they repent, forgive them.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:4] ​Even if they wrong you seven times a day, but turns to you every time and says ‘I am sorry,’ you must forgive them.”
[OEBcw - Luke 17:5] “Give us more faith,” said the apostles to the Master;
[OEBcw - Luke 17:6] but the Master said: “If your faith were only like a mustard seed, you could say to this mulberry tree ‘Be uprooted and planted in the sea,’ and it would obey you.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:7] ​Which of you, if he had a servant ploughing, or tending the sheep, would say to him, when he came in from the fields, ‘Come at once and take your place at the table,’
[OEBcw - Luke 17:8] ​Instead of saying ‘Prepare my dinner, and then make yourself ready and serve me while I am eating and drinking, and after that you will eat and drink yourself’?
[OEBcw - Luke 17:9] ​Does he feel grateful to his servant for doing what he is told?
[OEBcw - Luke 17:10] ​And so with you — when you have done all that you have been told, still say ‘We are but useless servants; we have done no more than we ought to have done.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 17:11] On the way to Jerusalem Jesus passed between Samaria and Galilee.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:12] As he was entering a village, ten lepers met him.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:13] Standing still, some distance off, they called out loudly: “Jesus! Sir! Pity us!”
[OEBcw - Luke 17:14] When Jesus saw them, he said: “Go and show yourselves to the priest.” And, as they were on their way, they were made clean.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:15] One of them, finding he was cured, came back, praising God loudly,
[OEBcw - Luke 17:16] and threw himself on his face at Jesus’ feet, thanking him for what he had done; and this man was a Samaritan.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:17] ​“Were not all the ten made clean? exclaimed Jesus. But the nine — where are they?
[OEBcw - Luke 17:18] ​Were there none to come back and praise God except this foreigner?
[OEBcw - Luke 17:19] ​Get up,” he said to him, “and go on your way. Your faith has delivered you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 17:20] Being once asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God was to come, Jesus answered: “The kingdom of God does not come in a way that can be seen,
[OEBcw - Luke 17:21] ​nor will people say ‘Look, here it is!’ or ‘There it is!’; for the kingdom of God is within you!
[OEBcw - Luke 17:22] ​The day will come,” he said to his disciples, “when you will long to see but one of the days of the Son of Man, and will not see it.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:23] ​People will say to you ‘There he is! Or ‘Here he is!’ Do not go and follow them.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:24] ​For, just as lightning will lighten and flare from one side of the heavens to the other, so will it be with the Son of Man.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:25] ​But first he must undergo much suffering, and he must be rejected by the present generation.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:26] ​As it was in the days of Noah, so will it be again in the days of the Son of Man.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:27] ​They were eating and drinking and marrying and being married, up to the very day on which Noah entered the ark, and then the flood came and destroyed them all.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:28] ​So, too, in the days of Lot. People were eating, drinking, buying, selling, planting, building;
[OEBcw - Luke 17:29] ​but, on the very day on which Lot came out of Sodom, it rained fire and sulphur from the skies and destroyed them all.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:30] ​It will be the same on the day on which the Son of Man reveals himself.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:31] ​On that day, if a person is on their house-top and their goods in the house, they must not go down to get them; nor again must one who is on the farm turn back.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:32] ​Remember Lot’s wife.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:33] ​Whoever is eager to get the most out of their life will lose it; but whoever will lose it will preserve it.
[OEBcw - Luke 17:34] ​On that night, I tell you, of two people on the same bed, one will be taken and the other left;
[OEBcw - Luke 17:35] ​of two women grinding grain together, one will be taken and the other left.”
[OEBcw - Luke 17:36] 
[OEBcw - Luke 17:37] “Where will it be, Master?” asked the disciples. “Where there is a body,” said Jesus, “‘there will the vultures flock.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 18 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 18:1] Jesus told his disciples a parable to show them that they should always pray and never despair.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:2] ​“There was,” he said, “in a certain town a judge, who had no fear of God nor regard for people.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:3] ​In the same town there was a widow who went to him again and again, and said ‘Grant me justice against my opponent.’
[OEBcw - Luke 18:4] ​For a time the judge refused, but afterwards he said to himself ‘Although I am without fear of God or regard for people,
[OEBcw - Luke 18:5] ​yet, as this widow is so troublesome, I will grant her justice, to stop her from plaguing me with her endless visits.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:6] Then the Master added: “Listen to what this iniquitous judge says!
[OEBcw - Luke 18:7] ​And God — will not he see that his own people, who cry to him night and day, have justice done them — though he holds his hand?
[OEBcw - Luke 18:8] ​He will, I tell you, give them justice soon enough! Yet, when the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on earth?”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:9] Another time, speaking to people who were satisfied that they were religious, and who regarded everyone else with scorn, Jesus told this parable —
[OEBcw - Luke 18:10] ​“Two men went up into the Temple Courts to pray. One was a Pharisee and the other a tax-gatherer.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:11] ​The Pharisee stood forward and began praying to himself in this way — ‘God, I thank you that I am not like other men — ​thieves, rogues, adulterers — or even like this tax-gatherer.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:12] ​I fast twice a week, and give a tenth of everything I get to God.’
[OEBcw - Luke 18:13] ​Meanwhile the tax-gatherer stood at a distance, not venturing even ‘to raise his eyes to heaven’; but he kept striking his breast and saying ‘God, have mercy on me, a sinner.’
[OEBcw - Luke 18:14] ​This man, I tell you, went home pardoned, rather than the other; for everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, while everyone who humbles himself will be exalted.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:15] Some of the people were bringing even their babies to Jesus, for him to touch them; but, when the disciples saw it, they began to find fault with those who had brought them.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:16] Jesus, however, called the little children to him. “Let the little children come to me,” he said, “and do not hinder them; for it is to the childlike that the kingdom of God belongs.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:17] ​I tell you, unless a man receives the kingdom of God like a child, he will not enter it at all.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:18] And one of the Presidents asked Jesus this question — “Good teacher, what must I do if I am to gain eternal life?”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:19] “Why do you call me good?” answered Jesus. “No one is good but God.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:20] ​You know the commandments — ‘Do not commit adultery, Do not kill, Do not steal, Do not say what is false about others, Honour your father and your mother.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:21] “I have observed all these,” he replied, “from childhood.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:22] Hearing this, Jesus said to him: “There is one thing still lacking in you; sell everything that you have, and distribute to the poor, and you will have wealth in heaven; then come and follow me.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:23] But the man became greatly distressed on hearing this, for he was extremely rich.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:24] Seeing this, Jesus said to his disciples: “How hard it is for the wealthy to enter the kingdom of God!
[OEBcw - Luke 18:25] ​It is easier, indeed, for a camel to get through a needle’s eye than for a rich person to enter the kingdom of God!”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:26] “Then who can be saved?” asked those who heard this.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:27] But Jesus said: “What is impossible with people is possible with God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:28] “But we,” said Peter, “we left what belonged to us and followed you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:29] “I tell you,” he answered, “that there is no one who has left house, or wife, or brothers, or parents, or children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
[OEBcw - Luke 18:30] ​who will not receive many times as much in the present, and in the age that is coming eternal life.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:31] Gathering the Twelve round him, Jesus said to them: “Listen! We are going up to Jerusalem; and there everything that is written in the prophets will be done to the Son of Man.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:32] ​For he will be given up to the Gentiles, mocked, insulted and spat on;
[OEBcw - Luke 18:33] ​they will scourge him, and then put him to death; and on the third day he will rise again.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:34] The apostles did not comprehend any of this; his meaning was unintelligible to them, and they did not understand what he was saying.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:35] As Jesus was getting near Jericho, a blind man was sitting by the roadside, begging.
[OEBcw - Luke 18:36] Hearing a crowd going by, the man asked what was the matter;
[OEBcw - Luke 18:37] and, when people told him that Jesus of Nazareth was passing,
[OEBcw - Luke 18:38] he shouted out: “Jesus, Son of David, take pity on me!”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:39] Those who were in front kept telling him to be quiet, but he continued to call out the louder: “Son of David, take pity on me!”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:40] Then Jesus stopped and ordered the man to be brought to him. And, when he had come close up to him, Jesus asked him:
[OEBcw - Luke 18:41] ​“What do you want me to do for you?” “Master,” he said, “I want to recover my sight.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:42] And Jesus said: “Recover your sight, your faith has delivered you.”
[OEBcw - Luke 18:43] Instantly he recovered his sight, and began to follow Jesus, praising God. And all the people, on seeing it, gave glory to God.
[OEBcw - Luke 19 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 19:1] Jesus entered Jericho and made his way through the town.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:2] There was a man there, known by the name of Zacchaeus, who was a commissioner of taxes and a rich man.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:3] He tried to see what Jesus was like; but, being short, he was unable to do so because of the crowd.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:4] So he ran on ahead and climbed into a mulberry tree, to see Jesus, for he knew that he must pass that way.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:5] When Jesus came to the place, he looked up and said to him: “Zacchaeus, be quick and come down, for I must stop at your house today.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:6] So Zacchaeus got down quickly, and joyfully welcomed him.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:7] On seeing this, everyone began to complain: “He has gone to stay with a man who is an outcast.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:8] But Zacchaeus stood forward and said to the Master: “Listen, Master! I will give half my property to the poor, and, if I have defrauded anyone of anything, I will give him back four times as much.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:9] “salvation has come to this house today,” answered Jesus, “for even this man is a son of Abraham.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:10] ​The Son of Man has come to ‘search for those who are lost’ and to save them.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:11] As the people were listening to this, Jesus went on to tell them a parable. He did so because he was near Jerusalem, and because they thought that the kingdom of God was going to be proclaimed at once.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:12] He said: “A nobleman once went to a distant country to receive his appointment to a kingdom and then return.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:13] ​He called ten of his servants and gave them ten pounds of silver each, and told them to trade with them during his absence.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:14] ​But his subjects hated him and sent envoys after him to say ‘We will not have this man as our king.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:15] ​On his return, after having been appointed king, he directed that the servants to whom he had given his money should be summoned, so that he might learn what amount of trade they had done.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:16] ​The first came up, and said ‘Sir, your ten pounds have made a hundred.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:17] ​‘Well done, good servant!’ exclaimed the master. ‘As you have proved trustworthy in a very small matter, I appoint you governor over ten towns.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:18] ​When the second came, he said ‘Your ten pounds, Sir, have produced fifty.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:19] ​So the master said to him ‘And you I appoint over five towns.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:20] ​Another servant also came and said ‘Sir, here are your ten pounds; I have kept them put away in a handkerchief.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:21] ​For I was afraid of you, because you are a stern man. You take what you have not planted, and reap what you have not sown.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:22] ​The master answered ‘Out of your own mouth I judge you, you worthless servant. You knew that I am a stern man, that I take what I have not planted, and reap what I have not sown?
[OEBcw - Luke 19:23] ​Then why did not you put my money into a bank? And I, on my return, could have claimed it with interest.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:24] ​Take away from him the ten pounds,’ he said to those standing by, ‘and give them to the one who has the hundred.’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:25] ​‘But, Sir,’ they said, ‘he has a hundred pounds already!’
[OEBcw - Luke 19:26] ​‘I tell you,’ he answered, ‘that, to him who has, more will be given, but, from him who has nothing, even what he has will be taken away.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:27] ​But as for my enemies, these men who would not have me as their king, bring them here and put them to death in my presence.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:28] After saying this, Jesus went on in front, going up to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:29] It was when Jesus had almost reached Bethphage and Bethany, near the Mount of Olives, that he sent on two of the disciples.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:30] ​“Go to the village facing us,” he said, “and, when you get there, you will find a foal tethered, which no one has yet ridden; untie it and lead it here.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:31] ​And, if anybody asks you ‘Why are you untying it?,’ you are to say this — ‘The Master wants it.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:32] So the two who were sent went and found it as Jesus had told them.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:33] While they were untying the foal, the owners asked them — “Why are you untying the foal?”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:34] And the two disciples answered — “The Master wants it.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:35] Then they led it back to Jesus, and threw their cloaks on the foal and put Jesus on it.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:36] As he went along, the people kept spreading their cloaks in the road.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:37] When he had almost reached the place where the road led down the Mount of Olives, everyone of the many disciples began in their joy to praise God loudly for all the miracles that they had seen:
[OEBcw - Luke 19:38] “Blessed is He who comes — Our king — in the name of the Lord! Peace in heaven, And glory on high.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:39] Some of the Pharisees in the crowd said to him: “Teacher, restrain your disciples.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:40] But Jesus answered: “I tell you that if they are silent, the ​stones will call out.”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:41] When he drew near, on seeing the city, he wept over it, and said:
[OEBcw - Luke 19:42] ​“If only you had known, while yet there was time — even you — the things that make for peace! But now they have been hidden from your sight.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:43] ​For a time is coming ​when your enemies will surround you with earthworks, and encircle you, and hem you in on all sides;
[OEBcw - Luke 19:44] ​they will trample you down and your children within you, and they will not leave in you one stone on another, because you did not know ‘the time of your visitation.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:45] Jesus went into the Temple Courts and began to drive out those who were selling,
[OEBcw - Luke 19:46] saying as he did so: “Scripture says — ‘My house will be a house of prayer’; but you have made it ‘a den of robbers.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 19:47] Jesus continued to teach each day in the Temple Courts; but the chief priests and teachers of the law were eager to take his life, and so also were the leaders of the people.
[OEBcw - Luke 19:48] Yet they could not see what to do, for the people all hung on his words.
[OEBcw - Luke 20 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 20:1] On one of these days, when Jesus was teaching the people in the Temple Courts and telling the good news, the chief priests and the teachers of the law, joined by the councillors, confronted him,
[OEBcw - Luke 20:2] and addressing him, said: “Tell us what authority you have to do these things. Who is it who has given you this authority?”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:3] “I, too,” said Jesus in reply, “will ask you one question. Give me an answer to it.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:4] ​It is about John’s baptism — was it of divine or of human origin?”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:5] But they began arguing together: “If we say ‘divine,’ he will say ‘Why did not you believe him?’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:6] But, if we say ‘human,’ the people will all stone us, for they are persuaded that John was a prophet.”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:7] So they answered that they did not know its origin.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:8] ​“Then I,” said Jesus, “refuse to tell you what authority I have to do these things.”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:9] But Jesus began to tell the people this parable — “A man once planted a vineyard, and then let it out to tenants, and went abroad for a long while.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:10] ​At the proper time he sent a servant to the tenants, so that they could give him a share of the produce of the vineyard. The tenants, however, beat him and sent him away empty-handed.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:11] ​The owner afterwards sent another servant; but the tenants beat and insulted this man too, and sent him away empty-handed.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:12] ​He sent a third; but they wounded this man also, and threw him outside.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:13] ​‘What should I do?’ said the owner of the vineyard. ‘I will send my son, who is very dear to me. Perhaps they will respect him.’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:14] ​But, on seeing him, the tenants consulted with one another. ‘Here is the heir!’ they said. ‘Let us kill him, and then the inheritance will become ours.’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:15] ​So they threw him outside the vineyard and killed him. Now what will the owner of the vineyard do to them?
[OEBcw - Luke 20:16] ​He will come and put those tenants to death, and will let the vineyard to others.” “heaven forbid!” they exclaimed when they heard it.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:17] But Jesus looked at them and said: “What then is the meaning of this passage? — ‘The ​stone which the builders despised has now itself become the corner-stone.’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:18] Everyone who falls on that stone will be dashed to pieces, while anyone on whom it falls — it will scatter him as dust.”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:19] After this the teachers of the law and the chief priest were eager to lay hands on Jesus then and there, but they were afraid of the people; for they saw that it was at them that he had aimed this parable.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:20] Having watched their opportunity, they afterwards sent some spies, who pretended to be good men, to catch Jesus in the course of conversation, and so enable them to give him up to the Governor’s jurisdiction and authority.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:21] These spies asked Jesus a question. They said: “Teacher, we know that you are right in what you say and teach, and that you do not take any account of a person’s position, but teach the way of God honestly;
[OEBcw - Luke 20:22] are we right in paying tribute to the Emperor or not?”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:23] Seeing through their deceitfulness, Jesus said to them:
[OEBcw - Luke 20:24] ​“Show me a coin. Whose head and title are on it?”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:25] “The Emperor’s,” they said; and Jesus replied: “Well then, pay to the Emperor what belongs to the Emperor, and to God what belongs to God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:26] They could not lay hold of this answer before the people; and, in their wonder at his reply, they held their tongues.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:27] Presently there came up some Sadducees, who maintain that there is no resurrection. Their question was this —
[OEBcw - Luke 20:28] “Teacher, Moses laid down for us in his writings that — ‘Should a man’s married brother die, and should he be childless, the man should take the widow as his wife, and raise up a family for his brother.’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:29] Well, there were once seven brothers; of whom the eldest, after taking a wife, died childless.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:30] The second and third brothers both took her as their wife;
[OEBcw - Luke 20:31] and so, too, did all seven — dying without children.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:32] The woman herself was the last to die.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:33] About the woman, then — at the resurrection, whose wife is she to be, all seven brothers having had her as their wife?”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:34] “The men and women of this world,” said Jesus, “marry and are given in marriage;
[OEBcw - Luke 20:35] ​but, for those who are thought worthy to attain to that other world and the resurrection from the dead, there is no marrying or being married,
[OEBcw - Luke 20:36] ​nor indeed can they die again, for they are like angels and, having shared in the resurrection, they are God’s children.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:37] ​As to the fact that the dead rise, even Moses indicated that, in the passage about the Bush, when he calls the Lord — ‘The God of Abraham, and the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:38] Now he is not God of dead people, but of living. For in his sight all are alive.”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:39] “Well said, teacher!” exclaimed some of the teachers of the law,
[OEBcw - Luke 20:40] for they did not venture to question him any further.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:41] But Jesus said to them: “How is it that people say that the Christ is to be David’s son?
[OEBcw - Luke 20:42] ​For David, in the book of Psalms, says himself — ‘The Lord said to my lord: “Sit at my right hand,
[OEBcw - Luke 20:43] until I put your enemies as a stool for your feet.”’
[OEBcw - Luke 20:44] David, then, calls him ‘lord,’ so how is he David’s son?”
[OEBcw - Luke 20:45] While all the people were listening, Jesus said to the disciples:
[OEBcw - Luke 20:46] ​“Be on your guard against the teachers of the law, who delight to walk about in long robes, and like to be greeted in the streets with respect, and to have the best seats in the Synagogues, and places of honour at dinner.
[OEBcw - Luke 20:47] ​These are the men who rob widows of their houses, and make a pretence of saying long prayers. Their sentence will be all the heavier.”
[OEBcw - Luke 21 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 21:1] Looking up, Jesus saw the rich people putting their gifts into the chests for the Temple offerings.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:2] He saw, too, a widow in poor circumstances putting two small coins into them.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:3] ​“I tell you” , he said “that this poor widow has put in more than all the others;
[OEBcw - Luke 21:4] ​for everyone else here put in something from what he had to spare, while she, in her need, has put in all she had to live on.”
[OEBcw - Luke 21:5] When some of them spoke about the Temple being decorated with beautiful stones and offerings, Jesus said:
[OEBcw - Luke 21:6] ​“As for these things that you are looking at, a time is coming when not one stone will be left on another here, which will not be thrown down.”
[OEBcw - Luke 21:7] So the disciples questioned Jesus: “But, teacher, when will this be? And what sign will there be when this is near?”
[OEBcw - Luke 21:8] And Jesus said: “See that you are not led astray; for many will take my name, and come saying ‘I am He,’ and ‘The time is close at hand.’ Do not follow them.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:9] ​And, when you hear of wars and disturbances, do not be terrified, for these things must occur first; but the end will not be at once.”
[OEBcw - Luke 21:10] Then he said to them: “‘Nation will rise against nation and kingdom against kingdom,’
[OEBcw - Luke 21:11] ​And there will be great earthquakes, and plagues and famines in various places, and there will be terrible appearances and signs in the heavens.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:12] ​Before all this, they will lay hands on you and persecute you, and they will betray you to Synagogues and put you in prison, when you will be brought before kings and governors for the sake of my name.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:13] ​Then will be your opportunity of witnessing for me.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:14] ​Make up your minds, therefore, not to prepare your defence;
[OEBcw - Luke 21:15] ​for I will myself give you words, and a wisdom which all your opponents together will be unable to resist or defy.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:16] ​You will be betrayed even by your parents and brothers and sisters and sisters and relations and friends, and they will cause some of you to be put to death,
[OEBcw - Luke 21:17] ​and you will be hated by everyone because of me my name.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:18] ​Yet not a single hair of your heads will be lost!
[OEBcw - Luke 21:19] ​By your endurance you will win yourselves life.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:20] ​As soon, however, as you see Jerusalem surrounded by armed camps, then you may know that the hour of her desecration is at hand.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:21] ​Then those of you who are in Judea must take refuge in the mountains, those who are in Jerusalem must leave at once, and those who are in the country places must not go into it.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:22] ​For these are to be the days of vengeance, when all that scripture says will be fulfilled.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:23] ​Alas for pregnant women, and for those who are nursing infants in those days! For there will be great suffering in the land, and anger against this people.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:24] ​They will fall by the edge of the sword, and will be taken prisoners to every land, and ‘Jerusalem will be under the heel of the Gentiles,’ until their day is over — as it will be.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:25] ​There will be signs, too, in the sun and moon and stars, and on the earth despair among the nations, in their dismay at the roar of the sea and the surge.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:26] ​People’s hearts will fail them through dread of what is coming upon the world; for ‘the forces of the heavens will be convulsed.’
[OEBcw - Luke 21:27] ​Then will be seen the ‘Son of Man coming in a cloud’ with power and great glory.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:28] ​And, when these things begin to occur, look upwards and lift your heads, for your deliverance will be at hand.”
[OEBcw - Luke 21:29] Then he taught them a lesson , saying — “Look at the fig tree and all the other trees.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:30] ​As soon as they shoot, you know, as you look at them, without being told, that summer is near.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:31] ​And so may you, as soon as you see these things happening, know that the kingdom of God is near.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:32] ​I tell you that even the present generation will not pass away until all has taken place.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:33] ​The heavens and the earth will pass away, but my words will never pass away.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:34] ​Be on your guard or your minds will become dulled by debauches or drunkenness or the anxieties of life, and 'that day' will close on you suddenly like a trap.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:35] ​For come it will on all who are living upon the face of the whole earth.
[OEBcw - Luke 21:36] ​Be on the watch at all times, and pray that you may have strength to escape all that is destined to happen, and to stand in the presence of the Son of Man.”
[OEBcw - Luke 21:37] During the days, Jesus continued to teach in the Temple Courts, but he went out and spent the nights on the hill called the ‘Mount of Olives.’
[OEBcw - Luke 21:38] And all the people would get up early in the morning and come to listen to him in the Temple Courts.
[OEBcw - Luke 22 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 22:1] The feast of the unleavened bread, known as the Passover, was near.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:2] The chief priest and the teachers of the law were looking for an opportunity of destroying Jesus, for they were afraid of the people.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:3] Now Satan took possession of Judas, who was known as Iscariot, and who belonged to the Twelve;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:4] and he went and discussed with the chief priests and officers in charge at the Temple the best way of betraying Jesus to them.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:5] They were glad of this, and agreed to pay him.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:6] So Judas assented, and looked for an opportunity to betray Jesus to them, in the absence of a crowd.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:7] When the day of the Festival of the unleavened bread came, on which the Passover lambs had to be killed,
[OEBcw - Luke 22:8] Jesus sent forward Peter and John, saying to them: “Go and make preparations for our eating the Passover.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:9] “Where do you wish us to make preparations?” they asked.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:10] ​“Listen,” he answered, “when you have got into the city, a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you; follow him into whatever house he enters;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:11] ​and you will say to the owner of the house ‘The teacher says to you — Where is the room where I am to eat the Passover with my disciples?’
[OEBcw - Luke 22:12] ​The man will show you a large upstairs room, set out; there make preparations.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:13] So Peter and John went on, and found everything just as Jesus had told them, and they prepared the Passover.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:14] When the time came, Jesus took his place at the table, and the apostles with him.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:15] ​“I have most earnestly wished,” he said, “to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:16] ​For I tell you that I will not eat it again, until it has had its fulfilment in the kingdom of God.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:17] Then, on receiving a cup, after saying the thanksgiving, he said:
[OEBcw - Luke 22:18] ​“Take this and share it among you. For I tell you that I will not, after today, drink of the juice of the grape, until the kingdom of God has come.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:19] Then Jesus took some bread, and, after saying the thanksgiving, broke it and gave to them, with the words: “This is my body.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:20] 
[OEBcw - Luke 22:21] ​Yet see! The hand of the man who is betraying me is beside me on the table!
[OEBcw - Luke 22:22] ​True, the Son of Man is passing, by the way ordained for him, yet alas for that man by whom he is being betrayed!”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:23] Then they began questioning one another which of them it could be who was going to do this.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:24] And a dispute arose among them as to which of them was to be regarded as the greatest.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:25] Jesus, however, said: “The kings of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their oppressors are styled ‘Benefactors.’
[OEBcw - Luke 22:26] ​But with you it must not be so. No, let the greatest among you become like the youngest, and him who leads like him who serves.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:27] ​Which is the greater — the master at the table or his servant? Is not it the master at the table? Yet I myself am among you as one who serves.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:28] ​You are the men who have stood by me in my trials;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:29] ​and, just as my Father has assigned me a kingdom, I assign you places,
[OEBcw - Luke 22:30] ​so that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom, and be seated on twelve thrones as judges of the twelve tribes of Israel.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:31] ​Simon! Simon! listen. Satan demanded leave to sift you all like wheat,
[OEBcw - Luke 22:32] ​but I prayed for you, Simon, that your faith should not fail. And you, when you have returned to me, are to strengthen the others.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:33] “Master,” said Peter, “with you I am ready to go both to prison and to death.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:34] “I tell you, Peter,” replied Jesus, “the cock will not crow today until you have disowned all knowledge of me three times.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:35] Then he said to them all: “When I sent you out as my messengers, without either purse, or bag, or sandals, were you in need of anything?” “No; nothing,” they answered.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:36] ​“Now, however,” he said, “he who has a purse must take it and his bag as well; and he who has not must sell his cloak and buy a sword.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:37] ​For, I tell you, that passage of scripture must be fulfilled in me, which says — ‘He was counted among the godless’; indeed all that refers to me is finding its fulfilment.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:38] “Master,” they exclaimed, “look, here are two swords!”  “Enough!” said Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:39] Jesus then went out, and made his way as usual to the Mount of Olives, followed by his disciples.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:40] And, when he reached the spot, he said to them: “Pray that you may not fall into temptation.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:41] Then he withdrew about a stone’s throw, and knelt down and began to pray.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:42] ​“Father,” he said, “if it is your pleasure, spare me this cup; only, not my will but your be done.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:43] Presently there appeared to him an angel from heaven, who strengthened him.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:44] And, as his anguish became intense, he prayed still more earnestly, while his sweat was like great drops of blood falling on the ground.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:45] Then he rose from praying, and came to the disciples and found them sleeping for sorrow.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:46] ​“Why are you asleep?” he asked them. “Rise and pray so that you don't fall into temptation.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:47] While he was still speaking, a crowd appeared in sight, led by the man called Judas, who was one of the Twelve. Judas approached Jesus, to kiss him;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:48] on which Jesus said to him: “Judas, is it by a kiss that you betray the Son of Man?”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:49] But when those who were round Jesus saw what was going to happen, they exclaimed: “Master, should we use our swords?”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:50] And one of them struck the high priest’s servant and cut off his right ear;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:51] on which Jesus said: “Let me at least do this”; and, touching his ear, he healed the wound.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:52] Then, turning to the chief priests and officers in charge at the Temple and councillors, who had come for him, he said: “Have you come out, as if after a robber, with swords and clubs?
[OEBcw - Luke 22:53] ​When I was with you day after day in the Temple Courts, you did not lay hands on me; but now your time has come, and the power of darkness.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:54] Those who had taken Jesus prisoner took him away into the house of the high priest. Peter followed at a distance.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:55] But, when they had lit a fire in the centre of the courtyard and had all sat down there, Peter seated himself in the middle of them.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:56] Presently a maidservant saw him sitting near the blaze of the fire. Fixing her eyes on him, she said: “Why, this man was one of his companions!”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:57] But Peter denied it. “I do not know him,” he replied.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:58] A little while afterwards some one else — a man — saw him and said: “Why, you are one of them!” “No,” Peter said, “I am not.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:59] About an hour later another man declared positively: “This man also was certainly with him. Why, he is a Galilean!”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:60] But Peter said: “I do not know what you are speaking about.” Instantly, while he was still speaking, a cock crowed.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:61] And the Master turned and looked at Peter; and Peter remembered the words that the Master had said to him — “Before a cock has crowed today, you will disown me three times”;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:62] and he went outside and wept bitterly.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:63] The men who held Jesus kept making sport of him and beating him.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:64] They blindfolded him and then questioned him. “Now play the prophet,” they said; “who was it that struck you?”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:65] And they heaped many other insults on him.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:66] At daybreak the National Council met — both the chief priests and the teachers of the law — and took Jesus before their High Council.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:67] “If you are the Christ,” they said, “tell us so.”  “If I tell you,” replied Jesus, “you will not believe me;
[OEBcw - Luke 22:68] ​and, if I question you, you will not answer.
[OEBcw - Luke 22:69] ​But from this hour ‘the Son of Man will be seated on the right hand of God Almighty.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:70] “Are you, then, the Son of God?” they all asked. “It is true,” answered Jesus, “I am.”
[OEBcw - Luke 22:71] At this they exclaimed: “Why do we want any more evidence? We have heard it ourselves from his own lips!”
[OEBcw - Luke 23 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 23:1] Then they all rose in a body and led Jesus before Pilate.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:2] And they began to accuse him: “This is a man whom we found misleading our people, preventing them from paying taxes to the Emperor, and giving out that he himself is ‘Christ, a king.’”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:3] “Are you the king of the Jews?” Pilate asked him. “It is true,” replied Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:4] But Pilate, turning to the chief priests and the people, said: “I do not see anything to find fault with in this man.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:5] But they insisted: “He is stirring up the people by his teaching all through Judea; he began with Galilee and has now come here.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:6] Hearing this, Pilate asked if the man was a Galilean;
[OEBcw - Luke 23:7] and, having satisfied himself that Jesus came under Herod’s jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who also was at Jerusalem at the time.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:8] When Herod saw Jesus, he was exceedingly pleased, for he had been wanting to see him for a long time, having heard a great deal about him; and he was hoping to see some sign given by him.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:9] So he questioned him at some length, but Jesus made no reply.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:10] Meanwhile the chief priests and the teachers of the law stood by and vehemently accused him.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:11] And Herod, with his soldiers, treated Jesus with scorn; he mocked him by throwing a gorgeous robe round him, and then sent him back to Pilate.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:12] And Herod and Pilate became friends that very day, for before that there had been ill-will between them.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:13] So Pilate summoned the chief priests, and the leading men, and the people,
[OEBcw - Luke 23:14] and said to them: “You brought this man before me charged with misleading the people; and yet, for my part, though I examined him before you, I did not find this man to blame for any of the things of which you accuse him;
[OEBcw - Luke 23:15] nor did Herod either; for he has sent him back to us. And, as a fact, he has not done anything deserving death;
[OEBcw - Luke 23:16] so I will have him scourged, and then release him.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:17] 
[OEBcw - Luke 23:18] But they began to shout as one man: “Kill this fellow, but release Barabbas for us.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:19] (Barabbas was a man who had been put in prison for a riot that had broken out in the city and for murder.)
[OEBcw - Luke 23:20] Pilate, however, wanting to release Jesus, called to them again;
[OEBcw - Luke 23:21] but they kept calling out: “Crucify, crucify him!”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:22] “Why, what harm has this man done?” Pilate said to them for the third time. “I have found nothing in him for which he could be condemned to death. So I will have him scourged, and then release him.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:23] But they persisted in loudly demanding his crucifixion; and their clamour gained the day.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:24] Pilate decided that their demand should be granted.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:25] He released the man who had been put in prison for riot and murder, as they demanded, and gave Jesus up to be dealt with as they pleased.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:26] And, as they were leading Jesus away, they laid hold of Simon from Cyrene, who was on his way in from the country, and they put the cross on his shoulders, for him to carry it behind Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:27] There was a great crowd of people following him, many being women who were beating their breasts and wailing for him.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:28] So Jesus turned and said to them: “Women of Jerusalem, do not weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:29] ​A time, I tell you, is coming, when it will be said — ‘Happy are the women who are barren, and those who have never borne children or nursed them!’
[OEBcw - Luke 23:30] ​At that time people will begin to say to the mountains ‘Fall on us,’ and to the hills ‘Cover us.’
[OEBcw - Luke 23:31] ​If what you see is done while the tree is green, what will happen when it is dry?”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:32] There were two others also, criminals, led out to be executed with Jesus.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:33] When they had reached the place called ‘The Skull,’ there they crucified Jesus and the criminals, one on the right, and one on the left.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:34] Then Jesus said: “Father, forgive them; they do not know what they are doing.” His clothes they divided among them by casting lots.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:35] Meanwhile the people stood looking on. Even the leading men said with a sneer: “He saved others, let him save himself, if he is God’s Christ, his chosen one.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:36] The soldiers, too, came up in mockery, bringing him common wine,
[OEBcw - Luke 23:37] and saying as they did so: “If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:38] Above him were the words — ‘THIS IS THE KING OF THE JEWS.’
[OEBcw - Luke 23:39] One of the criminals who were hanging beside Jesus railed at him. “Are not you the Christ? Save yourself and us,” he said.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:40] But the other rebuked him. “Have not you,” he said, “any fear of God, now that you are under the same sentence?
[OEBcw - Luke 23:41] And we justly so, for we are only reaping our deserts, but this man has not done anything wrong.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:42] Jesus,” he went on, “do not forget me when you have come to your kingdom.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:43] And Jesus answered: “I tell you, this very day you will be with me in Paradise.”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:44] It was nearly midday, when a darkness came over the whole country, lasting until three in the afternoon,
[OEBcw - Luke 23:45] the sun being eclipsed; and the Temple curtain was torn down the middle.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:46] Then Jesus, with a loud cry, said: “Father, into your hands I commit my spirit.” And with these words he expired.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:47] The Roman captain, on seeing what had happened, praised God, exclaiming: “This must have been a good man!”
[OEBcw - Luke 23:48] All the people who had collected to see the sight watched what occurred, and then went home beating their breasts.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:49] All the friends of Jesus had been standing at a distance, with the women who accompanied him from Galilee, watching all this.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:50] Now there was a man of the name of Joseph, who was a member of the Council, and who bore a good and upright character.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:51] (This man had not assented to the decision and action of the Council.) He belonged to Ramah, a town in Judea, and lived in expectation of the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:52] He now went to see Pilate, and asked for the body of Jesus;
[OEBcw - Luke 23:53] and, when he had taken it down, he wrapped it in a linen sheet, and laid him in a tomb cut out of stone, in which no one had yet been buried.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:54] It was the Preparation day, and just before the Sabbath began.
[OEBcw - Luke 23:55] The women who had accompanied Jesus from Galilee followed, and saw the tomb and how the body of Jesus was laid,
[OEBcw - Luke 23:56] and then went home, and prepared spices and perfumes.During the Sabbath they rested, as directed by the commandment.
[OEBcw - Luke 24 - start] 
[OEBcw - Luke 24:1] But very early on the first day of the week they went to the tomb, taking with them the spices that they had prepared.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:2] They found that the stone had been rolled away from the tomb;
[OEBcw - Luke 24:3] and, on going into it, they could not find the body .
[OEBcw - Luke 24:4] While they were at a loss to account for this, all at once two men stood beside them, in dazzling clothing.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:5] But, when in their fear the women bowed their faces to the ground, the men said to them: “Why are you looking among the dead for him who is living?
[OEBcw - Luke 24:6] Remember how he spoke to you before he left Galilee —
[OEBcw - Luke 24:7] How he said that the Son of Man must be betrayed into the hands of wicked men, and be crucified, and rise again on the third day.”
[OEBcw - Luke 24:8] Then they remembered the words of Jesus,
[OEBcw - Luke 24:9] and, on returning from the tomb, they told all this to the Eleven and to all the rest.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:10] There were Mary of Magdala, and Joanna, and Mary, the mother of James. The other women, too, spoke about this to the apostles.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:11] What they said seemed to the apostles mere nonsense, and they did not believe them.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:12] 
[OEBcw - Luke 24:13] It happened that very day that two of the disciples were going to a village called Emmaus, which was about seven miles from Jerusalem,
[OEBcw - Luke 24:14] talking together, as they went, about all that had just taken place.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:15] While they were talking about these things and discussing them, Jesus himself came up and went on their way with them;
[OEBcw - Luke 24:16] but their eyes were blinded so that they could not recognise him.
[OEBcw - Luke 24:17] ​“What is this that you are saying to each other as you walk along?” Jesus asked. They stopped, with sad looks on their faces,
