[OEBcw - John 12:37] But, though Jesus had given so many signs of his mission before their eyes, they still did not believe in him,
[OEBcw - John 12:38] in fulfilment of the words of the prophet Isaiah, where he says — ‘Lord, who has believed our teaching? And to whom has the might of the Lord been revealed?’
[OEBcw - John 12:39] The reason why they were unable to believe is given by Isaiah elsewhere, in these words —
[OEBcw - John 12:40] ‘He has blinded their eyes, and blunted their mind, so that they should not see with their eyes, and perceive with their mind, and turn — And I should heal them.’
[OEBcw - John 12:41] Isaiah said this, because he saw Christ’s glory; and it was of him that he spoke.
[OEBcw - John 12:42] Yet for all this, even among the leading men there were many who came to believe in Jesus; but, because of the Pharisees, they did not acknowledge it, because they were afraid that they should be expelled from their Synagogues;
[OEBcw - John 12:43] for they valued honour from people more than honour from God.
[OEBcw - John 12:44] But Jesus had proclaimed: “He who believes in me believes, not in me, but in him who sent me;
[OEBcw - John 12:45] ​and he who sees me sees him who sent me.
[OEBcw - John 12:46] ​I have come as a light into the world, so that no one who believes in me should remain in the darkness.
[OEBcw - John 12:47] ​When anyone hears my teaching and pays no heed to it, I am not his judge; for I came not to judge the world, but to save the world.
[OEBcw - John 12:48] ​He who rejects me, and disregards my teaching, has a judge already — the ​message which I have delivered will itself be his judge at the Last day.
[OEBcw - John 12:49] ​For I have not delivered it on my own authority; but the Father, who sent me, has himself given me his command as to what I should say, and what message I should deliver.
[OEBcw - John 12:50] ​And I know that eternal life lies in keeping his command. Therefore, whatever I say, I say only what the Father has taught me.”
[OEBcw - John 13 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 13:1] Before the Passover Festival began, Jesus knew that the time had come for him to leave the world and go to the Father. He had loved those who were his own in the world, and he loved them to the last.
[OEBcw - John 13:2] The devil had already put the thought of betraying Jesus into the mind of Judas Iscariot, the son of Simon;
[OEBcw - John 13:3] and at supper, Jesus — although knowing that the Father had put everything into his hands, and that he had come from God, and was to return to God —
[OEBcw - John 13:4] Rose from his place, and, taking off his upper garments, tied a towel round his waist.
[OEBcw - John 13:5] He then poured some water into the basin, and began to wash the disciples’ feet, and to wipe them with the towel which was tied round him.
[OEBcw - John 13:6] When he came to Simon Peter, Peter said: “You, Master! Are you going to wash my feet?”
[OEBcw - John 13:7] “You do not understand now what I am doing,” replied Jesus, “but you will learn by and by.”
[OEBcw - John 13:8] “You will never wash my feet!” exclaimed Peter. “Unless I wash you,” answered Jesus, “you have nothing in common with me.”
[OEBcw - John 13:9] “Then, Master, not my feet only,” exclaimed Simon Peter, “but also my hands and my head.”
[OEBcw - John 13:10] “He who has bathed,” replied Jesus, “has no need to wash, unless it be his feet, but is altogether clean; and you,” he said to the disciples, “are clean, yet not all of you.”
[OEBcw - John 13:11] For he knew who was going to betray him, and that was why he said ‘You are not all clean.’
[OEBcw - John 13:12] When he had washed their feet, and had put on his upper garments and taken his place, he spoke to them again. “Do you understand what I have been doing to you?” he asked.
[OEBcw - John 13:13] ​“You yourselves call me ‘the teacher’ and ‘the Master’, and you are right, for I am both.
[OEBcw - John 13:14] ​If I, then — ‘the Master’ and ‘the teacher’ — have washed your feet, you also ought to wash one another’s feet;
[OEBcw - John 13:15] ​for I have given you an example, so that you may do just as I have done to you.
[OEBcw - John 13:16] ​In truth I tell you, a servant is not greater than their master, nor yet a messenger than the one who sends them.
[OEBcw - John 13:17] ​Now that you know these things, happy are you if you do them.
[OEBcw - John 13:18] ​I am not speaking about all of you. I know whom I have chosen; but this is in fulfilment of the words of scripture — ‘He that is eating my bread has lifted his heel against me.’
[OEBcw - John 13:19] ​For the future I will tell you of things before they take place, so that, when they take place, you may believe that I am what I am.
[OEBcw - John 13:20] ​In truth I tell you, the one who receives anyone that I send receives me; and the person who receives me receives him who sent me.”
[OEBcw - John 13:21] After saying this, Jesus was much troubled, and said solemnly: “In truth I tell you that it is one of you who will betray me.”
[OEBcw - John 13:22] The disciples looked at one another, wondering whom he meant.
[OEBcw - John 13:23] Next to Jesus, in the place on his right hand, was one of his disciples, whom he loved.
[OEBcw - John 13:24] So Simon Peter made signs to that disciple, and whispered: “Tell me who it is that he means.”
[OEBcw - John 13:25] Being in this position, that disciple leant back on Jesus’ shoulder, and asked him: “Who is it, Master?”
[OEBcw - John 13:26] “It is the one,” answered Jesus, “to whom I will give a piece of bread after dipping it in the dish.” And, when Jesus had dipped the bread, he took it and gave it to Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot;
[OEBcw - John 13:27] and it was then, after he had received it, that Satan took possession of him. So Jesus said to him: “Do at once what you are going to do.”
[OEBcw - John 13:28] But no one at the table understood why he said this to Judas.
[OEBcw - John 13:29] Some thought that, as Judas kept the purse, Jesus meant that he was to buy some things needed for the Festival, or to give something to the poor.
[OEBcw - John 13:30] After taking the piece of bread, Judas went out immediately; and it was night.
[OEBcw - John 13:31] When Judas had gone out, Jesus said: “Now the Son of Man has been exalted, and God has been exalted through him;
[OEBcw - John 13:32] ​and God will exalt him with himself — yes, he will exalt him forthwith.
[OEBcw - John 13:33] ​My children, I am to be with you but a little while longer. You will look for me; and what I said to the people — ‘You cannot come where I am going’ — I now say to you.
[OEBcw - John 13:34] ​I give you a new commandment — love one another; love one another as I have loved you.
[OEBcw - John 13:35] ​It is by this that everyone will recognise you as my disciples — by your loving one another.”
[OEBcw - John 13:36] “Where are you going, Master?” asked Peter. “I am going where you cannot now follow me,” answered Jesus, “but you will follow me later.”
[OEBcw - John 13:37] “Why cannot I follow you now, Master?” asked Peter. “I will lay down my life for you.”
[OEBcw - John 13:38] “Will you lay down your life for me?” replied Jesus. “In truth I tell you, the cock will not crow until you have disowned me three times.
[OEBcw - John 14 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 14:1] ​Do not let your hearts be troubled. Believe in God; believe also in me.
[OEBcw - John 14:2] ​In my Father’s Home there are many dwellings. If it had not been so, I should have told you, for I am going to prepare a place for you.
[OEBcw - John 14:3] ​And, since I go and prepare a place for you, I will return and take you to be with me, so that you may be where I am;
[OEBcw - John 14:4] ​and you know the way to the place where I am going.”
[OEBcw - John 14:5] “We do not know where you are going, Master,” said Thomas; “so how can we know the way?”
[OEBcw - John 14:6] Jesus answered: “I am the way, and the truth, and the life; no one ever comes to the Father except through me.
[OEBcw - John 14:7] ​If you had recognised me, you would have known my Father also; for the future you will recognise him, indeed you have already seen him.”
[OEBcw - John 14:8] “Master, show us the Father,” said Philip, “and we will be satisfied.”
[OEBcw - John 14:9] “Have I been all this time among you,” said Jesus, “and yet you, Philip, have not recognised me? The person who has seen me has seen the Father, how can you say, then, ‘Show us the Father’?
[OEBcw - John 14:10] ​Do not you believe that I am in union with the Father, and the Father with me? In giving you my teaching I am not speaking on my own authority; but the Father himself, always in union with me, does his own work.
[OEBcw - John 14:11] ​Believe me,” he said to them all, “when I say that I am in union with the Father and the Father with me, or else believe me because of the work itself.
[OEBcw - John 14:12] ​In truth I tell you, the person who believes in me will themselves do the work that I am doing; and they will do greater work still, because I am going to the Father.
[OEBcw - John 14:13] ​Whatever you ask, in my name, I will do, so that the Father may be honoured in the Son.
[OEBcw - John 14:14] ​If you ask anything, in my name, I will do it.
[OEBcw - John 14:15] ​If you love me, you will lay my commands to heart,
[OEBcw - John 14:16] ​and I will ask the Father, and he will give you another helper, to be with you always — the Spirit of truth.
[OEBcw - John 14:17] ​The world cannot receive this Spirit, because it does not see him or recognise him, but you recognise him, because he is always with you, and is within you.
[OEBcw - John 14:18] ​I will not leave you bereaved; I will come to you.
[OEBcw - John 14:19] ​In a little while the world will see me no more, but you will still see me; because I am living, you will be living also.
[OEBcw - John 14:20] ​At that time you will recognise that I am in union with the Father, and you with me, and I with you.
[OEBcw - John 14:21] ​It is they who have my commands and lays them to heart that loves me; and the person who loves me will be loved by my Father, and I will love them, and will reveal myself to them.”
[OEBcw - John 14:22] “What has happened, Master,” said Judas (not Judas Iscariot), “that you are going to reveal yourself to us, and not to the world?”
[OEBcw - John 14:23] “Whoever loves me,” Jesus answered, “will lay my message to heart; and my Father will love him, and we will come to him and make our home with him.
[OEBcw - John 14:24] ​The person who does not love me will not lay my message to heart; and the message to which you are listening is not my own, but comes from the Father who sent me.
[OEBcw - John 14:25] ​I have told you all this while still with you,
[OEBcw - John 14:26] ​but the helper — the Holy Spirit whom the Father will send in my name — will teach you all things, and will recall to your minds all that I have said to you.
[OEBcw - John 14:27] ​Peace be with you! My own peace I give you. I do not give to you as the world gives. Do not let your hearts be troubled, or dismayed.
[OEBcw - John 14:28] ​You heard me say that I was going away and would return to you. Had you loved me, you would have been glad that I was going to the Father, because the Father is greater than I.
[OEBcw - John 14:29] ​And this I have told you now before it happens, so that, when it does happen, you may still believe in me.
[OEBcw - John 14:30] ​I will not talk with you much more, for the Spirit that is ruling the world is coming. He has nothing in common with me;
[OEBcw - John 14:31] ​but he is coming so that the world may see that I love the Father, and that I do as the Father commanded me. Come, let us be going.
[OEBcw - John 15 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 15:1] ​I am the True Vine, and my Father is the Vine-grower.
[OEBcw - John 15:2] ​Any unfruitful branch in me he takes away, and he cleanses every fruitful branch, so that it may bear more fruit.
[OEBcw - John 15:3] ​You are already clean because of the message that I have given you.
[OEBcw - John 15:4] ​Remain united to me, and I will remain united to you. As a branch cannot bear fruit by itself, unless it remains united to the vine; no more can you, unless you remain united to me.
[OEBcw - John 15:5] ​I am the Vine, you are the branches. If you remains united to me, while I remain united to you — you bear fruit plentifully; for you can do nothing apart from me.
[OEBcw - John 15:6] ​If anyone does not remain united to me, they are thrown away, as a branch would be, and withers up. Such branches are collected and thrown into the fire, and are burnt.
[OEBcw - John 15:7] ​If you remain united to me, and my teaching remains in your hearts, ask whatever you wish, and it will be yours.
[OEBcw - John 15:8] ​It is by your bearing fruit plentifully, and so showing yourselves my disciples, that my Father is honoured.
[OEBcw - John 15:9] ​As the Father has loved me, so have I loved you; remain in my love.
[OEBcw - John 15:10] ​If you lay my commands to heart, you will remain in my love; just as I have laid the Father’s commands to heart and remain in his love.
[OEBcw - John 15:11] ​I have told you all this so that my own joy may be yours, and that your joy may be complete.
[OEBcw - John 15:12] ​This is my command — love one another, as I have loved you.
[OEBcw - John 15:13] ​No one can give greater proof of love than by laying down their life for their friends.
[OEBcw - John 15:14] ​And you are my friends, if you do what I command you.
[OEBcw - John 15:15] ​I no longer call you ‘servants,’ because a servant does not know what their master is doing; but I have given you the name of ‘friends,’ because I made known to you everything that I learned from my Father.
[OEBcw - John 15:16] ​It was not you who chose me, but I who chose you, and I appointed you to go and bear fruit — fruit that should remain, so that the Father might grant you whatever you ask in my name.
[OEBcw - John 15:17] ​I am giving you these commands that you may love one another.
[OEBcw - John 15:18] ​If the world hates you, you know that it has first hated me.
[OEBcw - John 15:19] ​If you belonged to the world, the world would love its own. Because you do not belong to the world, but I have chosen you out of the world — that is why the world hates you.
[OEBcw - John 15:20] ​Remember what I said to you — ‘A servant is not greater than their master.’ If they have persecuted me, they will also persecute you; if they have laid my message to heart, they will lay yours to heart also.
[OEBcw - John 15:21] ​But they will do all this to you, because you believe in my name, for they do not know him who sent me.
[OEBcw - John 15:22] ​If I had not come and spoken to them, they would have had no sin to answer for; but as it is, they have no excuse for their sin.
[OEBcw - John 15:23] ​The person who hates me hates my Father also.
[OEBcw - John 15:24] ​If I had not done among them such work as no one else ever did, they would have had no sin to answer for; but, as it is, they have both seen and hated both me and my Father.
[OEBcw - John 15:25] ​And so is fulfilled what is said in their law — ‘They hated me without cause.’
[OEBcw - John 15:26] ​But, when the helper comes, whom I will send to you from the Father — the Spirit of truth, who comes from the Father — will bear testimony to me;
[OEBcw - John 15:27] ​yes, and you also are to bear testimony, because you have been with me from the first.
[OEBcw - John 16 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 16:1] I have spoken to you in this way so that you may not falter.
[OEBcw - John 16:2] ​They will expel you from their Synagogues; indeed the time is coming when anyone who kills you will think that they are making an offering to God.
[OEBcw - John 16:3] ​They will do this, because they have not learned to know the Father, or even me.
[OEBcw - John 16:4] ​But I have spoken to you of these things so that, when the time for them comes, you may remember that I told you about them myself.
[OEBcw - John 16:5] ​I did not tell you all this at first, because I was with you. But now I am to return to him who sent me; and yet not one of you asks me — ‘Where are you going?’
[OEBcw - John 16:6] ​Although your hearts are full of sorrow at all that I have been saying to you.
[OEBcw - John 16:7] ​Yet I am only telling you the truth; it is for your good that I should go away. For otherwise the helper will never come to you, but, if I leave you, I will send him to you.
[OEBcw - John 16:8] ​And he, when he comes, will bring conviction to the world as to sin, and as to righteousness, and as to judgment;
[OEBcw - John 16:9] ​as to sin, for people do not believe in me;
[OEBcw - John 16:10] ​as to righteousness, for I am going to the Father, and you will see me no longer;
[OEBcw - John 16:11] ​as to judgment, for the Spirit that is ruling this world has been condemned.
[OEBcw - John 16:12] ​I have still much to say to you, but you cannot bear it now.
[OEBcw - John 16:13] ​Yet when he — The Spirit of truth — comes, he will guide you into all truth; for he will not speak on his own authority, but he will speak of all that he hears; and he will tell you of the things that are to come.
[OEBcw - John 16:14] ​He will honour me; because he will take of what is mine, and will tell it to you.
[OEBcw - John 16:15] ​Everything that the Father has is mine; that is why I said that he takes of what is mine, and will tell it to you.
[OEBcw - John 16:16] ​In a little while you will no longer see me; and then in a little while you will see me indeed.”
[OEBcw - John 16:17] At this some of his disciples said to one another: “What does he mean by saying to us ‘In a little while you will not see me, and then in a little while you will see me indeed’; and by saying ‘Because I am going to the Father’?
[OEBcw - John 16:18] What does he mean by ‘In a little while’?” they said; “we do not know what he is speaking about.”
[OEBcw - John 16:19] Jesus saw that they were wanting to ask him a question, and said: “Are you trying to find out from one another what I meant by saying ‘In a little while you will not see me; and then in a little while you will see me indeed’?
[OEBcw - John 16:20] ​In truth I tell you that you will weep and mourn, but the world will rejoice; you will suffer pain, but your pain will turn to joy.
[OEBcw - John 16:21] ​A woman in labour is in pain because her time has come; but no sooner is the child born, than she forgets her trouble in her joy that a child has been born into the world.
[OEBcw - John 16:22] ​You, in the same way, are sorry now; but I will see you again, and your hearts will rejoice, and no one will rob you of your joy.
[OEBcw - John 16:23] ​And at that time you will not ask me anything; in truth I tell you, if you ask the Father for anything, he will grant it to you in my name.
[OEBcw - John 16:24] ​So far you have not asked for anything, in my name; ask, and you will receive, so that your joy may be complete.
[OEBcw - John 16:25] ​I have spoken to you of all this in figures; a time is coming, however, when I will not speak any longer to you in figures, but will tell you about the Father plainly.
[OEBcw - John 16:26] ​You will ask, at that time, in my name; and I do not say that I will intercede with the Father for you;
[OEBcw - John 16:27] ​for the Father himself loves you, because you have loved me, and have believed that I came from the Father.
[OEBcw - John 16:28] ​I came out from the Father, and have come into the world; and now I am to leave the world, and go to the Father.”
[OEBcw - John 16:29] “At last,” exclaimed the disciples, “you are using plain words and not speaking in figures at all.
[OEBcw - John 16:30] Now we are sure that you know everything, and need not wait for anyone to question you. This makes us believe that you did come from God.”
[OEBcw - John 16:31] “Do you believe that already?” Jesus answered.
[OEBcw - John 16:32] ​“Listen! A time is coming — indeed it has already come — when you are to be scattered, each going his own way, and to leave me alone; and yet I am not alone, because the Father is with me.
[OEBcw - John 16:33] ​I have spoken to you in this way, so that in me you may find peace. In the world you will find trouble; yet, take courage! I have conquered the world.”
[OEBcw - John 17 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 17:1] After saying this, Jesus raised his eyes heaven-wards, and said: “Father, the hour has come; honour your Son, so that your Son may honour you;
[OEBcw - John 17:2] ​even as you gave him power over all humanity, so that he should give eternal life to all those whom you has given him.
[OEBcw - John 17:3] ​And the eternal life is this — to know you the one true God, and Jesus Christ whom you has sent as your messenger.
[OEBcw - John 17:4] ​I have honoured you on earth by completing the work which you has given me to do;
[OEBcw - John 17:5] ​and now do you honour me, Father, at your own side, with the honour which I had at your side before the world began.
[OEBcw - John 17:6] ​I have revealed you to those whom you gave me from the world; they were your own, and you gave them to me; and they have laid your message to heart.
[OEBcw - John 17:7] ​They recognise now that everything that you gave me was from you;
[OEBcw - John 17:8] ​for I have given them the teaching which you gave me, and they received it, and clearly understood that I came from you, and they believed that you has sent me as your messenger.
[OEBcw - John 17:9] ​I intercede for them; I am not interceding for the world, but for those whom you has given me, for they are your own —
[OEBcw - John 17:10] ​All that is mine is yours, and all that is yours is mine — ​and I am honoured in them.
[OEBcw - John 17:11] ​Now I am to be in this world no longer, but they are still to be in the world, and I am to come to you. Holy Father, keep them by that revelation of your name which you has given me, so that they may be one, as we are.
[OEBcw - John 17:12] ​Whilst I was with them, I kept them by that revelation, and I have guarded them; and not one of them has been lost, except that lost soul — in fulfilment of scripture.
[OEBcw - John 17:13] ​But now I am to come to you; and I am speaking like this, while still in the world, so that they may have my own joy, in all its fullness, in their hearts.
[OEBcw - John 17:14] ​I have given them your message; and the world hated them, because they do not belong to the world, even as I do not belong to the world.
[OEBcw - John 17:15] ​I do not ask you to take them out of the world, but to keep them from evil.
[OEBcw - John 17:16] ​They do not belong to the world, even as I do not belong to the world.
[OEBcw - John 17:17] ​Consecrate them by the truth; your message is truth.
[OEBcw - John 17:18] ​Just as you has sent me as your messenger to the world, so I send them as my messengers to the world.
[OEBcw - John 17:19] ​And it is for their sakes that I am consecrating myself, so that they also may be truly consecrated.
[OEBcw - John 17:20] ​But it is not only for them that I am interceding, but also for those who believe in me through their message,
[OEBcw - John 17:21] ​that they all may be one — that as you, Father, are in union with us — and so the world may believe that you have sent me as your messenger.
[OEBcw - John 17:22] ​I have given them the honour which you has given me, so that they may be one as we are one —
[OEBcw - John 17:23] ​I in union with them and you with me — that so they may be perfected in their union, and so that the world may know that you have sent me as your messenger, and that you have loved them as you have loved me.
[OEBcw - John 17:24] ​Father, my desire for all those whom you have given me is that they may be with me where I am, so that they may see the honour which you have given me; for thou did love me before the beginning of the world.
[OEBcw - John 17:25] ​Righteous Father, though the world did not know you, I knew you; and these people knew that you have sent me as your messenger.
[OEBcw - John 17:26] ​I have made you known to them, and will do so still; that the love that you have had for me may be in their hearts, and that I may be in them also.”
[OEBcw - John 18 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 18:1] When Jesus had said this, he went out with his disciples and crossed the brook Kedron to a place where there was a garden, into which he and his disciples went.
[OEBcw - John 18:2] The place was well known to Judas, the betrayer, for Jesus and his disciples had often met there.
[OEBcw - John 18:3] So Judas, who had obtained the soldiers of the Roman garrison, and some police officers from the chief priests and the Pharisees, came there with lanterns, torches, and weapons.
[OEBcw - John 18:4] Jesus, aware of all that was coming upon him, went to meet them, and said to them: “For whom are you looking?”
[OEBcw - John 18:5] “Jesus of Nazareth,” was their answer. “I am he,” said Jesus. (Judas, the betrayer, was also standing with them.)
[OEBcw - John 18:6] When Jesus said ‘I am he,’ they drew back and fell to the ground.
[OEBcw - John 18:7] So he again asked for whom they were looking, and they answered: “Jesus of Nazareth.”
[OEBcw - John 18:8] “I have already told you that I am he,” replied Jesus, “so, if it is for me that you are looking, let these people go.”
[OEBcw - John 18:9] This was in fulfilment of his words — ‘Of those whom you have given me I have not lost one.’
[OEBcw - John 18:10] At this, Simon Peter, who had a sword with him, drew it, and struck the high priest’s servant, and cut off his right ear. The servant’s name was Malchus.
[OEBcw - John 18:11] But Jesus said to Peter: “Sheathe your sword. Should I not drink the cup which the Father has given me?”
[OEBcw - John 18:12] So the soldiers of the garrison, with their commanding officer and the Jewish police, arrested Jesus and bound him,
[OEBcw - John 18:13] and took him first of all to Annas. Annas was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was high priest that year.
[OEBcw - John 18:14] It was Caiaphas who had counselled the religious authorities, that it was best that one person should die for the people.
[OEBcw - John 18:15] Meanwhile Simon Peter followed Jesus, and so did another disciple. That disciple, being well-known to the high priest, went with Jesus into the high priest’s courtyard,
[OEBcw - John 18:16] while Peter stood outside by the door. Presently the other disciple — the one well-known to the high priest — went out and spoke to the portress, and brought Peter in.
[OEBcw - John 18:17] So the maidservant said to Peter: “Are not you also one of this man’s disciples?” “No, I am not,” he said.
[OEBcw - John 18:18] The servants and police officers were standing round a charcoal fire (which they had made because it was cold), and were warming themselves. Peter, too, was with them, standing and warming himself.
[OEBcw - John 18:19] The high priest questioned Jesus about his disciples and about his teaching.
[OEBcw - John 18:20] ​“For my part,” answered Jesus, “I have spoken to all the world openly. I always taught in some Synagogue, or in the Temple Courts, places where everyone assembles, and I never spoke of anything in secret.
[OEBcw - John 18:21] ​Why question me? Question those who have listened to me as to what I have spoken about to them. They must know what I said.”
[OEBcw - John 18:22] When Jesus said this, one of the police officers, who was standing near, gave him a blow with his hand. “Do you answer the high priest like that?” he exclaimed.
[OEBcw - John 18:23] ​“If I said anything wrong, give evidence about it,” replied Jesus; “but if not, why do you strike me?”
[OEBcw - John 18:24] Annas sent him bound to Caiaphas the high priest.
[OEBcw - John 18:25] Meanwhile Simon Peter was standing there, warming himself; so they said to him: “Are not you also one of his disciples?” Peter denied it. “No, I am not,” he said.
[OEBcw - John 18:26] One of the high priest’s servants, a relation of the man whose ear Peter had cut off, exclaimed: “Did not I myself see you with him in the garden?”
[OEBcw - John 18:27] Peter again denied it; and at that moment a cock crowed.
[OEBcw - John 18:28] From Caiaphas they took Jesus to the Government house. It was early in the morning. But they did not enter the Government house themselves, otherwise they might become ‘defiled,’ and so be unable to eat the Passover.
[OEBcw - John 18:29] Therefore Pilate came outside to speak to them. “What charge do you bring against this man?” he asked.
[OEBcw - John 18:30] “If he had not been a criminal, we should not have given him up to you,” they answered.
[OEBcw - John 18:31] “Take him yourselves,” said Pilate, “and try him by your own law.” “We have no power to put anyone to death,” the authorities replied —
[OEBcw - John 18:32] In fulfilment of what Jesus had said when indicating the death that he was destined to die.
[OEBcw - John 18:33] After that, Pilate went into the Government house again, and calling Jesus up, asked him: “Are you the king of the Jews?”
[OEBcw - John 18:34] “Do you ask me that yourself?” replied Jesus, “or did others say it to you about me?”
[OEBcw - John 18:35] “Do you take me for a Jew?” was Pilate’s answer. “It is your own nation and the chief priests who have given you up to me. What have you done?”
[OEBcw - John 18:36] “My kingly power,” replied Jesus, “is not due to this world. If it had been so, my servants would be doing their utmost to prevent my being given up to the authorities; but my kingly power is not from the world.”
[OEBcw - John 18:37] “So you are a king after all!” exclaimed Pilate. “Yes, it is true I am a king,” answered Jesus. “I was born for this, I have come into the world for this — to bear testimony to the truth. Everyone who is on the side of truth listens to my voice.”
[OEBcw - John 18:38] “What is truth?” exclaimed Pilate. After saying this, he went out to the crowd again, and said: “For my part, I find nothing with which he can be charged.
[OEBcw - John 18:39] It is, however, the custom for me to grant you the release of one man at the Passover Festival. Do you wish for the release of the king of the Jews?”
[OEBcw - John 18:40] “No, not this man,” they shouted again, “but Barabbas!” This Barabbas was a robber.
[OEBcw - John 19 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 19:1] After that, Pilate had Jesus scourged.
[OEBcw - John 19:2] The soldiers made a crown with some thorns and put it on his head and threw a purple robe round him.
[OEBcw - John 19:3] They kept coming up to him and saying: “Long live the king of the Jews!” and they gave him blow after blow with their hands.
[OEBcw - John 19:4] Pilate again came outside, and said to the people: “Look! I am bringing him out to you, so that you may know that I find nothing with which he can be charged.”
[OEBcw - John 19:5] Then Jesus came outside, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe; and Pilate said to them: “Here is the man!”
[OEBcw - John 19:6] When the chief priests and the police officers saw him, they shouted: “Crucify him! Crucify him!” “Take him yourselves and crucify him,” said Pilate. “For my part, I find nothing with which he can be charged.”
[OEBcw - John 19:7] “But we,” replied the crowd, “have a law, under which he deserves death for making himself out to be the Son of God.”
[OEBcw - John 19:8] When Pilate heard what they said, he became still more alarmed;
[OEBcw - John 19:9] and, going into the Government house again, he said to Jesus: “Where do you come from?”
[OEBcw - John 19:10] But Jesus made no reply. So Pilate said to him: “Do you refuse to speak to me? Do not you know that I have power to release you, and have power to crucify you?”
[OEBcw - John 19:11] “You would have no power over me at all,” answered Jesus, “if it had not been given you from above; and, therefore, the man who betrayed me to you is guilty of the greater sin.”
[OEBcw - John 19:12] This made Pilate anxious to release him; but the crowd shouted: “If you release that man, you are no friend of the Emperor! Anyone who makes himself out to be a king is setting himself against the Emperor!”
[OEBcw - John 19:13] On hearing what they said, Pilate brought Jesus out, and took his seat on the Bench at a place called ‘The Stone Pavement’ — in Hebrew ‘Gabbatha.’
[OEBcw - John 19:14] It was the Passover Preparation day, and about noon. Then he said to the crowd: “Here is your king!”
[OEBcw - John 19:15] At that the people shouted: “Kill him! Kill him! Crucify him!” “What! Should I crucify your king?” exclaimed Pilate. “We have no king but the Emperor,” replied the chief priests;
[OEBcw - John 19:16] so Pilate gave Jesus up to them to be crucified. So they took Jesus;
[OEBcw - John 19:17] and he went out, carrying his cross himself, to the place which is named from a scull, or, in Hebrew, Golgotha.
[OEBcw - John 19:18] There they crucified him, and two others with him — one on each side, and Jesus between them.
[OEBcw - John 19:19] Pilate also had these words written and put up over the cross — ‘JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWS.’
[OEBcw - John 19:20] These words were read by many people, because the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city; and they were written in Hebrew, Latin and Greek.
[OEBcw - John 19:21] The ​chief priests said to Pilate: “Do not write ‘The king of the Jews’, but write what the man said — ‘I am the king of the Jews.’”
[OEBcw - John 19:22] But Pilate answered: “What I have written, I have written.”
[OEBcw - John 19:23] When the soldiers had crucified Jesus, they took his clothes and divided them into four shares — a share for each soldier — and they took the coat also. The coat had no seam, being woven in one piece from top to bottom.
[OEBcw - John 19:24] So they said to one another: “Do not let us tear it, but let us cast lots for it, to see who will have it.” This was in fulfilment of the words of scripture — ‘They shared my clothes among them, And over my clothing they cast lots.’ That was what the soldiers did.
[OEBcw - John 19:25] Meanwhile near the cross of Jesus were standing his mother and his mother’s sister, as well as Mary the wife of Clopas and Mary of Magdala.
[OEBcw - John 19:26] When Jesus saw his mother, and the disciple whom he loved, standing near, he said to his mother: “There is your son.”
[OEBcw - John 19:27] Then he said to that disciple: “There is your mother.” And from that very hour the disciple took her to live in his house.
[OEBcw - John 19:28] Afterwards, knowing that everything was now finished, Jesus said, in fulfilment of the words of scripture: “I am thirsty.”
[OEBcw - John 19:29] There was a bowl standing there full of common wine; so they put a sponge soaked in the wine on the end of a hyssop-stalk, and held it up to his mouth.
[OEBcw - John 19:30] When Jesus had received the wine, he exclaimed: “All is finished!” Then, bowing his head, he resigned his spirit to God.
[OEBcw - John 19:31] It was the Preparation day, and so, to prevent the bodies from remaining on the crosses during the Sabbath (for that Sabbath was a great day), the Jews asked Pilate to have the legs broken and the bodies removed.
[OEBcw - John 19:32] Accordingly the soldiers came and broke the legs of the first man, and then those of the other who had been crucified with Jesus;
[OEBcw - John 19:33] but, on coming to him, when they saw that he was already dead, they did not break his legs.
[OEBcw - John 19:34] One of the soldiers, however, pierced his side with a spear, and blood and water immediately flowed from it.
[OEBcw - John 19:35] This is the statement of one who actually saw it — and his statement may be relied on, and he knows that he is speaking the truth — and it is given in order that you also may be convinced.
[OEBcw - John 19:36] For all this happened in fulfilment of the words of scripture — ‘Not one of its bones will be broken.’
[OEBcw - John 19:37] And there is another passage which says — ‘They will look on him whom they pierced.’
[OEBcw - John 19:38] After this, Joseph of Ramah, a disciple of Jesus — but a secret one, owing to his fear of the religious authorities — begged Pilate’s permission to remove the body of Jesus. Pilate gave him leave; so Joseph went and removed the body.
[OEBcw - John 19:39] Nicodemus, too — the man who had formerly visited Jesus by night — came with a roll of myrrh and aloes, weighing nearly a hundred pounds.
[OEBcw - John 19:40] They took the body of Jesus, and wound it in linen with the spices, according to the Jewish mode of burial.
[OEBcw - John 19:41] At the place where Jesus had been crucified there was a garden, and in the garden a newly made tomb in which no one had ever been laid.
[OEBcw - John 19:42] And so, because of its being the Preparation day, and as the tomb was close at hand, they laid Jesus there.
[OEBcw - John 20 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 20:1] On the first day of the week, early in the morning, while it was still dark, Mary of Magdala went to the tomb, and saw that the stone had been removed.
[OEBcw - John 20:2] So she came running to Simon Peter, and to that other disciple who was Jesus’ friend, and said to them: “They have taken away the Master out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid him!”
[OEBcw - John 20:3] So, Peter started off with that other disciple, and they went to the tomb.
[OEBcw - John 20:4] The two began running together; but the other disciple ran faster than Peter, and reached the tomb first.
[OEBcw - John 20:5] Stooping down, he saw the linen wrappings lying there, but did not go in.
[OEBcw - John 20:6] Presently Simon Peter came following behind him, and went into the tomb; and he looked at the linen wrappings lying there,
[OEBcw - John 20:7] and the cloth which had been on Jesus’ head, not lying with the wrappings, but rolled up on one side, separately.
[OEBcw - John 20:8] Then the other disciple, who had reached the tomb first, went inside too, and he saw for himself and was convinced.
[OEBcw - John 20:9] For they did not then understand the passage of scripture which says that Jesus must rise again from the dead.
[OEBcw - John 20:10] The disciples then returned to their companions.
[OEBcw - John 20:11] Meanwhile Mary was standing close outside the tomb, weeping. Still weeping, she leant forward into the tomb,
[OEBcw - John 20:12] and perceived two angels clothed in white sitting there, where the body of Jesus had been lying, one where the head and the other where the feet had been.
[OEBcw - John 20:13] “Why are you weeping?” asked the angels. “They have taken my Master away,” she answered, “and I do not know where they have laid him.”
[OEBcw - John 20:14] After saying this, she turned round, and looked at Jesus standing there, but she did not know that it was Jesus.
[OEBcw - John 20:15] ​“Why are you weeping? Whom are you seeking?” he asked. Supposing him to be the gardener, Mary answered: “If it was you, Sir, who carried him away, tell me where you have laid him, and I will take him away myself.”
[OEBcw - John 20:16] “Mary!” said Jesus. She turned round, and exclaimed in Hebrew: “Rabboni!” (or, as we should say, ‘teacher’).
[OEBcw - John 20:17] ​“Do not hold me,” Jesus said; “for I have not yet ascended to the Father. But go to my brothers, and tell them that I am ascending to him who is my Father and their Father, my God and their God.”
[OEBcw - John 20:18] Mary of Magdala went and told the disciples that she had seen the Master, and that he had said this to her.
[OEBcw - John 20:19] In the evening of the same day — the first day of the week — ​after the doors of the room, in which the disciples were, had been shut because they were afraid of the religious authorities, Jesus came and stood among them and said: “Peace be with you”;
[OEBcw - John 20:20] after which he showed them his hands and his side. The disciples were filled with joy when they saw the Master.
[OEBcw - John 20:21] Again Jesus said to them: “Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me as his messenger, so I am sending you.”
[OEBcw - John 20:22] After saying this, he breathed on them, and said: “Receive the Holy Spirit;
[OEBcw - John 20:23] ​if you remit anyone’s sins, they have been remitted; and, if you retain them, they have been retained.”
[OEBcw - John 20:24] But Thomas, one of the Twelve, called ‘The Twin,’ was not with them when Jesus came;
[OEBcw - John 20:25] so the rest of the disciples said to him: “We have seen the Master!” “Unless I see the marks of the nails in his hands,” he exclaimed, “and put my finger into the marks, and put my hand into his side, I will not believe it.”
[OEBcw - John 20:26] A week later the disciples were again in the house, and Thomas with them. After the doors had been shut, Jesus came and stood among them, and said: “Peace be with you.”
[OEBcw - John 20:27] Then he said to Thomas: “Place your finger here, and look at my hands; and place your hand here, and put it into my side; and do not refuse to believe, but believe.”
[OEBcw - John 20:28] And Thomas exclaimed: “My Master, and my God!”
[OEBcw - John 20:29] “Is it because you have seen me that you have believed?” said Jesus. “Blessed are they who have not seen, and yet have believed!”
[OEBcw - John 20:30] There were many other signs of his mission that Jesus gave in presence of the disciples, which are not recorded in this book;
[OEBcw - John 20:31] but these have been recorded so that you may believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God — and that, through your belief in his name, you may have life.
[OEBcw - John 21 - start] 
[OEBcw - John 21:1] Later on, Jesus showed himself again to the disciples by the Sea of Tiberias.
[OEBcw - John 21:2] It was in this way: — Simon Peter, Thomas, who was called ‘The Twin,’ Nathanael of Cana in Galilee, Zebedee’s sons, and two other disciples of Jesus, were together, when Simon Peter said:
[OEBcw - John 21:3] “I am going fishing.” “We will come with you,” said the others. They went out and got into the boat, but caught nothing that night.
[OEBcw - John 21:4] Just as day was breaking, Jesus came and stood on the beach; but the disciples did not know that it was he.
[OEBcw - John 21:5] ​“My children,” he said, “have you anything to eat?” “No,” they answered.
[OEBcw - John 21:6] ​“Cast your net to the right of the boat,” he said, “and you will find fish.” So they cast the net, and now they could not haul it in because of the quantity of fish.
[OEBcw - John 21:7] The disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter: “It is the Master!” When Simon Peter heard that it was the Master, he fastened his coat round him (for he had taken it off), and threw himself into the Sea.
[OEBcw - John 21:8] But the rest of the disciples came in the boat (for they were only about a hundred yards from shore), dragging the net full of fish.
[OEBcw - John 21:9] When they had come ashore, they found a charcoal fire ready, with some fish already on it, and some bread as well.
[OEBcw - John 21:10] ​“Bring some of the fish which you have just caught,” said Jesus.
[OEBcw - John 21:11] So Simon Peter got into the boat and hauled the net ashore full of large fish, a hundred and fifty-three of them; and yet, although there were so many, the net had not been torn.
[OEBcw - John 21:12] And Jesus said to them: “Come and breakfast.” Not one of the disciples ventured to ask him who he was, knowing that it was the Master.
[OEBcw - John 21:13] Jesus went and took the bread and gave it to them, and the fish too.
[OEBcw - John 21:14] This was the third time that Jesus showed himself to the disciples after he had risen from the dead.
[OEBcw - John 21:15] When breakfast was over, Jesus said to Simon Peter: “Simon, son of John, do you love me more than the others?” “Yes, Master,” he answered, “you know that I am your friend.”  “Feed my lambs,” said Jesus.
[OEBcw - John 21:16] Then, a second time, Jesus asked: “Simon, son of John, do you love me?” “Yes, Master,” he answered, “you know that I am your friend.”  “Tend my sheep,” said Jesus.
[OEBcw - John 21:17] The third time, Jesus said to him: “Simon, son of John, are you my friend?” Peter was hurt at his third question being ‘Are you my friend?’; and exclaimed: “Master, you know everything! You can tell that I am your friend.”  “Feed my sheep,” said Jesus.
[OEBcw - John 21:18] ​“In truth I tell you,” he continued, “when you were young, you used to put on your own girdle, and walk wherever you wished; but, when you have grown old, you will have to stretch out your hands, while some one else puts on your girdle, and takes you where you do not wish.”
[OEBcw - John 21:19] Jesus said this to show the death by which Peter was to honour God, and then he added: “Follow me.”
[OEBcw - John 21:20] Peter turned round, and saw the disciple whom Jesus loved following — the one who at the supper leant back on the Master’s shoulder, and asked him who it was who would betray him.
[OEBcw - John 21:21] Seeing him, Peter said to Jesus: “Master, what about this man?”
[OEBcw - John 21:22] “If it is my will that he should wait until I come,” answered Jesus, “what has that to do with you? Follow me yourself.”
[OEBcw - John 21:23] So the report spread among his followers that that disciple was not to die; yet Jesus did not say that he was not to die, but said “If it is my will that he should wait until I come, what has that to do with you?”
[OEBcw - John 21:24] It is this disciple who states these things, and who recorded them; and we know that his statement is true.
[OEBcw - John 21:25] There are many other things which Jesus did; but, if every one of them were to be recorded in detail, I suppose that even the world itself would not hold the books that would be written.
[OEBcw - Acts 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 1:1] The first account which I drew up, Theophilus, dealt with all that Jesus did and taught from the very first,
[OEBcw - Acts 1:2] down to that day on which he was taken up to heaven, after he had, by the help of the Holy Spirit, given instructions to the apostles whom he had chosen.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:3] With abundant proofs, he showed himself to them, still living, after his death; appearing to them from time to time during forty days, and speaking of all that related to the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:4] And once, when he had gathered them together, he charged them not to leave Jerusalem, but to wait there for the fulfilment of the Father’s promise — “that promise,” he said, “of which you have heard me speak;
[OEBcw - Acts 1:5] ​for, while John baptized with water, you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit before many days have passed.”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:6] So, when the apostles had met together, they asked Jesus this question — “Master, is this the time when you intend to re-establish the kingdom for Israel?”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:7] His answer was: “It is not for you to know times or hours, for the Father has reserved these for his own decision;
[OEBcw - Acts 1:8] ​but you will receive power, when the Holy Spirit will have descended on you, and will be witnesses for me not only in Jerusalem, but throughout Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:9] No sooner had Jesus said this than he was caught up before their eyes, and a cloud received him from their sight.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:10] While they were still gazing up into the heavens, as he went, suddenly two men, clothed in white, stood beside them,
[OEBcw - Acts 1:11] and said: “People of Galilee, why are you standing here looking up into the heavens? This same Jesus, who has been taken from you into the heavens, will come in the same way in which you have seen him go into the heavens.”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:12] Then the apostles returned to Jerusalem from the hill called Olivet, which is about three quarters of a mile from the city.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:13] When they reached Jerusalem, they went to the upstairs room, where they were staying. There were there Peter, John, James, and Andrew, Philip and Thomas, Bartholomew and Matthew, James the son of Alphaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas the son of James.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:14] They all united in devoting themselves to prayer, and so did some women, and Mary, the mother of Jesus, and his brothers.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:15] About this time, at a meeting of the Lord's followers, when there were about a hundred and twenty present, Peter rose to speak.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:16] “Friends,” he said, “it was necessary who the prediction of scripture should be fulfilled, which the Holy Spirit made by the lips of David about Judas, who acted as guide to the men that arrested Jesus,
[OEBcw - Acts 1:17] for he was one of our number and had his part allotted him in this work of ours.”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:18] (This man had bought a piece of land with the price of his treachery; and, falling heavily, his body had burst open, and all his bowels protruded.
[OEBcw - Acts 1:19] This became known to everyone living in Jerusalem, so that the field came to be called, in their language, ‘Akeldama,’ which means the ‘Field of Blood.’)
[OEBcw - Acts 1:20] “For in the book of Psalms,” Peter continued, “it is said — ‘Let his home, And let no one live in it’; and also — ‘His office let another take.’
[OEBcw - Acts 1:21] Therefore, from among the men who have been with us all the time that Jesus, our Master, went in and out among us —
[OEBcw - Acts 1:22] From his baptism by John down to that day on which he was taken from us — some one must be found to join us as a witness of his resurrection.”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:23] So they put forward two men, Joseph called Barsabas, whose other name was Justus, and Matthias;
[OEBcw - Acts 1:24] and they offered this prayer — “Lord, who reads all hearts, show which of these two men you have chosen
[OEBcw - Acts 1:25] To take the place in this apostolic work, which Judas has abandoned, to go to his proper place.”
[OEBcw - Acts 1:26] Then they drew lots between them; and, the lot having fallen on Matthias, he was added to the number of the eleven apostles.
[OEBcw - Acts 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 2:1] In the course of the Festival at the close of the Harvest the disciples had all met together,
[OEBcw - Acts 2:2] when suddenly there came from the heavens a noise like ​a strong wind rushing by; it filled the whole house in which they were sitting.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:3] Then there appeared tongues of what seemed to be flame, separating, so that one settled on each of them;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:4] and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and began to speak with strange ‘tongues’ as the Spirit prompted their utterances.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:5] Now there were then staying in Jerusalem religious Jews from every country in the world;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:6] and, when this sound was heard, numbers of people collected, in the greatest excitement, because each of them heard the disciples speaking in his own language.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:7] They were utterly amazed, and kept asking in astonishment: “What! Are not all these people who are speaking Galileans?
[OEBcw - Acts 2:8] Then how is it that we each of us hear them in our own ​language?
[OEBcw - Acts 2:9] Some of us are Parthians, some Medes, some Elamites; and some of us live in Mesopotamia, in Judea and Cappadocia, in Pontus and Roman Asia,
[OEBcw - Acts 2:10] in Phrygia and Pamphylia, in Egypt and the districts of Libya adjoining Cyrene; some of us are visitors from Rome,
[OEBcw - Acts 2:11] either Jews by birth or converts, and some are Cretans and Arabians — yet we all alike hear them speaking in our own tongues of the great things that God has done.”
[OEBcw - Acts 2:12] They were all utterly amazed and bewildered. “What does it mean?” they asked one another.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:13] But there were some who said with a sneer: “They have had too much new wine.”
[OEBcw - Acts 2:14] Then Peter, surrounded by the eleven other apostles, stood up, and, raising his voice, addressed the crowd. “People of Judea,” he began, “and all you who are staying in Jerusalem, let me tell you what this means. Mark well my words.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:15] These people are not drunk, as you suppose; for it is only now nine in the morning! No!
[OEBcw - Acts 2:16] This is what is spoken of in the prophet Joel —
[OEBcw - Acts 2:17] ‘It will come about in the last days,’ God says, ‘That I will pour out my Spirit on all humanity; Your sons and your daughters will become prophets, Your young men will see visions, And your old men dream dreams;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:18] Yes, even on the slaves — for they are mine — both men and women, I will in those days pour out my Spirit, And they will become prophets;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:19] And I will show wonders in the heavens above, And signs on the earth below — Blood and fire and mist of smoke;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:20] The sun will become darkness, And the moon blood-red, Before the day of the Lord comes — that great and awful day.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:21] Then will everyone who invokes the name of the Lord be saved.’
[OEBcw - Acts 2:22] People of Israel, listen to what I am saying. Jesus of Nazareth, a man whose mission from God to you was proved by miracles, wonders, and signs, which God showed among you through him, as you know full well —
[OEBcw - Acts 2:23] He, I say, in accordance with God’s definite plan and with his previous knowledge, was betrayed, and you, by the hands of lawless men, nailed him to a cross and put him to death.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:24] But God released him from the pangs of death and raised him to life, it being impossible for death to retain its hold on him.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:25] Indeed he was the one David was referring to when he said — ‘I have had the Lord ever before my eyes, For he stands at my right hand, so that I should not be disquieted.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:26] Therefore my heart was cheered, and my tongue told its delight; Yes, even my body, too, will rest in hope;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:27] For you will not abandon my soul to the place of death, Nor surrender me, your holy one, to undergo corruption.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:28] You have shown me the path to life, You will fill me with gladness in your presence.’
[OEBcw - Acts 2:29] Friends, I can speak to you the more confidently about the patriarch David, because he is dead and buried, and his tomb is here among us to this very day.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:30] David, then, prophet as he was, knowing that God ‘had solemnly sworn to him to set one of his descendants on his throne,’ looked into the future,
[OEBcw - Acts 2:31] and referred to the resurrection of the Christ when he said that ‘he had not been abandoned to the place of death, nor had his body undergone corruption.’
[OEBcw - Acts 2:32] It was this Jesus, whom God raised to life; and of that we are ourselves all witnesses.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:33] And now that he has been exalted to the right hand of God, and has received from the Father the promised gift of the Holy Spirit, he has begun to pour out that gift, as you yourselves now see and hear.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:34] It was not David who went up into heaven; for he himself says — ‘The Lord said to my master: “Sit on my right hand,
[OEBcw - Acts 2:35] Until I put your enemies as a footstool under your feet.”’
[OEBcw - Acts 2:36] So let the whole nation of Israel know beyond all doubt, that God has made him both Lord and Christ — this ​Jesus whom you crucified.”
[OEBcw - Acts 2:37] When the people heard this, they were conscience-smitten, and said to Peter and the rest of the apostles: “Friends, what can we do?”
[OEBcw - Acts 2:38] “Repent,” answered Peter, “and be baptized every one of you in the faith of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins; and then you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:39] For the promise is for you and for your children, and also for all those now far away, who may be called by the Lord our God.”
[OEBcw - Acts 2:40] Peter spoke to them for a long time using many other arguments and pleaded with them — “Save yourselves from the perverse spirit of this age.”
[OEBcw - Acts 2:41] So those who accepted his teaching were baptized, and about three thousand people joined the disciples on that day alone.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:42] They devoted themselves to the teaching of the apostles and to the Common life of the church, to the breaking of the bread and to the Prayers.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:43] A deep impression was made on everyone, and many wonders and signs were done at the hands of the apostles.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:44] All who became believers in Christ held everything for the common use;
[OEBcw - Acts 2:45] they sold their property and their goods, and shared the proceeds among them all, according to their individual needs.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:46] Every day they devoted themselves to meeting together in the Temple Courts, and to the breaking of bread at their homes, while they partook of their food in simple-hearted gladness, praising God, and winning the goodwill of all the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 2:47] And the Lord daily added to their company those who were in the path of salvation.
[OEBcw - Acts 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 3:1] One day, as Peter and John were going up into the Temple Courts for the three o’clock Prayers, a man, who had been lame from his birth, was being carried by.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:2] This man used to be set down every day at the gate of the Temple called ‘the Beautiful Gate,’ to beg of those who went in.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:3] Seeing Peter and John on the point of entering, he asked them to give him something.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:4] Peter fixed his eyes on him, and so did John, and then Peter said: “Look at us.”
[OEBcw - Acts 3:5] The man was all attention, expecting to get something from them;
[OEBcw - Acts 3:6] but Peter added: “I have no gold or silver, but I give you what I have. In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, get up and walk.”
[OEBcw - Acts 3:7] Grasping the lame man by the right hand, Peter lifted him up. Instantly the man’s feet and ankles became strong,
[OEBcw - Acts 3:8] and, leaping up, he stood and began to walk about, and then went with them into the Temple Courts, walking, and leaping, and praising God.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:9] All the people saw him walking about and praising God;
[OEBcw - Acts 3:10] and, when they recognised him as the man who used to sit begging at the Beautiful Gate of the Temple, they were utterly astonished and amazed at what had happened to him.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:11] While the man still clung to Peter and John, the people all quickly gathered round them in the Colonnade named after Solomon, in the greatest astonishment.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:12] On seeing this, Peter said to the people: “People of Israel, why are you surprised at this? And why do you stare at us, as though we, by any power or piety of our own, had enabled this man to walk?
[OEBcw - Acts 3:13] The God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the God of our ancestors, has done honour to his servant Jesus — him whom you gave up and disowned before Pilate, when he had decided to set him free.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:14] You, I say, disowned the holy and righteous one, and asked for the release of a murderer!
[OEBcw - Acts 3:15] The ​guide to life you put to death! But God raised him from the dead — and of that we are ourselves witnesses.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:16] And it is by faith in the name of Jesus, that this man, whom you all see and know, has — by his name — been made strong. Yes, it is the faith inspired by Jesus that has made this complete cure of the man, before the eyes of you all.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:17] And yet, my friends, I know that you acted as you did from ignorance, and your rulers also.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:18] But it was in this way that God fulfilled all that he had long ago foretold, as to the sufferings of his Christ, by the lips of all the prophets.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:19] Therefore, repent and turn so that your sins may be wiped away; so that happier times may come from the Lord himself,
[OEBcw - Acts 3:20] and so that he may send you, in Jesus, your long-appointed Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:21] But heaven must be his home, until the days of the Universal Restoration, of which God has spoken by the lips of his holy prophets from the very first.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:22] Moses himself said — ‘The Lord your God will raise up from among yourselves a prophet, as he raised me. To him you will listen whenever he speaks to you.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:23] And it will be that should anyone among the people not listen to that prophet, he will be utterly destroyed.’
[OEBcw - Acts 3:24] Yes, and all the prophets from Samuel onwards, and all their successors who had a message to deliver, told of these days.
[OEBcw - Acts 3:25] You yourselves are the heirs of the prophets, and heirs, too, of the covenant which God made with your ancestors, when he said to Abraham — ‘In your descendants will all the nations of the earth be blessed.’
[OEBcw - Acts 3:26] For you, first, God raised up his servant, and sent him to bless you, by turning each one of you from his wicked ways.”
[OEBcw - Acts 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 4:1] While Peter and John were still speaking to the people, the chief priest, with the officer in charge at the Temple and the Sadducees, came up to them,
[OEBcw - Acts 4:2] much annoyed because they were teaching the people, and because, through Jesus, they were preaching the resurrection from the dead.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:3] They arrested the apostles and, as it was already evening, had them placed in custody until the next day.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:4] Many, however, of those who had heard the apostles’ message became believers in Christ, the number of the men alone amounting to about five thousand.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:5] The next day, a meeting of the leaders of the people, the councillors, and the teachers of the law was held in Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:6] There were present Annas the high priest, Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and all who were of High-Priestly rank.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:7] They had Peter and John brought before them, and questioned them. “By what power,” they asked, “Or in whose name have men like you done this thing?”
[OEBcw - Acts 4:8] Then, Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said: “Leaders of the people and councillors,
[OEBcw - Acts 4:9] since we are on our trial today for a kind act done to a helpless man, and are asked in what way the man here before you has been cured,
[OEBcw - Acts 4:10] let me tell you all and all the people of Israel, that it is by the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified and whom God raised from the dead — it is, I say, by his name that this man stands here before you lame no longer.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:11] Jesus is ‘the stone which, scorned by you the builders, has yet become the corner stone.’
[OEBcw - Acts 4:12] And salvation is in him alone; for there is no other name in the whole world, given to people, to which we must look for our salvation.”
[OEBcw - Acts 4:13] When the Council saw how boldly Peter and John spoke, and found that they were uneducated men of humble station, they were surprised, and realised that they had been companions of Jesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:14] But, when they looked at the man who had been healed, standing there with them, they had nothing to say.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:15] So they ordered them out of court, and then began consulting together.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:16] “What are we to do to these men?” they asked one another. “That a remarkable sign has been given through them is obvious to everyone living in Jerusalem, and we cannot deny it.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:17] But, to prevent this thing from spreading further among the people, let us warn them not to speak in this name any more to anyone whatever.”
[OEBcw - Acts 4:18] So they called the apostles in, and ordered them not to speak or teach in the name of Jesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:19] But Peter and John replied: “Whether it is right, in the sight of God, to listen to you rather than to him —
[OEBcw - Acts 4:20] judge for yourselves, for we cannot help speaking of what we have seen and heard.”
[OEBcw - Acts 4:21] However, after further warnings, the Council set them at liberty, not seeing any safe way of punishing them, because of the people, for they were all praising God for what had occurred;
[OEBcw - Acts 4:22] for the man who was the subject of this miraculous cure was more than forty years old.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:23] After they had been set at liberty, the apostles went to their friends and told them what the chief priests and the councillors had said to them.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:24] All who heard their story, moved by a common impulse, raised their voices to God in prayer: “Sovereign Lord, it is you who has ‘made the heavens, the earth, the sea, and everything that is in them,’
[OEBcw - Acts 4:25] And who, by the lips of our ancestor, your servant David, who spoke under the influence of the Holy Spirit, have said — ‘Why did the nations rage, And the peoples form vain designs?
[OEBcw - Acts 4:26] The kings of the earth set their array, And its rulers gathered together, Against the Lord and against his Christ.’
[OEBcw - Acts 4:27] There have indeed gathered together in this city against your holy servant Jesus, whom you has consecrated the Christ, not Herod and Pontius Pilate only, but the nations and the people of Israel besides —
[OEBcw - Acts 4:28] Yet only to do what you, by your power and of your own will, did long ago destine to be done.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:29] Now, therefore, Lord, mark their threats, and enable your servants, with all fearlessness, to tell your message,
[OEBcw - Acts 4:30] while you stretch out your hand to heal, and cause signs and wonders to take place through the name of your holy servant Jesus.”
[OEBcw - Acts 4:31] When their prayer was ended, the place in which they were assembled was shaken; and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and began to tell God’s message fearlessly.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:32] The whole body of those who had become believers in Christ were of one heart and mind. Not one of them claimed any of his goods as his own, but everything was held for the common use.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:33] The apostles continued with great power to bear their testimony to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus, and God’s blessing rested on them all abundantly.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:34] Nor was there anyone in need among them, for all who were owners of land or houses sold them, and brought the proceeds of the sales
[OEBcw - Acts 4:35] And laid them at the apostles’ feet; and then everyone received a share in proportion to his wants.
[OEBcw - Acts 4:36] A Levite of Cyprian birth, named Joseph, (who had received from the apostles the additional name of ‘Barnabas’ — which means ‘The Consoler,’)
[OEBcw - Acts 4:37] Sold a farm that belonged to him, and brought the money and laid it at the apostles’ feet.
[OEBcw - Acts 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 5:1] There was, however, a man named Ananias, who, with his wife Sapphira, sold some property,
[OEBcw - Acts 5:2] and, with her connivance, kept back some of the proceeds. He brought only a part and laid it at the apostles’ feet.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:3] “Ananias,” Peter exclaimed, “how is it that Satan has so taken possession of your heart that you have lied to the Holy Spirit, and kept back a part of the money paid for the land?
[OEBcw - Acts 5:4] While it was unsold, was not it your own? And after it was sold, was not the money at your own disposal? How did you come to think of such a thing? You have lied, not to people, but to God!”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:5] As Ananias heard these words, he fell down and expired; and everyone who heard of it was appalled.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:6] The young men got up, and, winding the body in a sheet, carried it out and buried it.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:7] After an interval of about three hours his wife came in, not knowing what had happened.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:8] “Is it true,” Peter asked, addressing her, “that you sold your land for such a sum?” “Yes,” she answered, “we did.”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:9] Then Peter said: “How did you come to agree to provoke the Spirit of the Lord? Listen! The footsteps of those who have buried your husband are at the door; and they will carry you out too.”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:10] Instantly Sapphira fell down at Peter’s feet and expired. On coming in, the young men found her dead; so they carried her out and buried her by her husband’s side.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:11] The whole church and all who heard of these events were appalled.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:12] Many signs and wonders continued to occur among the people, through the instrumentality of the apostles, whose custom it was to meet all together in the Colonnade of Solomon;
[OEBcw - Acts 5:13] but of the rest no one ventured to join them. On the other hand, the people were full of their praise,
[OEBcw - Acts 5:14] and still larger numbers, both of men and women, as they became believers in the Lord, were added to their number.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:15] The consequence was that people would bring out their sick even into the streets, and lay them on mattresses and mats, in the hope that, as Peter came by, at least his shadow might fall on some one of them.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:16] Besides this, the inhabitants of the towns round Jerusalem flocked into the city, bringing with them their sick and those who were troubled by foul spirits; and they were cured everyone.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:17] At this the high priest was roused to action, and he and all his supporters (who formed the party of the Sadducees), moved by jealousy,
[OEBcw - Acts 5:18] arrested the apostles, and had them placed in custody.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:19] An angel of the Lord, however, opened the prison doors at night and led them out.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:20] “Go,” he said, “and stand in the Temple Courts, and tell the people the whole message of this new life.”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:21] When they heard this, they went at daybreak into the Temple Courts, and began to teach. The high priest and his party, on their arrival, summoned the High Council, including all the leaders of the people among the Israelites, and sent to the jail to fetch the apostles.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:22] But, when the officers got there, they did not find them in the prison; so they returned and reported that,
[OEBcw - Acts 5:23] while they had found the goal barred securely and the guards posted at the doors, yet, on opening them, they had not found anyone inside.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:24] When the officer in charge at the Temple and the chief priests heard their story, they were perplexed about the apostles and as to what all this would lead to.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:25] Presently, however, some one came and told them, that the men whom they had put in prison were actually standing in the Temple Courts, teaching the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:26] Then, the officer went with his men and fetched the apostles — without using violence, for they were afraid of being stoned by the people —
[OEBcw - Acts 5:27] And then brought them before the Council. The high priest demanded an explanation from them.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:28] “We gave you strict orders,” he said, “not to teach in this name. Yet you have actually flooded Jerusalem with your teaching, and you want to make us responsible for the death of this man.”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:29] To this Peter and the apostles replied: “We must obey God rather than people.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:30] The God of our ancestors raised Jesus, whom you put to death by hanging him on a cross.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:31] It is this Jesus whom God has exalted to his right hand, to be a guide and a Saviour, to give Israel repentance and forgiveness of sins.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:32] And we are witness to the truth of this, and so is the Holy Spirit — the gift of God to those who obey him.”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:33] The members of the Council became frantic with rage on hearing this, and were for putting the apostles to death.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:34] But Gamaliel, a Pharisee, who was a Doctor of the law and who was held in universal respect, rose in the Council, and directed that the men should be taken out of court for a little while.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:35] He then said: “People of Israel, take care as to what you intend to do with these men.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:36] For not long ago Theudas appeared, professing to be somebody, and was joined by a body of some four hundred men. But he was killed; and all his followers scattered and dwindled away.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:37] After him, Judas the Galilean appeared at the time of the census, and induced people to follow him; Yet he, too, perished and all his followers were dispersed.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:38] And, in this present case, my advice to you is not to interfere with these men, but to let them alone, for, if their designs and their work are merely of human origin, they will come to an end;
[OEBcw - Acts 5:39] but, if they are of divine origin, you will be powerless to put an end to them — or else you may find yourselves fighting against God!”
[OEBcw - Acts 5:40] The Council followed his advice, and, calling the apostles in, had them flogged, and then, after cautioning them not to speak in the name of Jesus, set them free.
[OEBcw - Acts 5:41] But the apostles left the Council, rejoicing that they had been thought worthy to suffer disgrace for that name;
[OEBcw - Acts 5:42] and never for a single day, either in the Temple Courts or in private houses, did they cease to teach, or to tell the good news of Jesus, the Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 6:1] About this time, when the number of the disciples was constantly increasing, complaints were made by the Greek speaking Jews against the Aramaic speaking Jews, that their widows were being overlooked in the daily distribution.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:2] The Twelve, therefore, called together the general body of the disciples and said to them: “It is not well for us to see to the distribution at the tables and neglect God’s message.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:3] Therefore, friends, look for seven men of reputation among yourselves, wise and spiritually-minded men, and we will appoint them to attend to this matter;
[OEBcw - Acts 6:4] while we, for our part, will devote ourselves to prayer, and to the delivery of the message.”
[OEBcw - Acts 6:5] This proposal was unanimously agreed to; and the disciples chose Stephen — a man full of faith and of the Holy Spirit — and Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicholas of Antioch, a former convert to Judaism;
[OEBcw - Acts 6:6] and they brought these men to the apostles, who, after praying, placed their hands on them.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:7] So God’s message spread, and the number of the disciples continued to increase rapidly in Jerusalem, and a large body of the priests accepted the faith.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:8] Meanwhile Stephen, divinely helped and strengthened, was showing great wonders and signs among the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:9] But some members of the Synagogue of the Freed Slaves (as it was called), Cyrenians, Alexandrians, and Visitors from Cilicia and Roman Asia, were roused to action and began disputing with Stephen;
[OEBcw - Acts 6:10] yet they were quite unable to withstand the wisdom and the inspiration with which he spoke.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:11] Then they induced some men to assert that they had heard Stephen saying blasphemous things against Moses, and against God;
[OEBcw - Acts 6:12] and they stirred up the people, as well as the councillors and the teachers of the law, and set on Stephen, and arrested him, and brought him before the High Council.
[OEBcw - Acts 6:13] There they produced witnesses who gave false evidence. “This man,” they said, “is incessantly saying things against this Holy place and the law;
[OEBcw - Acts 6:14] indeed, we have heard him declare that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place, and change the customs handed down to us by Moses.”
[OEBcw - Acts 6:15] The eyes of all the members of the Council were riveted on Stephen, and they saw his face looking like the face of an angel.
[OEBcw - Acts 7 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 7:1] Then the high priest asked: “Is this true?”
[OEBcw - Acts 7:2] Stephen replied: “Brothers and fathers, hear what I have to say. God, who manifests himself in the glory, appeared to our ancestor Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, and before he settled in Haran, and said to him —
[OEBcw - Acts 7:3] ‘Leave your country and your kindred, and come into the country that I will show you.’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:4] And so Abraham left the country of the Chaldaeans and settled in Haran; and from there, after his father’s death, God caused him to migrate into this ​country, in which you are now living.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:5] God did not at that time give him any part of it, not even a foot of ground. But he promised to ‘give him possession of it and his descendants after him, though at that time he had no child.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:6] God’s words were these — ‘Abraham’s descendants will live in a foreign country, where they will be enslaved and ill-treated for four hundred years.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:7] But I myself will judge the nation, to which they will be enslaved,’ God said, ‘and after that they will leave the country and worship me in this place.’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:8] Then God made with Abraham the covenant of circumcision; and under it Abraham became the father of Isaac, and circumcised him when he was eight days old; and Isaac became the father of Jacob; and Jacob of the Twelve Patriarchs.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:9] The Patriarchs, out of jealousy, sold Joseph into slavery in Egypt; but God was with him,
[OEBcw - Acts 7:10] and delivered him out of all his troubles, and enabled him to win favour and show wisdom before Pharaoh, king of Egypt, who appointed him Governor of Egypt and of his whole household.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:11] Then a famine spread over the whole of Egypt and Canaan, causing great distress, and our ancestors could find no food.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:12] Hearing, however, that there was corn in Egypt, Jacob sent our ancestors there on their first visit.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:13] In the course of their second visit, Joseph revealed himself to his brothers, and his family became known to Pharaoh.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:14] Then Joseph sent an urgent invitation to his father Jacob and to his relations, seventy-five persons in all;
[OEBcw - Acts 7:15] and so Jacob went down into Egypt. There he died, and our ancestors also,
[OEBcw - Acts 7:16] and their bodies were removed to Shechem, and laid in the tomb which Abraham had bought for a sum of money from the sons of Hamor in Shechem.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:17] As the time drew near for the fulfilment of the promise which God had made to Abraham, the people increased largely in numbers in Egypt,
[OEBcw - Acts 7:18] until a new king, who knew nothing of Joseph, came to the throne.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:19] This king acted deceitfully towards our race and ill-treated our ancestors, making them abandon their own infants, so that they should not be reared.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:20] It was just at this time that Moses was born. He was an exceedingly beautiful child, and for three months was brought up in his own father’s house;
[OEBcw - Acts 7:21] and, when he was abandoned, the daughter of Pharaoh found him and brought him up as her own son.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:22] So Moses was educated in all the learning of the Egyptians, and proved his ability both by his words and actions.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:23] When he was in his fortieth year, he resolved to visit his fellow Israelites;
[OEBcw - Acts 7:24] and, seeing an Israelite ill-treated, he defended him, and avenged the man, who was being wronged, by striking down the Egyptian.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:25] He thought his own people would understand that God was using him to save them; but they failed to do so.
