[OEBcw - Acts 7:26] The next day he again appeared on the scene, when some of them were fighting, and tried to make peace between them. ‘Men,’ he said, ‘you are brothers; how is it that you are ill-treating one another?’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:27] But the man who was ill-treating his fellow workman pushed Moses aside saying — ‘Who made you a ruler and judge over us?
[OEBcw - Acts 7:28] Do you mean to make away with me as you did yesterday with that Egyptian?’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:29] At these words Moses took to flight, and became an exile in Midian; and there he had two sons born to him.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:30] Forty years had passed when there appeared to him, in the desert of Mount Sinai, an angel in a flame of fire in a bush.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:31] When Moses saw it, he was astonished at the vision; but on his going nearer to look at it more closely, the voice of the Lord was heard to say —
[OEBcw - Acts 7:32] ‘I am the God of your ancestors, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.’ Moses trembled, and did not dare to look.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:33] Then the Lord said to him — ‘Take your sandals off your feet, for the spot where you are standing is holy ground.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:34] I have seen the oppression of my people who are in Egypt, and heard their groans, and I have come down to deliver them. Come now and I will send you into Egypt.’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:35] This same Moses, whom they had disowned with the words — ‘Who made you a ruler and a judge?’ was the ​man whom God sent to be both a ruler and a deliverer, under the guidance of the angel that had appeared to him in the bush.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:36] He it was who led them out, after he had shown wonders and signs in Egypt, in the Red Sea, and in the desert during forty years.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:37] This was the Moses who said to the people of Israel — ‘God will raise up for you, from among yourselves, a prophet, as he raised up me.’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:38] He, too, it was who was present at the assembly in the desert, with the angel who talked to him on Mount Sinai, and with our ancestors, and who received living truths to impart to you.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:39] Yet our ancestors refused him obedience; more than that, they rejected him, and in their hearts turned back to Egypt,
[OEBcw - Acts 7:40] while they said to Aaron — ‘Make us Gods who will lead the way for us, since, as for this Moses who has brought us out of Egypt, we do not know what has become of him.’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:41] That was the time when they made the calf and offered sacrifice to their idol, and held festivities in honour of their own handiwork!
[OEBcw - Acts 7:42] So God turned from them and left them to the worship of the Starry Host, as is written in the book of the prophets — ‘Did you offer victims and sacrifices to me, house of Israel, All those forty years in the desert?
[OEBcw - Acts 7:43] You took with you the tent where Moloch is worshipped And the star of the god Rephan — The images which you had made to worship. Therefore I will exile you beyond Babylon.’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:44] Our ancestors had the tent where they worshipped God in the desert, constructed, just as he who spoke to Moses had directed him to make it, after the model which he had seen.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:45] This tent, which was handed down to them, was brought into this country by our ancestors who accompanied Joshua (at the conquest of the nations that God drove out before their advance), and remained here until the time of David.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:46] David found favour with God, and prayed that he might provide the God of Jacob with a place to reside.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:47] But it was Solomon who built a house for God.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:48] Yet it is not in buildings made by hands that the Most High dwells. As the prophet says —
[OEBcw - Acts 7:49] ‘The heavens are a throne for me, And the earth a stool for my feet. What manner of house will you build me, saith the Lord, Or what place is there where I may rest?
[OEBcw - Acts 7:50] Was it not my hand that made all these things?’
[OEBcw - Acts 7:51] Stubborn race, heathen in heart and ears, you are for ever resisting the Holy Spirit; your ancestors did it, and you are doing it still.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:52] Which of the prophets escaped persecution at their hands? They killed those who foretold the coming of the righteous one; of whom you, in your turn, have now become the betrayers and murderers —
[OEBcw - Acts 7:53] You who received the law as transmitted by angels and yet failed to keep it.”
[OEBcw - Acts 7:54] As they listened to this, the Council grew frantic with rage, and gnashed their teeth at Stephen.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:55] He, filled as he was with the Holy Spirit, fixed his eyes intently on the heavens, and saw the glory of God and Jesus standing at God’s right hand.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:56] “Look,” he exclaimed, “I see heaven open and the Son of Man standing at God’s right hand!”
[OEBcw - Acts 7:57] At this, with a loud shout, they stopped their ears and all rushed on him, forced him outside the city,
[OEBcw - Acts 7:58] and began to stone him, the witnesses laying their clothes at the feet of a young man named Saul.
[OEBcw - Acts 7:59] And they stoned Stephen, while he cried to the Lord: “Lord Jesus! Receive my spirit!”
[OEBcw - Acts 7:60] Falling on his knees, he called out loudly: “Lord! Do not charge them with this sin;” and with these words he fell asleep.
[OEBcw - Acts 8 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 8:1] Saul approved of his being put to death. On that very day a great persecution broke out against the church which was in Jerusalem; and its members, with the exception of the apostles, were all scattered over the districts of Judea and Samaria.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:2] Some religious men buried Stephen, with loud lamentations for him.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:3] But Saul began to devastate the church; he entered house after house, dragged out men and women alike, and threw them into prison.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:4] Now those who were scattered in different directions went from place to place proclaiming the good news.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:5] Philip went down to the city of Samaria, and there began to preach the Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:6] The people, one and all, listened attentively to what Philip told them, when they heard of, and saw, the miracles which he was working.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:7] For there were many instances of people with foul spirits, where the spirits, with loud screams, came out of them;
[OEBcw - Acts 8:8] and many who were paralysed or lame were cured, so that there was great rejoicing throughout that city.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:9] There was staying in the city a man named Simon, who had been practicing magic there and mystifying the Samaritan people, giving himself out to be some great being.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:10] Everyone, high and low, paid attention to him. ‘This man,’ they used to say, ‘must be that power of God which people call “The Great Power.”’
[OEBcw - Acts 8:11] And they paid attention to him because they had for a long time been mystified by his magic arts.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:12] However, when they came to believe Philip, as he told them the good news about the kingdom of God and the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, both men and women.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:13] Even Simon believed, and after his baptism attached himself to Philip, and was in his turn mystified at seeing signs and great miracles constantly occurring.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:14] When the apostles at Jerusalem heard that the Samaritans had welcomed God’s message, they sent Peter and John to them;
[OEBcw - Acts 8:15] and they, on their arrival, prayed that the Samaritans might receive the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:16] (As yet the Spirit had not descended on any of them; they had only been baptized into the faith of the Lord Jesus).
[OEBcw - Acts 8:17] Then Peter and John placed their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:18] When Simon saw that it was through the placing of the apostles’ hands on them that the Spirit was given, he brought them a sum of money and said:
[OEBcw - Acts 8:19] “Give me also this power of yours, so that, if I place my hands on anyone, he may receive the Holy Spirit.”
[OEBcw - Acts 8:20] “A curse on you and on your money,” Peter exclaimed, “for thinking that God’s free gift can be bought with gold!
[OEBcw - Acts 8:21] You have no share or part in our message, for your ‘heart is not right with God.’
[OEBcw - Acts 8:22] Therefore repent of this wickedness of yours, and pray to the Lord, that, if possible, you may be forgiven for such a thought;
[OEBcw - Acts 8:23] for I see that you have fallen into the ‘bitterness of envy’ and the ‘fetters of sin.’”
[OEBcw - Acts 8:24] “Pray to the Lord for me, all of you,” Simon answered, “so that none of the things you have spoken of may happen to me.”
[OEBcw - Acts 8:25] Peter and John, having borne their testimony and delivered the Lord’s message, returned to Jerusalem, telling the good news, as they went, in many Samaritan villages.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:26] Meanwhile an angel of the Lord had said to Philip: “Set out on a journey southwards, along the road that runs down from Jerusalem to Gaza.” (It is now deserted).
[OEBcw - Acts 8:27] So Philip set out on a journey; and on his way he came on an official of high rank, in the service of Candace, Queen of the Abyssinians. He was her treasurer, and had been to Jerusalem to worship,
[OEBcw - Acts 8:28] and was now on his way home, sitting in his carriage and reading the prophet Isaiah.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:29] The Spirit said to Philip: “Go up to the carriage over there and keep close to it.”
[OEBcw - Acts 8:30] So Philip ran up, and he heard the Abyssinian reading the prophet Isaiah. “Do you understand what you are reading?” he asked.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:31] “How can I,” the other answered, “unless some one will explain it to me?” and he invited Philip to get up and sit by his side.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:32] The passage of scripture which he was reading was this — ‘Like a sheep, he was led away to slaughter, And as a lamb is dumb in the hands of its shearer, So he refrains from opening his lips.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:33] He was humiliated and justice was denied him. Who will tell the story of his generation? For his life is cut off from earth.’
[OEBcw - Acts 8:34] “Now,” said the Treasurer, addressing Philip, “tell me, of whom is the prophet speaking? Of himself, or of some one else?”
[OEBcw - Acts 8:35] Then Philip began, and, taking this passage as his text, told him the good news about Jesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:36] Presently, as they were going along the road, they came to some water, and the Treasurer exclaimed: “Look! Here is water; what is to prevent my being baptized?”
[OEBcw - Acts 8:37] 
[OEBcw - Acts 8:38] So he ordered the carriage to stop, and they went down into the water — both Philip and the Treasurer — and Philip baptized him.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:39] But, when they came up out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord caught Philip away, and the Treasurer saw no more of him; for he continued his journey with a joyful heart.
[OEBcw - Acts 8:40] But Philip was found at Ashdod, and, as he went on his way, he told the good news in all the towns through which he passed, until he came to Caesarea.
[OEBcw - Acts 9 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 9:1] Meanwhile Saul, still breathing murderous threats against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest,
[OEBcw - Acts 9:2] and asked him to give him letters to the Jewish congregations at Damascus, authorising him, if he found there any supporters of the cause, whether men or women, to have them put in chains and brought to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:3] While on his journey, as he was nearing Damascus, suddenly a light from the heavens flashed around him.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:4] He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him — “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:5] “Who are you, Lord?” he asked.  “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting,” the voice answered;
[OEBcw - Acts 9:6] ​“Yet stand up and go into the city, and you will be told what you must do.”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:7] The men traveling with Saul were meanwhile standing speechless; they heard the sound of the voice, but saw no one.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:8] When Saul got up from the ground, though his eyes were open, he could see nothing. So his men led him by the hand, and brought him into Damascus;
[OEBcw - Acts 9:9] and for three days he was unable to see, and took nothing either to eat or to drink.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:10] Now there was at Damascus a disciple named Ananias, to whom, in a vision, the Lord said: “Ananias.” “Yes, Lord,” he answered.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:11] ​“Go at once,” said the Lord, “to the ‘Straight Street’, and ask at Judas’s house for a man named Saul, from Tarsus. He is at this moment praying,
[OEBcw - Acts 9:12] ​and he has seen, in a vision, a man named Ananias coming in and placing his hands on him, so that he may recover his sight.”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:13] “Lord,” exclaimed Ananias, “I have heard from many people about this man — how much harm he has done at Jerusalem to your people there.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:14] And, here, too, he holds authority from the chief priests to put in chains all those who invoke your name.”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:15] But the Lord said to him: “Go, for this man is my chosen instrument to uphold my name before the Gentiles and their kings, and the people of Israel.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:16] ​I will myself show him all that he has to suffer for my name.”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:17] So Ananias went, entered the house, and, placing his hands on Saul, said: “Saul, my brother, I have been sent by the Lord — by Jesus, who appeared to you on your way here — so that you may recover your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:18] Instantly it seemed as if a film fell from Saul’s eyes, and his sight was restored. Then he got up and was baptized,
[OEBcw - Acts 9:19] and, after he had taken food, he felt his strength return. Saul stayed for some days with the disciples who were at Damascus,
[OEBcw - Acts 9:20] and at once began in the Synagogues to proclaim Jesus as the Son of God.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:21] All who heard him were amazed. “Is not this,” they asked, “the man who worked havoc in Jerusalem among those that invoke this name, and who had also come here for the express purpose of having such persons put in chains and taken before the chief priests?”
[OEBcw - Acts 9:22] Saul’s influence, however, kept steadily increasing, and he confounded the Jewish people who lived in Damascus by the proofs that he gave that Jesus was the Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:23] After some time some of them laid a plot to kill Saul,
[OEBcw - Acts 9:24] but it became known to him. They even watched the gates day and night, to kill him;
[OEBcw - Acts 9:25] but his disciples let him down by night through an opening in the wall, lowering him in a basket.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:26] On his arrival in Jerusalem, Saul attempted to join the disciples, but they were all afraid of him, as they did not believe that he was really a disciple.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:27] Barnabas, however, taking him by the hand, brought him to the apostles, and told them the whole story of how Saul on his journey had seen the Lord, and how the Lord had talked to him, and how in Damascus he had spoken out fearlessly in the name of Jesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:28] After that, Saul remained in Jerusalem, in close intercourse with the apostles; and he spoke fearlessly in the name of the Lord,
[OEBcw - Acts 9:29] talking and arguing with the Jews of foreign birth, who, however, made attempts to kill him.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:30] But, when the followers found this out, they took him down to Caesarea, and sent him on his way to Tarsus.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:31] And so it came about that the church, throughout Judea, Galilee, and Samaria, enjoyed peace and became firmly established; and, ordering its life by respect for the Lord and the help of the Holy Spirit, it increased in numbers.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:32] Peter, while traveling from place to place throughout the country, went down to visit the people of Christ living at Lydda.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:33] There he found a man named Aeneas, who had been bedridden for eight years with paralysis.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:34] “Aeneas,” Peter said to him, “Jesus Christ cures you. Get up, and make your bed.” Aeneas got up at once;
[OEBcw - Acts 9:35] and all the inhabitants of Lydda and of the Plain of Sharon saw him, and came over to the Lord’s side.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:36] At Jaffa there lived a disciple whose name was Tabitha, which is in Greek ‘Dorcas’ — a Gazelle. Her life was spent in doing kind and charitable actions.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:37] Just at that time she was taken ill, and died; and they had washed her body and laid it out in an upstairs room.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:38] Jaffa was near Lydda, and the disciples, having heard that Peter was at Lydda, sent two men with the request that he come to them without delay.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:39] Peter returned with them at once. On his arrival, he was taken upstairs, and all the widows came round him in tears, showing the coats and other clothing which Dorcas had made while she was among them.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:40] But Peter sent everybody out of the room, and knelt down and prayed. Then, turning to the body, he said: “Tabitha! Stand up.” She opened her eyes, and, seeing Peter, sat up.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:41] Giving her his hand, Peter raised her up, and, calling in the widows and others of Christ’s people, presented her to them alive.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:42] This became known all through Jaffa, and numbers of people came to believe in the Lord.
[OEBcw - Acts 9:43] And Peter stayed some days at Jaffa with a tanner named Simon.
[OEBcw - Acts 10 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 10:1] At Caesarea there was a man named Cornelius, a captain in the regiment known as the ‘Italian Regiment,’
[OEBcw - Acts 10:2] A religious man and one who reverenced God, with all his household. He was liberal in his charities to the people, and prayed to God constantly.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:3] One afternoon, about three o’clock, he distinctly saw in a vision an angel from God come to him, and call him by name.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:4] Cornelius fixed his eyes on him and, in great alarm, said: “What is it, Lord?” “Your prayers and your charities,” the angel answered, “have been an acceptable offering to God.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:5] And now, send messengers to Jaffa and fetch a man called Simon, who is also known as Peter.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:6] He is lodging with a tanner named Simon, who has a house near the sea.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:7] When the angel, who had spoken to him, had gone, Cornelius called two servants and a religious soldier, who was one of his constant attendants,
[OEBcw - Acts 10:8] and, after telling them the whole story, sent them to Jaffa.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:9] On the next day, while these men were on their way, just as they were nearing the town, Peter went up on the housetop about midday to pray.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:10] He became hungry and wanted something to eat; but while it was being prepared, he fell into a trance,
[OEBcw - Acts 10:11] and saw that the heavens were open, and that something like a great sail was descending, let down by its four corners towards the earth.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:12] In it were all kinds of quadrupeds, reptiles, and birds.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:13] Then he was aware of a voice which said — “Stand up, Peter, kill something, and eat.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:14] “No, Lord, I cannot,” answered Peter, “for I have never eaten anything ‘defiled’ and ‘unclean’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:15] Again he was aware of a voice which said — “What God has pronounced ‘clean’, do not regard as ‘defiled’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:16] This happened three times, and then suddenly it was all taken up into the heavens.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:17] While Peter was still perplexed as to the meaning of the vision that he had seen, the men sent by Cornelius, having enquired the way to Simon’s house, came up to the gate,
[OEBcw - Acts 10:18] and called out and asked if the Simon, who was also known as Peter, was lodging there.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:19] Peter was still pondering over the vision, when the Spirit said to him: “There are two men looking for you at this moment.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:20] Go down at once and do not hesitate to go with them, for I have sent them.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:21] Peter went down to the men and said: “I am the person you are looking for. What is your reason for coming?”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:22] The men replied: “Our captain, Cornelius, a pious man who reverences God and is well spoken of by the whole Jewish nation, has been instructed by a holy angel to send for you to his house, and to listen to what you have to say.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:23] So Peter invited them in and entertained them. The next day he lost no time in setting out with them, accompanied by some of the Lord's followers from Jaffa;
[OEBcw - Acts 10:24] and the day following he entered Caesarea. Cornelius was expecting them, and had invited his relations and intimate friends to meet them.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:25] So, when Peter entered the city, Cornelius met him, and, throwing himself at Peter’s feet, bowed to the ground.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:26] Peter, however, lifted him up, saying as he did so: “Stand up, I am only human like yourself.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:27] Talking with him as he went, Peter entered the house, where he found a large gathering of people, to whom he said:
[OEBcw - Acts 10:28] “You are doubtless aware that it is forbidden for a Jew to be intimate with a foreigner, or even to enter his house; and yet God has shown me that I ought not to call anyone ‘defiled’ or ‘unclean.’
[OEBcw - Acts 10:29] That was why I came, when I was sent for, without raising any objection. And now I ask your reason for sending for me.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:30] “Just three days ago this very hour,” Cornelius said, “I was in my house, saying the Afternoon Prayers, when a man in dazzling clothing suddenly stood before me.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:31] ‘Cornelius,’ he said, ‘your prayer has been heard, and your charities have been accepted, by God.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:32] Therefore send to Jaffa, and invite the Simon, who is also known as Peter, to come here. He is lodging in the house of Simon the tanner, near the sea.’
[OEBcw - Acts 10:33] Accordingly I sent to you at once, and you have been so good as to come. And now we are all here in the presence of God, to listen to all that you have been instructed by the Lord to say.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:34] Then Peter began. “I see, beyond all doubt,” he said, “that ‘God does not show partiality,’
[OEBcw - Acts 10:35] But that in every nation he who reverences him and does what is right is acceptable to him.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:36] God has sent his message to the Israelites and told them, through Jesus Christ, the good news of peace — and Jesus is Lord of all!
[OEBcw - Acts 10:37] You yourselves know the story which spread through all Judea, how, beginning form Galilee, after the baptism which John proclaimed —
[OEBcw - Acts 10:38] The story, I mean, of Jesus of Nazareth, and how God consecrated him his Christ by enduing him with the Holy Spirit and with power; and how he went about doing good and curing all who were under the power of the devil, because God was with him.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:39] We are ourselves, too, witnesses to all that he did in Judea and in Jerusalem; yet they put him to death by hanging him on a cross!
[OEBcw - Acts 10:40] This Jesus God raised on the third day, and enabled him to appear,
[OEBcw - Acts 10:41] not indeed to everyone, but to witnesses chosen beforehand by God — to us, who ate and drank with him after his resurrection from the dead.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:42] Further, God charged us to proclaim to the people, and solemnly affirm, that it is Jesus who has been appointed by God judge of the living and the dead.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:43] To him it is that all the prophets bear witness, when they say that everyone who believes in him receives through his name forgiveness of sins.”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:44] Before Peter had finished saying these words, the Holy Spirit fell on all who were listening to the message.
[OEBcw - Acts 10:45] Those converts from Judaism, who had come with Peter, were amazed that the gift of the Holy Spirit had been bestowed even on the Gentiles;
[OEBcw - Acts 10:46] for they heard them speaking with ‘tongues’ and extolling God. At this Peter asked:
[OEBcw - Acts 10:47] “Can anyone refuse the water for the baptism of these people, now that they have received the Holy Spirit as we did ourselves?”
[OEBcw - Acts 10:48] And he directed that they should be baptized in the faith of Jesus Christ; after which they asked him to stay there a few days longer.
[OEBcw - Acts 11 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 11:1] The apostles and the followers throughout Judea heard that even the Gentiles had welcomed God’s message.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:2] But, when Peter went up to Jerusalem, those who were converts from Judaism began to attack him,
[OEBcw - Acts 11:3] on the ground that he had visited people who were not circumcised, and had taken meals with them.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:4] So Peter began to relate the facts to them as they had occurred.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:5] “I was in the town of Jaffa,” he said, “and was praying; and, while in a trance, I saw a vision. There was something like a great sail descending, let down by its four corners out of the heavens; and it came right down to me.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:6] Looking intently at it, I began to distinguish quadrupeds, wild beasts, reptiles, and birds;
[OEBcw - Acts 11:7] and I also heard a voice saying to me — ‘Stand up, Peter, kill something and eat.’
[OEBcw - Acts 11:8] ‘No, Lord, I cannot,’ I answered, ‘for nothing ‘defiled’ or ‘unclean’ has ever passed my lips.’
[OEBcw - Acts 11:9] Then a second time there came a voice from the heavens. “What God has pronounced ‘clean’,” it said, “you must not call ‘defiled’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 11:10] This happened three times, and then all was drawn up again into the heavens.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:11] At that moment three men, who had been sent from Caesarea to see me, came up to the house in which we were.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:12] The Spirit told me to go with them without hesitation. These six companions also went with me. And, when we came into the man’s house,
[OEBcw - Acts 11:13] he told us how he had seen the angel standing in his house, and how the angel had said to him — ‘Send to Jaffa and fetch the Simon, who is also known as Peter;
[OEBcw - Acts 11:14] for he will tell you truths, which will prove the means of salvation to you and all your household.’
[OEBcw - Acts 11:15] I had but just begun to speak,” continued Peter, “when the Holy Spirit fell on them, exactly as on us at the first;
[OEBcw - Acts 11:16] and I recalled the saying of the Master — ‘John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit.’
[OEBcw - Acts 11:17] Since then, God had given them the very same gift as he gave us when we became believers in Jesus Christ the Master — who was I that I could thwart God?”
[OEBcw - Acts 11:18] On hearing this statement, they said no more, but broke out into praise of God. “So even to the Gentiles,” they exclaimed, “God has granted the repentance which leads to life!”
[OEBcw - Acts 11:19] Now those who had been scattered in different directions, in consequence of the persecution that followed ​the death of Stephen, went as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, telling the message — but only to Jews.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:20] Some of them, however, who were men of Cyprus and Cyrene, on coming to Antioch, addressed themselves also to the Jews of foreign birth, telling them the good news about that Lord Jesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:21] The power of the Lord was with them, so that a great number who had learned to believe came over to the Lord’s side.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:22] The news about them reached the ears of the church at Jerusalem, and they sent Barnabas to Antioch.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:23] On coming there he saw to his great joy these tokens of the loving kindness of God, and encouraged them all to make up their minds to be faithful to the Lord —
[OEBcw - Acts 11:24] For Barnabas was a good man and full of the Holy Spirit and of faith — and a large number of people took their stand on the Lord’s side.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:25] Afterwards Barnabas left for Tarsus to look for Saul;
[OEBcw - Acts 11:26] and, when he had found him, he brought him to Antioch. And so it came about that, for a whole year, they attended the meetings of the church there, and taught a large number of people; and it was in Antioch that the disciples were first called ‘Christians.’
[OEBcw - Acts 11:27] During this time, some prophets came to Antioch from Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:28] One of them, named Agabus, came forward and, under the influence of the Spirit, foretold a great famine that was to spread over all the world — a famine which occurred in the reign of Claudius.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:29] So the disciples, without exception, determined, in proportion to their means, to send something to help the followers living in Judea.
[OEBcw - Acts 11:30] And this they did, sending it to the officers of the church by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.
[OEBcw - Acts 12 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 12:1] It was at that time that King Herod began to ill-treat some of the members of the church.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:2] He had James, the brother of John, beheaded;
[OEBcw - Acts 12:3] and, when he saw that the Jews were pleased with this, he proceeded to arrest Peter also. (This was during the Festival of the unleavened bread.)
[OEBcw - Acts 12:4] After seizing Peter, Herod put him in prison, and entrusted him to the keeping of four Guards of four soldiers each, intending, after the Passover, to bring him up before the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:5] So Peter was kept in prison, but meanwhile the prayers of the church were being earnestly offered to God on his behalf.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:6] Just when Herod was intending to bring him before the people, on that very night Peter was asleep between two soldiers, chained to them both, while there were sentries in front of the door, guarding the prison.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:7] Suddenly an angel of the Lord stood by him, and a light shone in the cell. The angel struck Peter on the side, and roused him with the words: “Get up quickly.”
[OEBcw - Acts 12:8] The chains dropped from his wrists, and then the angel said: “Put on your girdle and sandals.” When Peter had done so, the angel added: “Throw your cloak round you and follow me.”
[OEBcw - Acts 12:9] Peter followed him out, not knowing that what was happening under the angel’s guidance was real, but thinking that he was seeing a vision.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:10] Passing the first Guard, and then the second, they came to the iron gate leading into the city, which opened to them of itself; and, when they had passed through that, and had walked along one street, all at once the angel left him.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:11] Then Peter came to himself and said: “Now I know beyond all doubt that the Lord has sent his angel, and has rescued me from Herod’s hands and from all that the Jewish people have been expecting.”
[OEBcw - Acts 12:12] As soon as he realized what had happened, he went to the house of Mary, the mother of John who was also known as Mark, where a number of people were gathered together, praying.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:13] On his knocking at the door in the gate, a maidservant, named Rhoda, came to answer it.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:14] She recognized Peter’s voice, but in her joy left the gate unopened, and ran in, and told them that Peter was standing outside.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:15] “You are mad!” they exclaimed. But, when she persisted that it was so, they said: “It must be his spirit!”
[OEBcw - Acts 12:16] Meanwhile Peter went on knocking, and, when they opened the gate and saw him, they were amazed.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:17] Peter signed to them with his hand to be silent, and then told them how the Lord had brought him out of the prison, adding: “Tell James and the others all this.” Then he left the house, and went away to another place.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:18] In the morning there was a great stir among the soldiers — ​what could have become of Peter!
[OEBcw - Acts 12:19] And, when Herod had made further search for him and failed to find him, he closely questioned the Guard, and ordered them away to execution. Then he went down from Judea to stay at Caesarea.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:20] It happened that Herod was deeply offended with the people of Tyre and Sidon, but they went in a body to him, and, having succeeded in winning over Blastus, the Chamberlain, they begged Herod for a reconciliation, because their country was dependent on the king’s for its food supply.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:21] On an appointed day Herod, wearing his state robes, seated himself on his throne, and delivered an oration.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:22] The people kept shouting: “It is the voice of God, and not of a person!”
[OEBcw - Acts 12:23] Instantly an angel of the Lord struck him, because he did not give God the glory; and he was attacked with worms, and died.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:24] Meanwhile the Lord’s message kept extending, and spreading far and wide.
[OEBcw - Acts 12:25] When Barnabas and Saul had carried out their mission, they returned to Jerusalem, and took with them John, who was also known as Mark.
[OEBcw - Acts 13 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 13:1] Among the members of the church at Antioch there were several prophets and teachers — Barnabas, Simeon who was known by the name of ‘Black’, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, foster-brother of Prince Herod, and Saul.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:2] While they were engaged in the worship of the Lord and were fasting, the Holy Spirit said: “Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul, for the work to which I have called them.”
[OEBcw - Acts 13:3] Accordingly, after fasting and prayer, they placed their hands on them and dismissed them.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:4] Barnabas and Saul, sent on this mission, as they were, by the Holy Spirit, went down to Seleucia, and from there sailed to Cyprus.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:5] On reaching Salamis, they began to tell the message of God in the Jewish Synagogues; and they had John with them as an assistant.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:6] After passing through the whole island, they reached Paphos, where they found an astrologer who pretended to be a prophet — a Jew by birth, whose name was Barjoshua.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:7] He was at the court of the Governor, Sergius Paulus, a man of intelligence, who sent for Barnabas and Saul and asked to be told God’s message.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:8] But Elymas, the astrologer (for that is the meaning of the word), opposed them, eager to divert the Governor’s attention from the faith.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:9] However, Saul (who is the same as Paul), full of the Holy Spirit, fixed his eyes on him and said:
[OEBcw - Acts 13:10] “You incarnation of deceit and all fraud! You son of the devil! You opponent of all that is good! Will you never cease to divert ‘the straight paths of the Lord’? Listen!
[OEBcw - Acts 13:11] The hand of the Lord is on you even now, and you will be blind for a time and unable to see the sun.” Immediately a mist and darkness fell on him, and he went feeling about for some one to guide him.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:12] When the Governor saw what had happened, he became a believer in Christ, being greatly impressed by the teaching about the Lord.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:13] After this, Paul and his companions set sail from Paphos and went to Perga in Pamphylia, where John left them and returned to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:14] The others went on from Perga and arrived at Antioch in Pisidia. There they went into the Synagogue on the Sabbath and took their seats.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:15] After the reading of the law and the prophets, the President of the Synagogue sent them this message — “Friends, if you have any helpful words to address to the people, now is the time to speak.”
[OEBcw - Acts 13:16] So Paul rose and, motioning with his hand, said: “People of Israel and all here who worship God, hear what I have to say.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:17] The God of this people Israel chose our ancestors, and during their stay in Egypt increased the prosperity of the people, and then ‘with uplifted arm brought them out from that land.’
[OEBcw - Acts 13:18] For about forty years ‘he bore with them in the desert’;
[OEBcw - Acts 13:19] then, after destroying seven heathen nations in Canaan, he allotted their land to this people —
[OEBcw - Acts 13:20] For about four hundred and fifty years. In later times he gave them Judges, of whom the prophet Samuel was the last.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:21] And, when they demanded a king, God gave them Saul the son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, who reigned for forty years.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:22] After removing him, he raised David to the throne, and bore this testimony to him — ‘In David, the son of Jesse, I have found a man after my own heart, who will carry out all my purposes.’
[OEBcw - Acts 13:23] It was from this man’s descendants that God, in accordance with his promise, gave Israel a Saviour — Jesus;
[OEBcw - Acts 13:24] John having first proclaimed, before the appearance of Jesus, a baptism on repentance for all the people of Israel.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:25] As John was drawing towards the end of his career, he said what do you suppose that I am? I am not the Christ. But there is “one coming” after me, whose ​sandal I am not worthy to untie.’
[OEBcw - Acts 13:26] Brothers and sisters, descendants of Abraham, and all those among you who worship God, it was to us that the message of this salvation was sent.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:27] The people of Jerusalem and their leaders, failing to recognise Jesus, and not understanding the utterances of the prophets that are read every Sabbath, fulfilled them by condemning him.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:28] They found no ground at all for putting him to death, and yet demanded his execution from Pilate;
[OEBcw - Acts 13:29] and, after carrying out everything written about him, they took Jesus down from the cross, and laid him in a tomb.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:30] But God raised him from the dead;
[OEBcw - Acts 13:31] and he appeared for many days to those who had gone up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, and who are now witnesses for him to the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:32] We also have good news to tell you, about the promise made to our ancestors —
[OEBcw - Acts 13:33] That our children have had this promise completely fulfilled to them by God, by his raising Jesus. That is just what is said in the second Psalm — ‘You are my Son; this day I have become your Father.’
[OEBcw - Acts 13:34] As to his raising Jesus from the dead, never again to return to corruption, this is what is said — ‘I will give to you the sacred promises made to David;’
[OEBcw - Acts 13:35] And, therefore, in another Psalm it is said — ‘You will not give up the Holy One to undergo corruption.’
[OEBcw - Acts 13:36] David, after obediently doing God’s will in his own time, ‘fell asleep and was laid by the side of his ancestors, and did undergo corruption;
[OEBcw - Acts 13:37] but Jesus, whom God raised from the dead, did not undergo corruption.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:38] I would, therefore, like you to know, friends, that through Jesus forgiveness of sins is being proclaimed to you,
[OEBcw - Acts 13:39] and that, in union with him, everyone who believes in him is absolved from every sin from which under the law of Moses you could not be absolved.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:40] Beware, therefore, that what is said in the prophets does not come true of you —
[OEBcw - Acts 13:41] ‘Look, you despisers, and wonder, and perish; For I am doing a deed in your days — A deed which, though told you in full, you will never believe’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 13:42] As Paul and Barnabas were leaving the Synagogue, the people begged for a repetition of this teaching on the next Sabbath.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:43] After the congregation had dispersed, many of the Jews, and of the converts who joined in their worship, followed Paul and Barnabas, who talked with them and urged them to continue to rely on the loving kindness of God.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:44] On the following Sabbath, almost all the city gathered to hear God’s message.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:45] But the sight of the crowds of people filled the minds of the Jews with jealousy, and they kept contradicting Paul’s statements in violent language.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:46] Then Paul and Barnabas spoke out fearlessly, and said: “It was necessary that the message of God should be told to you first; but, since you reject it and reckon yourselves not worthy of the eternal life — we turn to the Gentiles!
[OEBcw - Acts 13:47] For this is the Lord’s command to us — ‘I have destined you for a light to the Gentiles, A means of salvation to the ends of the earth’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 13:48] On hearing this, the Gentiles were glad and extolled God’s message; and all those who had been enrolled for eternal life became believers in Christ;
[OEBcw - Acts 13:49] and the Lord’s message was carried throughout that district.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:50] But the Jews incited the women of high social standing who worshiped with them, and the leading men of the town, and started a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and drove them out of their neighbourhood.
[OEBcw - Acts 13:51] They, however, shook the dust off their feet in protest,
[OEBcw - Acts 13:52] and went to Iconium, leaving the disciples full of joy and of the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Acts 14 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 14:1] The same thing occurred in Iconium, where Paul and Barnabas went into the Jewish Synagogue, and spoke in such a way that a great number of both Jews and Greeks believed in Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:2] But the Jews who refused to believe stirred up the Gentiles, and poisoned their minds against the Lord's followers.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:3] Therefore Paul and Barnabas spent a long time there, and spoke out fearlessly, relying on the Lord, who confirmed the message of his love by permitting signs and wonders to take place at their hands.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:4] But the townspeople were divided, some siding with the Jews, some with the apostles;
[OEBcw - Acts 14:5] and, when there was an attempt on the part of both Gentiles and Jews, with their leaders, to resort to violence and to stone them,
[OEBcw - Acts 14:6] the apostles heard of it, and took refuge in Lystra and Derbe, towns in Lycaonia, and in the district round,
[OEBcw - Acts 14:7] and there they continued to tell the good news.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:8] In the streets of Lystra there used to sit a man who had no power in his feet; he had been lame from his birth, and had never walked.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:9] This man was listening to Paul speaking, when Paul, fixing his eyes on him, and seeing that he had the faith to be healed,
[OEBcw - Acts 14:10] said loudly: “Stand upright on your feet.” The man leaped up, and began walking about,
[OEBcw - Acts 14:11] and the crowd, seeing what Paul had done, called out in the Lycaonian language: “The Gods have come down to us in human form.”
[OEBcw - Acts 14:12] So they called Barnabas ‘Zeus,’ and Paul ‘Hermes,’ because he took the lead in speaking;
[OEBcw - Acts 14:13] and the priest of Zeus-beyond-the-Walls, accompanied by the crowd, brought bullocks and garlands to the gates, with the intention of offering sacrifices.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:14] But, when the apostles Barnabas and Paul heard of it, they tore their clothes and rushed out into the crowd. “Friends, why are you doing this?” they shouted.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:15] “We are only people like yourselves, and we have come with the good news that you should turn away from these follies to a living God, ‘who made the heavens, the earth, the sea, and everything that is in them.’
[OEBcw - Acts 14:16] In bygone times he permitted all the nations to go their own ways.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:17] Yet he has not failed to give you, in the good he does, some revelation of himself — sending you from heaven rain and fruitful seasons, and gladdening your hearts with plenty and good cheer.”
[OEBcw - Acts 14:18] Even with this appeal they could hardly restrain the people from offering sacrifice to them.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:19] Presently, however, there came some Jews from Antioch, and Iconium who, after they had won over the people, stoned Paul, and dragged him out of the town, thinking him to be dead.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:20] But, when the disciples had gathered round him, he got up and went back into the town; the next day he went with Barnabas to Derbe.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:21] After telling the good news throughout that town, and making a number of converts, they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch,
[OEBcw - Acts 14:22] reassuring the minds of the disciples, urging them to remain true to the faith, and showing that it is only through many troubles that we can enter the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:23] They also appointed officers for them in every church, and, after prayer and fasting, commended them to the Lord in whom they had learned to believe.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:24] Paul and Barnabas then went through Pisidia, and came into Pamphylia,
[OEBcw - Acts 14:25] and, after telling the message at Perga, went down to Attaleia.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:26] From there they sailed to Antioch — the place where they had been committed to the gracious care of God for the work which they had now finished.
[OEBcw - Acts 14:27] After their arrival, they gathered the church together, and gave an account of all that God had helped them to do, and especially how he had opened to the Gentiles the door of faith;
[OEBcw - Acts 14:28] and at Antioch they stayed with the disciples for a considerable time.
[OEBcw - Acts 15 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 15:1] But certain persons came down from Judea, and began to teach the Lord's followers that, unless they were circumcised, in accordance with the custom required by Moses, they could not be saved.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:2] This gave rise to a serious dispute, and much discussion, between Paul and Barnabas and these people, and it was therefore settled that Paul and Barnabas and others of their number should go up to Jerusalem, to consult the apostles and officers of the church about the matter under discussion.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:3] The church, therefore, sent them on their journey, and they made their way through Phoenicia and Samaria, telling the story of the conversion of the Gentiles, to the great joy of all the followers.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:4] On their arrival at Jerusalem, they were welcomed by the church, as well as by the apostles and the officers, and gave an account of all that God had helped them to do.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:5] Some of the Pharisees’ party, however, who had become believers in Christ, came forward and declared that they were bound to circumcise converts and to direct them to observe the law of Moses.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:6] The apostles and the officers of the church held a meeting to consider this question.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:7] After much discussion, Peter rose and said: “You, my friends, know well that long ago God singled me out — that through my lips the Gentiles should hear the message of the good news, and become believers in Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:8] Now God, who reads all hearts, declared his acceptance of the Gentiles, by giving them the Holy Spirit, just as he did to us.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:9] He made no distinction between them and us, when he purified their hearts by their faith.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:10] Why, then, do you now provoke God, by putting on the necks of these disciples a yoke which neither our ancestors nor we were able to bear?
[OEBcw - Acts 15:11] No, it is through the loving kindness of the Lord Jesus that we, just as they do, believe that we have been saved.”
[OEBcw - Acts 15:12] Every voice in the assembly was hushed, as they listened to Barnabas and Paul, while they gave an account of all the signs and wonders which God had shown among the Gentiles through them.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:13] After they had finished speaking, James addressed the Council. “Friends,” he began, “hear what I have to say.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:14] Simon has described the manner in which God first visited the Gentiles, in order to take from among them a people to bear his name.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:15] And that is in harmony with the words of the prophets, where they say —
[OEBcw - Acts 15:16] ‘“After this I will return; And I will rebuild the house of David which has fallen — Its ​ruins I will rebuild, And will set it up once more;
[OEBcw - Acts 15:17] That so the rest of mankind may earnestly seek the Lord — Even all the Gentiles on whom my name has been bestowed.”
[OEBcw - Acts 15:18] Says the Lord, as he does these things, foreknown from of old.’
[OEBcw - Acts 15:19] In my judgment, therefore, we should not add to the difficulties of those Gentiles who are turning to God,
[OEBcw - Acts 15:20] but we should write to them to abstain from food that has been polluted by being sacrificed to idols, from impurity, from eating the flesh of strangled animals, and from blood.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:21] For in every town, for generations past, there have been those who preach Moses, read as he is in the Synagogues every Sabbath.”
[OEBcw - Acts 15:22] It was then decided by the apostles and the officers, with the assent of the whole church, to choose some of their number, and send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas. Those chosen were Judas (called Barsabas) and Silas, who were leaders among the community.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:23] They were bearers of the following letter — ‘The apostles, and the followers who are the officers of the church, send their greetings to the followers of the Lord of Gentile birth in Antioch, Syria, and Cilicia.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:24] As we had heard that some of our number had upset you by their assertions, and unsettled your minds — without instructions from us —
[OEBcw - Acts 15:25] We met and decided to choose certain men and send them to you with our dear friends Barnabas and Paul,
[OEBcw - Acts 15:26] who have risked their lives for the name of our Lord, Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:27] We are accordingly sending Judas and Silas, and they will tell you by word of mouth what we are now writing.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:28] We have, therefore, decided, under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, to lay no further burden on you beyond these necessary conditions —
[OEBcw - Acts 15:29] That you abstain from food offered to idols, from blood, from eating the flesh of strangled animals, and from impurity. If you guard yourselves against such things, it will be well with you. Farewell.’
[OEBcw - Acts 15:30] So the bearers of this letter were sent on their way, and went down to Antioch. There they called a meeting of all the followers,
[OEBcw - Acts 15:31] and delivered the letter, the reading of which caused great rejoicing by its encouraging contents.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:32] Judas and Silas, who were themselves prophets, further encouraged the them by many an address, and strengthened their faith.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:33] After some stay, they were dismissed with kind farewells from the followers, and returned to those who had sent them.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:34] 
[OEBcw - Acts 15:35] Paul and Barnabas, however, remained in Antioch, where they taught and, with the help of many others, told the good news of the Lord’s message.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:36] Some time after this, Paul said to Barnabas: “Let us go back and visit the Lord's followers in every town in which we have told the Lord’s message, and see how they are prospering.”
[OEBcw - Acts 15:37] Barnabas wished to take with them John, whose other name was Mark;
[OEBcw - Acts 15:38] but Paul felt that they ought not to take with them the man who had deserted them in Pamphylia, and had not gone on with them to their work.
[OEBcw - Acts 15:39] This caused such unpleasant feeling between them that they parted ways, Barnabas taking Mark and sailing for Cyprus,
[OEBcw - Acts 15:40] while Paul chose Silas for his companion and, after he had been committed by the followers to the gracious care of the Lord,
[OEBcw - Acts 15:41] started on his journey and went through Syria and Cilicia, strengthening the churches in the faith.
[OEBcw - Acts 16 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 16:1] Among other places Paul went to Derbe and Lystra. At the latter place they found a disciple, named Timothy, whose mother was a Jewess who had become a believer in Christ, while his father was a Greek,
[OEBcw - Acts 16:2] and who was well spoken of by the followers of the Lord in Lystra and Iconium.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:3] Wishing to take this man with him on his journey, Paul caused him to be circumcised out of consideration for the Jews in that neighbourhood, for they all knew that his father had been a Greek.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:4] As they traveled from town to town, they gave the followers the decisions which had been reached by the apostles and officers of the church at Jerusalem, for them to observe.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:5] So the churches grew stronger in the faith, and increased in numbers from day to day.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:6] They next went through the Phrygian district of Galatia, but were restrained by the Holy Spirit from delivering the message in Roman Asia.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:7] When they reached the borders of Mysia, they attempted to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not permit them.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:8] Passing through Mysia, they went down to Troas;
[OEBcw - Acts 16:9] and there one night Paul saw a vision. A Macedonian was standing and appealing to him — ‘Come over to Macedonia and help us.’
[OEBcw - Acts 16:10] So, immediately after Paul had seen the vision, we looked for an opportunity to cross over to Macedonia, concluding that God had summoned us to tell the good news to the people there.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:11] Accordingly we set sail from Troas, and ran before the wind to Samothrace, reaching Neapolis the next day.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:12] From there we made our way to Philippi, which is the principal city of that part of Macedonia, and also a Roman Settlement. In that city we spent several days.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:13] On the Sabbath we went outside the gate to the riverside, where we supposed there would be a place of prayer; and we sat down and talked to the women who were gathered there.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:14] Among them was a woman, named Lydia, belonging to Thyatira, a dealer in purple cloth, who was accustomed to join in the worship of God. The Lord touched this woman’s heart, so that she gave attention to the message delivered by Paul,
[OEBcw - Acts 16:15] and, when she and her household had been baptized, she urged us to become her guests. “Since you have shown your conviction,” she said, “that I really am a believer in the Lord, come and stay in my house.” And she insisted on our doing so.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:16] One day, as we were on our way to the place of prayer, we were met by a girl possessed by a divining spirit, who made large profits for her masters by fortune-telling.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:17] This girl followed Paul and the rest of us, calling: “These men are servants of the most high God, and they are bringing you news of a way to salvation.”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:18] She had been doing this for several days, when Paul, much vexed, turned and said to the spirit within her: “In the name of Jesus Christ I command you to leave her.” That very moment the spirit left her.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:19] When her masters saw that there was no hope of further profit from her, they seized Paul and Silas, dragged them into the public square to the authorities,
[OEBcw - Acts 16:20] and took them before the Magistrates. “These men are causing a great disturbance in our town,” they complained;
[OEBcw - Acts 16:21] “They are Jews, and they are teaching customs which it is not right for us, as Romans, to sanction or adopt.”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:22] The mob rose as one person against them, and the Magistrates stripped them of their clothing and ordered them to be beaten with rods.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:23] After beating them severely, the Magistrates put them in prison, with orders to the jailer to keep them in safe custody.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:24] On receiving so strict an order, the Governor put them into the inner cell, and secured their feet in the stocks.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:25] About midnight, while Paul and Silas were praying and singing hymns to God, and while the prisoners were listening to them,
[OEBcw - Acts 16:26] suddenly there was an earthquake of such violence that the jail was shaken to its foundations; all the doors flew open, and all the prisoners’ chains were loosened.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:27] Roused from his sleep, and seeing the prison doors open, the Governor drew his sword intending to kill himself, in the belief that the prisoners had escaped.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:28] But Paul called our loudly: “Do not harm yourself; we are all here.”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:29] Calling for a light, the Governor rushed in, and flung himself trembling at the feet of Paul and Silas.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:30] Then he led them out, and said: “What must I do to be saved?”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:31] “Believe in Jesus, our Lord,” they replied, “and you will be saved, you and your household too.”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:32] Then they spoke to him of God’s message, and to all his household as well.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:33] And that very hour of the night he took them and washed their wounds, and he himself and everyone belonging to him were baptized without delay.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:34] Afterwards he took them up to his house and set before them something to eat, rejoicing that he, with all his household, had come to believe in God.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:35] In the morning the Magistrates sent the police with an order for the men to be discharged.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:36] The jailer told Paul of his instructions. “The Magistrates have sent an order for your discharge,” he said, “so you had better leave the place at once and go quietly away.”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:37] But Paul’s answer to them was: “They have flogged us in public without trial, though we are Roman citizens, and they have put us in prison, and now they are for sending us out secretly! No, indeed! Let them come and take us out themselves.”
[OEBcw - Acts 16:38] The police reported his words to the Magistrates, who, on hearing that Paul and Silas were Roman citizens, were alarmed,
[OEBcw - Acts 16:39] and went to the prison, and did their best to conciliate them. Then they took them out, and begged them to leave the city.
[OEBcw - Acts 16:40] When Paul and Silas left the prison, they went to Lydia’s house, and, after they had seen the Lord's followers, and encouraged them, they left the place.
[OEBcw - Acts 17 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 17:1] After passing through Amphipolis and Apollonia, Paul and Silas came to Thessalonica. Here the Jews had a Synagogue;
[OEBcw - Acts 17:2] and, following his usual custom, Paul joined them, and for three Sabbaths addressed them, drawing his arguments from the scriptures.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:3] He laid before them and explained that the Christ must undergo suffering and rise from the dead; and “It is this man,” he declared, “who is the Christ — this Jesus about whom I am telling you.”
[OEBcw - Acts 17:4] Some of the people were convinced, and threw in their lot with Paul and Silas, as did also a large body of Greeks who were accustomed to join in the Jewish services, and a great number of leading women.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:5] But the Jewish leaders, becoming jealous, engaged some worthless fellows from the streets, and, getting a mob together, kept the city in an uproar. They attacked Jason’s house, with the intention of bringing Paul and Silas before the Popular Assembly;
[OEBcw - Acts 17:6] and, not finding them there, they proceeded to drag Jason and some of the Lord's followers before the city magistrates, shouting out: “These men, who have turned the world upside down, have now come here,
[OEBcw - Acts 17:7] and have been harboured by Jason! They say that some one else is king — a man called Jesus!”
[OEBcw - Acts 17:8] On hearing this, the people and the city magistrates were much concerned;
[OEBcw - Acts 17:9] and, before letting them go, they took bail from Jason and the others.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:10] That very night the followers sent Paul and Silas off to Beroea; and on reaching that place, they went to the Jewish Synagogue.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:11] These Jews of Beroea were better disposed than those in Thessalonica, for they welcomed the message with great readiness, and daily examined the scriptures to see if what was said was true.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:12] As a consequence, many of them became believers in Christ, besides a considerable number of Greek women of position, and of men also.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:13] But, when the Jewish leaders in Thessalonica found out that God’s message had been delivered by Paul at Beroea, they came there too, exciting and disturbing the minds of the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:14] The followers immediately arranged for Paul to go away to the coast, but both Silas and Timothy stayed behind in Beroea.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:15] The friends who escorted Paul took him as far as Athens, and, after receiving a message for Silas and Timothy to join him as quickly as possible, they started on their return.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:16] While Paul was waiting for them at Athens, his heart was stirred at seeing the whole city full of idols.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:17] So he argued in the Synagogue with the Jews and with those who joined in their worship, as well as daily in the public Square with those who happened to be there.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:18] Among others, some Epicurean and Stoic Philosophers joined issue with him. Some asked “What is this prater wanting to make out?”, while others said “He seems to be a preacher of foreign Deities.” (This was because he was telling the good news about Jesus and the resurrection).
[OEBcw - Acts 17:19] So they laid hold of him and took him to the Court of Areopagus. “May we hear,” they asked, “what new teaching this is which you are giving?
[OEBcw - Acts 17:20] For you are bringing some strange things to our notice, and we should like to know what they mean.”
[OEBcw - Acts 17:21] (All Athenians and the foreigners staying in the city found no time for anything else but telling, or listening to, the last new thing.)
[OEBcw - Acts 17:22] So Paul took his stand in the middle of the Court, and said — “People of Athens, on every hand I see signs of your being very devout.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:23] For as I was going about, looking at your sacred shrines, I came upon an altar with this inscription — ‘To an Unknown God.’ What, therefore, you worship in ignorance, that I am now proclaiming to you.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:24] The God who made the world and all things that are in it — ​he, Lord as he is of heaven and Earth, does not live in temples made by hands,
[OEBcw - Acts 17:25] nor yet do human hands minister to his wants, as though he needed anything, since he himself gives, to all, life, and breath, and all things.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:26] He made all races of the earth’s surface — fixing a time for their rise and fall, and the limits of their settlements —
[OEBcw - Acts 17:27] That they might search for God, if by any means they might feel their way to him and find him. And yet he is not really far from any one of us;
[OEBcw - Acts 17:28] for in him we live and move and are. To use the words of some of your own poets — ‘His offspring, too, are we.’
[OEBcw - Acts 17:29] Therefore, as the offspring of God, we must not think that the Deity has any resemblance to anything made of gold, or silver, or stone — a work of human art and imagination.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:30] True, God looked with indulgence on the days of people’s ignorance, but now he is announcing to everyone everywhere the need for repentance,
[OEBcw - Acts 17:31] because he has fixed a day on which he intends to ‘judge the world with justice,’ by a man whom he has appointed — and of this he has given all people a pledge by raising this man from the dead.”
[OEBcw - Acts 17:32] On hearing of a resurrection of the dead, some began jeering, but others said that they wanted to hear what he had to say about that another time.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:33] And so Paul left the Court.
[OEBcw - Acts 17:34] There were, however, some people who joined him, and became believers in Christ. Among them were Dionysius, a member of the Court of Areopagus, a woman named Damaris, and several others.
[OEBcw - Acts 18 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 18:1] On leaving Athens, Paul next went to Corinth.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:2] There he met a Jew of the name of Aquila, from Pontus, who, with his wife Priscilla, had lately come from Italy, in consequence of the order which had been issued by the Emperor Claudius for all Jews to leave Rome. Paul paid them a visit,
[OEBcw - Acts 18:3] and, since their trade was the same as his, he stayed and worked with them — their trade was tent-making.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:4] Every Sabbath Paul gave addresses in the Synagogue, trying to convince both Jews and Greeks.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:5] But, when Silas and Timothy had come down from Macedonia, Paul devoted himself entirely to delivering the message, earnestly maintaining before the Jews that Jesus was the Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:6] However, as they set themselves against him and became abusive, Paul shook his clothes in protest and said to them: “Your blood be on your own heads. My conscience is clear. From this time forward I will go to the Gentiles.”
[OEBcw - Acts 18:7] So he left, and went to the house of a certain Titius Justus, who had been accustomed to join in the worship of God, and whose house was next door to the Synagogue.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:8] Crispus, the President of the Synagogue, came to believe in the Lord, and so did all his household; and many of the Corinthians, as they listened to Paul, became believers in Christ and were baptized.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:9] One night the Lord said to Paul, in a vision: “Have no fear, but continue to speak, and refuse to be silenced;
[OEBcw - Acts 18:10] ​for I am with you, and no one will do you harm, for I have many people in this city.”
[OEBcw - Acts 18:11] So he settled there for a year and a half, and taught God’s message among the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:12] While Gallio was governor of Greece, some of the Jewish leaders made a combined attack on Paul, and brought him before the Governor’s Bench,
[OEBcw - Acts 18:13] charging him with persuading people to worship God in a way forbidden by the law.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:14] Just as Paul was on the point of speaking, Gallio said to them: “If this were a case of misdemeanour or some serious crime, there would be some reason for my listening patiently to you;
[OEBcw - Acts 18:15] but, since it is a dispute about words, and names, and your own law, you must see to it yourselves. I do not choose to be a judge in such matters.”
[OEBcw - Acts 18:16] Saying this, he drove them back from the Bench.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:17] Then they all set on Sosthenes, the President of the Synagogue, and beat him in front of the Bench, but Gallio did not trouble himself about any of these things.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:18] Paul remained there some time after this, and then took leave of the followers, and sailed to Syria with Priscilla and Aquila, but not before his head had been shaved at Cenchreae, because he was under a vow.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:19] They put into Ephesus, and there Paul, leaving his companions, went into the Synagogue and addressed the Jews.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:20] When they asked him to prolong his stay, he declined, saying however,
[OEBcw - Acts 18:21] as he took his leave, “I will come back again to you, please God,” and then set sail from Ephesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:22] On reaching Caesarea, he went up to Jerusalem and exchanged greetings with the church, and then went down to Antioch.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:23] After making some stay in Antioch, he set out on a tour through the Phrygian district of Galatia, strengthening the faith of all the disciples as he went.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:24] Meanwhile there had come to Ephesus an Alexandrian Jew, named Apollos, an eloquent man, who was well-versed in the scriptures.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:25] He had been well-instructed in the cause of the Lord, and with burning zeal he spoke of, and taught carefully, the facts about Jesus, though he knew of no baptism but John’s.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:26] This man began to speak out fearlessly in the Synagogue; and when Priscilla and Aquila heard him, they took him home and explained the cause of God to him more carefully still.
[OEBcw - Acts 18:27] When he wanted to cross to Greece, the followers furthered his plans, and wrote to the disciples there to welcome him. On his arrival he proved of great assistance to those who had, through the loving kindness of God, become believers in Christ,
[OEBcw - Acts 18:28] for he vigorously confuted the Jews, publicly proving by the scriptures that Jesus was the Christ.
[OEBcw - Acts 19 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 19:1] While Apollos was at Corinth, Paul passed through the inland districts of Roman Asia, and went to Ephesus. There he found some disciples, of whom he asked:
[OEBcw - Acts 19:2] “Did you, when you became believers in Christ, receive the Holy Spirit?” “No,” they answered, “we did not even hear that there was a Holy Spirit.”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:3] “What then was your baptism?” Paul asked.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:4] “John’s baptism was a baptism on repentance,” rejoined Paul, “and John told the people (speaking of the ‘one coming; after him) that they should believe in him — that is in Jesus.”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:5] On hearing this, they were baptized into the faith of the Lord Jesus,
[OEBcw - Acts 19:6] and, after Paul had placed his hands on them, the Holy Spirit descended on them, and they began to speak with ‘tongues’ and to preach.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:7] There were about twelve of them in all.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:8] Paul went to the Synagogue there, and for three months spoke out fearlessly, giving addresses and trying to convince his hearers, about the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:9] Some of them, however, hardened their hears and refused to believe, denouncing the cause before the people. So Paul left them and withdrew his disciples, and gave daily addresses in the lecture-hall of Tyrannus.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:10] This went on for two years, so that all who lived in Roman Asia, Jews and Greeks alike, heard the Lord’s message.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:11] God did miracles of no ordinary kind by Paul’s hands;
[OEBcw - Acts 19:12] so that people would carry home to the sick handkerchiefs or aprons that had touched his body, and their diseases would leave them and the wicked spirits go out of them.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:13] An attempt was made by some itinerant Jews, who were exorcists, to use the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had wicked spirits in them. “I order you,” they would say, “by the Jesus, whom Paul preaches.”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:14] The seven sons of Sceva, a Jewish chief priest, were doing this;
[OEBcw - Acts 19:15] but the wicked spirit answered them: “Jesus I acknowledge, and Paul I know, but you — who are you?”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:16] Then the man, in whom this wicked spirit was, sprang on them, mastered both of them, and so completely overpowered them, that they fled out of the house, stripped of their clothes, and wounded.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:17] This incident came to the knowledge of all the Jews and Greeks living at Ephesus; they were all awe-struck, and the name of the Lord Jesus was held in the highest honour.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:18] Many, too, of those who had become believers in Christ came with a full confession of their practices;
[OEBcw - Acts 19:19] while a number of people, who had practiced magic, collected their books and burnt them publicly; and on reckoning up the price of these, they found it amounted to fifty thousand silver coins.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:20] So irresistibly did the Lord’s message spread and prevail.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:21] Sometime after these events Paul resolved to go through Macedonia and Greece, and then make his way to Jerusalem. “And after I have been there,” he said, “I must visit Rome also.”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:22] So he sent to Macedonia two of his helpers, Timothy and Erastus, while he himself stayed for some time longer in Roman Asia.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:23] Just about that time a great disturbance arose about the cause.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:24] A silversmith named Demetrius, who made silver models of the shrine of Artemis, and so gave a great deal of work to the artisans,
[OEBcw - Acts 19:25] got these men together, as well as the workmen engaged in similar occupations, and said: “Men, you know that our prosperity depends on this work,
[OEBcw - Acts 19:26] and you see and hear that not only at Ephesus, but in almost the whole of Roman Asia, this Paul has convinced and won over great numbers of people, by his assertion that those Gods which are made by hands are not Gods at all.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:27] So that not only is this business of ours likely to fall into discredit, but there is the further danger that the Temple of the great Goddess Artemis will be thought nothing of, and that she herself will be deprived of her splendour — though all Roman Asia and the whole world worship her.”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:28] When they heard this, the men were greatly enraged, and began shouting — “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:29] The commotion spread through the whole city, and the people rushed together into the amphitheater, dragging with them Gaius and Aristarchus, two Macedonians who were Paul’s traveling companions.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:30] Paul wished to go into the amphitheater and face the people, but the disciples would not let him,
[OEBcw - Acts 19:31] while some of the chief religious officials of the province, who were friendly to him, sent repeated entreaties to him not to trust himself inside.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:32] Meanwhile some were shouting one thing and some another, for the Assembly was all in confusion, most of those present not even knowing why they had met.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:33] But some of the crowd prompted Alexander, whom several of the Jewish leaders had pushed to the front, and he waved his hand to show that he wanted to speak in their defence to the people.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:34] However, when they recognised him as a Jew, one cry broke from them all, and they continued shouting for two hours — “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:35] When the Recorder had succeeded in quieting the crowd, he said: “People of Ephesus, who is there, I ask you, who needs to be told that this city of Ephesus is the Warden of the Temple of the great Artemis, and of the statue which fell down from Zeus?
[OEBcw - Acts 19:36] As these are undeniable facts, you ought to keep calm and do nothing rash;
[OEBcw - Acts 19:37] for you have brought these men here, though they are neither robbers of Temples nor blasphemers of our Goddess.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:38] If, however, Demetrius and the artisans who are acting with him have a charge to make against anyone, there are court days and there are Magistrates; let both parties take legal proceedings.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:39] But if you want anything more, it will have to be settled in the regular Assembly.
[OEBcw - Acts 19:40] For I tell you that we are in danger of being proceeded against for today’s riot, there being nothing to account for it; and in that case we will be at a loss to give any reason for this disorderly gathering.”
[OEBcw - Acts 19:41] With these words he dismissed the Assembly.
[OEBcw - Acts 20 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 20:1] When the uproar had ceased, Paul sent for the disciples, and, with encouraging words, bade them goodbye, and started on his journey to Macedonia.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:2] After going through those districts and speaking many encouraging words to the disciples, he went into Greece, where he stayed three months.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:3] He was about to sail to Syria, when he learned that a plot had been laid against him by several of the Jewish leaders; so he decided to return by way of Macedonia.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:4] He was accompanied by Sopater the son of Pyrrhus, of Beroea, Aristarchus and Secundus from Thessalonica, Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy, as well as by Tychicus and Trophimus of Roman Asia.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:5] These people went to Troas and waited for us there;
[OEBcw - Acts 20:6] while we ourselves sailed from Philippi after the Passover, and joined them five days later at Troas, where we stayed for a week.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:7] On the first day of the week, when we had met for the breaking of bread, Paul, who was intending to leave the next day, began to address those who were present, and prolonged his address until midnight.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:8] There were a good many lamps in the upstairs room, where we had met;
[OEBcw - Acts 20:9] and a young man named Eutychus, sitting at the window, was gradually overcome with great drowsiness, as Paul continued his address. At last, quite overpowered by his drowsiness, he fell from the third story to the ground, and was picked up for dead.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:10] But Paul went down, threw himself on him, and put his arms round him. “Do not be alarmed,” he said, “he is still alive.”
[OEBcw - Acts 20:11] Then he went upstairs; and, after breaking and partaking of the bread, he talked with them at great length until daybreak, and then left.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:12] Meanwhile they had taken the lad away alive, and were greatly comforted.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:13] We started first, went on board ship, and sailed for Assos, intending to take Paul on board there. This was by his own arrangement, as he intended to go by land himself.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:14] So, when he met us at Assos, we took him on board and went on to Mitylene.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:15] The day after we had sailed from there, we arrived off Chios, touched at Samos the following day, and the next day reached Miletus;
[OEBcw - Acts 20:16] for Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so as to avoid spending much time in Roman Asia. He was making haste to reach Jerusalem, if possible, by the Festival at the close of the Harvest.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:17] From Miletus, however, he sent to Ephesus and invited the officers of the church to meet him;
[OEBcw - Acts 20:18] and, when they came, he said to them: “You know well the life that I always led among you from the very first day that I set foot in Roman Asia,
[OEBcw - Acts 20:19] serving the Lord, as I did, in all humility, amid the tears and trials which fell to my lot through the plots of some of the Jewish leaders.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:20] I never shrank from telling you anything that could be helpful to you, or from teaching you both in public and in private.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:21] I earnestly pointed both Jews and Greeks to the repentance that leads to God, and to faith in Jesus, our Lord.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:22] And now, under spiritual constraint, I am here on my way to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
[OEBcw - Acts 20:23] except that in town after town the Holy Spirit plainly declares to me that imprisonment and troubles await me.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:24] But I count my life of no value to myself, if only I may complete the course marked out for me, and the task that was allotted me by the Lord Jesus — which was to declare the good news of the love of God.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:25] And now, I tell you, I know that none of you will ever see my face again — you among whom I have gone about proclaiming the kingdom.
