[OEBcw - Acts 20:26] Therefore I declare to you this day, that my conscience is clear in regard to the fate of any of you,
[OEBcw - Acts 20:27] for I have not shrunk from announcing the whole purpose of God regarding you.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:28] Be watchful over yourselves, and over the whole flock, of which the Holy Spirit has placed you in charge, to shepherd the church of God, which he won for himself at the cost of his life.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:29] I know that, after my departure, merciless wolves will get in among you, who will not spare the flock;
[OEBcw - Acts 20:30] and from among yourselves, too, people will arise, who will teach perversions of truth, so as to draw away the disciples after them.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:31] Therefore, be on your guard, remembering how for three years, night and day, I never ceased, even with tears, to warn each one of you.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:32] And now I commend you to the Lord and to the message of his love — a message which has the power to build up your characters, and to give you your place among all those who have become Christ’s people.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:33] I have never coveted anyone’s gold or silver or clothing.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:34] You, yourselves, know that these hands of mine provided not only for my own wants, but for my companions also.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:35] I left nothing undone to show you that, labouring as I laboured, you ought to help the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said himself — ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’”
[OEBcw - Acts 20:36] When Paul had finished speaking, he knelt down and prayed with them all.
[OEBcw - Acts 20:37] All were in tears; and throwing their arms round Paul’s neck, they kissed him again and again,
[OEBcw - Acts 20:38] grieving most of all over what he had said — that they would never see his face again. Then they escorted him to the ship.
[OEBcw - Acts 21 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 21:1] When we had torn ourselves away and had set sail, we ran before the wind to Cos; the next day we came to Rhodes, and from there to Patara,
[OEBcw - Acts 21:2] where we found a ship crossing to Phoenicia, and went on board and set sail.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:3] After sighting Cyprus and leaving it on the left, we sailed to Syria, and put into Tyre, where the ship was to discharge her cargo.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:4] There we found the disciples and stayed a week with them. Speaking under the influence of the Spirit, they warned Paul not to set foot in Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:5] However, when we had come to the end of our visit, we went on our way, all the disciples with their wives and children escorting us out of the city. We knelt down on the beach, and prayed,
[OEBcw - Acts 21:6] and then said goodbye to one another; after which we went on board, and they returned home.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:7] After we had made the run from Tyre, we landed at Ptolemais, and exchanged greetings with the followers there, and spent a day with them.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:8] The next day we left, and reached Caesarea, where we went to the house of Philip, the missionary, who was one of ‘the Seven,’ and stayed with him.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:9] He had four unmarried daughters, who had the gift of prophecy.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:10] During our visit, which lasted several days, a prophet, named Agabus, came down from Judea.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:11] He came to see us, and, taking Paul’s girdle, and binding his own feet and hands with it, said: “This is what the Holy Spirit says — ‘The man to whom this girdle belongs will be bound like this by the religious authorities in Jerusalem, and they will give him up to the Gentiles’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:12] When we heard that, we and the people of the place began to entreat Paul not to go up to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:13] It was then that Paul made the reply: “Why are you weeping and breaking my heart like this? For my part, I am ready not only to be bound, but even to suffer death at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:14] So, as he would not be persuaded, we said no more to him, only adding — “The Lord’s will be done.”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:15] At the end of our visit, we made our preparations, and started on our way up to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:16] Some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us, and brought Mnason with them, a Cypriot disciple of long standing, with whom we were to stay.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:17] On our arrival at Jerusalem, the followers of the Lord there gave us a hearty welcome;
[OEBcw - Acts 21:18] and the next day Paul went with us to see James, and all the officers of the church were present.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:19] After greeting them, Paul related in detail all that God had done among the Gentiles through his efforts;
[OEBcw - Acts 21:20] and, when they had heard it, they began praising God, and said to Paul: “You see, brother, that those of our people who have become believers in Christ may be numbered by tens of thousands, and they are all naturally earnest in upholding the Jewish law.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:21] Now they have heard it said about you, that you teach all of our people in foreign countries to forsake Moses, for you tell them not to circumcise their children or even to observe Jewish customs.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:22] Well now, as they are certain to hear of your arrival, do what we are going to suggest.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:23] We have four men here, who have of their own accord put themselves under a vow.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:24] Join these men, share their purification, and bear their expenses, so that they may shave their heads; and then all will see that there is no truth in what they have been told about you, but that, on the contrary, you yourself rule your life in obedience to the Jewish law.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:25] As to the Gentiles who have become believers in Christ, we have sent our decision that they should avoid food offered to idols, and blood, and the flesh of strangled animals, and impurity.”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:26] Paul joined the men, and the next day shared their purification, and went into the Temple, and gave notice of the expiration of the period of purification when the usual offering should have been made on behalf of each of them.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:27] But, just as the seven days were drawing to a close, some of the Jewish people from Roman Asia caught sight of Paul in the Temple, and caused great excitement among all the people present, by seizing Paul and shouting:
[OEBcw - Acts 21:28] “People of Israel! Help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against our people, our law, and this place; and, what is more, he has actually brought Greeks into the Temple and defiled this sacred place.”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:29] (For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian in Paul’s company in the city, and were under the belief that Paul had taken him into the Temple.)
[OEBcw - Acts 21:30] The whole city was stirred, and the people quickly collected, seized Paul, and dragged him out of the Temple, when the doors were immediately shut.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:31] They were bent on killing him, when it was reported to the officer commanding the garrison, that all Jerusalem was in commotion.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:32] He instantly got together some officers and soldiers, and charged down on the crowd, who, when they saw the commanding officer and his soldiers, stopped beating Paul.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:33] Then he went up to Paul, arrested him, ordered him to be doubly chained, and proceeded to inquire who he was, and what he had been doing.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:34] Some of the crowd said one thing, and some another; and, as he could get no definite reply because of the uproar, he ordered Paul to be taken into the barracks.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:35] When Paul reached the steps, he was actually being carried by the soldiers, owing to the violence of the mob;
[OEBcw - Acts 21:36] for the people were following in a mass, shouting out: “Kill him!”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:37] Just as he was about to be taken into the Fort, Paul said to the commanding officer: “May I speak to you?” “Do you know Greek?” asked the commanding officer.
[OEBcw - Acts 21:38] “Are not you, then, the Egyptian who some time ago raised an insurrection and led the four thousand Bandits out into the wilderness?”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:39] “No,” said Paul, “I am a Jew of Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of a city of some note; and I beg you to give me permission to speak to the people.”
[OEBcw - Acts 21:40] The commanding officer gave his permission, and Paul, standing on the steps, made signs with his hand to the people, and, when comparative silence had been obtained, he said to them in Hebrew:
[OEBcw - Acts 22 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 22:1] “Brothers and fathers, listen to the defence which I am about to make.”
[OEBcw - Acts 22:2] When they heard that he was speaking to them in Hebrew, they were still more quiet; and Paul went on:
[OEBcw - Acts 22:3] “I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, but I was brought up in this city under the teaching of Gamaliel, and educated in accordance with the strict system of our ancestral law. I was as zealous in God’s service as any of you who are here today.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:4] In my persecution of this cause I did not stop even at the taking of life. I put in chains, and imprisoned, men and women alike —
[OEBcw - Acts 22:5] And to that the high priest himself and all the Council can testify. For I had letters of introduction from them to our fellow Jews at Damascus, and I was on my way to that place, to bring those whom I might find there prisoners to Jerusalem for punishment.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:6] While I was still on my way, just as I was getting close to Damascus, about midday, suddenly there flashed from the heavens a great light all round me.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:7] I fell to the ground, and heard a voice saying to me ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
[OEBcw - Acts 22:8] ‘Who are you, Lord?’ I replied. Then the voice said ‘I am Jesus of Nazareth whom you are persecuting.’
[OEBcw - Acts 22:9] The men with me saw the light, but did not hear the speaker’s voice.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:10] Then I said ‘What am I to do, Lord?’ ‘Get up and go into Damascus,’ The Lord said to me, ‘and there you will be told all that you have been appointed to do.’
[OEBcw - Acts 22:11] In consequence of that dazzling light I could not see, but my companions held me by the hand, until I reached Damascus.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:12] There a man named Ananias, a strict observer of our law, well spoken of by all the Jewish inhabitants, came to see me.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:13] Standing close to me, he said ‘Saul, my brother, recover your sight.’ And then and there I recovered my sight and looked up at him.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:14] Then he said ‘The God of our ancestors has appointed you to learn his will, and to see the righteous one, and to hear words from his lips;
[OEBcw - Acts 22:15] for you will be a witness for him to all the world of what you have just seen and heard.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:16] And now why wait any longer: Be baptized at once, wash away your sins, and invoke his name.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:17] After my return to Jerusalem, while I was praying one day in the Temple, I fell into a trance,
[OEBcw - Acts 22:18] and saw Jesus saying to me ‘Make haste and leave Jerusalem at once, because they will not accept your testimony about me.’
[OEBcw - Acts 22:19] ‘Lord,’ I answered, ‘these people know that I used to imprison and scourge, in Synagogue after Synagogue, those who believed in you;
[OEBcw - Acts 22:20] and, when the blood of your martyr, Stephen, was being shed, I was myself standing by, approving of his death, and took charge of the clothes of those who were murdering him.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:21] But Jesus said to me ‘Go; for I will send you to the Gentiles far away’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 22:22] Up to this point the people had been listening to Paul, but at these words they called out: “Kill him! A fellow like this ought not to have been allowed to live!”
[OEBcw - Acts 22:23] As they were shouting, tearing off their clothes, and throwing dust in the air,
[OEBcw - Acts 22:24] the commanding officer ordered Paul to be taken into the Fort, and directed that he should be examined under the lash so that he might find out the reason for their outcry against him.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:25] But just as they had tied him up to be scourged, Paul said to the captain standing near: “Is it legal for you to scourge a Roman citizen, unconvicted?”
[OEBcw - Acts 22:26] On hearing this, the captain went and reported it to the commanding officer. “Do you know what you are doing?” he said. “This man is a Roman citizen.”
[OEBcw - Acts 22:27] So the commanding officer went up to Paul and said: “Tell me, are you a Roman citizen?” “Yes,” replied Paul.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:28] “I had to pay a heavy price for my position as citizen,” said the officer. “I am one by birth,” rejoined Paul.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:29] The men who were to have examined Paul immediately drew back, and the officer, finding that Paul was a Roman citizen, was alarmed at having put him in chains.
[OEBcw - Acts 22:30] On the next day the commanding officer, wishing to find out the real reason why Paul was denounced by the Jewish leaders, had his chains taken off, and directed the chief priests and the whole of the High Council to assemble, and then took Paul down and brought him before them.
[OEBcw - Acts 23 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 23:1] Paul fixed his eyes on the Council, and began: “Brothers, for my part, I have always ordered my life before God, with a clear conscience, up to this very day.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:2] At this, the high priest Ananias ordered the men standing near to strike him on the mouth;
[OEBcw - Acts 23:3] Paul turned to him and said: “God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! Are you sitting there to try me in accordance with law, and yet, in defiance of law, order me to be struck?”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:4] The people standing near said to Paul: “Do you know that you are insulting God’s high priest?”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:5] “I did not know, brothers, that it was the high priest,” said Paul, “for scripture says — ‘Of the Ruler of your people you should speak no ill’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:6] Noticing that some of those present were Sadducees and others Pharisees, Paul called out in the Council: “Brothers, I am a Pharisee and a son of Pharisees. It is on the question of hope for the dead and of their resurrection that I am on my trial.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:7] As soon as he said this, a dispute arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees; and there was a sharp division of opinion among those present.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:8] (For Sadducees say there is no such thing as a resurrection, and that there is neither angel nor spirit, while Pharisees believe in both.)
[OEBcw - Acts 23:9] So a great uproar ensued, and some of the Teaches of the law belonging to the Pharisees’ party stood up and hotly protested: “We find nothing whatever wrong in this man. Suppose a spirit did speak to him, or an angel...”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:10] The dispute was becoming so violent, that the commanding officer, fearing that Paul would be torn in pieces between them, ordered the Guard to go down and rescue him from them, and take him into the Fort.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:11] That night the Lord came and stood by Paul, and said: “Courage! You have borne witness for me in Jerusalem and you must bear witness in Rome also.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:12] In the morning some Jewish men combined together, and took an oath that they would not eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:13] There were more than forty in the plot;
[OEBcw - Acts 23:14] and they went to the chief priests and the councillors, and said: “We have taken a solemn oath not to touch food until we have killed Paul.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:15] So we want you now, with the consent of the Council, to suggest to the commanding officer that he should bring Paul down before you, as though you intended to go more fully into his case; but, before he comes here, we will be ready to make away with him.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:16] However, the son of Paul’s sister, hearing of the plot, went to the Fort, and on being admitted, told Paul about it.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:17] Paul called one of the Captains of the garrison and asked him to take the lad to the commanding officer, as he had something to tell him.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:18] The captain went with the lad to the commanding officer, and said: “The prisoner Paul called me and asked me to bring this lad to you, as he has something to tell you.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:19] The commanding officer took the lad by the hand, and, stepping aside, asked what it was he had to tell him.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:20] “Some men have agreed,” answered the lad, “to ask you to bring Paul down before the Council tomorrow, on the plea of your making further inquiry into his case.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:21] But do not let them persuade you, for more than forty of them are lying in wait for him, who have taken an oath that they will not eat or drink, until they have made away with him; and they are at this very moment in readiness, counting on your promise.”
[OEBcw - Acts 23:22] The commanding officer then dismissed the lad, cautioning him not to mention to anybody that he had given him that information.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:23] Then he called two Captains, and ordered them to have two hundred soldiers ready to go to Caesarea, as well as seventy troopers and two hundred lancers, by nine o’clock that night,
[OEBcw - Acts 23:24] and to have horses ready for Paul to ride, so that they might take him safely to Felix, the Governor.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:25] He also wrote a letter along these lines:
[OEBcw - Acts 23:26] ‘Claudius Lysias sends his compliments to His Excellency Felix the Governor.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:27] The man whom I send with this had been seized by some Jews, and was on the point of being killed by them, when I came upon them with the force under my command, and rescued him, as I learned that he was a Roman citizen.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:28] Wanting to know exactly the ground of the charges they made against him, I brought him before their Council,
[OEBcw - Acts 23:29] when I found that their charges were connected with questions of their own law, and that there was nothing alleged involving either death or imprisonment.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:30] Having, however, information of a plot against the man, which was about to be put into execution, I am sending him to you at once, and I have also directed his accusers to prosecute him before you.’
[OEBcw - Acts 23:31] The soldiers, in accordance with their orders, took charge of Paul and conducted him by night to Antipatris;
[OEBcw - Acts 23:32] and on the next day, leaving the troopers to go on with him, they returned to the Fort.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:33] On arriving at Caesarea, the troopers delivered the letter to the Governor, and brought Paul before him.
[OEBcw - Acts 23:34] As soon as Felix had read the letter, he enquired to what province Paul belonged, and, learning that he came from Cilicia, he said:
[OEBcw - Acts 23:35] “I will hear all you have to say as soon as your accusers have arrived.” And he ordered Paul to be kept under guard in Herod’s Government house.
[OEBcw - Acts 24 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 24:1] Five days afterwards the high priest Ananias came down with some of the councillors and a barrister named Tertullus. They laid an information with the Governor against Paul;
[OEBcw - Acts 24:2] and, when the hearing came on, Tertullus began his speech for the prosecution.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:3] “We owe it to your Excellency,” he said, “that we are enjoying profound peace, and we owe it to your foresight that this nation is constantly securing reforms — advantages which we very gratefully accept at all times and places.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:4] But — not to be tedious — I beg you, with your accustomed fairness, to listen to a brief statement of our case.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:5] We have found this man a public pest; he is one who stirs up disputes among our people all the world over, and is a ringleader of the Nazarene heretics.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:6] He even attempted to desecrate the Temple itself, but we caught him;
[OEBcw - Acts 24:7] 
[OEBcw - Acts 24:8] and you will be able, by examining him on all these points, to satisfy yourself as to the charges which we are bringing against him.”
[OEBcw - Acts 24:9] The Jewish crowd also joined in the attack and bore out his statements.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:10] On a sign from the Governor, Paul made this reply: “Knowing, as I do, for how many years you have acted as judge to this nation, it is with confidence that I undertake my own defence.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:11] For you can easily verify that it is not more than twelve days ago that I went up to worship at Jerusalem,
[OEBcw - Acts 24:12] where my prosecutors never found me holding discussions with anyone, or causing a crowd to collect — either in the Temple, or in the Synagogues, or about the city;
[OEBcw - Acts 24:13] and they cannot establish the charges which they are now making against me.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:14] This, however, I do acknowledge to you, that it is as a believer in the cause which they call heretical, that I worship the God of my ancestors. At the same time, I believe everything that is in accordance with the law and that is written in the prophets;
[OEBcw - Acts 24:15] and I have a hope that rests in God — a hope which they also cherish — that there will one day be a resurrection of good and bad alike.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:16] This being so, I strive at all times to keep my conscience clear before both God and people.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:17] After some years’ absence I had come to bring charitable gifts to my nation, and to make offerings;
[OEBcw - Acts 24:18] and it was while engaged in this that they found me in the Temple, after completing a period of purification, but not with any crowd or disorder.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:19] There were, however, some Jews from Roman Asia who ought to have been here before you, and to have made any charge that they may have against me —
[OEBcw - Acts 24:20] Or else let my opponents here say what they found wrong in me when I was before the Council,
[OEBcw - Acts 24:21] except as to the one sentence that I shouted out as I stood among them — ‘It is about the resurrection of the dead that I am on my trial before you today’.”
[OEBcw - Acts 24:22] Felix, however, adjourned the case — though he had a fairly accurate knowledge of all that concerned the cause — with the promise: “When Lysias, the commanding officer, comes down, I will give my decision in your case.”
[OEBcw - Acts 24:23] So he gave orders to the captain in charge of Paul to keep him in custody, but to relax the regulations, and not to prevent any of his personal friends from attending to his wants.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:24] Some days later Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was herself a Jewess, and, sending for Paul, listened to what he had to say about faith in Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:25] But, while Paul was speaking at length about righteousness, self-control, and the coming judgment, Felix became terrified, and interrupted him — “Go for the present, but, when I find an opportunity, I will send for you again.”
[OEBcw - Acts 24:26] He was hoping, too, for a bribe from Paul, and so he used to send for him frequently and talk with him.
[OEBcw - Acts 24:27] But, after the lapse of two years, Felix was succeeded by Porcius Festus; and, wishing to gain popularity with the Jewish leaders, he left Paul a prisoner.
[OEBcw - Acts 25 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 25:1] Three days after Festus had arrived in his province, he left Caesarea and went up to Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:2] There the chief priests and the leading men among the Jews laid an information before him against Paul,
[OEBcw - Acts 25:3] and asked a favour of him, to Paul’s injury — to have Paul brought to Jerusalem. All the while they were plotting to make away with him on the road.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:4] But Festus answered that Paul was in prison at Caesarea, and that he himself would be leaving for that place shortly.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:5] “So let the influential men among you,” he said, “go down with me, and if there is anything amiss in the man, charge him formally with it.”
[OEBcw - Acts 25:6] After staying among them some eight or ten days, Festus went down to Caesarea. The next day he took his seat on the Bench, and ordered Paul to be brought before him.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:7] On Paul’s appearance, the Jewish leaders who had come down from Jerusalem surrounded him, and made many serious charges, which they failed to establish.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:8] Paul’s answer to the charge was — ‘I have not committed any offence against the Jewish law, or the Temple, or the Emperor.’
[OEBcw - Acts 25:9] But, as Festus wished to gain popularity with the Jews, he interrupted Paul with the question: “Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem and be tried on these charges before me there?”
[OEBcw - Acts 25:10] “No,” replied Paul, “I am standing at the Emperor’s court, where I ought to be tried. I have not wronged the Jews, as you yourself are well aware.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:11] If, however, I am breaking the law and have committed any offence deserving death, I do not ask to escape the penalty; but, if there is nothing in the accusations of these people, no one has the power to give me up to them. I appeal to the Emperor.”
[OEBcw - Acts 25:12] Festus, after conferring with his Council, answered: “You have appealed to the Emperor; to the Emperor you will go.”
[OEBcw - Acts 25:13] Some days later King Agrippa and Bernice came down to Caesarea, and paid a visit of congratulation to Festus;
[OEBcw - Acts 25:14] and, as they were staying there for several days, Festus laid Paul’s case before the king. “There is a man here,” he said, “left a prisoner by Felix,
[OEBcw - Acts 25:15] about whom, when I came to Jerusalem, the Jewish chief priest and the councillors laid an information, demanding judgment against him.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:16] My answer to them was, that it was not the practice of Romans to give up anyone to their accusers until the accused had met them face to face, and had also had an opportunity of answering the charges brought against them.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:17] So they met here, and without loss of time I took my seat on the Bench the very next day, and ordered the man to be brought before me.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:18] But, when his accusers came forward, they brought no charge of wrong-doing such as I had expected;
[OEBcw - Acts 25:19] but I found that there were certain questions in dispute between them about their own religion, and about some dead man called Jesus, whom Paul declared to be alive.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:20] And, as I was at a loss how to enquire into questions of this kind, I asked Paul if he were willing to go up to Jerusalem, and be put on trial there.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:21] Paul, however, appealed to have his case reserved for the consideration of his August Majesty, so I ordered him to be detained in custody, until I could send him to the Emperor.”
[OEBcw - Acts 25:22] “I should like to hear this man myself,” Agrippa said to Festus. “You will hear him tomorrow,” Festus answered.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:23] So the next day, when Agrippa and Bernice had come in full state and had entered the Audience Chamber, with the superior officers and the principal people of the city, by the order of Festus Paul was brought before them.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:24] Then Festus said: “King Agrippa, and all here present, you see before you the man about whom the whole Jewish people have applied to me, both at Jerusalem and here, loudly asserting that he ought not to be allowed to live.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:25] I found, however, that he had not done anything deserving death; so, as he had himself appealed to his August Majesty, I decided to send him.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:26] But I have nothing definite to write about him to my Imperial Master; and for that reason I have brought him before you all, and especially before you, King Agrippa, that, after examining him, I may have something to write.
[OEBcw - Acts 25:27] For it seems to me absurd to send a prisoner, without at the same time stating the charges made against him.”
[OEBcw - Acts 26 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 26:1] Turning to Paul, Agrippa said: “You are at liberty to speak for yourself.” Then Paul stretched out his hand and began his defence.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:2] “I have been congratulating myself, King Agrippa,” he said, “that it is before you that I have to make my defence today, with regard to all the charges brought against me by my own people,
[OEBcw - Acts 26:3] especially as you are so well-versed in all the customs and questions of the Jewish world. I beg you therefore to give me a patient hearing.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:4] My life, then, from youth upwards, was passed, from the very first, among my own nation, and in Jerusalem, and is within the knowledge of all Jews;
[OEBcw - Acts 26:5] and they have always known — if they choose to give evidence — that, in accordance with the very strictest form of our religion, I lived a true Pharisee.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:6] Even now, it is because of my hope in the promise given by God to our ancestors that I stand here on my trial —
[OEBcw - Acts 26:7] A promise which our twelve tribes, by earnest service night and day, hope to see fulfilled. It is for this hope, your Majesty, that I am accused — and by Jews themselves!
[OEBcw - Acts 26:8] Why do you all hold it incredible that God should raise the dead?
[OEBcw - Acts 26:9] I myself, it is true, once thought it my duty to oppose in every way the name of Jesus of Nazareth;
[OEBcw - Acts 26:10] and I actually did so at Jerusalem. Acting on the authority of the chief priests, I myself threw many of the people of Christ into prison, and, when it was proposed to put them to death, I gave my vote for it.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:11] Time after time, in every Synagogue, I tried by punishments to force them to blaspheme. So frantic was I against them, that I pursued them even to towns beyond our borders.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:12] It was while I was traveling to Damascus on an errand of this kind, entrusted with full powers by the chief priests,
[OEBcw - Acts 26:13] that at midday, your Majesty, I saw right in my path, coming from the heavens, a light brighter than the glare of the sun, which shone all round me and those traveling with me.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:14] We all fell to the ground, and then I heard a voice saying to me in Hebrew — ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? By kicking against the goad you are punishing yourself.’
[OEBcw - Acts 26:15] ‘Who are you, Lord?’ I asked. And the Lord said: “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting;
[OEBcw - Acts 26:16] ​but get up and stand upright; for I have appeared to you in order to appoint you a servant and a witness of those revelations of me which you have already had, and of those in which I will yet appear to you,
[OEBcw - Acts 26:17] ​since I am choosing you out from your own people and from the Gentiles, to whom I now send you,
[OEBcw - Acts 26:18] ​to open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God; so that they may receive pardon for their sins, and a place among those who have become God’s people, by faith in me.’
[OEBcw - Acts 26:19] After that, King Agrippa, I did not fail to obey the heavenly vision;
[OEBcw - Acts 26:20] on the contrary, first to those at Damascus and Jerusalem, and then through the whole of Judea, and to the Gentiles as well, I began to preach repentance and conversion to God, and a life befitting that repentance.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:21] This is why some men seized me in the Temple, and made attempts on my life.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:22] However I have received help from God to this very day, and so stand here, and bear my testimony to high and low alike — without adding a word to what the prophets, as well as Moses, declared should happen —
[OEBcw - Acts 26:23] That the Christ must suffer, and that, by rising from the dead, he was destined to be the first to bring news of light, not only to our nation, but also to the Gentiles.”
[OEBcw - Acts 26:24] While Paul was making this defence, Festus called out loudly: “You are mad, Paul; your great learning is driving you mad.”
[OEBcw - Acts 26:25] “I am not mad, your Excellency,” he replied; “on the contrary, the statements that I am making are true and sober.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:26] Indeed, the king knows about these matters, so I speak before him without constraint. I am sure that there is nothing whatever of what I have been telling him that has escaped his attention; for all this has not been done in a corner.
[OEBcw - Acts 26:27] King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you do.”
[OEBcw - Acts 26:28] But Agrippa said to Paul: “You are soon trying to make a Christian of me!”
[OEBcw - Acts 26:29] “Whether it is soon or late,” answered Paul, “I pray to God that not only you, but all who are listening to me, might today become just what I am myself — except for these chains!”
[OEBcw - Acts 26:30] Then the king rose, with the Governor and Bernice and those who had been sitting with them,
[OEBcw - Acts 26:31] and, after retiring, discussed the case among themselves. “There is nothing,” they said, “deserving death or imprisonment in this man’s conduct”;
[OEBcw - Acts 26:32] and, speaking to Festus, Agrippa added: “The man might have been discharged, if he had not appealed to the Emperor.”
[OEBcw - Acts 27 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 27:1] As it was decided that we were to sail to Italy, Paul and some other prisoners were put in charge of a captain of the Augustan Guard, named Julius.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:2] We went on board a ship from Adramyttium, which was on the point of sailing to the ports along the coast of Roman Asia, and put to sea. Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, went with us.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:3] The next day we put in to Sidon, where Julius treated Paul in a friendly manner, and allowed him to go to see his friends and receive their hospitality.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:4] Putting to sea again, we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the wind was against us;
[OEBcw - Acts 27:5] and, after crossing the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we reached Myra in Lycia.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:6] There the Roman officer found an Alexandrian ship on her way to Italy, and put us on board of her.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:7] For several days our progress was slow, and it was only with difficulty that we arrived off Cnidus. As the wind was still unfavourable when we came off Cape Salmone, we sailed under the lee of Crete,
[OEBcw - Acts 27:8] and with difficulty, by keeping close in shore, we reached a place called ‘Fair Havens,’ near which was the town of Lasea.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:9] This had taken a considerable time, and sailing was already dangerous, for the Fast was already over; and so Paul gave this warning.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:10] “My friends,” he said, “I see that this voyage will be attended with injury and much damage, not only to the cargo and the ship, but to our own lives also.”
[OEBcw - Acts 27:11] The Roman officer, however, was more influenced by the captain and the owner than by what was said by Paul.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:12] And, as the harbour was not a suitable one to winter in, the majority were in favour of continuing the voyage, in hope of being able to reach Phoenix, and winter there. Phoenix was a Cretan harbour, open to the north-east and south-east.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:13] So, when a light wind sprang up from the south, thinking that they had found their opportunity, they weighed anchor and kept along the coast of Crete, close in shore.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:14] But shortly afterwards a hurricane came down on us off the land — a north-easter, as it is called.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:15] The ship was caught by it and was unable to keep her head to the wind, so we had to give way and let her drive before it.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:16] Running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we only just managed to secure the ship’s boat,
[OEBcw - Acts 27:17] and, after hoisting it on board, the men frapped the ship. But, afraid of being driven on to the Syrtis Sands, they lowered the yard, and then drifted.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:18] So violently were we tossed about by the storm, that the next day they began throwing the cargo overboard,
[OEBcw - Acts 27:19] and, on the following day, threw out the ship’s tackle with their own hands.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:20] As neither sun nor stars were visible for several days, and, as the gale still continued severe, all hope of our being saved was at last abandoned.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:21] It was then, when they had gone a long time without food, that Paul came forward, and said: “My friends, you should have listened to me, and not have sailed from Crete and so incurred this injury and damage.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:22] Yet, even as things are, I beg you not to lose courage, for there will not be a single life lost among you — only the ship.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:23] For last night an angel of the God to whom I belong, and whom I serve, stood by me, and said —
[OEBcw - Acts 27:24] ‘Have no fear, Paul; you must appear before the Emperor, and God himself has given you the lives of all your fellow voyagers.’
[OEBcw - Acts 27:25] Therefore, courage, my friends! For I believe God, that everything will happen exactly as I have been told.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:26] We will, however, have to be driven on some island.”
[OEBcw - Acts 27:27] It was now the fourteenth night of the storm, and we were drifting about in the Adriatic Sea, when, about midnight, the sailors began to suspect that they were drawing near land.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:28] So they took soundings, and found twenty fathoms of water. After waiting a little, they took soundings again, and found fifteen fathoms.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:29] Then, as they were afraid of our being driven on some rocky coast, they let go four anchors from the stern, and longed for daylight.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:30] The sailors wanted to leave the ship, and had lowered the boat, on pretence of running out anchors from the bows,
[OEBcw - Acts 27:31] when Paul said to the Roman officer and his men: “Unless the sailors remain on board, you cannot be saved.”
[OEBcw - Acts 27:32] So the soldiers cut the ropes which held the boat, and let her drift away.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:33] In the interval before daybreak Paul kept urging them all to take something to eat. “It is a fortnight today,” he said, “that, owing to your anxiety, you have gone without food, taking nothing.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:34] So I beg you to take something to eat; your safety depends on it, for not one of you will lose even a hair of his head.”
[OEBcw - Acts 27:35] With these words he took some bread, and, after saying the thanksgiving to God before them all, broke it in pieces, and began to eat;
[OEBcw - Acts 27:36] and the men all felt cheered and had something to eat themselves.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:37] There were about seventy-six of us on board, all told.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:38] After satisfying their hunger, they further lightened the ship by throwing the grain into the sea.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:39] When daylight came, they could not make out what land it was, but, observing a creek in which there was a beach, they consulted as to whether they could run the ship safely into it.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:40] Then they cast off, and abandoned the anchors, and at the same time unlashed the gear of the steering oars, hoisted the foresail to the wind, and made for the beach.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:41] They got, however, into a kind of channel, and there ran the ship aground. The bows stuck fast and could not be moved, while the stern began breaking up under the strain.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:42] The advice of the soldiers was that the prisoners should be killed, so that none of them could swim away and make their escape.
[OEBcw - Acts 27:43] But the Roman officer, anxious to save Paul, prevented their carrying out their intention, and ordered that those who could swim should be the first to jump into the sea and try to reach the shore;
[OEBcw - Acts 27:44] and that the rest should follow, some on planks, and others on different pieces of the ship. In these various ways everyone managed to get safely ashore.
[OEBcw - Acts 28 - start] 
[OEBcw - Acts 28:1] When we were all safe, we found that the island was called Malta.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:2] The island's people showed us marked kindness, for they lit a fire and took us all under shelter, because it had come on to rain and was cold.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:3] Paul had gathered a quantity of dry sticks and laid them on the fire, when a poisonous snake, driven out by the heat, fastened on his hand.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:4] When the islanders saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another: “Evidently this man is a murderer, for though he has been saved from the sea, Justice has not allowed him to live.”
[OEBcw - Acts 28:5] However, Paul shook the creature off into the fire and took no harm.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:6] The islanders were expecting inflammation to set in, or that he would suddenly fall dead; but, after waiting for a long time, and seeing that there was nothing amiss with him, they changed their minds and said that he was a God.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:7] In that neighbourhood there was an estate belonging to the Governor of the island, whose name was Publius. He took us up to his house, and for three days entertained us most courteously.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:8] It happened that the father of Publius was lying ill of fever and dysentery. So Paul went to see him; and, after praying, he placed his hands on him and cured him.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:9] After this, all the people in the island who had any illness came to Paul, and were cured.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:10] They also presented us with many gifts, and when we set sail they put supplies of necessaries on board.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:11] After three months, we set sail in a ship that had wintered in the island. She was an Alexandrian vessel, and had the Twin sons of Zeus for her figure-head.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:12] We put in at Syracuse and stayed there three days,
[OEBcw - Acts 28:13] and from there we worked to windward and so got to Rhegium. A day later a south wind sprang up and took us to Puteoli in two days.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:14] There we found some of the Lord's followers, and were urged to stay a week with them; after which we went on to Rome.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:15] The followers there had heard about us, and came out as far as the Market of Appius and the Three Taverns to meet us. At sight of them Paul thanked God and was much cheered.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:16] On our reaching Rome, Paul was allowed to live by himself, except for the soldier who was in charge of him.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:17] Three days after our arrival, Paul invited the leading Jews to meet him; and, when they came, he said: “Brothers, although I had done nothing hostile to the interests of our nation or to our ancestral customs, yet I was sent from Jerusalem as a prisoner, and handed over to the Romans.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:18] The Romans, when they had examined me, were ready to release me, because there was nothing in my conduct deserving death.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:19] But, as the Jewish leaders opposed my release, I was compelled to appeal to the Emperor — not, indeed, that I had any charge to make against my own nation.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:20] This, then, is my reason for urging you to come to see me and talk with me; because it is for the sake of the hope of Israel that I am here in chains.”
[OEBcw - Acts 28:21] “We,” was their reply, “have not had any letter about you from Judea, nor have any of our fellow Jews come and reported or said anything bad about you.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:22] But we will be glad to hear from you what your views are, for, with regard to this sect, we are well aware that it is spoken against on all sides.”
[OEBcw - Acts 28:23] They then fixed a day with him, and came to the place where he was staying, in even larger numbers, when Paul proceeded to lay the subject before them. He bore his testimony to the kingdom of God, and tried to convince them about Jesus, by arguments drawn from the law of Moses and from the prophets — speaking from morning until evening.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:24] Some were inclined to accept what he said; others, however, rejected it.
[OEBcw - Acts 28:25] So, as they disagreed among themselves, they began to disperse, Paul adding only — “True, indeed, was the declaration made by the Holy Spirit, through the prophet Isaiah to your ancestors —
[OEBcw - Acts 28:26] ‘Go to this nation and say — “You will hear with your ears without ever understanding, And, though you have eyes, you will see without ever perceiving.”
[OEBcw - Acts 28:27] For the mind of this nation has grown dense, And their ears are dull of hearing, Their eyes also have they closed; Otherwise some day they might see with their eyes, And with their ears they might hear, And in their mind they might understand, and might turn — And I might heal them.’
[OEBcw - Acts 28:28] Understand, then, that this salvation of God was sent for the Gentiles; and they will listen.”
[OEBcw - Acts 28:29] 
[OEBcw - Acts 28:30] For two whole years Paul stayed in a house which he rented for himself, welcoming all who came to see him,
[OEBcw - Acts 28:31] proclaiming the kingdom of God, and teaching about the Lord Jesus Christ, with perfect fearlessness, unmolested.
[OEBcw - Rom 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 1:1] To all in Rome who are dear to God and have been called to become Christ’s people, from Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, who has been called to become an apostle, and has been set apart to tell God’s good news.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:2] This good news God promised long ago through his prophets in the sacred scriptures,
[OEBcw - Rom 1:3] concerning his Son, Jesus Christ, our Lord; who, as to his human nature, was descended from David,
[OEBcw - Rom 1:4] but, as to the spirit of holiness within him, was miraculously designated Son of God by his resurrection from the dead.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:5] Through him we received the gift of the apostolic office, to win submission to the faith among all nations for the glory of his name.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:6] And among these nations are you — you who have been called to belong to Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:7] May God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you and give you peace.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:8] First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ about you all, because the report of your faith is spreading throughout the world.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:9] God, to whom I offer the worship of my soul as I tell the goodness of his Son, is my witness how constantly I mention you when I pray,
[OEBcw - Rom 1:10] asking that, if he be willing, I may some day at last find the way open to visit you.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:11] For I long to see you, in order to impart to you some spiritual gift and so give you fresh strength —
[OEBcw - Rom 1:12] or rather that both you and I may find encouragement in each other’s faith.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:13] I want you to know, my friends, that I have many times intended coming to see you — but until now I have been prevented — that I might find among you some fruit of my labours, as I have already among the other nations.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:14] I have a duty to both the Greek and the barbarian, to both the cultured and the ignorant.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:15] And so, for my part, I am ready to tell the good news to you also who are in Rome.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:16] For I am not ashamed of the good news; it is the power of God which brings salvation to everyone who believes in Christ, to the Jew first, but also to the Greek.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:17] For in it there is a revelation of the divine righteousness resulting from faith and leading on to faith; as scripture says — ‘Through faith the righteous will find life.’
[OEBcw - Rom 1:18] So, too, there is a revelation from heaven of the divine wrath against every form of ungodliness and wickedness on the part of those people who, by their wicked lives, are stifling the truth.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:19] This is so, because what can be known about God is plain to them; for God himself has made it plain.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:20] For ever since the creation of the universe God’s invisible attributes — his everlasting power and divinity — are to be seen and studied in his works, so that people have no excuse;
[OEBcw - Rom 1:21] because, although they learned to know God, yet they did not offer him as God either praise or thanksgiving. Their speculations about him proved futile, and their undiscerning minds were darkened.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:22] Professing to be wise, they showed themselves fools;
[OEBcw - Rom 1:23] and they transformed the glory of the immortal God into the likeness of mortal humans, and of birds, and beasts, and reptiles.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:24] Therefore God abandoned them to impurity, letting them follow the cravings of their hearts, until they dishonoured their own bodies;
[OEBcw - Rom 1:25] for they had substituted a lie for the truth about God, and had reverenced and worshiped created things more than the Creator, who is to be praised for ever. Amen.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:26] That, I say, is why God abandoned them to degrading passions. Even the women among them perverted the natural use of their bodies to the unnatural;
[OEBcw - Rom 1:27] while the men, disregarding that for which women were intended by nature, were consumed with passion for one another. Men indulged in vile practices with men, and incurred in their own persons the inevitable penalty for their perverseness.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:28] Then, as they would not keep God before their minds, God abandoned them to depraved thoughts, so that they did all kinds of shameful things.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:29] They revelled in every form of wickedness, evil, greed, vice. Their lives were full of envy, murder, quarrelling, treachery, malice.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:30] They became back-biters, slanderers, impious, insolent, boastful. They devised new sins. They disobeyed their parents.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:31] They were undiscerning, untrustworthy, without natural affection or pity.
[OEBcw - Rom 1:32] Well aware of God’s decree, that those who do such things deserve to die, not only are they guilty of them themselves, but they even applaud those who do them.
[OEBcw - Rom 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 2:1] Therefore you have nothing to say in your own defence, whoever you are who set yourself up as a judge. In judging others you condemn yourself, for you who set yourself up as a judge do the very same things.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:2] And we know that God’s judgment falls unerringly on those who do them.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:3] You who judge those that do such things and yet are yourself guilty of them — do you suppose that you of all people will escape God’s judgment?
[OEBcw - Rom 2:4] Or do you think lightly of his abundant kindness, patience, and forbearance, not realising that his kindness is meant to lead you to repentance?
[OEBcw - Rom 2:5] Hard-hearted and impenitent as you are, you are storing up for yourself wrath on the ‘day of wrath,’ when God’s justice as a judge will be revealed;
[OEBcw - Rom 2:6] for ‘he will give to everyone what their actions deserve.’
[OEBcw - Rom 2:7] To those who, by perseverance in doing good, aim at glory, honour, and all that is imperishable, he will give immortal life;
[OEBcw - Rom 2:8] while as to those who are factious, and disobedient to truth but obedient to evil, wrath and anger, distress and despair,
[OEBcw - Rom 2:9] will fall on every human being who persists in wrong-doing — on the Jew first, but also on the Greek.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:10] But there will be glory, honour, and peace for everyone who does right — for the Jew first, but also for the Greek,
[OEBcw - Rom 2:11] since God shows no partiality.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:12] All who, when they sin, are without law will also perish without law; while all who, when they sin, are under law, will be judged as being under law.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:13] It is not those who hear the words of a law that are righteous before God, but it is those who obey it that will be pronounced righteous.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:14] When Gentiles, who have no law, do instinctively what the law requires, they, though they have no law, are a law to themselves;
[OEBcw - Rom 2:15] for they show the demands of the law written on their hearts; their consciences corroborating it, while in their thoughts they argue either in self-accusation or, it may be, in self-defence —
[OEBcw - Rom 2:16] on the day when God passes judgment on people’s inmost lives, as the good news that I tell declares that he will do through Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:17] But, perhaps, you bear the name of ‘Jew,’ and are relying on law, and boast of belonging to God, and understand his will,
[OEBcw - Rom 2:18] and, having been carefully instructed from the law, have learned to appreciate the finer moral distinctions.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:19] Perhaps you are confident that you are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in the dark, an instructor of the unintelligent,
[OEBcw - Rom 2:20] and a teacher of the childish, because in the law you possess the outline of all knowledge and truth.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:21] Why, then, you teacher of others, do not you teach yourself? Do you preach against stealing, and yet steal?
[OEBcw - Rom 2:22] Do you forbid adultery, and yet commit adultery? Do you loathe idols, and yet plunder temples?
[OEBcw - Rom 2:23] Boasting, as you do, of your law, do you dishonour God by breaking the law?
[OEBcw - Rom 2:24] For, as scripture says — ‘The Gentiles insult God's name because of you’!
[OEBcw - Rom 2:25] Circumcision has its value, if you are obeying the law. But, if you are a breaker of the law, your circumcision is no better than uncircumcision.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:26] If, then, an uncircumcised man pays regard to the requirements of the law, will not he, although not circumcised, be regarded by God as if he were?
[OEBcw - Rom 2:27] Indeed, the person who, owing to his birth, remains uncircumcised, and yet scrupulously obeys the law, will condemn you, who, for all your written law and your circumcision, are yet a breaker of the law.
[OEBcw - Rom 2:28] For a man who is only a Jew outwardly is not a real Jew; nor is outward bodily circumcision real circumcision. The real Jew is the person who is a Jew in soul;
[OEBcw - Rom 2:29] and the real circumcision is the circumcision of the heart, a spiritual and not a literal thing. Such a person wins praise from God, though not from people.
[OEBcw - Rom 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 3:1] What is the advantage, then, of being a Jew? Or what is the good of circumcision?
[OEBcw - Rom 3:2] Great in every way. First of all, because the Jews were entrusted with God’s utterances.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:3] What follows then? Some, no doubt, showed a want of faith; but will their want of faith make God break faith? Heaven forbid!
[OEBcw - Rom 3:4] God must prove true, though everyone prove a liar! As scripture says of God — ‘That you may be pronounced righteous in what you say, and gain your cause when people would judge you.’
[OEBcw - Rom 3:5] But what if our wrong-doing makes God’s righteousness all the clearer? Will God be wrong in inflicting punishment? (I can but speak as a person.) Heaven forbid!
[OEBcw - Rom 3:6] Otherwise how can God judge the world?
[OEBcw - Rom 3:7] But, if my falsehood redounds to the glory of God, by making his truthfulness more apparent, why am I like others, still condemned as a sinner?
[OEBcw - Rom 3:8] Why should we not say — as some people slanderously assert that we do say — ‘Let us do evil that good may come’? The condemnation of such people is indeed just!
[OEBcw - Rom 3:9] What follows, then? Are we Jews in any way superior to others? Not at all. Our indictment against both Jews and Greeks was that all alike were in subjection to sin.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:10] As scripture says — ‘There is not even one who is righteous,
[OEBcw - Rom 3:11] not one who understands, not one who is searching for God!
[OEBcw - Rom 3:12] They have all gone astray; they have one and all become depraved; there is no one who is doing good — no, not one!’
[OEBcw - Rom 3:13] ‘Their throats are like opened graves; they deceive with their tongues.’ ‘The venom of snakes lies behind their lips,’
[OEBcw - Rom 3:14] ‘And their mouths are full of bitter curses.’
[OEBcw - Rom 3:15] ‘Swift are their feet to shed blood.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:16] Distress and trouble dog their steps,
[OEBcw - Rom 3:17] and the path of peace they do not know.’
[OEBcw - Rom 3:18] ‘The fear of God is not before their eyes.’
[OEBcw - Rom 3:19] Now we know that everything said in the law is addressed to those who are under its authority, in order that every mouth may be closed, and to bring the whole world under God's judgment.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:20] For ‘no human being will be pronounced righteous before God’ as the result of obedience to law; for it is law that shows what sin is.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:21] But now, quite apart from law, the divine righteousness stands revealed, and to it the law and the prophets bear witness —
[OEBcw - Rom 3:22] the divine righteousness which is bestowed, through faith in Jesus Christ, on all, without distinction, who believe in him.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:23] For all have sinned, and all fall short of God’s glorious ideal,
[OEBcw - Rom 3:24] but, in his loving kindness, are being freely pronounced righteous through the deliverance found in Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:25] For God set him before the world, to be, by the shedding of his blood, a means of reconciliation through faith. And this God did to prove his righteousness, and because, in his forbearance, he had passed over the sins that people had previously committed;
[OEBcw - Rom 3:26] as a proof, I repeat, at the present time, of his own righteousness, that he might be righteous in our eyes, and might pronounce righteous the person who takes their stand on faith in Jesus.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:27] What, then, becomes of our boasting? It is excluded. By what sort of law? A law requiring obedience? No, a law requiring faith.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:28] For we conclude that a person is pronounced righteous on the ground of faith, quite apart from obedience to law.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:29] Or can it be that God is the God only of the Jews? Is not he also the God of the Gentiles?
[OEBcw - Rom 3:30] Yes, of the Gentiles also, since there is only one God, and he will pronounce those who are circumcised righteous as the result of faith, and also those who are uncircumcised on their showing the same faith.
[OEBcw - Rom 3:31] Do we, then, use this faith to abolish law? Heaven forbid! No, we establish law.
[OEBcw - Rom 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 4:1] What then, it may be asked, are we to say about Abraham, the ancestor of our nation?
[OEBcw - Rom 4:2] If he was pronounced righteous as the result of obedience, then he has something to boast of. Yes, but not before God.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:3] For what are the words of scripture? ‘Abraham had faith in God, and his faith was regarded by God as righteousness.’
[OEBcw - Rom 4:4] Now wages are regarded as due to the person who works, not as a favour, but as a debt;
[OEBcw - Rom 4:5] while, as for the person who does not rely on their obedience, but has faith in him who can pronounce the godless righteous, their faith is regarded by God as righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:6] In precisely the same way David speaks of the blessing pronounced on the person who is regarded by God as righteous apart from actions —
[OEBcw - Rom 4:7] ‘Blessed are those whose wrong-doings have been forgiven and over whose sins a veil has been drawn!
[OEBcw - Rom 4:8] Blessed the man whom the Lord will never regard as sinful!’
[OEBcw - Rom 4:9] Is this blessing, then, pronounced on the circumcised only or on the uncircumcised as well? We say that — ‘Abraham’s faith was regarded by God as righteousness.’
[OEBcw - Rom 4:10] Under what circumstances, then, did this take place? After his circumcision or before it?
[OEBcw - Rom 4:11] Not after, but before. And it was as a sign of this that he received the rite of circumcision — to show the righteousness due to the faith of an uncircumcised man — in order that he might be the father of all who have faith in God even when uncircumcised, so that they also may be regarded by God as righteous;
[OEBcw - Rom 4:12] as well as father of the circumcised — to those who are not only circumcised, but who also follow our father Abraham in that faith which he had while still uncircumcised.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:13] For the promise that he should inherit the world did not come to Abraham or his descendants through law, but through the righteousness due to faith.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:14] If those who take their stand on law are to inherit the world, then faith is robbed of its meaning and the promise comes to nothing!
[OEBcw - Rom 4:15] Law entails punishment; but, where no law exists, no breach of it is possible.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:16] That is why everything is made to depend on faith: so that everything may be God’s gift, and in order that the fulfilment of the promise may be made certain for all Abraham’s descendants — not only for those who take their stand on the law, but also for those who take their stand on the faith of Abraham. (He is the Father of us all;
[OEBcw - Rom 4:17] as scripture says — ‘I have made you the Father of many nations.’) And this they do in the sight of that God in whom Abraham had faith, and who gives life to the dead, and speaks of what does not yet exist as if it did.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:18] With no ground for hope, Abraham, sustained by hope, put faith in God; in order that, in fulfilment of the words — ‘So many will your descendants be,’ he might become ‘the Father of many nations.’
[OEBcw - Rom 4:19] Though he was nearly a hundred years old, yet his faith did not fail him, even when he thought of his own body, then utterly worn out, and remembered that Sarah was past bearing children.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:20] He was not led by want of faith to doubt God’s promise.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:21] On the contrary, his faith gave him strength; and he praised God, in the firm conviction that what God has promised he is also able to carry out.
[OEBcw - Rom 4:22] And therefore his faith ‘was regarded as righteousness.’
[OEBcw - Rom 4:23] Now these words — ‘it was regarded as righteousness’ — were not written with reference to Abraham only;
[OEBcw - Rom 4:24] but also with reference to us. Our faith, too, will be regarded by God in the same light, if we have faith in him who raised Jesus, our Lord, from the dead;
[OEBcw - Rom 4:25] for Jesus ‘was given up to death to atone for our offences,’ and was raised to life that we might be pronounced righteous.
[OEBcw - Rom 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 5:1] Therefore, having been pronounced righteous as the result of faith, let us enjoy peace with God through Jesus Christ, our Lord.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:2] It is through him that, by reason of our faith, we have obtained admission to that place in God’s favour in which we not stand. So let us exult in our hope of attaining God’s glorious ideal.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:3] And not only that, but let us also exult in our troubles;
[OEBcw - Rom 5:4] for we know that trouble develops endurance, and endurance strength of character, and strength of character hope,
[OEBcw - Rom 5:5] and that ‘hope never disappoints.’ For the love of God has filled our hearts through the Holy Spirit which was given us;
[OEBcw - Rom 5:6] seeing that, while we were still powerless, Christ, in God’s good time, died on behalf of the godless.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:7] Even for an upright person scarcely anyone will die. For a really good person perhaps some one might even dare to die.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:8] But God puts his love for us beyond all doubt by the fact that Christ died on our behalf while we were still sinners.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:9] Much more, then, now that we have been pronounced righteous by virtue of the shedding of his blood, will we be saved through him from the wrath of God.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:10] For if, when we were God’s enemies, we were reconciled to him through the death of his Son, much more, now that we have become reconciled, will we be saved by virtue of Christ’s life.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:11] And not only that, but we exult in God, through Jesus Christ, our Lord, through whom we have now obtained this reconciliation.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:12] Therefore, just as sin came into the world through one man, and through sin came death; so, also, death spread to all humanity, because every person has sinned.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:13] Even before the time of the law there was sin in the world; but sin cannot be charged against someone where no law exists.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:14] Yet, from Adam to Moses, death reigned even over those whose sin was not a breach of a law, as Adam’s was. And Adam foreshadows the One to come.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:15] But there is a contrast between Adam’s offence and God’s gracious gift. For, if by reason of the offence of the one man the whole race died, far more were the loving kindness of God, and the gift given in the loving kindness of the one man, Jesus Christ, lavished on the whole race.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:16] There is a contrast, too, between the gift and the results of the one man’s sin. The judgment, which followed on the one man’s sin, resulted in condemnation, but God’s gracious gift, which followed on many offences, resulted in a decree of righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:17] For if, by reason of the offence of the one man, death reigned through that one man, far more will those, on whom God’s loving kindness and his gift of righteousness are lavished, find life, and reign through the one man, Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:18] Briefly then, just as a single offence resulted for all humanity in condemnation, so, too, a single decree of righteousness resulted for all humanity in that declaration of righteousness which brings life.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:19] For, as through the disobedience of the one man the whole race was rendered sinful, so, too, through the obedience of the one, the whole race will be rendered righteous.
[OEBcw - Rom 5:20] law was introduced in order that offences might be multiplied. But, where sins were multiplied, the loving kindness of God was lavished the more,
[OEBcw - Rom 5:21] in order than, just as sin had reigned in the realm of death, so, too, might Loving-kindness reign through righteousness, and result in eternal life, through Jesus Christ, our Lord.
[OEBcw - Rom 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 6:1] What are we to say, then? Are we to continue to sin, in order that God’s loving kindness may be multiplied?
[OEBcw - Rom 6:2] Heaven forbid! We became dead to sin, and how can we go on living in it?
[OEBcw - Rom 6:3] Or can it be that you do not know that all of us, who were baptized into union with Christ Jesus, in our baptism shared his death?
[OEBcw - Rom 6:4] Consequently, through sharing his death in our baptism, we were buried with him; that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by a manifestation of the Father’s power, so we also may live a new life.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:5] If we have become united with him by the act symbolic of his death, surely we will also become united with him by the act symbolic of his resurrection.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:6] We recognise the truth that our old self was crucified with Christ, in order that the body, the stronghold of sin, might be rendered powerless, so that we should no longer be slaves to sin.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:7] For the man who has so died has been pronounced righteous and released from sin.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:8] And our belief is, that, as we have shared Christ’s death, we will also share his life.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:9] We know, indeed, that Christ, having once risen from the dead, will not die again. Death has power over him no longer.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:10] For the death that he died was a death to sin, once and for all. But the life that he now lives, he lives for God.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:11] So let it be with you — regard yourselves as dead to sin, but as living for God, through union with Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:12] Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal bodies and compel you to obey its cravings.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:13] Do not offer any part of your bodies to sin, in the cause of unrighteousness, but once for all offer yourselves to God (as those who, though once dead, now have life), and devote every part of your bodies to the cause of righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:14] For sin will not lord it over you. You are living under the reign, not of law, but of love.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:15] What follows, then? Are we to sin because we are living under the reign of love and not of law? Heaven forbid!
[OEBcw - Rom 6:16] Surely you know that, when you offer yourselves as servants, to obey anyone, you are the servants of the person whom you obey, whether the service be a service sin which leads to death, or a service Duty which leads to righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:17] God be thanked that, though you were once servants of sin, yet you learned to give hearty obedience to that form of doctrine under which you were placed.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:18] Set free from the control of sin, you became servants to righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:19] I can but speak as people do because of the weakness of your earthly nature. Once you offered every part of your bodies to the service of impurity, and of wickedness, which leads to further wickedness. Now, in the same way, offer them to the service of righteousness, which leads to holiness.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:20] While you were still servants of sin, you were free as regards righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:21] But what were the fruits that you reaped from those things of which you are now ashamed? For the end of such things is death.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:22] But now that you have been set free from the control of sin, and have become servants to God, the fruit that you reap is an ever increasing holiness, and the end eternal life.
[OEBcw - Rom 6:23] The wages of sin are death, but the gift of God is eternal life, through union with Christ Jesus, our Lord.
[OEBcw - Rom 7 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 7:1] Surely, friends, you know (for I am speaking to people who know what law means) that law has power over a person only as long as they lives.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:2] For example, by law a married woman is bound to her husband while he is living; but, if her husband dies, she is set free from the law that bound her to him.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:3] If, then, during her husband’s lifetime, she unites herself to another man, she will be called an adulteress; but, if her husband dies, the law has no further hold on her, nor, if she unites herself to another man, is she an adulteress.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:4] And so with you, my friends; as far as the law was concerned, you underwent death in the crucified body of the Christ, so that you might be united to another, to him who was raised from the dead, in order that our lives might bear fruit for God.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:5] When we were living merely earthly lives, our sinful passions, aroused by the law, were active in every part of our bodies, with the result that our lives bore fruit for death.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:6] But now we are set free from the law, because we are dead to that which once kept us under restraint; and so we serve under new, spiritual conditions, and not under old, written regulations.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:7] What are we to say, then? That law and sin are the same thing? Heaven forbid! On the contrary, I should not have learned what sin is, had not it been for law. If the law did not say ‘You must not covet,’ I should not know what it is to covet.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:8] But sin took advantage of the Commandment to arouse in me every form of covetousness, for where there is no consciousness of law sin shows no sign of life.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:9] There was a time when I myself, unconscious of law, was alive; but when the Commandment was brought home to me, sin sprang into life, while I died!
[OEBcw - Rom 7:10] The ​Commandment that should have meant life I found to result in death!
[OEBcw - Rom 7:11] sin took advantage of the Commandment to deceive me, and used it to bring about my death.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:12] And so the law is holy, and each Commandment is also holy, and just, and good.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:13] Did, then, a thing, which in itself was good, involve death in my case? Heaven forbid! It was sin that involved death; so that, by its use of what I regarded as good to bring about my death, its true nature might appear; and in this way the Commandment showed how intensely sinful sin is.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:14] We know that the law is spiritual, but I am earthly — sold into slavery to sin.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:15] I do not understand my own actions. For I am so far from habitually doing what I want to do, that I find myself doing the ​thing that I hate.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:16] But when I do what I want not to do, I am admitting that the law is right.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:17] This being so, the action is no longer my own, but is done by the sin which is within me.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:18] I know that there is nothing good in me — I mean in my earthly nature. For, although it is easy for me to want to do right, to act rightly is not easy.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:19] I fail to do the good thing that I want to do, but the bad thing that I want not to do — that I habitually do.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:20] But, when I do the ​thing that I want not to do, the action is no longer my own, but is done by the sin which is within me.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:21] This, then, is the law that I find — when I want to do right, wrong presents itself!
[OEBcw - Rom 7:22] At heart I delight in the law of God;
[OEBcw - Rom 7:23] but throughout my body I see a different law, one which is in conflict with the law accepted by my reason, and which endeavours to make me a prisoner to that law of sin which exists throughout my body.
[OEBcw - Rom 7:24] Miserable man that I am! Who will deliver me from the body that is bringing me to this death?
[OEBcw - Rom 7:25] Thank God, there is deliverance through Jesus Christ, our Lord! Well then, for myself, with my reason I serve the law of God, but with my earthly nature the law of sin.
[OEBcw - Rom 8 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 8:1] There is, therefore, now no condemnation for those who are in union with Christ Jesus;
[OEBcw - Rom 8:2] for through your union with Christ Jesus, the law of the life-giving Spirit has set you free from the law of sin and death.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:3] What law could not do, in so far as our earthly nature weakened its action, God did, by sending his own Son, with a nature resembling our sinful nature, to atone for sin. He condemned sin in that earthly nature,
[OEBcw - Rom 8:4] so that the requirements of the law might be satisfied in us who live now in obedience, not to our earthly nature, but to the Spirit.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:5] They who follow their earthly nature are earthly-minded, while they who follow the Spirit are spiritually minded.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:6] To be earthly-minded means death, to be spiritually minded means life and peace;
[OEBcw - Rom 8:7] because to be earthly-minded is to be an enemy to God, for such a mind does not submit to the law of God, nor indeed can it do so.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:8] They who are earthly cannot please God.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:9] You, however, are not earthly but spiritual, since the Spirit of God lives within you. Unless a person has the Spirit of Christ, they do not belong to Christ;
[OEBcw - Rom 8:10] but, if Christ is within you, then, though the body is dead as a consequence of sin, the spirit is life as a consequence of righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:11] And, if the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead lives within you, he who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will give life even to your mortal bodies, through his Spirit living within you.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:12] So then, friends, we owe nothing to our earthly nature, that we should live in obedience to it.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:13] If you live in obedience to your earthly nature, you will inevitably die; but if, by the power of the Spirit, you put an end to the evil habits of the body, you will live.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:14] All who are guided by the Spirit of God are sons of God.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:15] For you did not receive the spirit of a slave, to fill you once more with fear, but the spirit of a son which leads us to cry ‘Abba, Our Father.’
[OEBcw - Rom 8:16] The Spirit himself unites with our spirits in bearing witness to our being God’s children,
[OEBcw - Rom 8:17] and if children, then heirs — heirs of God, and joint heirs with Christ, since we share Christ’s sufferings in order that we may also share his glory.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:18] I do not count the sufferings of our present life worthy of mention when compared with the glory that is to be revealed and bestowed on us.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:19] All Nature awaits with eager expectation the appearing of the sons of God.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:20] For Nature was made subject to imperfection — not by its own choice, but owing to him who made it so —
[OEBcw - Rom 8:21] yet not without the hope that some day Nature, also, will be set free from enslavement to decay, and will attain to the freedom which will mark the glory of the children of God.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:22] We know, indeed, that all Nature alike has been groaning in the pains of labour to this very hour.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:23] And not Nature only; but we ourselves also, though we have already a first gift of the Spirit — we ourselves are inwardly groaning, while we eagerly await our full adoption as sons — the redemption of our bodies.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:24] By our hope we were saved. But the thing hoped for is no longer an object of hope when it is before our eyes; for who hopes for what is before his eyes?
[OEBcw - Rom 8:25] But when we hope for what is not before our eyes, then we wait for it with patience.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:26] So, also, the Spirit supports us in our weakness. We do not even know how to pray as we should; but the Spirit himself pleads for us in sighs that can find no utterance.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:27] Yet he who searches all our hearts knows what the Spirit’s meaning is, because the pleadings of the Spirit for Christ’s people are in accordance with his will.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:28] But we do know that God causes all things to work together for the good of those who love him — those who have received the call in accordance with his purpose.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:29] For those whom God chose from the first he also destined from the first to be transformed into likeness to his Son, so that his Son might be the eldest among many brothers and sisters.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:30] And those whom God destined for this he also called; and those whom he called he also pronounced righteous; and those whom he pronounced righteous he also brought to glory.
[OEBcw - Rom 8:31] What are we to say, then, in the light of all this? If God is on our side, who can there be against us?
[OEBcw - Rom 8:32] God did not withhold his own Son, but gave him up on behalf of us all; will he not, then, with him, freely give us all things?
[OEBcw - Rom 8:33] Who will bring a charge against any of God’s people? He who pronounces them righteous is God!
[OEBcw - Rom 8:34] Who is there to condemn them? He who died for us is Christ Jesus! — or, rather, it was he who was raised from the dead, and who is now at God’s right hand and is even pleading on our behalf!
[OEBcw - Rom 8:35] Who is there to separate us from the love of the Christ? Will trouble, or difficulty, or persecution, or hunger, or nakedness, or danger, or the sword?
