[OEBcw - Rom 8:36] scripture says — ‘For your sake we are being killed all the day long, We are regarded as sheep to be slaughtered.’
[OEBcw - Rom 8:37] Yet amidst all these things we more than conquer through him who loved us!
[OEBcw - Rom 8:38] For I am persuaded that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor archangels, nor the Present, nor the Future, nor any powers,
[OEBcw - Rom 8:39] nor Height, nor Depth, nor any other created thing, will be able to separate us from the love of God revealed in Christ Jesus, our Lord!
[OEBcw - Rom 9 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 9:1] I am speaking the truth as one in union with Christ; it is no lie; and my conscience, enlightened by the Holy Spirit,
[OEBcw - Rom 9:2] bears me out when I say that there is a great weight of sorrow on me and that my heart is never free from pain.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:3] I could wish that I were myself accursed and severed from the Christ, for the sake of my people — my own flesh and blood.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:4] For they are Israelites, and theirs are the adoption as sons, the visible presence, the Covenants, the revealed law, the Temple worship, and the Promises.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:5] They are descended from the Patriarchs; and, as far as his human nature was concerned, from them came the Christ — he who is supreme over all things, God for ever blessed. Amen.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:6] Not that God’s Word has failed. For it is not all who are descended from Israel who are true Israelites;
[OEBcw - Rom 9:7] nor, because they are Abraham’s descendants, are they all his children; but — ‘It is Isaac’s children who will be called your descendants.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:8] This means that it is not the children born in the course of nature who are God’s children, but it is the children born in fulfilment of the Promise who are to be regarded as Abraham’s descendants.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:9] For these words are the words of a promise — ‘About this time I will come, and Sarah will have a son.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:10] Nor is that all. There is also the case of Rebecca, when she was about to bear children to our ancestor Isaac.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:11] For in order that the purpose of God, working through selection, might not fail — a selection depending, not on obedience, but on his call — Rebecca was told, before her children were born and before they had done anything either right or wrong,
[OEBcw - Rom 9:12] that ‘the elder would be a servant to the younger.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:13] The words of scripture are — ‘I loved Jacob, but I hated Esau.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:14] What are we to say, then? Is God guilty of injustice? Heaven forbid!
[OEBcw - Rom 9:15] For his words to Moses are — ‘I will take pity on whom I take pity, and be merciful to whom I am merciful.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:16] So, then, all depends, not on human wishes or human efforts, but on God’s mercy.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:17] In scripture, again, it is said to Pharaoh — ‘It was for this ​purpose that I raised you to the throne, to show my power by my dealings with you, and to make my name known throughout the world.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:18] So, then, where God wills, he takes pity, and where he wills, he hardens the heart.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:19] Perhaps you will say to me — ‘How can anyone still be blamed? For who withstands his purpose?’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:20] I might rather ask ‘Who are you who are arguing with God?’ Does a thing which a person has moulded say to the person who has moulded it ‘Why did you make me like this?’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:21] Has not the potter absolute power over their clay, so that out of the same lump they make one thing for better, and another for common, use?
[OEBcw - Rom 9:22] And what if God, intending to reveal his displeasure and make his power known, bore most patiently with the objects of his displeasure, though they were fit only to be destroyed,
[OEBcw - Rom 9:23] so as to make known his surpassing glory in dealing with the objects of his mercy, whom he prepared beforehand for glory,
[OEBcw - Rom 9:24] and whom he called — even us — Not only from among the Jews but from among the Gentiles also!
[OEBcw - Rom 9:25] This, indeed, is what he says in the book of Hosea — ‘Those who were not my people, I will call my people, and those who were unloved I will love.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:26] And in the ​place where it was said to them — “You are not my people”, they will be called sons of the living God.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:27] And Isaiah cries aloud over Israel — ‘Though the sons of Israel are like the sand of the sea in number, only a remnant of them will escape!
[OEBcw - Rom 9:28] For the Lord will execute his sentence on the world, fully and without delay.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:29] It is as Isaiah foretold — ‘Had not the Lord of Hosts spared some few of our race to us, we should have become like Sodom and been made to resemble Gomorrah.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:30] What are we to say, then? Why, that Gentiles, who were not in search of righteousness, secured it — a righteousness which was the result of faith;
[OEBcw - Rom 9:31] while Israel, which was in search of a law which would ensure righteousness, failed to discover one.
[OEBcw - Rom 9:32] And why? Because they looked to obedience, and not to faith, to secure it. They stumbled over ‘the Stumbling-block.’
[OEBcw - Rom 9:33] As scripture says — ‘See, I place a Stumbling-block in Zion — ​a Rock which will prove a hindrance; and he who believes in him will have no cause for shame.’
[OEBcw - Rom 10 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 10:1] My friends, my heart’s desire and prayer to God for my people is for their salvation.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:2] I can testify that they are zealous for the honour of God; but they are not guided by true insight,
[OEBcw - Rom 10:3] for, in their ignorance of the divine righteousness, and in their eagerness to set up a righteousness of their own, they refused to accept with submission the divine righteousness.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:4] For Christ has brought law to an end, so that righteousness may be obtained by everyone who believes in him.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:5] For Moses writes that, as for the righteousness which results from law, ‘those who practice it will find life through it.’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:6] But the righteousness which results from faith finds expression in these words — ‘Do not say to yourself “Who will go up into heaven?”’ — which means to bring Christ down —
[OEBcw - Rom 10:7] ‘or “Who will go down into the depths below?”’ — which means to bring Christ up from the dead.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:8] No, but what does it say? ‘The message of faith’ which we proclaim.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:9] For, if with your lips you acknowledge the truth of the message that JESUS IS LORD, and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:10] For with their hearts people believe and so attain to righteousness, while with their lips they make their Profession of faith and so find salvation.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:11] As the passage of scripture says — ‘No one who believes in him will have any cause for shame.’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:12] For no distinction is made between the Jew and the Greek, for all have the same Lord, and he is bountiful to all who invoke him.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:13] For ‘everyone who invokes the name of the Lord will be saved.’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:14] But how, it may be asked, are they to invoke one in whom they have not learned to believe? And how are they to believe in one whose words they have not heard? And how are they to hear his words unless some one proclaims him?
[OEBcw - Rom 10:15] And how is anyone to proclaim him unless they are sent as his messengers? As scripture says — ‘How beautiful are the feet of those who bring good news!’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:16] Still, it may be said, everyone did not give heed to the good news. No, for Isaiah asks — ‘Lord, who has believed our teaching?’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:17] And so we gather, faith is a result of teaching, and the teaching comes in the message of Christ.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:18] But I ask ‘Is it possible that people have never heard?’ No, indeed, for — ‘Their voices spread through all the earth, and their message to the ​ends of the world.’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:19] But again I ask ‘Did not the people of Israel understand? First there is Moses, who says — ‘I, the Lord, will stir you to rivalry with a nation which is no nation; Against an undiscerning nation I will arouse your anger.’
[OEBcw - Rom 10:20] And Isaiah says boldly — ‘I was found by those who were not seeking me; I made myself known to those who were not inquiring of me.
[OEBcw - Rom 10:21] But of the people of Israel he says — ‘All day long I have stretched out my hands to a people who disobey and contradict.’
[OEBcw - Rom 11 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 11:1] I ask, then, ‘Has God rejected his people?’ Heaven forbid! For I myself am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:2] God has not rejected his people, whom he chose from the first. Have you forgotten the words of scripture in the story of Elijah — ​how he appeals to God against Israel?
[OEBcw - Rom 11:3] ‘Lord, they have killed your prophets, they have pulled down your altars, and I only am left; and now they are eager to take my life.’
[OEBcw - Rom 11:4] But what was the divine response? ‘I have kept for myself seven thousand who have never bowed the knee to Baal.’
[OEBcw - Rom 11:5] And so in our own time, too, there is to be found a remnant of our nation selected by God in love.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:6] But if in love, then no longer as a result of obedience. Otherwise love would cease to be love.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:7] What follows from this? Why, that Israel as a nation failed to secure what it was seeking, while those whom God selected did secure it.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:8] The rest grew callous; as scripture says — ‘God has given them a deadness of mind — eyes that are not to see and ears that are not to hear — and it is so to this very day.’
[OEBcw - Rom 11:9] David, too, says — ‘May their feasts prove a snare and a trap to them — a hindrance and a retribution;
[OEBcw - Rom 11:10] may their eyes be darkened, so that they cannot see; and do you always make their backs to bend.’
[OEBcw - Rom 11:11] I ask then — ‘Was their stumbling to result in their fall?’ Heaven forbid! On the contrary, through their falling away salvation has reached the Gentiles, to stir the rivalry of Israel.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:12] And, if their falling away has enriched the world, and their failure has enriched the Gentiles, how much more will result from their full restoration!
[OEBcw - Rom 11:13] But I am speaking to you who were Gentiles.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:14] Being myself an apostle to the Gentiles, I exalt my office, in the hope that I may stir my countrymen to rivalry, and so save some of them.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:15] For, if their being cast aside has meant the reconciliation of the world, what will their reception mean, but life from the dead?
[OEBcw - Rom 11:16] If the first handful of dough in holy, so is the whole mass; and if the root is holy, so are the branches.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:17] Some, however, of the branches were broken off, and you, who were only a wild olive, were grafted in among them, and came to share with them the root which is the source of the richness of the cultivated olive.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:18] Yet do not exult over the other branches. But, if you do exult over them, remember that you do not support the root, but that the root supports you.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:19] But branches, you will say, were broken off, so that I might be grafted in.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:20] True; it was because of their want of faith that they were broken off, and it is because of your faith that you are standing. Do not think too highly of yourself, but beware.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:21] For, if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will he spare you.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:22] See, then, both the goodness and the severity of God — his severity towards those who fell, and his goodness towards you, provided that you continue to confide in that goodness; otherwise you, also, will be cut off.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:23] And they, too, if they do not continue in their unbelief, will be grafted in; for God has it in his power to graft them in again.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:24] If you were cut off from your natural stock — a wild olive — ​and were grafted, contrary to the course of nature, on a good olive, much more will they — the natural branches — be grafted back into their parent tree.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:25] My friends, so that you don't think too highly of yourselves, I want you to recognise the truth, hitherto hidden, that the callousness which has come over Israel is only partial, and will continue only until the whole Gentile world has been gathered in.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:26] And then all Israel will be saved. As scripture says — ‘From Zion will come the Deliverer; he will banish ungodliness from Jacob.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:27] And they will see the fulfilment of my covenant, when I have taken away their sins.’
[OEBcw - Rom 11:28] From the standpoint of the good news, the Jews are God’s enemies for your sake; but from the standpoint of God’s selection, they are dear to him for the sake of the Patriarchs.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:29] For God never regrets his gifts or his call.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:30] Just as you at one time were disobedient to him, but have now found mercy in the day of their disobedience;
[OEBcw - Rom 11:31] so, too, they have now become disobedient in your day of mercy, in order that they also in their turn may now find mercy.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:32] For God has given all alike over to disobedience, that to all alike he may show mercy.
[OEBcw - Rom 11:33] Oh! The unfathomable wisdom and knowledge of God! How inscrutable are his judgments, how untraceable his ways! Yes —
[OEBcw - Rom 11:34] ‘Who has ever comprehended the mind of the Lord? Who has ever become his counsellor?
[OEBcw - Rom 11:35] Or who has first given to him, so that he may claim a reward?’
[OEBcw - Rom 11:36] For all things are from him, through him, and for him. And to him be all glory for ever and ever! Amen.
[OEBcw - Rom 12 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 12:1] I entreat you, then, friends, by the mercies of God, to offer your bodies as a living and holy sacrifice, acceptable to God, for this is your rational worship.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:2] Do not conform to the fashion of this world; but be transformed by the complete change that has come over your minds, so that you may discern what God’s will is — all that is good, acceptable, and perfect.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:3] In fulfilment of the charge with which I have been entrusted, I tell every one of you not to think more highly of himself than he ought to think, but to think until he learns to think soberly — in accordance with the measure of faith that God has allotted to each.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:4] For, just as in the human body there is a union of many parts, and each part has its own function,
[OEBcw - Rom 12:5] so we, by our union in Christ, many though we are, form but one body, and individually we are related one to another as its parts.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:6] Since our gifts differ in accordance with the particular charge entrusted to us, if our gift is to preach, let our preaching correspond to our faith;
[OEBcw - Rom 12:7] if it is to minister to others, let us devote ourselves to our ministry; the teacher to their teaching,
[OEBcw - Rom 12:8] the counselor to their counsel. Let the person who gives in charity do so with a generous heart; let the person who is in authority exercise due diligence; let the person who shows kindness do so in a cheerful spirit.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:9] Let your love be sincere. Hate the wrong; cling to the right.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:10] In the love of the community of the Lord's followers, be affectionate to one another; in showing respect, set an example of deference to one another;
[OEBcw - Rom 12:11] never flagging in zeal; fervent in spirit; serving the Master;
[OEBcw - Rom 12:12] rejoicing in your hope; steadfast under persecution; persevering in prayer;
[OEBcw - Rom 12:13] relieving the wants of Christ’s people; devoted to hospitality.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:14] Bless your persecutors — bless and never curse.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:15] Rejoice with those who are rejoicing, and weep with those who are weeping.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:16] Let the same spirit of sympathy animate you all, not a spirit of pride; enjoy the company of ordinary people. Do not think too highly of yourselves.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:17] Never return injury for injury. Aim at doing what everyone will recognise as honourable.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:18] If it is possible, as far as rests with you, live peaceably with everyone.
[OEBcw - Rom 12:19] Never avenge yourselves, dear friends, but make way for the wrath of God; for scripture declares — ‘“It is for me to avenge, I will requite,” says the Lord.’
[OEBcw - Rom 12:20] Rather — ‘If your enemy is hungry, feed him; if he is thirsty, give him to drink. By doing this you will heap coals of fire on his head.’
[OEBcw - Rom 12:21] Never be conquered by evil, but conquer evil with good.
[OEBcw - Rom 13 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 13:1] Let everyone obey the supreme Authorities. For no Authority exists except by the will of God, and the existing Authorities have been appointed by God.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:2] Therefore he who sets himself against the authorities is resisting God’s appointment, and those who resist will bring a judgment on themselves.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:3] A good action has nothing to fear from Rulers; a bad action has. Do you want to have no reason to fear the Authorities? Then do what is good, and you will win their praise.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:4] For they are God’s servants appointed for your good. But, if you do what is wrong, you may well be afraid; for the sword they carry is not without meaning! They are God’s servants to inflict his punishments on those who do wrong.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:5] You are bound, therefore, to obey, not only through fear of God’s punishments, but also as a matter of conscience.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:6] This, too, is the reason for your paying taxes; for the officials are God’s officers, devoting themselves to this special work.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:7] In all cases pay what is due from you — tribute where tribute is due, taxes where taxes are due, respect where respect is due, and honour where honour is due.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:8] Owe nothing to anyone except love; for they who love their neighbour have satisfied the law.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:9] The commandments, ‘You must not commit adultery, You must not kill, You must not steal, You must not covet,’ and whatever other commandment there is, are all summed up in the words — ‘You must love your neighbour as you love yourself.’
[OEBcw - Rom 13:10] Love never wrongs a neighbour. Therefore love fully satisfies the law.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:11] This I say, because you know the crisis that we have reached, for the time has already come for you to rouse yourselves from sleep; our salvation is nearer now than when we accepted the faith.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:12] The night is almost gone; the day is near. Therefore let us have done with the deeds of darkness, and arm ourselves with the weapons of light.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:13] Being in the light of day, let us live becomingly, not in revelry and drunkenness, not in lust and licentiousness, not in quarrelling and jealousy.
[OEBcw - Rom 13:14] No! Arm yourselves with the spirit of the Lord Jesus Christ, and spend no thought on your earthly nature, to satisfy its cravings.
[OEBcw - Rom 14 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 14:1] As for those whose faith is weak, always receive them as friends, but not for the purpose of passing judgment on their scruples.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:2] One person’s faith permits of their eating food of all kinds, while another whose faith is weak eats only vegetable food.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:3] The person who eats meat must not despise the person who abstains from it; nor must the person who abstains from eating meat pass judgment on the one who eats it, for God himself has received them.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:4] Who are you, that you should pass judgment on the servant of another? Their standing or falling concerns their own master. And stand they will, for their Master can enable them to stand.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:5] Again, one person considers some days to be more sacred than others, while another considers all days to be alike. Everyone ought to be fully convinced in their own mind.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:6] The person who observes a day, observes it to the Master’s honour. They, again, who eat meat eat it to the Master’s honour, for they give thanks to God; while the person who abstains from it abstains from it to the Master’s honour, and also gives thanks to God.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:7] There is not one of us whose life concerns ourselves alone, and not one of us whose death concerns ourself alone;
[OEBcw - Rom 14:8] for, if we live, our life is for the Master, and, if we die, our death is for the Master. Whether, then, we live or die we belong to the Master.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:9] The ​purpose for which Christ died and came back to life was this — that he might be Lord over both the dead and the living.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:10] I would ask the one ‘Why do you judge other followers of the Lord?’ And I would ask the other ‘Why do you despise them?’ For we will all stand before the court of God.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:11] For scripture says — ‘“As surely as I live,” says the Lord, “every knee will bend before me; and every tongue will make acknowledgment to God.”’
[OEBcw - Rom 14:12] So, then, each one of us will have to render account of himself to God.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:13] Let us, then, cease to judge one another. Rather let this be your resolve — never to place a stumbling-block or an obstacle in the way of a fellow follower of the Lord.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:14] Through my union with the Lord Jesus, I know and am persuaded that nothing is ‘defiling in itself.’ A thing is ‘defiling’ only to the person who holds it to be so.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:15] If, for the sake of what you eat, you wound your fellow follower’s feelings, your life has ceased to be ruled by love. Do not, by what you eat, ruin someone for whom Christ died!
[OEBcw - Rom 14:16] Do not let what is right for you become a matter of reproach.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:17] For the kingdom of God does not consist of eating and drinking, but of righteousness and peace and gladness through the presence of the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:18] The person who serves the Christ in this way pleases God, and wins the approval of their fellows.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:19] Therefore our efforts should be directed towards all that makes for peace and the mutual building up of character.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:20] Do not undo God’s work for the sake of what you eat. Though everything is ‘clean,’ yet, if a person eats so as to put a stumbling-block in the way of others, they do wrong.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:21] The right course is to abstain from meat or wine or, indeed, anything that is a stumbling-block to your fellow follower of the Lord.
[OEBcw - Rom 14:22] As for yourself — keep this faith of yours to yourself, as in the presence of God. Happy the person who never has to condemn themselves in regard to something they think right!
[OEBcw - Rom 14:23] The person, however, who has misgivings stands condemned if they still eat, because their doing so is not the result of faith. And anything not done as the result of faith is a sin.
[OEBcw - Rom 15 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 15:1] We, the strong, ought to take on our own shoulders the weaknesses of those who are not strong, and not merely to please ourselves.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:2] Let each of us please our neighbour for our neighbour’s good, to help in the building up of their character.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:3] Even the Christ did not please himself! On the contrary, as scripture says of him — ‘The reproaches of those who were reproaching you fell upon me.’
[OEBcw - Rom 15:4] Whatever was written in the scriptures in days gone by was written for our instruction, so that, through patient endurance, and through the encouragement drawn from the scriptures, we might hold fast to our hope.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:5] And may God, the giver of this patience and this encouragement, grant you to be united in sympathy in Christ,
[OEBcw - Rom 15:6] so that with one heart and one voice you may praise the God and Father of Jesus Christ, our Lord.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:7] Therefore always receive one another as friends, just as the Christ himself received us, to the glory of God.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:8] For I tell you that Christ, in vindication of God’s truthfulness, has become a minister of the covenant of circumcision, so that he may fulfil the promises made to our ancestors,
[OEBcw - Rom 15:9] and that the Gentiles also may praise God for his mercy. As scripture says — ‘Therefore will I make acknowledgment to you among the Gentiles and sing in honour of your name.’
[OEBcw - Rom 15:10] And again it says — ‘Rejoice, you Gentiles, with God’s people.’
[OEBcw - Rom 15:11] And yet again — ‘Praise the Lord, all you Gentiles, and let all Peoples sing his praises.’
[OEBcw - Rom 15:12] Again, Isaiah says — ‘There will be a Scion of the house of Jesse, One who is to arise to rule the Gentiles; on him will the Gentiles rest their hopes.’
[OEBcw - Rom 15:13] May God, who inspires our hope, grant you perfect happiness and peace in your faith, until you are filled with this hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:14] I am persuaded, my friends — yes, I Paul, with regard to you — that you are yourselves full of kindness, furnished with all Christian learning, and well able to give advice to one another.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:15] But in parts of this letter I have expressed myself somewhat boldly — by way of refreshing your memories —
[OEBcw - Rom 15:16] because of the charge with which God has entrusted me, that I should be a minister of Christ Jesus to go to the Gentiles — that I should act as a priest of God’s good news, so that the offering up of the Gentiles may be an acceptable sacrifice, consecrated by the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:17] It is, then, through my union with Christ Jesus that I have a proud confidence in my work for God.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:18] For I will not dare to speak of anything but what Christ has done through me to win the obedience of the Gentiles —
[OEBcw - Rom 15:19] by my words and actions, through the power displayed in signs and marvels, and through the power of the Holy Spirit. And so, starting from Jerusalem and its neighbourhood, and going as far as Illyria, I have told in full the good news of the Christ;
[OEBcw - Rom 15:20] yet always with the ambition to tell the good news where Christ’s name had not previously been heard, so as to avoid building on another’s foundations.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:21] But as scripture says — ‘They to whom he had never been proclaimed will see; and they who have never heard will understand!’
[OEBcw - Rom 15:22] That is why I have so often been prevented from coming to you.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:23] But now there are no further openings for me in these parts, and I have for several years been longing to come to you whenever I may be going to Spain.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:24] For my hope is to visit you on my journey, and then to be sent on my way by you, after I have first partly satisfied myself by seeing something of you.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:25] Just now, however, I am on my way to Jerusalem, to take help to Christ’s people there.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:26] For Macedonia and Greece have been glad to make a collection for the poor among Christ’s people at Jerusalem.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:27] Yes, they were glad to do so; and indeed it is a duty which they owe to them. For the Gentile converts who have shared their spiritual blessings are in duty bound to minister to them in the things of this world.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:28] When I have settled this matter, and have secured to the poor at Jerusalem the enjoyment of these benefits, I will go, by way of you, to Spain.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:29] And I know that, when I come to you, it will be with a full measure of blessing from Christ.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:30] I beg you, then, friends, by Jesus Christ, our Lord, and by the love inspired by the Spirit, to join me in earnest prayer to God on my behalf.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:31] Pray that I may be rescued from those in Judea who reject the faith, and that the help which I am taking to Jerusalem may prove acceptable to Christ’s people;
[OEBcw - Rom 15:32] so that, God willing, I may be able to come to you with a joyful heart, and enjoy some rest among you.
[OEBcw - Rom 15:33] May God, the giver of peace, be with you all. Amen.
[OEBcw - Rom 16 - start] 
[OEBcw - Rom 16:1] I commend to your care our sister, Phoebe, who is a minister of the church at Cenchreae;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:2] and I ask you to give her a Christian welcome — one worthy of Christ’s people — and to aid her in any matter in which she may need your assistance. She has proved herself a staunch friend and protector and to many others.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:3] Give my greeting to Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in the cause of Christ Jesus,
[OEBcw - Rom 16:4] who risked their own lives to save mine. It is not I alone who thank them, but all the churches among the Gentiles thank them also.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:5] Give my greeting, also, to the church that meets at their house, as well as to my dear friend Epaenetus, one of the first in Roman Asia to believe in Christ;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:6] to Mary, who worked hard for you;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:7] to Andronicus and Junia, fellow Jews and once my fellow prisoners, who are people of note among the apostles, and who became Christians before I did;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:8] to my dear Christian friend Ampliatus;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:9] to Urban, our fellow worker in the cause of Christ, and to my dear friend Stachys;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:10] to that proved Christian Apelles; to the household of Aristobulus;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:11] to my countryman Herodion; to the Christians in the household of Narcissus;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:12] to Tryphaena and Tryphosa, who have worked hard for the Master; to my dear friend Persis, for she has done much hard work for the Master;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:13] to that eminent Christian, Rufus, and to his mother, who has been a mother to me also;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:14] to Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and our friends with them;
[OEBcw - Rom 16:15] also to Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and to all Christ’s people who are with them.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:16] Greet one another with a sacred kiss. All the churches of the Christ send you greetings.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:17] I beg you, friends, to be on your guard against people who, by disregarding the teaching which you received, cause divisions and create difficulties; dissociate yourselves from them.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:18] For such persons are not serving Christ, our Master, but are slaves to their own appetites; and, by their smooth words and flattery, they deceive simple-minded people.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:19] Everyone has heard of your ready obedience. It is true that I am very happy about you, but I want you to be well versed in all that is good, and innocent of all that is bad.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:20] And God, the giver of peace, will before long crush Satan under your feet. May the blessing of Jesus, our Lord, be with you.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:21] Timothy, my fellow worker, sends you his greetings, and Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, my countrymen, send theirs.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:22] I Tertius, who am writing this letter, send you my Christian greeting.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:23] My host Gaius, who extends his hospitality to the whole church, sends you his greeting; and Erastus, the city treasurer, and Quartus, our dear friend, add theirs.
[OEBcw - Rom 16:24] 
[OEBcw - Rom 16:25] Now to him who is able to strengthen you, as promised in the good news entrusted to me and in the proclamation of Jesus Christ, in accordance with the revelation of that hidden purpose, which in past ages was kept secret but now has been revealed
[OEBcw - Rom 16:26] and, in obedience to the command of the immortal God, made known through the writings of the prophets to all nations, to secure submission to the faith —
[OEBcw - Rom 16:27] to him, I say, the wise and only God, be ascribed, through Jesus Christ, all glory for ever and ever. Amen.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:1] To the church of God in Corinth, to those who have been consecrated by union with Christ Jesus and called to become his people, and also to all, wherever they may be, who invoke the name of our Lord Jesus Christ — their Master and ours,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:2] from Paul, who has been called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and from Sosthenes, our fellow follower of the Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:3] May God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you and give you peace.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:4] I always thank God about you for the blessing bestowed on you in Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:5] For through union with him you were enriched in every way — in your power to preach, and in your knowledge of the truth;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:6] and so became yourselves a confirmation of my testimony to the Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:7] There is no gift in which you are deficient, while waiting for the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:8] And God himself will strengthen you to the end, so that at the day of our Lord Jesus Christ you may be found blameless.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:9] God will not fail you, and it is he who called you into communion with his Son, Jesus Christ, our Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:10] But I appeal to you, my friends, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, to agree in what you profess, and not to allow divisions to exist among you, but to be united — of one mind and of one opinion.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:11] For I have been informed, my friends, by the members of Chloe’s household, that party feeling exists among you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:12] I mean this: that every one of you says either ‘I follow Paul,’ or ‘I Apollos,’ or ‘I Cephas,’ or ‘I Christ.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:13] You have torn the Christ in pieces! Was it Paul who was crucified for you? Or were you baptized into the faith of Paul?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:14] I am thankful that I did not baptize any of you except Crispus and Gaius,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:15] so that no one can say that you were baptized into my faith.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:16] I baptized also the household of Stephanas. I do not know that I baptized anyone else.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:17] My mission from Christ was not to baptize, but to tell the good news; not, however, in the language of philosophy, in case the cross of the Christ should be robbed of its meaning.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:18] The message of the cross is indeed mere folly to those who are in the path to ruin, but to us who are in the path of salvation it is the ​power of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:19] For scripture says — ‘I will bring the philosophy of the philosophers to nought, and the shrewdness of the shrewd I will bring to nothing.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:20] Where is the philosopher? Where the teacher of the law? Where the disputant of today? Has not God shown the world’s philosophy to be folly?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:21] For since the world, in God’s wisdom, did not by its philosophy learn to know God, God saw fit, by the ‘folly’ of our proclamation, to save those who believe in Christ!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:22] While Jews ask for miraculous signs, and Greeks study philosophy,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:23] we are proclaiming Christ crucified! — to the Jews an obstacle, to the Gentiles mere folly,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:24] but to those who have received the call, whether Jews or Greeks, Christ, the power of God and the wisdom of God!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:25] For God’s ‘folly’ is wiser than people, and God’s ‘weakness’ is stronger than people.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:26] Look at the facts of your call, friends. There are not many among you who are wise, as people reckon wisdom, not many who are influential, not many who are high-born;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:27] but God chose what the world counts foolish to put its wise to shame, and God chose what the world counts weak to put its strong to shame,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:28] and God chose what the world counts poor and insignificant — ​things that to it are unreal — to bring its ‘realities’ to nothing,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:29] so that in his presence no one should boast.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:30] But you, by your union with Christ Jesus, belong to God; and Christ, by God’s will, became not only our wisdom, but also our righteousness, holiness, and deliverance,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 1:31] so that — in the words of scripture — ‘Let him who boasts make his boast of the Lord!’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:1] For my own part, friends, when I came to you, it was with no display of eloquence or philosophy that I came to tell the hidden purpose of God;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:2] for I had determined that, while with you, I would forget everything Jesus Christ — and him crucified!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:3] Indeed, when I came among you, I was weak, and full of fears, and in great anxiety.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:4] My message and my proclamation were not delivered in the persuasive language of philosophy, but were accompanied by the manifestation of spiritual power,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:5] so that your faith should be based, not on the human wisdom, but on the power of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:6] Yet there is a philosophy that we teach to those whose faith is matured, but it is not the philosophy of today, or of the leaders of today — whose downfall is at hand.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:7] No, it is a divine philosophy that we teach, one concerned with the hidden purpose of God — that long hidden philosophy which God, before time began, destined for our glory.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:8] This philosophy is not known to any of the leaders of today; for, had they known it, they would not have crucified our glorified Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:9] It is what scripture speaks of as — ‘What eye never saw, nor ear ever heard, what never entered people's minds ​— even all that God has prepared for those who love him.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:10] Yet to us God revealed it through his Spirit; for the Spirit fathoms all things, even the inmost depths of God’s being.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:11] For what person is there who knows what a person is, except the person’s own spirit within them? So, also, no one comprehends what God is, except the Spirit of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:12] And as for us, it is not the spirit of the world that we have received, but the Spirit that comes from God, so that we may realize the blessings given to us by him.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:13] And we speak of these gifts, not in language taught by human philosophy, but in language taught by the Spirit, explaining spiritual things in spiritual words.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:14] The merely intellectual person rejects the teaching of the Spirit of God; for to them it is mere folly; they cannot grasp it, because it is to be understood only by spiritual insight.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:15] But the person with spiritual insight is able to understand everything, although they themselves are understood by no one.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 2:16] For ‘who has so comprehended the mind of the Lord as to be able to instruct him?’ We, however, have the ​mind of Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:1] But I, my friends, could not speak to you as people with spiritual insight, but only as worldly-minded — mere infants in the faith of Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:2] I fed you with milk, not with solid food, for you were not then able to take it. No, and even now you are not able; you are still worldly.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:3] While there exist among you jealousy and party feeling, is it not true that you are worldly, and are acting merely as other people do?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:4] When one says ‘I follow Paul,’ and another ‘I follow Apollos,’ are not you like other people?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:5] What, I ask, is Apollos? Or what is Paul? Servants through whom you were led to accept the faith; and that only as the Lord helped each of you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:6] I planted, and Apollos watered, but it was God who caused the growth.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:7] Therefore neither the one who plants, nor the one who waters, counts for anything, but only God who causes the growth.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:8] In this the person who plants and the person who waters are one; yet each will receive their own reward in proportion to their own labour.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:9] For we are God’s fellow workers; you are God’s harvest field, God’s building.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:10] In fulfilment of the charge which God had entrusted to me, I laid the foundation like a skilful master; but someone else is now building on it. Let everyone take care how they build;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:11] for no one can lay any other foundation than the one already laid — Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:12] Whatever is used by those who build on this foundation, whether gold, silver, costly stones, wood, hay, or straw,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:13] the quality of each man’s work will become known, for the day will make it plain; because that day is to be ushered in with fire, and the fire itself will test the quality of every man’s work.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:14] If anyone’s work, which they have built on that foundation, still remains, they will gain a reward.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:15] If anyone’s work is burnt up, they will suffer loss; though they themselves will escape, but only as one who has passed through fire.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:16] Do not you know that you are God’s Temple, and that God’s Spirit has his home in you?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:17] If any one destroys the Temple of God, God will destroy them; for the Temple of God is sacred, and so also are you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:18] Let no one deceive himself. If any one among you imagines that, as regards this world, they are wise, let them become a ‘fool,’ that they may become wise.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:19] For in God’s sight this world’s wisdom is folly. Scripture tells of ​— ‘One who catches the wise in their own craftiness,’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:20] And it says again ​— ‘The Lord sees how fruitless are the deliberations of the wise.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:21] Therefore let no one boast about people; for all things are yours —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:22] Whether Paul, or Apollos, or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or the present, or the future — all things are yours!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 3:23] But you are Christ’s and Christ is God’s.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:1] Let people look on us as Christ’s servants, and as stewards of the hidden truths of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:2] Now what we look for in stewards is that they should be trustworthy.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:3] But it weighs very little with me that I am judged by you or by any human tribunal. No, I do not even judge myself;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:4] for, though I am conscious of nothing against myself, that does not prove me innocent. It is the Lord who is my judge.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:5] Therefore do not pass judgment before the time, but wait until the Lord comes. He will throw light on what is now dark and obscure, and will reveal the motives in people’s minds; and then everyone will receive due praise from God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:6] All this, friends, I have, for your sakes, applied to Apollos and myself, so that, from our example, you may learn to observe the precept — ‘Keep to what is written,’ that none of you may speak boastfully of one teacher to the disparagement of another.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:7] For who makes any one of you superior to others? And what have you that was not given you? But if you received it as a gift, why do you boast as if you had not?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:8] Are you all so soon satisfied? Are you so soon rich? Have you begun to reign without us? Would indeed that you had, so that we also might reign with you!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:9] For, as it seems to me, God has exhibited us, the apostles, last of all, as people doomed to death. We are made a spectacle to the universe, both to angels and to people!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:10] We, for Christ’s sake, are ‘fools,’ but you, by your union with Christ, are people of discernment. We are weak, but you are strong. You are honoured, but we are despised.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:11] To this very hour we go hungry, thirsty, and naked; we are beaten; we are homeless;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:12] we work hard, toiling with our own hands. We meet abuse with blessings, we meet persecution with endurance,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:13] we meet slander with gentle appeals. We have been treated as the scum of the earth, the vilest of the vile, to this very hour.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:14] It is with no wish to shame you that I am writing like this; but to warn you as my own dear children.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:15] Though you may have thousands of instructors in the faith of Christ, yet you have not many fathers. It was I who, through union with Christ Jesus, became your father by means of the good news.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:16] Therefore I entreat you — Follow my example.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:17] This is my reason for sending Timothy to you. He is my own dear faithful child in the Master’s service, and he will remind you of my methods of teaching the faith of Christ Jesus — methods which I follow everywhere in every church.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:18] Some, I hear, are puffed up with pride, thinking that I am not coming to you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:19] But come to you I will, and that soon, if it please the Lord; and then I will find out, not what words these people use who are so puffed up, but what power they possess;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:20] for the kingdom of God is based, not on words, but on power.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 4:21] What do you wish? Am I to come to you with a rod, or in a loving and gentle spirit?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:1] There is a wide-spread report respecting a case of immorality among you, and that, too, of a kind that does not occur even among the Gentiles — a man, I hear, is living with his father’s wife!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:2] Instead of grieving over it and taking steps for the expulsion of the man who has done this thing, is it possible that you are still puffed up?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:3] For I myself, though absent in body, have been present with you in spirit, and in the name of our Lord Jesus I have already passed judgment, just as if I had been present, on the man who has acted in this way.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:4] I have decided — having been present in spirit at your meetings, when the power of the Lord Jesus was with us —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:5] to deliver such a man as this over to Satan, that what is sensual in him may be destroyed, so that his spirit may be saved at the day of the Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:6] Your boasting is unseemly. Do not you know that even a little leaven leavens all the dough?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:7] Get rid entirely of the old leaven, so that you may be like new dough — free from leaven, as in truth you are. For our passover lamb is already sacrificed — Christ himself;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:8] therefore let us keep our festival, not with the leaven of former days, nor with the leaven of vice and wickedness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:9] I told you, in my letter, not to associate with immoral people —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:10] not, of course, meaning people of the world who are in immoral, or who are covetous and grasping, or who worship idols; for then you would have to leave the world altogether.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:11] But, as things are, I say that you are not to associate with anyone who, although a follower of Christ in name, is immoral, or covetous, or an idolater, or abusive, or a drunkard, or grasping — no, not even to sit down to eat with such people.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:12] What have I to do with judging those outside the church? Is it not for you to judge those who are within the church,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 5:13] while God judges those who are outside? ‘Put away the wicked from among you.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:1] Can it be that, when one of you has a dispute with another, they dare to have their case tried before the heathen, instead of before Christ’s people?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:2] Do not you know that Christ’s people will try the world? And if the world is to be tried by you, are you unfit to try the most trivial cases?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:3] Do not you know that we are to try angels — to say nothing of the affairs of this life?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:4] Why, then, if you have cases relating to the affairs of this life, do you set to try them those who carry no weight with the church? To your shame I ask it.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:5] Can it be that there is not one among you wise enough to decide between two of their fellow followers?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:6] Must a follower sue a fellow follower? In front of unbelievers?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:7] To begin with, it is undoubtedly a loss to you to have lawsuits with one another. Why not rather let yourselves be wronged? Why not rather let yourselves be cheated?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:8] Instead of this, you wrong and cheat others yourselves — yes, even other followers!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:9] Do not you know that wrong-doers will have no share in God’s kingdom? Do not be deceived. No one who is immoral, or an idolater, or an adulterer, or licentious, or a sexual pervert,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:10] or a thief, or covetous, or a drunkard, or abusive, or grasping, will have any share in God’s kingdom.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:11] Such some of you used to be; but you washed yourselves clean. You became Christ’s people! You were pronounced righteous through the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, and through the Spirit of our God!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:12] Everything is allowable for me! Yes, but everything is not profitable. Everything is allowable for me! Yes, but for my part, I will not let myself be enslaved by anything.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:13] Food exists for the stomach, and the stomach for food; but God will put an end to both the one and the other. The body, however, exists, not for immorality, but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:14] and, as God has raised the Lord, so he will raise up us also by the exercise of his power.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:15] Do not you know that your bodies are Christ’s members? Am I, then, to take the members that belong to the Christ and make them the members of a prostitute? Heaven forbid!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:16] Or do not you know that a man who unites himself with a prostitute is one with her in body (for ‘the two,’ it is said, ‘will become one’);
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:17] while a man who is united with the Lord is one with him in spirit?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:18] Shun all immorality. Every other sin that people commit is something outside the body; but an immoral person sins against their own body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:19] Again, do not you know that your body is a shrine of the Holy Spirit that is within you – the Spirit which you have from God?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 6:20] Moreover, you are not your own masters; you were bought, and the price was paid. Therefore, honour God in your bodies.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:1] With reference to the subjects about which you wrote to me: It is good for a man to remain single.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:2] But, owing to the prevalence of immorality, I advise every man to have his own wife, and every woman her husband.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:3] A husband should give his wife her due, and a wife her husband.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:4] It is not the wife, but the husband, who exercises power over her body; and so, too, it is not the husband, but the wife, who exercises power over his body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:5] Do not deprive each other of what is due — unless it is only for a time and by mutual consent, so that your minds may be free for prayer until you again live as man and wife — otherwise Satan might take advantage of your want of self-control and tempt you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:6] I say this, however, as a concession, not as a command.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:7] I should wish everyone to be just what I am myself. But everyone has his own gift from God — one in one way, and one in another.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:8] My advice, then, to those who are not married, and to widows, is this: It would be good for them to remain as I am myself.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:9] But, if they cannot control themselves, let them marry, for it is better to marry than to be consumed with passion.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:10] To those who are married my direction is — yet it is not mine, but the Master’s — that a woman is not to leave her husband
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:11] (If she has done so, let her remain as she is, or else be reconciled to her husband) and also that a man is not to divorce his wife.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:12] To all others I say — I, not the Master — If a follower of the Lord is married to a woman, who is an unbeliever but willing to live with him, he should not divorce her;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:13] and a woman who is married to a man, who is an unbeliever but willing to live with her, should not divorce her husband.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:14] For, through his wife, the husband who is an unbeliever has become associated with Christ’s people; and the wife who is an unbeliever has become associated with Christ’s people through the Lord's follower whom she has married. Otherwise your children would be ‘defiled,’ but, as it is, they belong to Christ’s people.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:15] However, if the unbeliever wishes to be separated, let him be so. Under such circumstances neither is bound; God has called you to live in peace.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:16] How can you tell, wife, whether you may not save your husband? And how can you tell, husband, whether you may not save your wife?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:17] In any case, a person should continue to live in the condition which the Lord has allotted to them, and in which they were when God called them. This is the rule that I lay down in every church.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:18] Was a man already circumcised when he was called? Then he should not efface his circumcision. Has a man been called when uncircumcised? Then he should not be circumcised.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:19] Circumcision is nothing; the want of it is nothing; but to keep the commands of God is everything.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:20] Let everyone remain in that condition of life in which they were when the call came to them.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:21] Were you a slave when you were called? Do not let that trouble you. No, even if you are able to gain your freedom, still do your best.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:22] For the person who was a slave when they were called to the master’s service is the Master’s freedman; so, too, the person who was free when called is Christ’s slave.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:23] You were bought, and the price was paid. Do not let yourselves become slaves to people.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:24] Friends, let everyone remain in the condition in which they were when they were called, in close communion with God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:25] With regard to unmarried women, I have no command from the Master to give you, but I tell you my opinion, and the Master in his mercy has made me worthy to be trusted.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:26] I think, then, that, in view of the time of suffering that has now come upon us, what I have already said is best — that a man should remain as he is.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:27] Are you married to a wife? Then do not seek to be separated. Are you separated from a wife? Then do not seek for a wife.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:28] still, if you should marry, that is not wrong; nor, if a young woman marries, is that wrong. But those who marry will have much trouble to bear, and my wish is to spare you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:29] What I mean, friends, is this — The time is short. Meanwhile, let those who have wives live as if they had none,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:30] those who are weeping as if not weeping, those who are rejoicing as if not rejoicing, those who buy as if not possessing,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:31] and those who use the good things of the world as using them sparingly; for this world as we see it is passing away.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:32] I want you to be free from anxiety. The unmarried man is anxious about the Master’s cause, desiring to please him;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:33] while the married man is anxious about worldly matters, desiring to please his wife;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:34] and so his interests are divided. Again, the unmarried woman, whether she is old or young, is anxious about the Master’s cause, striving to be pure both in body and in spirit, while the married woman is anxious about worldly matters, desiring to please her husband.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:35] I say this for your own benefit, not with any intention of putting a halter round your necks, but in order to secure for the Master seemly and constant devotion, free from all distraction.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:36] If, however, a father thinks that he is not acting fairly by his unmarried daughter, when she is past her youth, and if under these circumstances her marriage ought to take place, let him act as he thinks right. He is doing nothing wrong — let the marriage take place.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:37] On the other hand, a father, who has definitely made up his mind, and is under no compulsion, but is free to carry out his own wishes, and who has come to the decision, in his own mind, to keep his unmarried daughter at home will be doing right.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:38] In short, the one who consents to his daughter’s marriage is doing right, and yet the other will be doing better.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:39] A wife is bound to her husband as long as he lives; but, if the husband should pass to his rest, the widow is free to marry anyone she wishes, provided he is a believer.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 7:40] Yet she will be happier if she remains as she is — in my opinion, for I think that I also have the Spirit of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:1] With reference to food that has been offered in sacrifice to idols — We are aware that all of us have knowledge! Knowledge breeds conceit, while love builds up character.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:2] If someone thinks that they know anything, they have not yet reached that knowledge which they ought to have reached.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:3] On the other hand, if a person loves God, they are known by God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:4] With reference, then, to eating food that has been offered to idols — we are aware that an idol is nothing in the world, and that there is no God but one.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:5] Even supposing that there are so-called ‘gods’ either in heaven or on earth — and there are many such ‘gods’ and ‘lords’ —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:6] Yet for us there is only one God, the Father, from whom all things come (and for him we live), and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things come (and through him we live).
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:7] Still, it is not everyone that has this knowledge. Some people, because of their association with idols, continued down to the present time, eat the food as food offered to an idol; and their consciences, while still weak, are dulled.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:8] What we eat, however, will not bring us nearer to God. We lose nothing by not eating this food, and we gain nothing by eating it.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:9] But take care that this right of yours does not become in any way a stumbling-block to the weak.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:10] For if some one should see you who possess this knowledge, feasting in an idol’s temple, will not their conscience, if they are weak, become so hardened that they, too, will eat food offered to idols?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:11] And so, through this knowledge of yours, the weak person is ruined — someone for whose sake Christ died!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:12] In this way, by sinning against your fellow followers of the Lord and injuring their consciences, while still weak, you sin against Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 8:13] Therefore, if what I eat makes a follower of the Lord fall, rather than make them fall, I will never eat meat again.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:1] Am I not free? Am I not an apostle? Have I not seen our Lord Jesus? Are not you yourselves my work achieved in union with the Lord?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:2] If I am not an apostle to others, yet at least I am to you; for you are the seal that stamps me as an apostle in union with the Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:3] The defence that I make to my critics is this:
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:4] Have not we a right to food and drink?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:5] Have not we a right to take a wife with us, if she is a Christian, as the other apostles and the Master’s brothers and Cephas all do?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:6] Or is it only Barnabas and I who have no right to give up working for our bread?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:7] Does anyone ever serve as a soldier at his own expense? Does anyone plant a vineyard and not eat its produce? Or does anyone look after a herd and not drink the milk?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:8] Am I, in all this, speaking only from the human standpoint? Does not the law also say the same?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:9] For in the law of Moses it is said ​— ‘You should not muzzle a bullock while it is treading out the grain.’ Is it the bullocks that God is thinking of?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:10] Or is not is said entirely for our sakes? Surely it was written for our sakes, for the ploughman ought not to plough, nor the thrasher to thrash, without expecting a share of the grain.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:11] Since we, then, sowed spiritual seed for you, is it too much that we should reap from you an earthly harvest?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:12] If others share in this right over you, do not we even more? Still we did not avail ourselves of this right. No, we endure anything rather than impede the progress of the good news of the Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:13] Do not you know that those who do the work of the Temple live on what comes from the Temple, and that those who serve at the altar share the offerings with the altar?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:14] So, too, the Master has appointed that those who tell the good news should get their living from the good news.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:15] I, however, have not availed myself of any of these rights. I am not saying this to secure such an arrangement for myself; indeed, I would far rather die — Nobody will make my boast a vain one!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:16] If I tell the good news, I have nothing to boast of, for I can but do so. Woe is me if I do not tell it!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:17] If I do this work willingly, I have a reward; but, if unwillingly, I have been charged to perform a duty.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:18] What is my reward, then? To present the good news free of all cost, and so make but a sparing use of the rights which it gives me.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:19] Although I was entirely free, yet, to win as many converts as possible, I made myself everyone’s slave.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:20] To the Jews I became like a Jew, to win Jews. To those who are subject to law I became like a man subject to law — though I was not myself subject to law — to win those who are subject to law.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:21] To those who have no law I became like a man who has no law — not that I am free from God’s law; no, for I am under Christ’s law — to win those who have no law.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:22] To the weak I became weak, to win the weak. I have become all things to all people, so as at all costs to save some.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:23] And I do everything for the sake of the good news, so that with them I may share in its blessings.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:24] Do not you know that on a racecourse, though all run, yet only one wins the prize? Run in such a way that you may win.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:25] Every athlete exercises self-restraint in everything; they, indeed, for a crown that fades, we for one that is unfading.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:26] I, therefore, run with no uncertain aim. I box — not like a man hitting the air.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 9:27] No, I bruise my body and make it my slave, so that I, who have called others to the contest, will not myself be rejected.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:1] I want you to bear in mind, friends, that all our ancestors were beneath the cloud, and all passed through the sea;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:2] that in the cloud and in the sea they all underwent baptism as followers of Moses;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:3] and that they all ate the same supernatural food,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:4] and all drank the same supernatural water, for they used to drink from a supernatural rock which followed them, and that rock was the Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:5] Yet with most of them God was displeased; for they were ‘struck down in the desert.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:6] Now these things happened as warnings to us, to teach us not to long for evil things as our forefathers longed.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:7] Do not become idolaters, as some of them became. Scripture says ​— ‘The people sat down to eat and drink, and stood up to dance.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:8] Nor let us act immorally, as some of them acted, with the result that twenty-three thousand of them fell dead in a single day.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:9] Nor let us try the patience of the Lord too far, as some of them tried it, with the result that they ‘were, one after another, destroyed by the snakes.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:10] And do not murmur, as some of them murmured, and so ‘were destroyed by the angel of death.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:11] These things happened to them by way of warning, and were recorded to serve as a caution to us, in whose days the close of the ages has come.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:12] Therefore let the person who thinks that they stand take care that they do not fall.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:13] No temptation has come upon you that is not common to all humanity. God will not fail you, and he will not allow you to be tempted beyond your strength; but, when he sends the temptation, he will also provide the way of escape, so that you may have strength to endure.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:14] Therefore, my dear friends, shun the worship of idols.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:15] I speak to you as man of discernment; form your own judgment about what I am saying.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:16] In the cup of blessing which we bless, is not there a sharing in the blood of the Christ? And in the bread which we break, is not there a sharing in the body of the Christ?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:17] The bread is one, and we, though many, are one body; for we all partake of that one bread.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:18] Look at the people of Israel. Do not those who eat the sacrifices share with the altar?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:19] What do I mean? ​That an offering made to an idol, or the idol itself, is anything?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:20] No; what I say is that the sacrifices offered by the Gentiles ‘are offered to demons and to a being who is no God,’ and I do not want you to share with demons.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:21] You cannot drink both the Cup of the Lord and the cup of demons. You cannot partake at the Table of the Lord and at the table of demons.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:22] Or ‘are we to rouse the jealousy of the Lord’? Are we stronger than he?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:23] Everything is allowable! Yes, but everything is not profitable. Everything is allowable! Yes, but everything does not build up character.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:24] A person must not study their own interests, but the interests of others.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:25] Eat anything that is sold in the market, without making inquiries to satisfy your scruples;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:26] for ‘the earth, with all that is in it, belongs to the Lord.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:27] If an unbeliever invites you to his house and you consent to go, eat anything that is put before you, without making inquiries to satisfy your scruples.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:28] But, if anyone should say to you ‘This has been offered in sacrifice to an idol,’ then, for the sake of the speaker and his scruples, do not eat it.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:29] I do not say ‘your’ scruples, but ‘his.’ For why should the freedom that I claim be condemned by the scruples of another?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:30] If, for my part, I take the food thankfully, why should I be abused for eating that for which I give thanks?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:31] Whether, then, you eat or drink or whatever you do, do everything to the honour of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:32] Do not cause offence either to Jews or Greeks or to the church of God;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 10:33] for I, also, try to please everybody in everything, not seeking my own advantage, but do what is best for others, so that they may be saved.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:1] Imitate me, as I myself imitate Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:2] I praise you, indeed, because you never forget me, and are keeping my injunctions in mind, exactly as I laid them on you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:3] But I am anxious that you should understand that the Christ is the head of every man, that man is the head of woman, and that God is the head of the Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:4] Any man who keeps his head covered, when praying or preaching in public, dishonours him who is his head;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:5] while any woman, who prays or preaches in public bare-headed, dishonours him who is her head; for that is to make herself like one of the shameless women who shave their heads.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:6] Indeed, if a woman does not keep her head covered, she may as well cut her hair short. But, since to cut her hair short, or shave it off, marks her as one of the shameless women, let her keep her head covered.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:7] A man ought not to have his head covered, for he has been from the beginning ‘the likeness of God’ and the reflection of his glory, but woman is the reflection of man’s glory.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:8] For it was not man who was taken from woman, but woman who was taken from man.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:9] Besides, man was not created for the sake of woman, but woman for the sake of man.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:10] And, therefore, a woman ought to wear on her head a symbol of her subjection, because of the presence of the angels.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:11] Still, when in union with the Lord, woman is not independent of man, or man of woman;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:12] for just as woman came from man, so man comes by means of woman; and all things come from God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:13] judge for yourselves. Is it fitting that a woman should pray to God in public with her head uncovered?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:14] Does not nature herself teach us that, while for a man to wear his hair long is degrading to him,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:15] a woman’s long hair is her glory? Her hair has been given her to serve as a covering.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:16] If, however, anyone still thinks it right to contest the point — well, we have no such custom, nor have the churches of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:17] In giving directions on the next subject, I cannot praise you; because your meetings do more harm than good.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:18] To begin with, I hear you and, to some extent, I believe it.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:19] Indeed, there must be actual parties among you, for so only will the people of real worth become known.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:20] When you meet together, as I understand, it is not possible to eat the Lord’s Supper;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:21] for, as you eat, each of you tries to secure his own supper first, with the result that one has too little to eat, and another has too much to drink!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:22] Have you no houses in which you can eat and drink? Or are you trying to show your contempt for the church of God, and to humiliate the poor? What can I say to you? Should I praise you? In this matter I cannot praise you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:23] For I myself received from the Lord the account which I have in turn given to you — how the Lord Jesus, on the very night of his betrayal, took some bread,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:24] and, after saying the thanksgiving, broke it and said “This is my own body given on your behalf. Do this in memory of me.”
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:25] And in the same way with the cup, after supper, saying “This cup is the new covenant made by my blood. Do this, whenever you drink it, in memory of me.”
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:26] For whenever you eat this bread and drink the cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death — until he comes.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:27] Therefore, whoever eats the bread, or drinks the Lord’s cup, in an irreverent spirit, will have to answer for an offence against the Lord’s body and blood.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:28] Let everyone look into their own heart, and only then eat of the bread and drink from the cup.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:29] For the person who eats and drinks brings a judgment on themselves by their eating and drinking, when they do not discern the body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:30] That is why so many among you are weak and ill, and why some are sleeping.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:31] But, if we judged ourselves rightly, we should not be judged.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:32] Yet, in being judged by the Lord, we are undergoing discipline, so that we may not have judgment passed on us with the rest of the world.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:33] Therefore, my friends, when you meet together to eat the Supper, wait for one another.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 11:34] If anyone is hungry, let them eat at home, so that your meetings may not bring a judgment on you. The other details I will settle when I come.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:1] In the next place, friends, I do not want you to be ignorant about spiritual gifts.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:2] You know that there was a time when you were Gentiles, going astray after idols that could not speak, just as you happened to be led.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:3] Therefore I tell you plainly that no one who speaks under the influence of the Spirit of God says ‘JESUS IS ACCURSED,’ and that no one can say ‘JESUS IS LORD,’ except under the influence of the Holy Spirit.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:4] Gifts differ, but the Spirit is the same;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:5] ways of serving differ, yet the Master is the same;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:6] results differ, yet the God who brings about every result is in every case the same.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:7] To each of us there is given spiritual illumination for the general good.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:8] To one is given the power to speak with wisdom through the Spirit; to another the power to speak with knowledge, due to the same Spirit;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:9] to another faith by the same Spirit; to another power to cure diseases by the one Spirit; to another supernatural powers;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:10] to another the gift of preaching; to another the gift of distinguishing between true and false inspiration; to another varieties of the gift of ‘tongues’; to another the power to interpret ‘tongues.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:11] All these result from one and the same Spirit, who distributes his gifts to each individually as he wills.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:12] For just as the human body is one whole, and yet has many parts, and all its parts, many though they are, form but one body, so it is with the Christ;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:13] for it was by one Spirit that we were all baptized to form one body, whether Jews or Greeks, slaves or free, and were all imbued with one Spirit.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:14] The human body, I repeat, consists not of one part, but of many.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:15] If the foot says ‘Since I am not a hand, I do not belong to the body,’ it does not because of that cease to belong to the body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:16] Or if the ear says ‘Since I am not an eye, I do not belong to the body,’ it does not because of that cease to belong to the body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:17] If all the body were an eye, where would the hearing be? If it were all hearing, where would the sense of smell be?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:18] But in fact God has placed each individual part just where he thought fit in the body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:19] If, however, they all made up only one part, where would the body be?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:20] But in fact, although it has many parts, there is only one body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:21] The eye cannot say to the hand ‘I do not need you,’ nor, again, the head to the feet ‘I do not need you.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:22] No! Those parts of the body that seem naturally the weaker are indispensable;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:23] and those parts which we deem less honourable we surround with special honour; and our ungraceful parts receive a special grace which our graceful parts do not require.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:24] Yes, God has so constructed the body — by giving a special honour to the part that lacks it —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:25] As to secure that there should be no disunion in the body, but that the parts should show the same care for one another.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:26] If one part suffers, all the others suffer with it, and if one part has honour done it, all the others share its joy.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:27] Together you are the body of Christ, and individually its parts.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:28] In the church God has appointed, first, apostles, secondly preachers, thirdly teachers; then he has given supernatural powers, then power to cure diseases, aptness for helping others, capacity to govern, varieties of the gift of ‘tongues.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:29] Can everyone be an apostle? Can everyone be a preacher? Can everyone be a teacher? Can everyone have supernatural powers?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:30] Can everyone have power to cure diseases? Can everyone speak in ‘tongues’? Can everyone interpret them?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 12:31] Strive for the greater gifts. Yet I can still show you a way beyond all comparison the best.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:1] Though I speak in the ‘tongues’ of people, or even of angels, yet have not love, I have become mere echoing brass, or a clanging cymbal!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:2] Even though I have the gift of preaching, and fathom all hidden truths and all the depths of knowledge; even though I have such faith as might move mountains, yet have not love, I am nothing!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:3] Even though I dole my substance to the poor, even though I sacrifice my body in order to boast, yet have not love, it avails me nothing!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:4] love is long-suffering, and kind; love is never envious, never boastful, never conceited, never behaves unbecomingly;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:5] love is never self-seeking, never provoked, never reckons up her wrongs;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:6] love never rejoices at evil, but rejoices in the triumph of truth;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:7] love bears with all things, every trustful, ever hopeful, ever patient.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:8] love never fails. But, whether it be the gift of preaching, it will be done with; whether it be the gift of ‘tongues,’ it will cease; whether it be knowledge, it, too, will be done with.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:9] For our knowledge is incomplete, and our preaching is incomplete,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:10] but, when the perfect has come, that which is incomplete will be done with.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:11] When I was a child, I talked as a child, I felt as a child, I reasoned as a child; now that I am a man, I have done with childish ways.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:12] As yet we see, in a mirror, dimly, but then — face to face! As yet my knowledge is incomplete, but then I will know in full, as I have been fully known.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 13:13] Meanwhile faith, hope, and love endure — these three, but the greatest of these is love.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:1] Seek this love earnestly, and strive for spiritual gifts, above all for the gift of preaching.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:2] The person who, when speaking, uses the gift of ‘tongues’ is speaking, not to people, but to God, for no one understands them; yet in spirit they are speaking of hidden truths.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:3] But those who preach are speaking to their fellow men and women words that will build up faith, and give them comfort and encouragement.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:4] Those who, when speaking, use the gift of ‘tongues’ builds up their own faith, while those who preach build up the faith of the church.
