[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:5] Now I want you all to speak in ‘tongues,’ but much more I wish that you should preach. A preacher is worth more than one who speaks in ‘tongues,’ unless they interprets their words, so that the faith of the church may be built up.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:6] This being so, friends, what good will I do you, if I come to you and speak in ‘tongues,’ unless my words convey some revelation, or knowledge, or take the form of preaching or teaching?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:7] Even with inanimate things, such as a flute or a harp, though they produce sounds, yet unless the notes are quite distinct, how can the tune played on the flute or the harp be recognised?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:8] If the bugle sounds a doubtful call, who will prepare for battle?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:9] And so with you; unless, in using the gift of ‘tongues,’ you utter intelligible words, how can what you say be understood? You will be speaking to the winds!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:10] There is, for instance, a certain number of different languages in the world, and not one of them fails to convey meaning.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:11] If, however, I do not happen to know the language, I will be a foreigner to those who speak it, and they will be foreigners to me.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:12] And so with you; since your are striving for spiritual gifts, be eager to excel in such as will build up the faith of the church.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:13] Therefore let him who, when speaking, uses the gift of ‘tongues’ pray for ability to interpret them.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:14] If, when praying, I use the gift of ‘tongues,’ my spirit indeed prays, but my mind is a blank.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:15] What, then, is my conclusion? Simply this — I will pray with my spirit, but with my mind as well; I will sing with my spirit, but with my mind as well.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:16] If you bless God with your spirit only, how can people in the congregation who are without your gift say ‘Amen’ to your thanksgiving? They do not know what you are saying!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:17] Your thanksgiving may be excellent, but the other is not helped by it.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:18] Thank God, I use the gift of ‘tongues’ more than any of you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:19] But at a meeting of the church I would rather speak five words with my mind, and so teach others, than ten thousand words when using the gift of ‘tongues.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:20] My friends, do not show yourselves children in understanding. In wickedness be infants, but in understanding show yourselves adults.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:21] It is said in the law ​— ‘In strange tongues and by the lips of strangers will I speak to this people, but even then they will not listen to me, says the Lord.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:22] Therefore the gift of the ‘tongues’ is intended as a sign, not for those who believe in Christ, but for those who do not, while the gift of preaching is intended as a sign, not for those who do not believe in Christ, but for those who do.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:23] So, when the whole church meets, if all present use the gift of ‘tongues,’ and some people who are without the gift, or who are unbelievers, come in, will not they say that you are mad?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:24] While, if all those present use the gift of preaching, and an unbeliever, or someone without the gift, comes in, they are convinced of their sinfulness by them all, they are called to account by them all;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:25] the secrets of their heart are revealed, and then, throwing themselves on their face, they will worship God, and declare ‘God is indeed among you!’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:26] What do I suggest, then, friends? Whenever you meet for worship, each of you comes, either with a hymn, or a lesson, or a revelation, or the gift of ‘tongues,’ or the interpretation of them; let everything be directed to the building up of faith.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:27] If any of you use the gift of ‘tongues,’ not more than two, or at the most three, should do so — each speaking in his turn — and some one should interpret them.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:28] If there is no one able to interpret what is said, they should remain silent at the meeting of the church, and speak to themselves and to God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:29] Of preachers two or three should speak, and the rest should weigh well what is said.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:30] But, if some revelation is made to another person as he sits there, the first speaker should stop.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:31] For you can all preach in turn, so that all may learn some lesson and all receive encouragement.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:32] (The spirit that moves the preachers is within the preachers’ control;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:33] for God is not a God of disorder, but of peace.) This custom prevails in all the churches of Christ’s people.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:34] At the meetings of the church married women should remain silent, for they are not allowed to speak in public; they should take a subordinate place, as the law itself directs.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:35] If they want information on any point, they should ask their husbands about it at home; for it is unbecoming for a married woman to speak at a meeting of the church.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:36] What! Did God’s message to the world originate with you? Or did it find its way to none but you?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:37] If anyone thinks that he has the gift of preaching or any other spiritual gift, let him recognise that what I am now saying to you is a command from the Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:38] Anyone who ignores it may be ignored.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:39] Therefore, my friends, strive for the gift of preaching, and yet do not forbid speaking in ‘tongues.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 14:40] Let everything be done in a proper and orderly manner.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:1] Next, friends, I would like to remind you of the good news which I told you, and which you received — the good news on which you have taken your stand,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:2] and by means of which you are being saved. I would like to remind you of the ​words that I used in telling it to you, since you are still holding fast to it, and since it was not in vain that you became believers in Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:3] For at the very beginning of my teaching I gave you the account which I had myself received — that Christ died for our sins (as the scriptures had foretold),
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:4] that he was buried, that on the third day he was raised (as the scriptures had foretold),
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:5] and that he appeared to Cephas, and then to the Twelve.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:6] After that, he appeared to more than five hundred of his followers at one time, most of whom are still alive, though some have gone to their rest.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:7] After that, he appeared to James, and then to all the apostles.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:8] Last of all, he appeared even to me, who am, as it were, the abortion.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:9] For I am the meanest of the apostles, I who am unworthy of the name of ‘apostle,’ because I persecuted the church of God.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:10] But it is through the love of God that I am what I am, and the love that he showed me has not been wasted. No, I have toiled harder than any of them, and yet it was not I, but the love of God working with me.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:11] Whether, then, it was I or whether it was they, this we proclaim, and this you believed.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:12] Now, if it is proclaimed of Christ that he has been raised from the dead, how is it that some of you say that there is no such thing as a resurrection of the dead?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:13] But, if there is no such thing as a resurrection of the dead, then even Christ has not been raised;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:14] and, if Christ has not been raised, then our proclamation is without meaning, and our faith without meaning also!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:15] Yes, and we are being proved to have borne false testimony about God; for we testified of God that he raised the Christ, whom he did not raise, if, indeed, the dead do not rise!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:16] For, if the dead do not rise, then even Christ himself has not been raised,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:17] and, if Christ has not been raised, your faith is folly — your sins are on you still!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:18] Yes, and they, who have passed to their rest in union with Christ, perished!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:19] If all that we have done has been to place our hope in Christ for this life, then we of all people are the most to be pitied.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:20] But, in truth, Christ has been raised from the dead, the first-fruits of those who are at rest.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:21] For, since through a man there is death, so, too, through a man there is a resurrection of the dead.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:22] For, as through union with Adam all die, so through union with the Christ will all be made to live.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:23] But each in their proper order — Christ the first-fruits; afterwards, at his coming, those who belong to the Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:24] Then will come the end — when he surrenders the kingdom to his God and Father, having overthrown all other rule and all other authority and power.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:25] For he must reign until God ‘has put all his enemies under his feet.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:26] The last enemy to be overthrown is death;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:27] for God has placed all things under Christ’s feet. (But, when it is said that all things have been placed under Christ, it is plain that God is excepted who placed everything under him.)
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:28] And, when everything has been placed under him, the Son will place himself under God who placed everything under him, so that God may be all in all!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:29] Again, what good will they be doing who are baptized on behalf of the dead? If it is true that the dead do not rise, why are people baptized on their behalf?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:30] Why, too, do we risk our lives every hour?
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:31] Daily I face death — I swear it, friends, by the pride in you that I feel through my union with Christ Jesus, our Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:32] If with only human hopes I had fought in the arena at Ephesus, what should I have gained by it? If the dead do not rise, then — ‘Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die’!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:33] Do not be deceived. ‘Good character is marred by evil company.’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:34] Wake up to a righteous life, and cease to sin. There are some who have no true knowledge of God. I speak in this way to shame you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:35] Some one, however, may ask ‘How do the dead rise? And in what body will they come?’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:36] You foolish person! The seed you yourself sow does not come to life, unless it dies!
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:37] And when you sow, you sow not the body that will be, but a mere grain — perhaps of wheat, or something else.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:38] God gives it the body that he pleases — to each seed its special body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:39] All forms of life are not the same; there is one for people, another for beasts, another for birds, and another for fishes.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:40] There are heavenly bodies, and earthly bodies; but the beauty of the heavenly bodies is not the beauty of the earthly.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:41] There is a beauty of the sun, and a beauty of the moon, and a beauty of the stars; for even star differs from star in beauty.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:42] It is the same with the resurrection of the dead. Sown a mortal body, it rises immortal; sown disfigured, it rises beautiful;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:43] sown weak, it rises strong; sown a human body, it rises a spiritual body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:44] As surely as there is a human body, there is also a spiritual body.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:45] That is what is meant by the words — ‘Adam, the first man, became a human being’; the last Adam became a life-giving spirit.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:46] That which comes first is not the spiritual, but the human; afterwards comes the spiritual;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:47] the first man was from the dust of the earth; the second man from heaven.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:48] Those who are of the dust are like him who came from the dust; and those who are of heaven are like him who came from heaven.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:49] And as we have borne the likeness of him who came from the dust, so let us bear the likeness of him who came from heaven.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:50] This I say, friends — Flesh and blood can have no share in the kingdom of God, nor can the perishable share the imperishable.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:51] Listen, I will tell you God’s hidden purpose! We will not all have passed to our rest, but we will all be transformed — in a moment, in the twinkling of an eye,
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:52] at the last trumpet-call; for the trumpet will sound, and the dead will rise immortal, and we, also, will be transformed.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:53] For this perishable body of ours must put on an imperishable form, and this dying body a deathless form.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:54] And, when this dying body has put on its deathless form, then indeed will the words of scripture come true —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:55] ‘death has been swallowed up in victory! Where, Death, is your victory? Where, death, is your sting?’
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:56] It is sin that gives death its sting, and it is the law that gives sin its power.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:57] But thanks be to God, who gives us the victory, through Jesus Christ, our Lord.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 15:58] Therefore, my dear friends, stand firm, unshaken, always diligent in the Lord’s work, for you know that, in union with him, your toil is not in vain.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:1] With reference to the collection for Christ’s people, I want you to follow the instructions that I gave to the churches in Galatia.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:2] On the first day of every week each of you should put by what he can afford, so that no collections need be made after I have come.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:3] On my arrival, I will send any persons, whom you may authorise by letter, to carry your gift to Jerusalem;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:4] and, if it appears to be worth while for me to go also, they will go with me.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:5] I will come to you as soon as I have been through Macedonia — for I am going through Macedonia —
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:6] And I will probably make some stay with you or, perhaps, remain for the winter, so that you may yourselves send me on my way, wherever I may be going.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:7] I do not propose to pay you a visit in passing now, for I hope to stay with you for some time, if the Lord permits.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:8] I intend, however, staying at Ephesus until the Festival at the close of the Harvest;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:9] for a great opening for active work has presented itself, and there are many opponents.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:10] If Timothy comes, take care that he has no cause for feeling anxious while he is with you. He is doing the Master’s work no less than I am.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:11] No one, therefore, should slight him. See him safely on his way to me, for I am expecting him with some of our friends.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:12] As for our friend Apollos, I have often urged him to go to you with the others. He has, however, been very unwilling to do so as yet; but he will go as soon as he finds a good opportunity.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:13] Be watchful; stand firm in your faith; be brave; be strong.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:14] Let everything you do be done in a loving spirit.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:15] I have another request to make of you, friends. You remember Stephanas and his household, and that they were the first-fruits gathered in from Greece, and set themselves to serve Christ’s people.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:16] I want you, on your part, to show deference to such people as these, as well as to every fellow labourer and earnest worker.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:17] I am glad Stephanas and Fortunatus and Achaicus have come, for they have made up for your absence;
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:18] they have cheered my heart, and your hearts also. Recognise the worth of such people as these.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:19] The churches in Roman Asia send you their greetings. Aquila and Prisca and the church that meets at their house send you many Christian greetings.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:20] All of the Lord's followers send you greetings. Greet one another with a sacred kiss.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:21] I, Paul, add this greeting in my own handwriting.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:22] Accursed be anyone who has no love for the Lord. THE LORD IS COMING.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:23] May the blessing of the Lord Jesus be with you.
[OEBcw - 1Cor 16:24] My love to all of you who are in union with Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:1] To the church of God in Corinth, and to all Christ’s people throughout Greece, from Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus, by the will of God, and from Timothy, who is also a follower.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:2] May God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you and give you peace.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:3] Blessed is the God and Father of Jesus Christ our Lord, the all-merciful Father, the God ever ready to console,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:4] who consoles us in all our troubles, so that we may be able to console those who are in any trouble with the consolation that we ourselves receive from him.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:5] It is true that we have our full share of the sufferings of the Christ, but through the Christ we have also our full share of consolation.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:6] If we meet with trouble, it is for the sake of your consolation and salvation; and, if we find consolation, it is for the sake of the consolation that you will experience when you are called to endure the ​sufferings that we ourselves are enduring;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:7] and our hope for you remains unshaken. We know that, as you are sharing our sufferings, you will also share our consolation.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:8] We want you, friends, to know that, in the troubles which befell us in Roman Asia, we were burdened altogether beyond our strength, so much so that we even despaired of life.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:9] Indeed, we had the presentiment that we must die, so that we might rely, not on ourselves, but on God who raises the dead.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:10] And from so imminent a death God delivered us, and will deliver us again; for in him we have placed our hopes of future deliverance, while you, also, help us by your prayers.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:11] And then many lips will give thanks on our behalf for the blessing granted us in answer to many prayers.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:12] Indeed, our main ground for satisfaction is this — Our conscience tells us that our conduct in the world, and still more in our relations with you, was marked by a purity of motive and a sincerity that were inspired by God, and was based, not on worldly policy, but on the help of God.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:13] We never write anything to you other than what you will acknowledge to the very end —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:14] And, indeed, you have already partly acknowledged it about us — that you have a right to be proud of us, as we will be proud of you, on the day of our Lord Jesus.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:15] With this conviction in my mind, I planned to come to see you first, so that your pleasure might be doubled —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:16] To visit you both on my way to Macedonia, and to come to you again on my return from Macedonia, and then to get you to send me on my way into Judea.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:17] As this was my plan, where, pray, did I show any fickleness of purpose? Or do you think that my plans are formed on mere impulse, so that in the same breath I say ‘Yes’ and ‘No’?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:18] As God is true, the message that we brought you does not waver between ‘Yes’ and ‘No’!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:19] The Son of God, Christ Jesus, whom we — Silas, Timothy, and I — proclaimed among you, never wavered between ‘Yes’ and ‘No.’ With him it has always been ‘Yes.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:20] For, many as were the promises of God, in Christ is the ‘Yes’ that fulfils them. Therefore, through Christ again, let the ‘Amen’ rise, through us, to the glory of God.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:21] God who brings us, with you, into close union with Christ, and who consecrated us,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:22] also set his seal on us, and gave us his Spirit in our hearts as a pledge of future blessings.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:23] But, as my life will answer for it, I call God to witness that it was to spare you that I deferred my visit to Corinth.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 1:24] I do not mean that we are to dictate to you with regard to your faith; on the contrary, we work with you for your true happiness; indeed, it is through your faith that you are standing firm.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:1] For my own sake, as well, I decided not to pay you another painful visit.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:2] If it is I who cause you pain, why, who is there to cheer me, except the ​person whom I am paining?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:3] So I wrote as I did because I was afraid that if I had come, I should have been pained by those who ought to have made me glad; for I felt sure that it was true of you all that my joy was in every case yours also.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:4] I wrote to you in sore trouble and distress of heart and with many tears, not to give you pain, but to let you see how intense a love I have for you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:5] Now whoever has caused the pain has not so much pained me, as he has, to some extent — not to be too severe — pained every one of you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:6] The man to whom I refer has been sufficiently punished by the penalty inflicted by the majority of you;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:7] so that now you must take the opposite course, and forgive and encourage him, or else he may be overwhelmed by the intensity of his pain.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:8] So I entreat you to assure him of your love.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:9] I had this further object, also, in what I wrote — to find out whether you might be relied on to be obedient in everything.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:10] Anyone you forgive, I forgive them, too. Indeed, for my part, whatever I have forgiven (if I have had to forgive anything), I have forgiven for your sakes, in the presence of Christ,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:11] so as to prevent Satan from taking advantage of us; for we are not ignorant of his devices.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:12] When I went to the district round Troas to tell the good news of the Christ, even though there was an opening for serving the Master,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:13] I could get no peace of mind because I failed to find Titus, my friend; so I took leave of the people there, and went on to Macedonia.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:14] All thanks to God, who, through our union with the Christ, leads us in one continual triumph, and uses us to spread the sweet perfume of the knowledge of him in every place.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:15] For we are the fragrance of Christ ascending to God — both among those who are in the path of salvation and among those who are in the path to ruin.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:16] To the latter we are a stench which arises from death and tells of death; to the former a fragrance which arises from life and tells of life. But who is equal to such a task?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 2:17] Unlike many people, we are not in the habit of making profit out of God’s message; but in all sincerity, and bearing God’s commission, we speak before him in union with Christ.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:1] Are we beginning to commend ourselves again? Or are we like some who need letters of commendation to you, or from you?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:2] You yourselves are our letter — a letter written on our hearts, and one which everybody can read and understand.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:3] All can see that you are a letter from Christ delivered by us, a letter written, not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God, not on ‘tablets of stone,’ but on ‘tablets of human hearts.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:4] This, then, is the confidence in regard to God that we have gained through the Christ.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:5] I do not mean that we are fit to form any judgment by ourselves, as if on our own authority;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:6] our fitness comes from God, who himself made us fit to be ministers of a new covenant, of which the substance is, not a written law, but a Spirit. For the written law means death, but the Spirit gives life.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:7] If the system of religion which involved death, embodied in a written law and engraved on stones, began amid such glory, that the Israelites were unable to gaze at the face of Moses because of its glory, though it was but a passing glory,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:8] will not the religion that confers the Spirit have still greater glory?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:9] For, if there was a glory in the religion that involved condemnation, far greater is the glory of the religion that confers righteousness!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:10] Indeed, that which then had glory has lost its glory, because of the glory which surpasses it.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:11] And, if that which was to pass away was attended with glory, far more will that which is to endure be surrounded with glory!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:12] With such a hope as this, we speak with all plainness;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:13] unlike Moses, who covered his face with a veil, to prevent the Israelites from gazing at the disappearance of what was passing away.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:14] But their minds were slow to learn. Indeed, to this very day, at the public reading of the old covenant, the same veil remains ; only for those who are in union with Christ does it pass away.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:15] But, even to this day, whenever Moses is read, a veil lies on their hearts.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:16] ‘Yet, whenever someone turns to the Lord, the veil is removed.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:17] And the ‘Lord’ is the Spirit, and, where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 3:18] And all of us, with faces from which the veil is lifted, seeing, as if reflected in a mirror, the glory of the Lord, are being transformed into his likeness, from glory to glory, as it is given by the Lord, the Spirit.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:1] Therefore, since it is by God’s mercy that we are engaged in this ministry, we do not lose heart.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:2] No, we have renounced the secrecy prompted by shame, refusing to adopt crafty ways, or to tamper with God’s message, and commending ourselves to everyone’s conscience, in the sight of God, by our exhibition of the truth.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:3] And, even if the good news that we bring is veiled, it is veiled only in the case of those who are on the path to ruin —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:4] people whose minds have been blinded by the God of this age, unbelievers as they are, so that the light from the good news of the glory of the Christ, who is the ​incarnation of God, should not shine for them.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:5] (For it is not ourselves that we proclaim, but Christ Jesus, as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus’ sake.)
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:6] Indeed, the same God who said ‘Out of darkness light will shine,’ has shone in on our hearts, so that we should bring out into the light the knowledge of the glory of God, seen in the face of Christ.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:7] This treasure we have in these earthen vessels, so that its all-prevailing power may be seen to come from God, and not to be our own.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:8] Though hard pressed on every side, we are never hemmed in; through perplexed, never driven to despair;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:9] though pursued, never abandoned; though struck down, never killed!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:10] We always bear on our bodies the marks of the death that Jesus died, so that the life also of Jesus may be exhibited in our bodies.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:11] Indeed, we who still live are continually being given over to death for Jesus’ sake, so that the life also of Jesus may be exhibited in our mortal nature.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:12] And so, while death is at work within us, life is at work within you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:13] But, in the same spirit of faith as that expressed in the words — ‘I believed, and therefore I spoke,’ we, also believe, and therefore speak.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:14] For we know that he who raised the Lord Jesus will raise us also with him, and will bring us, with you, into his presence.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:15] For all this is for your sakes, so that the loving kindness of God, spreading from heart to heart, may cause yet more hearts to overflow with thanksgiving, to his glory.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:16] Therefore, as I said, we do not lose heart. No, even though outwardly we are wasting away, yet inwardly we are being renewed day by day.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:17] The light burden of our momentary trouble is preparing for us, in measure transcending thought, a weight of imperishable glory;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 4:18] we, all the while, gazing not on what is seen, but on what is unseen; for what is seen is transient, but what is unseen is imperishable.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:1] For we know that if our tent — that earthly body which is now our home — is taken down, we have a house of God’s building, a home not made by hands, imperishable, in heaven.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:2] Even while in our present body we sigh, longing to put over it our heavenly house,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:3] sure that, when we have put it on, we will never be found discarnate.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:4] For we who are in this ‘tent’ sigh under our burden, unwilling to take it off, yet wishing to put our heavenly body over it, so that all that is mortal may be absorbed in life.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:5] And he who has prepared us for this change is God, who has also given us his Spirit as a pledge.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:6] Therefore we are always confident, knowing that, while our home is in the body, we are absent from our home with the Lord.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:7] For we guide our lives by faith, and not by what we see.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:8] And in this confidence we would gladly leave our home in the body, and make our home with the Lord.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:9] Therefore, whether in our home or absent from our home, our one ambition is to please him.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:10] For at the court of the Christ we must all appear in our true characters, so that each may reap the results of the life which he has lived in the body, in accordance with his actions — whether good or worthless.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:11] Therefore, because we know the fear inspired by the Lord, it is true that we are trying to win people over, but our motives are plain to God; and I hope that in your inmost hearts they are plain to you also.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:12] We are not “commending ourselves” again to you, but rather are giving you cause for pride in us, so that you may have an answer ready for those who pride themselves on appearances and not on character.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:13] For, if we were “beside ourselves,” it was in God’s service! If we are not in our senses, it is in yours!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:14] It is the love of the Christ which compels us, when we reflect that, as one died for all, therefore all died;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:15] and that he died for all, so that the living should no longer live for themselves, but for him who died and rose for them.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:16] For ourselves, then, from this time forward, we refuse to regard anyone from the world’s standpoint. Even if we once thought of Christ from the standpoint of the world, yet now we do so no longer.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:17] Therefore, if anyone is in union with Christ, he is a new being! His old life has passed away; a new life has begun!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:18] But all this is the work of God, who reconciled us to himself through Christ, and gave us the Ministry of Reconciliation —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:19] To proclaim that God, in Christ, was reconciling the world to himself, not reckoning people’s offences against them, and that he had entrusted us with the message of this reconciliation.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:20] It is, then, on Christ’s behalf that we are acting as ambassadors, God, as it were, appealing to you through us. We implore you on Christ’s behalf — Be reconciled to God.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 5:21] For our sake God made Christ, who was innocent of sin, one with our sinfulness, so that in him we might be made one with the righteousness of God.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:1] Therefore, as God’s fellow workers, we also appeal to you not to receive his loving kindness in vain.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:2] For he says — ‘At the time for acceptance I listened to you, And on the day of deliverance I helped you.’ Now is the time for acceptance! Now is the day of deliverance!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:3] Never do we put an obstacle in anyone’s way, so that no fault may be found with our ministry.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:4] No, we are trying to commend ourselves under all circumstances, as God’s ministers should — in many an hour of endurance, in troubles, in hardships, in difficulties,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:5] in floggings, in imprisonments, in riots, in toils, in sleepless nights, in fastings;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:6] by purity, by knowledge, by patience, by kindliness, by holiness of spirit, by unfeigned love;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:7] by the message of truth, and by the power of God; by the weapons of righteousness in the right hand and in the left;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:8] amid honour and disrepute, amid slander and praise; regarded as deceivers, yet proved to be true;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:9] as unknown, yet well-known; as at death’s door, yet, see, we are living; as chastised, yet not killed;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:10] as saddened, yet always rejoicing; as poor, yet enriching many; as having nothing, and yet possessing all things!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:11] We have been speaking freely to you, dear friends in Corinth; we have opened our heart;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:12] there is room there for you, yet there is not room, in your love, for us.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:13] Can you not in return — I appeal to you as I should to children — open your hearts to us?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:14] Do not enter into inconsistent relations with those who reject the faith. For what partnership can there be between righteousness and lawlessness? Or what has light to do with darkness?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:15] What harmony can there be between Christ and Belial? Or what can those who accept the faith have in common with those who reject it?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:16] What agreement can you be between a temple of God and idols? And we are a temple of the living God. That is what God meant when he said — ‘I will live among them, and walk among them; And I will be their God, and they will be my people.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:17] Therefore “Come out from among the nations, and separate yourselves from them,” says the Lord, “And touch nothing impure; And I will welcome you;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 6:18] and I will be a father to you, and you will be my sons and daughters,” says the Lord, the Ruler of all.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:1] With these promises, dear friends, let us purify ourselves from everything that pollutes either body or spirit, and, in deepest respect for God, aim at perfect holiness.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:2] Make room for us in your hearts. In no instance have we ever wronged, or harmed, or taken advantage of, anyone.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:3] I am not saying this to condemn you. Indeed, I have already said that you are in our ​heart, to live and die together.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:4] I have the utmost confidence in you; I am always boasting about you. I am full of encouragement and, in spite of all our troubles, my heart is overflowing with happiness.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:5] Ever since we reached Macedonia, we have had no rest in body or mind; on every side there have been troubles — conflicts without, anxieties within.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:6] But God, who encourages the downcast, has encouraged us by the arrival of Titus.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:7] And it is not only by his arrival that we are encouraged, but also by the encouragement which he received from you; for he tells us of your strong affection, your penitence, and your zeal on my behalf — so that I am happier still.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:8] For, though I caused you sorrow by my letter, I do not regret it. Even if I were inclined to regret it — for I see that my letter did cause you sorrow though only for a time —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:9] I am glad now; not because of the sorrow it caused you, but because your sorrow brought you to repentance. For it was God’s will that you should feel sorrow, in order that you should not suffer loss in any way at our hands.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:10] For, when sorrow is in accordance with God’s will, it results in a repentance leading to salvation, and which will never be regretted. The sure result of the sorrow that the world knows is death.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:11] For see what results that other sorrow — sorrow in accordance with God’s will — has had in your case. What earnestness it produced! What explanations! What strong feeling! What alarm! What longing! What eagerness! What readiness to punish! You have proved yourselves altogether free from guilt in that matter.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:12] So, then, even though I did write to you, it was not for the sake of the wrong-doer, or of the man who was wronged, but to make you conscious, in the sight of God, of your own earnest care for us. And it is this that has encouraged us.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:13] In addition to the encouragement that this gave us, we were made far happier still by the happiness of Titus for his heart has been cheered by you all.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:14] Although I have been boasting a little to him about you, you did not put me to shame; but, just as every thing we had said to you was true, so our boasting to Titus about you has also proved to be the truth.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:15] And his affection for you is all the greater, as he remembers the deference that you all showed him, and recalls how you received him with anxious care.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 7:16] I am glad that I can feel perfect confidence in you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:1] We want to remind you, friends, of the love that God has shown to the churches in Macedonia —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:2] How, tired though they were by many a trouble, their overflowing happiness, and even their deep poverty, resulted in a flood of generosity.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:3] I can bear witness that to the full extent of their power, and even beyond their power, spontaneously,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:4] and with many an appeal to us for permission, they showed their love, and contributed their share towards the fund for their fellow Christians.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:5] And that, not only in the way we had expected; but first they gave themselves to the Lord, and to us also, in accordance with God’s will.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:6] And this led us beg Titus, since he had started the work for you, he should also see to the completion of this expression of your love.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:7] And, remembering how you excel in everything — in faith, in teaching, in knowledge, in unfailing earnestness, and in the affection that we have awakened in you — I ask you to excel also in this expression of your love.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:8] I am not laying a command on you, but I am making use of the earnestness shown by others to test the genuineness of your affection.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:9] For you do not forget the loving kindness of our Lord Jesus Christ — how that for your sakes, although he was rich, he became poor, so that you also might become rich through his poverty.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:10] I am only making suggestions on this matter; for this is the best course for you, since you were a year before others, not only in taking action, but also in showing your readiness to do so.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:11] And now I want you to complete the work, so that its completion may correspond with your willing readiness — in proportion, of course, to your means.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:12] For, where there is willingness, a person’s gift is valued by its comparison with what they have, and not with what they do not have.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:13] For our object is not to give relief to others and bring distress on you. It is a matter of a fair balance.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:14] On this occasion what you can spare will supply what they need, at another time what they can spare may supply your need, and so things will be equal.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:15] As scripture says — ‘Those who had much had nothing over, and those who had little did not lack!’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:16] I thank God for inspiring Titus with the same keen interest in your welfare that I have;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:17] for Titus has responded to my appeals and, in his great earnestness, is starting to go to you of his own accord.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:18] We are sending with him one of the Lord's followers whose fame in the service of the good news has spread through all the churches;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:19] and not only that, but he has been elected by the churches to accompany us on our journey, in connexion with this expression of your love, which we are personally administering to the honour of the Lord, and to show our deep interest.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:20] What we are specially guarding against is that any fault should be found with us in regard to our administration of this charitable fund;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:21] for we are trying to make arrangements which will be right, not only in the eyes of the Lord, but also in the eyes of people.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:22] We are also sending with them another of our friends, whose earnestness we have many a time proved in many ways, and whom we now find made even more earnest by his great confidence in you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:23] If I must say anything about Titus, he is my intimate companion, and he shares my work for you; if it is our friends, they are delegates of the churches, an honour to Christ.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 8:24] Show them, therefore — so that the churches may see it — ​the proof of your affection, and the ground for our boasting to them about you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:1] With reference, indeed, to the Fund for your fellow Christians, it is quite superfluous for me to say anything to you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:2] I know, of course, your willingness to help, and I am always boasting of it to the Macedonians. I tell them that you in Greece have been ready for a year past; and it was really your zeal that stimulated most of them.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:3] So my reason for sending our friends is to prevent what we said about you from proving, in this particular matter, an empty boast, and to enable you to be as well prepared as I have been saying that you are.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:4] Otherwise, if any Macedonians were to come with me, and find you unprepared, we — to say nothing of you — should feel ashamed of our present confidence.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:5] Therefore I think it necessary to beg the friends to go to you in advance, and to complete the arrangements for the gift, which you have already promised, so that it may be ready, as a gift, before I come, and not look as if it were being given under pressure.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:6] Remember the saying — ‘Scanty sowing, scanty harvest; plentiful sowing, plentiful harvest.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:7] Let everyone give as he has determined before hand, not grudgingly or under compulsion; for God loves ‘a cheerful giver.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:8] God has power to shower all kinds of blessings on you, so that, having, under all circumstances and on all occasions, all that you can need, you may be able to shower all kinds of benefits on others.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:9] (As scripture says — ‘He scattered broadcast, he gave to the poor; His righteousness continues for ever.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:10] And he who supplies ‘seed to the sower, and bread for eating,’ will supply you with seed, and cause it to increase, and will multiply ‘the fruits of your righteousness’).
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:11] Rich in all things yourselves, you will be able to show liberality to all, which, with our help, will cause thanksgiving to be offered to God.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:12] For the rendering of a public service such as this, not only relieves the needs of your fellow Christians, but also results in the offering to God of many a thanksgiving.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:13] Through the evidence afforded by the service ​rendered, you cause people to praise God for your fidelity to your profession of faith in the good news of the Christ, as well as for the liberality of your contributions for them and for all others.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:14] And they also, in their prayers for you, express their longing to see you, because of the surpassing love of God displayed toward you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 9:15] All thanks to God for his inestimable gift!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:1] Now, I, Paul, make a personal appeal to you by the meekness and gentleness of the Christ — I who, “in your presence, am humble in my bearing towards you, but, when absent, am bold in my language to you” —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:2] I implore you not to drive me to “show my boldness,” when I do come, by the confident tone which I expect to have to adopt towards some of you, who are expecting to find us influenced in our conduct by earthly motives.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:3] For, though we live an earthly life, we do not wage an earthly war.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:4] The weapons for our warfare are not earthly, but, under God, are powerful enough to pull down strongholds.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:5] We are engaged in confuting arguments and pulling down every barrier raised against the knowledge of God. We are taking captive every hostile thought, to bring it into submission to the Christ,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:6] and are fully prepared to punish every act of rebellion, when once your submission is complete.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:7] You look at the outward appearance of things! Let anyone, who is confident that he belongs to Christ, reflect, for himself, again on the fact — that we belong to Christ no less than he does.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:8] Even if I boast extravagantly about our authority — which the Lord gave us for building up your faith and not for overthrowing it — still I have no reason to be ashamed.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:9] I say this so that it doesn't seem as if I am trying to overawe you by my letters.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:10] For people say “His letters are impressive and vigorous, but his personal appearance is insignificant and his speaking contemptible.”
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:11] Let such a person be assured of this — that our words in our letters show us to be, when absent, just what our deeds will show us to be, when present.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:12] We have not indeed the audacity to class or compare ourselves with some of those who indulge in self-commendation! But, when such persons measure themselves by themselves, and compare themselves with themselves, they show a want of wisdom.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:13] We, however, will not give way to unlimited boasting, but will confine ourselves to the limits of the sphere to which God limited us, when he permitted us to come as far as Corinth.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:14] For it is not the case, as it would be if we were not in the habit of coming to you, that we are exceeding our bounds! Why, we were the very first to reach you with the good news of the Christ!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:15] Our boasting, therefore, is not unlimited, nor does it extend to the labours of others; but our hope is that, as your faith grows, our influence among you may be very greatly increased — ​though still confined to our sphere —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:16] So that we will be able to tell the good news in the districts beyond you, without trespassing on the sphere assigned to others, or boasting of what has been already done.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:17] ‘Let anyone who boasts make their boast of the Lord.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 10:18] For it is not those who commend themselves that stand the test, but those who are commended by the Lord.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:1] I could wish that you would tolerate a little folly in me! But indeed you do tolerate me.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:2] I am jealous over you with the jealousy of God. For I engaged you to one husband so that I might present you to the Christ a pure bride.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:3] Yet I fear that it may turn out that, just as the snake by his craftiness deceived Eve, so your minds may have lost the loyalty and purity due from you to the Christ.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:4] For, if some newcomer is proclaiming a Jesus other than him whom we proclaimed, or if you are receiving a Spirit different from the Spirit which you received, or a good news different from that which you welcomed, then you are marvellously tolerant!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:5] I do not regard myself as in any way inferior to the most eminent apostles!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:6] Though I am no trained orator, yet I am not without knowledge; indeed we made this perfectly clear to you in every way.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:7] Perhaps you say that I did wrong in humbling myself that you might be exalted — I mean because I told you God’s good news without payment.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:8] I robbed other churches by taking pay from them, so that I might serve you!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:9] And, when I was with you in need, I did not become a burden to any of you; for our friends, on coming from Macedonia, supplied my needs. I kept myself, and will keep myself from being an expense to you in any way.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:10] As surely as I know anything of the truth of Christ, this boast, as far as I am concerned, will not be stopped in any part of Greece.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:11] Why? Because I do not love you? God knows that I do!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:12] What I am doing now I will continue to do in order to cut away the ground from under those who are wishing for some ground for attacking me, so that as regards the thing of which they boast they may appear in their true characters, just as we do.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:13] Such people are false apostles, treacherous workers, disguising themselves as apostles of Christ!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:14] And no wonder; for even Satan disguises himself as an angel of light.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:15] It is not surprising, therefore, if his servants also disguise themselves as servants of righteousness. But their end will be in accordance with their actions.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:16] I say again — Let no one think me a fool! Yet, if you do, at least welcome me as you would a fool, so that I, too may indulge in a little boasting.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:17] When I speak like this, I am not speaking as the Master would, but as a fool might, in boasting so confidently.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:18] As so many are boasting of earthly things, I, too, will boast.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:19] For all your cleverness, you tolerate fools willingly enough!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:20] You tolerate a person even when they enslave you, when they plunder you, when they get you into their power, when they put on airs of superiority, when they strike you in the face!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:21] I admit, to my shame, that we have been weak. But whatever the subject on which others are not afraid to boast — though it is foolish to say so — I am not afraid either!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:22] Are they Hebrews? So am I! Are they Israelites? So am I! Are they descendants of Abraham? So am I!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:23] Are they ‘Servants of Christ’? Though it is madness to talk like this, I am more so than they! I have had more of toil, more of imprisonment! I have been flogged times without number. I have been often at death’s door.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:24] Five times I received at the hands of my own people forty lashes, all but one.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:25] Three times I was beaten with rods. Once I was stoned. Three times I was shipwrecked. I have spent a whole day and night in the deep.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:26] My journeys have been many. I have been through dangers from rivers, dangers from robbers, dangers from my own people, dangers from the Gentiles, dangers in towns, dangers in the country, dangers on the sea, dangers among people pretending to be followers of the Lord.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:27] I have been through toil and hardship. I have passed many a sleepless night; I have endured hunger and thirst; I have often been without food; I have known cold and nakedness.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:28] And, not to speak of other things, there is my daily burden of anxiety about all the churches.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:29] Who is weak without my being weak? Who is led astray without my burning with indignation?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:30] If I must boast, I will boast of things which show my weakness!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:31] The God and Father of the Lord Jesus — he who is for ever blessed — knows that I am speaking the truth.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:32] When I was in Damascus, the Governor under King Aretas had the gates of that city guarded, so as to arrest me,
[OEBcw - 2Cor 11:33] but I was let down in a basket through a window in the wall, and so escaped his hands.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:1] I must boast! It is unprofitable; but I will pass to visions and revelations given by the Lord.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:2] I know a man in union with Christ, who, fourteen years ago — ​whether in the body or out of the body I do not know; God knows — ​was caught up (this man of whom I am speaking) to the third heaven.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:3] And I know that this man — whether in the body or separated from the body I do not know; God knows —
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:4] Was caught up into Paradise, and heard unspeakable things of which no human being may tell.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:5] About such a man I will boast, but about myself I will not boast except as regards my weaknesses.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:6] Yet if I choose to boast, I will not be a fool; for I will be speaking no more than the truth. But I refrain, in case anyone should credit me with more than he can see in me or hear from me, and because of the marvellous character of the revelations.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:7] It was for this reason, and to prevent my thinking too highly of myself, that a thorn was sent to pierce my flesh — an instrument of Satan to discipline me — so that I should not think too highly of myself.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:8] About this I three times entreated the Lord, praying that it might leave me.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:9] But his reply has been — ‘My help is enough for you; for my strength attains its perfection in the midst of weakness.’ Most gladly, then, will I boast all the more of my weaknesses, so that the strength of the Christ may overshadow me.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:10] That is why I delight in weakness, ill treatment, hardship, persecution, and difficulties, when borne for Christ. For, when I am weak, then it is that I am strong!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:11] I have been “playing the fool!” It is you who drove me to it. For it is you who ought to have been commending me! Although I am nobody, in no respect did I prove inferior to the most eminent apostles.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:12] The marks of the true apostle were exhibited among you in constant endurance, as well as by signs, by marvels, and by miracles.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:13] In what respect, I ask, were you treated worse than the other churches, unless it was that, for my part, I refused to become a burden to you? Forgive me the wrong I did to you!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:14] Remember, this is the third time that I have made every preparation to come to see you, and I will refuse to be a burden to you; I want, not your money, but you. It is not the duty of children to put by for their parents, but of parents to put by for their children.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:15] For my part, I will most gladly spend, and be spent, for your welfare. Can it be that the more intensely I love you the less I am to be loved?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:16] You will admit that I was not a burden to you but you say that I was “crafty” and caught you “by a trick”!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:17] Do you assert that I took advantage of you through any of those whom I have sent to you?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:18] I urged Titus to go, and I sent another follower with him. Did Titus take any advantage of you? Did not we live in the same Spirit, and tread in the same footsteps?
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:19] Have you all this time been fancying that it is to you that we are making our defence? No, it is in the sight of God, and in union with Christ, that we are speaking. And all this, dear friends, is to build up your characters;
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:20] for I am afraid that perhaps, when I come, I may find that you are not what I want you to be, and, on the other hand, that you may find that I am what you do not want me to be. I am afraid that I may find quarrelling, jealousy, ill feeling, rivalry, slandering, backbiting, self-assertion, and disorder.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 12:21] I am afraid that, on my next visit, my God may humble me in regard to you, and that I may have to mourn over many who have long been sinning, and have not repented of the impurity, immorality, and sensuality, in which they have indulged.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:1] For the third time I am coming to see you. ‘By the word of two or three witnesses each statement will be established.’
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:2] I have said it, and I say it again before I come, just as if I were with you on my second visit, though for the moment absent, I say to those who have been long sinning, as well as to all others — that if I come again, I will spare no one.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:3] And that will be the proof, which you are looking for, that the Christ speaks through me. There is no weakness in his dealings with you. No, he shows his power among you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:4] For though his crucifixion was due to weakness, his life is due to the power of God. And we, also, are weak in his weakness, but with him we will live for you through the power of God.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:5] Put yourselves to the proof, to see whether you are holding to the faith. Test yourselves. Surely you recognise this fact about yourselves — that Jesus Christ is in you! Unless indeed you cannot stand the test!
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:6] But I hope that you will recognise that we can stand the test.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:7] We pray God that you may do nothing wrong, not that we may be seen to stand the test, but that you may do what is right, even though we may seem not to stand the test.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:8] We have no power at all against the truth, but we have power in the service of the truth.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:9] We are glad when we are weak, if you are strong. And what we pray for is that you may become perfect.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:10] This is my reason for writing as I am now doing, while I am away from you, so that, when I am with you, I may not act harshly in the exercise of the authority which the Lord gave me — and gave me for building up and not for pulling down.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:11] And now, friends, goodbye. Aim at perfection; take courage; agree together; live in peace. And then God, the source of all love and peace, will be with you.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:12] Greet one another with a sacred kiss.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:13] All Christ’s people here send you their greetings.
[OEBcw - 2Cor 13:14] May the blessing of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion with the Holy Spirit, be with you all.
[OEBcw - Gal 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Gal 1:1] To the churches in Galatia, from Paul, an apostle whose commission is not from any human authority and is given, not by human beings, but by Jesus Christ and God the Father who raised him from the dead;
[OEBcw - Gal 1:2] and from all the followers of the Lord here.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:3] May God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ, bless you and give you peace. For Christ, to rescue us from this present wicked age,
[OEBcw - Gal 1:4] gave himself for our sins, in accordance with the will of God and Father,
[OEBcw - Gal 1:5] to whom be ascribed all glory for ever and ever. Amen.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:6] I am astonished at your so soon deserting him, who called you through the love of Christ, for a different ‘good news,’
[OEBcw - Gal 1:7] Which is really no good news at all. But then, I know that there are people who are harassing you, and who want to pervert the good news of the Christ.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:8] Yet even if we — or if an angel from heaven were to tell you any other ‘good news’ than that which we told you, may he be accursed!
[OEBcw - Gal 1:9] We have said it before, and I repeat it now — If anyone tells you a ‘good news’ other than that which you received, may he be accursed!
[OEBcw - Gal 1:10] Is this, I ask, trying to conciliate people, or God? Am I seeking to please people? If I were still trying to please people, I should not be a servant of Christ.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:11] I ​remind you, friends, that the good news which I told is no mere human invention.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:12] I, at least, did not receive it from any human being, nor was I taught it, but it came to me through a revelation made by Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:13] You heard, no doubt, of my conduct when I was devoted to Judaism — how I persecuted the church of God to an extent beyond belief, and made havoc of it,
[OEBcw - Gal 1:14] and how, in my devotion to Judaism, I surpassed many of my contemporaries among my own people in my intense earnestness in upholding the traditions of my ancestors.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:15] But when God, who had set me apart even before my birth, and who called me by his love,
[OEBcw - Gal 1:16] saw fit to reveal his Son in me, so that I might tell the good news of him among the Gentiles, then at once, instead of consulting any human being,
[OEBcw - Gal 1:17] or even going up to Jerusalem to see those who were apostles before me, I went to Arabia, and came back again to Damascus.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:18] Three years afterwards I went up to Jerusalem to make the acquaintance of Peter, and I stayed a fortnight with him.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:19] I did not, however, see any other apostle, except James, the Master’s brother.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:20] (As to what I am now writing to you, I call God to witness that I am speaking the truth).
[OEBcw - Gal 1:21] Afterwards I went to the districts of Syria and Cilicia.
[OEBcw - Gal 1:22] But I was still unknown even by sight to the Christian churches in Judea;
[OEBcw - Gal 1:23] all that they had heard was — ‘The man who once persecuted us is now telling the good news of the ​faith of which he once made havoc.’
[OEBcw - Gal 1:24] And they praised God for my sake.
[OEBcw - Gal 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - Gal 2:1] Fourteen years afterwards I went up to Jerusalem again with Barnabas, and I took Titus also with me.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:2] It was in obedience to a revelation that I went; and I laid before the apostles the good news that I am proclaiming among the Gentiles. I did this privately before those who are thought highly of because I was afraid that I might possibly be taking, or might have already taken, a course which would prove useless.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:3] Yet even my companion, Titus, though a Greek, was not compelled to be circumcised.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:4] But, because of those who pretended to be followers who had stolen in, the intruders who had crept in to spy on the liberty which we have through union with Christ Jesus, in order to bring us back to slavery —
[OEBcw - Gal 2:5] Why, we did not for a moment yield submission to them, so that the truth of the good news might be yours always!
[OEBcw - Gal 2:6] Of those who are thought somewhat highly of — what they once were makes no difference to me; God does not recognise human distinctions — those, I say, who are thought highly of added nothing to my message.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:7] On the contrary, they saw that I had been entrusted with the good news for the Gentiles, just as Peter had been for the Jews.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:8] For he who gave Peter power for his mission to the Jews gave me, also, power to go to the Gentiles.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:9] Recognising the charge entrusted to me, James, Peter, and John, who were regarded as pillars of the church, openly acknowledged Barnabas and me as fellow workers, agreeing that we should go to the Gentiles, and they to the Jews.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:10] Only we were to remember the poor — the ​thing I was myself anxious to do.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:11] But, when Peter came to Antioch, I opposed him to his face; for he stood self-condemned.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:12] Before certain persons came from James, he had been in the habit of eating with the Gentile converts; but, when they came, he began to withdraw and hold aloof, because he was afraid of offending those who still held to circumcision.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:13] The rest of the Jewish converts were guilty of the same hypocrisy, so that even Barnabas was led away by it.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:14] But, when I saw that they were not dealing straightforwardly with the truth of the good news, I said to Peter, before them all, “If you, who were born a Jew, adopt Gentile customs, instead of Jewish, why are you trying to compel the Gentile converts to adopt Jewish customs?”
[OEBcw - Gal 2:15] We, though we are Jews by birth and not outcasts of Gentile origin, know that no one is pronounced righteous as the result of obedience to law, but only through faith in Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:16] So we placed our faith in Christ Jesus, in order that we might be pronounced righteous, as the result of faith in Christ, and not of obedience to law; for such obedience ‘will not result in even one soul’s being pronounced righteous.’
[OEBcw - Gal 2:17] If, while seeking to be pronounced righteous through union with Christ, we were ourselves seen to be outcasts, would that make Christ an agent of sin? Heaven forbid!
[OEBcw - Gal 2:18] For, if I rebuild the ​things that I pulled down, I prove myself to have done wrong.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:19] I, indeed, through law became dead to law, in order to live for God.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:20] I have been crucified with Christ. So it is no longer I that live, but it is Christ who lives in me; and, as for my present earthly life, I am living it by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave himself for me.
[OEBcw - Gal 2:21] I do not reject the love of God. If righteousness comes through law, then there was no need for Christ to die!
[OEBcw - Gal 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - Gal 3:1] Foolish Galatians! Who has been fascinating you — you before whose ​eyes Jesus Christ was depicted on the cross?
[OEBcw - Gal 3:2] Here is the one thing that I want to find out from you — Did you receive the Spirit as the result of obedience to law, or of your having listened with faith?
[OEBcw - Gal 3:3] Can you be so foolish? After beginning with what is spiritual, do you now end with what is external?
[OEBcw - Gal 3:4] Did you go through so much to no purpose? — if indeed it really was to no purpose!
[OEBcw - Gal 3:5] He who supplies you abundantly with his Spirit and endows you with such powers — does he do this as the result of obedience to law? Or as the result of your having listened with faith?
[OEBcw - Gal 3:6] It is just as it was with Abraham — ‘He had faith in God, and his faith was regarded by God as righteousness.’
[OEBcw - Gal 3:7] You see, then, that those whose lives are based on faith are the sons of Abraham.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:8] And scripture, foreseeing that God would pronounce the Gentiles righteous as the result of faith, foretold the good news to Abraham in the words — ‘Through you all the Gentiles will be blessed.’
[OEBcw - Gal 3:9] And, therefore, those whose lives are based on faith share the blessings bestowed on the faith of Abraham.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:10] All who rely on obedience to law are under a curse, for scripture says — ‘Cursed is everyone who does not abide by all that is written in the book of the law, and do it.’
[OEBcw - Gal 3:11] Again, it is evident that no one is pronounced righteous before God through law, for we read — ‘Through faith the righteous will find life.’
[OEBcw - Gal 3:12] But the law is not based on faith; no, its words are — ‘Those who practice these precepts will find life through them.’
[OEBcw - Gal 3:13] Christ ransomed us from the curse pronounced in the law, by taking the curse on himself for us, for scripture says — ‘Cursed is anyone who is hanged on a tree.’
[OEBcw - Gal 3:14] And this he did that the blessing given to Abraham might be extended to the Gentiles through their union with Jesus Christ; that so, through our faith, we also might receive the promised gift of the Spirit.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:15] To take an illustration, friends, from daily life — No one sets aside even an agreement between two people, when once it has been confirmed, nor do they add conditions to it.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:16] Now it was to Abraham that the promises were made, ‘and to his offspring.’ It was not said ‘to his offsprings,’ as if many persons were meant, but the words were ‘to your offspring,’ showing that one person was meant — and that was Christ.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:17] My point is this — An agreement already confirmed by God cannot be canceled by the law, which came four hundred and thirty years later, so as to cause the promise to be set aside.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:18] If our heritage is the result of law, then it has ceased to be the result of a promise. Yet God conferred it on Abraham by a promise.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:19] What, then, you ask, was the use of the law? It was a later addition, to make people conscious of their wrong-doings, and intended to last only until the coming of that ‘offspring’ to whom the promise had been made; and it was delivered through angels by a mediator.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:20] Now mediation implies more than one person, but God is one only.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:21] Does that set the law in opposition to God’s promises? Heaven forbid! For, if a law had been given capable of bestowing life, then righteousness would have actually owed its existence to law.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:22] But the words of scripture represent the whole world as being in bondage to sin, so that the promised blessing, dependent, as it is, on faith in Jesus Christ, may be given to those who have faith in him.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:23] Before the coming of faith, we were kept under the guard of the law, in bondage, awaiting the faith that was destined to be revealed.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:24] Thus the law has proved a guide to lead us to Christ, in order that we may be pronounced righteous as the result of faith.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:25] But now that faith has come we no longer need a guide.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:26] For you are all sons of God, through your faith in Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:27] For all of you who were baptized into union with Christ clothed yourselves with Christ.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:28] All distinctions between Jew and Greek, slave and free, male and female, have vanished; for in union with Christ Jesus you are all one.
[OEBcw - Gal 3:29] And, since you belong to Christ, it follows that you are Abraham’s offspring and, under the promise, sharers in the inheritance.
[OEBcw - Gal 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - Gal 4:1] My point is this — As long as the heir is under age, there is no difference between him and a slave, though he is master of the whole estate.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:2] He is subject to the control of guardians and stewards, during the period for which his father has power to appoint them.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:3] And so is it with us; when we were under age, as it were, we were slaves to the puerile teaching of this world;
[OEBcw - Gal 4:4] but, when the full time came, God sent his Son — born a woman’s child, born subject to law —
[OEBcw - Gal 4:5] To ransom those who were subject to law, so that we might take our position as sons.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:6] And it is because you are sons that God sent into our hearts the Spirit of his Son, with the cry — ‘Abba, our Father.’
[OEBcw - Gal 4:7] You, therefore, are no longer a slave, but a son; and, if a son, then an heir also, by God’s appointment.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:8] Yet formerly, in your ignorance of God, you became slaves to ‘gods’ which were no gods.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:9] But now that you have found God — or, rather, have been found by him — how is it that you are turning back to that poor and feeble puerile teaching, to which yet once again you are wanting to become slaves?
[OEBcw - Gal 4:10] You are scrupulous in keeping days and months and seasons and years!
[OEBcw - Gal 4:11] You make me fear that the labour which I have spent on you may have been wasted.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:12] I entreat you, friends, to become like me, as I became like you. You have never done me any wrong.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:13] You remember that it was owing to bodily infirmity that on the first occasion I told you the good news.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:14] And as for what must have tried you in my condition, it did not inspire you with scorn or disgust, but you welcomed me as if I had been an angel of God — or Christ Jesus himself!
[OEBcw - Gal 4:15] What has become then, of your blessings? For I can bear witness that, had it been possible, you would have torn out your eyes and given them to me!
[OEBcw - Gal 4:16] Am I to think, then, that I have become your enemy by telling you the truth?
[OEBcw - Gal 4:17] Certain people are seeking your favour, but with no honourable object. No, indeed, they want to isolate you, so that you will have to seek their favour.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:18] It is always honourable to have your favour sought in an honourable cause, and not only when I am with you, my dear children —
[OEBcw - Gal 4:19] You for whom I am again enduring a mother’s pains, until a likeness to Christ will have been formed in you.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:20] But I could wish to be with you now and speak in a different tone, for I am perplexed about you.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:21] Tell me, you who want to be still subject to law — Why do not you listen to the law?
[OEBcw - Gal 4:22] scripture says that Abraham had two sons, one the child of the slave-woman and the other the child of the free woman.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:23] But the child of the slave-woman was born in the course of nature, while the child of the free woman was born in fulfilment of a promise.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:24] This story may be taken as an allegory. The women stand for two Covenants. One covenant, given from Mount Sinai, produces a race of slaves and is represented by Hagar
[OEBcw - Gal 4:25] (The word Hagar meaning in Arabia Mount Sinai) and it ranks with the Jerusalem of today, for she and her children are in slavery.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:26] But the Jerusalem above is free, and she it is who is our mother.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:27] For scripture says — ‘Rejoice, you barren one, who does never bear, Break into shouts, you who are never in labour, For many are the children of her who is desolate — aye, more than of her who has a husband.’
[OEBcw - Gal 4:28] As for ourselves, friends, we, like Isaac, are children born in fulfilment of a promise.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:29] Yet at that time the child born in the course of nature persecuted the child born by the power of the Spirit; and it is the same now.
[OEBcw - Gal 4:30] But what does the passage of scripture say? ‘Send away the slave-woman and her son; for the slave’s son will not be coheir with the son of the free woman.’
[OEBcw - Gal 4:31] And so, friends, we are not children of a slave, but of her who is free.
[OEBcw - Gal 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - Gal 5:1] It is for freedom that Christ set us free; stand firm therefore, and do not again be held under the yoke of slavery.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:2] Understand that I, Paul, myself tell you that if you allow yourselves to be circumcised, Christ will avail you nothing.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:3] I again declare to everyone who receives circumcision, that he binds himself to obey the whole law.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:4] You have severed yourselves from Christ — you who are seeking to be pronounced righteous through law; you have fallen away from love.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:5] For we, by the help of the Spirit, are eagerly waiting for the fulfilment of our hope — that we may be pronounced righteous as the result of faith.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:6] If we are in union with Christ Jesus, neither is circumcision nor the omission of it anything, but faith, working through love, is everything.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:7] You were once making good progress! Who has hindered you from obeying the truth?
[OEBcw - Gal 5:8] The persuasion brought to bear on you does not come from him who calls you.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:9] A little leaven leavens all the dough.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:10] I, through my union with the Lord, am persuaded that you will learn to think with me. But the man who is disturbing your minds will have to bear his punishment, whoever he may be.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:11] If I, friends, am still proclaiming circumcision, why am I still persecuted? It seems that the cross has ceased to be an obstacle!
[OEBcw - Gal 5:12] I could even wish that the people who are unsettling you would go further still and mutilate themselves.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:13] Remember, friends, to you the call came to give you freedom. Only do not make your freedom an opportunity for self-indulgence, but serve one another in a loving spirit.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:14] Indeed, the whole law has been summed up in this one precept — ‘You must love your neighbour as you love yourself.’
[OEBcw - Gal 5:15] But, if you are continually wounding and preying on one another, take care that you are not destroyed by one another.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:16] This is what I have to say — Let your steps be guided by the Spirit, and then you will never gratify the cravings of your earthly nature.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:17] For these cravings of our earthly nature conflict with the Spirit, and the Spirit with our earthly nature — they are two contrary principles — so that you cannot do what you wish.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:18] But, if you follow the guidance of the Spirit, you are not subject to law.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:19] The sins of our earthly nature are unmistakable. They are sins like these — sexual immorality, impurity, indecency,
[OEBcw - Gal 5:20] idolatry, sorcery, quarrels, strife, jealousy, outbursts of passion, rivalries, dissensions, divisions,
[OEBcw - Gal 5:21] feelings of envy, drunkenness, revelry, and the like. And I warn you, as I warned you before, that those who indulge in such things will have no place in the kingdom of God.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:22] But the fruit produced by the Spirit is love, joy, peace, forbearance, kindliness, generosity, trustfulness, gentleness, self-control.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:23] Against such things there is no law!
[OEBcw - Gal 5:24] And those who belong to Jesus, the Christ, have already crucified their earthly nature, with its passions and its cravings.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:25] Since our life is due to the Spirit, let us rule our conduct also by the Spirit.
[OEBcw - Gal 5:26] Do not let us grow vain, and provoke or envy one another.
[OEBcw - Gal 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - Gal 6:1] My friends, even if someone should be caught committing a sin, you who are spiritually minded should, in a gentle spirit, help them to recover themselves, taking care that you yourselves are not tempted.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:2] Bear one another’s burdens, and so carry out the law of the Christ.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:3] If a person imagines themselves to be somebody, when they are really nobody, they deceive themselves.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:4] Let everyone test their own work, and then their cause for satisfaction will be in themselves and not in a comparison with their neighbour;
[OEBcw - Gal 6:5] for everyone must bear their own load.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:6] The person, however, who is being instructed in the message ought always to share their blessings with their teacher.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:7] Do not be deceived. God cannot be mocked. What a person sows that they will reap.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:8] For the person who sows the field of their earthly nature will from that earthly nature reap corruption; while the one who sows the field of the spirit will from that spirit reap eternal life.
[OEBcw - Gal 6:9] Let us never tire of doing right, for at the proper season we will reap our harvest, if we do not grow weary.
