[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:1] How true is this saying:‘To aspire to be to be a presiding officer in the church is to be ambitious for a noble task.’
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:2] The presiding officer should be ​of blameless character; a faithful partner; living a temperate, discreet, and well-ordered life; hospitable, and a skilful teacher,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:3] not addicted to drink or brawling, but of a forbearing and peaceable disposition, and not a lover of money;
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:4] they should provide for own household well, and their children should kept under control and be well-behaved.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:5] If someone does not know how to provide for their own household, how can they take charge of the church of God?
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:6] The presiding officer should not be a recent convert, or they might become blinded by pride and fall under the same condemnation as the devil.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:7] They should also be well spoken of by outsiders, so that they may not incur censure and so fall into the devil's trap.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:8] So, too, assistant officers should be serious and straightforward, not given to taking much drink or to questionable money-making,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:9] but people who hold the deep truths of the faith and have a clear conscience.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:10] They should be tested first, and only appointed to their office if no objection is raised against them.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:11] It should be the same with the women in this office. They should be serious, not gossips, sober, and trustworthy in all respects.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:12] Assistant officers should be faithful partners who manage their children and their households well.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:13] Those who have filled that post with honour gain for themselves an honourable position, as well as great confidence through the faith that they place in Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:14] I am writing this to you, though I hope that I will come to see you before long;
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:15] but in case I should be delayed, I want you to know what your conduct ought to be in the Household of God, which is the church of the living God — the pillar and stay of the truth.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 3:16] Yes, and confessedly wonderful are the deep truths of our religion; for — ‘He was revealed in our nature, Pronounced righteous in spirit, Seen by angels, Proclaimed among the Gentiles, Believed on in the world, Taken up into glory.’
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:1] But the Spirit distinctly says that in later times there will be some who will fall away from the faith, and devote their attention to misleading spirits, and to the teaching of demons,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:2] who will make use of the hypocrisy of lying teachers. These people’s consciences are seared,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:3] and they discourage marriage and enjoin abstinence from certain kinds of food; though God created these foods to be enjoyed thankfully by those who hold the faith and have attained a full knowledge of the truth.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:4] Everything created by God is good, and there in nothing that need be rejected — provided only that it is received thankfully;
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:5] for it is consecrated by God’s blessing and by prayer.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:6] Put all this before the followers, and you will be a good servant of Christ Jesus, sustained by the precepts of the faith and of that good teaching by which you have guided your life.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:7] As for profane legends and old wives’ tales, leave them alone. Train yourself to lead a religious life;
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:8] for while the training of the body is of service in some respects, religion is of service in all, carrying with it, as it does, a promise of life both here and hereafter.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:9] How true that saying is and worthy of the fullest acceptance!
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:10] With that aim we toil and struggle, for we have set our hopes on the living God, who is the Saviour of all, and especially of those who hold the faith.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:11] Remember these things in your teaching.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:12] Do not let anyone look down on you because you are young, but, by your conversation, your conduct, your love, your faith, and your purity, be an example to those who hold the faith.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:13] Until I come, apply yourself to public reading, preaching, and teaching.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:14] Do not neglect the divine gift within you, which was given you, amid many a prediction, when the hands of the officers of the church were laid on your head.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:15] Practice these things, devote yourself to them, so that your progress may be plain to everyone.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 4:16] Look to yourself as well as to your teaching. Persevere in this, for your doing so will mean salvation for yourself as well as for your hearers.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:1] Do not reprimand an older man, but plead with him as if he were your father. Treat the young men as brothers,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:2] the older women as mothers, and the younger women as sisters — with all purity.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:3] Show consideration for widows — I mean those who are really widowed.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:4] but, if a widow has children or grandchildren, let them learn to show proper regard for the members of their own family first, and to make some return to their parents; for that is pleasing in God’s sight.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:5] As for the woman who is really widowed and left quite alone, her hopes are fixed on God, and she devotes herself to prayers and supplications night and day.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:6] But the life of a widow who is devoted to pleasure is a living death.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:7] Those are the points you should teach, so that there may be no call for your censure.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:8] Anyone who fails to provide for their own relations, and especially for those under their own roof, has disowned the faith, and is worse than an unbeliever.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:9] A widow, when her name is added to the list, should not be less than sixty years old; she should have been a faithful wife,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:10] and be well spoken of for her kind actions. She should have brought up children, have shown hospitality to strangers, have washed the feet of her fellow Christians, have relieved those who were in distress, and devoted herself to every kind of good action.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:11] But you should exclude the younger widows from the list; for, when they grow restive under the yoke of the Christ, they want to marry,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:12] and so they bring condemnation on themselves for having broken their previous promise.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:13] And not only that, but they learn to be idle as they go about from house to house. Nor are they merely idle, but they also become gossips and busybodies, and talk of what they ought not.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:14] Therefore I advise young widows to marry, bear children, and attend to their homes, and so avoid giving the enemy an opportunity for scandal.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:15] There are some who have already left us, to follow Satan.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:16] Any Christian woman, who has relations who are widows, ought to relieve them and not allow them to become a burden to the church, so that the church may relieve those widows who are really widowed.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:17] Those officers of the church who fill their office well should be held deserving of especial consideration, particularly those whose work lies in preaching and teaching.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:18] The words of scripture are — ‘You should not muzzle the ox while it is treading out the grain.’ and again —  ‘The worker is worth their wages.’
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:19] Do not receive a charge against an officer of the church, unless it is supported by two or three witnesses;
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:20] but rebuke offenders publicly, so that others may take warning.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:21] I charge you solemnly, before God and Christ Jesus and the chosen angels, to carry out these directions, unswayed by prejudice, never acting with partiality.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:22] Never ordain anyone hastily, and take no part in the wrong-doing of others. Keep your life pure.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:23] Do not continue to drink water only, but take a little wine because of the weakness of your stomach, and your frequent ailments.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:24] There are some people whose sins are conspicuous and lead on to judgment, while there are others whose sins dog their steps.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 5:25] In the same way noble deeds become conspicuous, and those which are otherwise cannot be concealed.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:1] All who are in the position of slaves should regard their masters as deserving of the greatest respect, so that the name of God, and our teaching, may not be maligned.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:2] Those who have Christian masters should not think less of them because they are also followers of Christ, but on the contrary they should serve them all the better, because those who are to benefit by their good work are dear to them as their fellow Christians.Those are the things to insist on in your teaching.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:3] Anyone who teaches otherwise, and refuses their assent to sound instruction — the instruction of our Lord Jesus Christ — and to the teaching of religion,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:4] is puffed up with conceit, not really knowing anything, but having a morbid craving for discussions and arguments. Such things only give rise to envy, quarrelling, recriminations, base suspicions,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:5] and incessant wrangling on the part of these corrupt-minded people who have lost all hold on the truth, and who think of religion only as a source of gain.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:6] And a great source of gain religion is, when it brings contentment with it!
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:7] For we brought nothing into the world, because we cannot even carry anything out of it.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:8] So, with food and shelter, we will be content.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:9] Those who want to be rich fall into the net of temptation, and become the prey of many foolish and harmful ambitions, which plunge people into destruction and ruin.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:10] Love of money is a source of all kinds of evil; and in their eagerness to be rich some have wandered away from the faith, and have been pierced to the heart by many a regret.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:11] But you must, servant of God, avoid all this. Aim at righteousness, piety, faith, love, endurance, gentleness.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:12] Run the great race of the faith, and win the eternal life. It was for this that you received the call, and, in the presence of many witnesses, made the great profession of faith.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:13] I beg you, as in the sight of God, the source of all life, and of Christ Jesus who before Pontius Pilate made the great profession of faith —
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:14] I implore you to keep his command free from stain or reproach, until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:15] This will be brought about in his own time by the one ever-blessed Potentate, the king of all kings and Lord of all lords,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:16] who alone is possessed of immortality and dwells in unapproachable light, whom no one has ever seen or ever can see — to whom be ascribed honour and power for ever. Amen.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:17] Teach those who are wealthy in this life not to pride themselves, or fix their hopes, on so uncertain a thing as wealth, but on God, who gives us a wealth of enjoyment on every side.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:18] Teach them to show kindness, to exhibit a wealth of good actions, to be open-handed and generous,
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:19] storing up for themselves what in the future will prove to be a good foundation, so that they may gain the only true life.
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:20] Timothy, guard what has been entrusted to you. Avoid the profane prattle and contradictions of what some miscall ‘theology,’
[OEBcw - 1Tim 6:21] for there are those who, while asserting their proficiency in it, have yet, as regards the faith, gone altogether astray. God bless you all.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:1] To Timothy, my dear child, from Paul who, by the will of God, is an apostle of Christ Jesus, charged to proclaim the life that comes from union with Christ Jesus. May God, the Father, and Christ Jesus, our Lord, bless you, and be merciful to you, and give you peace.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:2] 
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:3] I am thankful to God, whom I serve, as my ancestors did, with a clear conscience, when I remember you, as I never fail to do, in my prayers — night and day alike,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:4] as I think of your tears, longing to see you, that my happiness may be completed,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:5] now that I have been reminded of the sincere faith that you have shown. That faith was seen first in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice, and is now, I am convinced, in you also.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:6] And that is my reason for reminding you to stir into flame that gift of God, which is yours through your ordination at my hands.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:7] For the Spirit which God gave us was not a spirit of cowardice, but a spirit of power, love, and self-control.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:8] Do not, therefore, be ashamed of the testimony which we have to bear to our Lord, nor yet of me who am a prisoner for him; but join with me in suffering for the good news, as far as God enables you.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:9] It was God who saved us, and from him we received our solemn call — not as a reward for anything that we had done, but in fulfilment of his own loving purpose. For that love was extended to us, through Christ Jesus, before time began,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:10] and has now been made apparent through the appearing of our Saviour, Christ Jesus; who has made an end of death, and has brought life and Immortality to light by that good news,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:11] of which I was myself appointed a herald and apostle, and teacher.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:12] That is why I am undergoing these sufferings; yet I feel no shame, for I know in whom I have put my faith, and am convinced that he is able to guard what I have entrusted to him until ‘that day.’
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:13] Keep before you, as an example of sound teaching, all that you learnt from me as you listened with that faith and love which come from union with Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:14] Guard by the help of the Holy Spirit, who is within us, the glorious trust that has been committed to you.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:15] You know, of course, that all our friends in Roman Asia turned their backs on me, and among them Phygellus and Hermogenes.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:16] May the Lord show mercy to the household of Onesiphorus; for he often cheered me and was not ashamed of my chains.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:17] On the contrary, when he arrived in Rome, he sought eagerly for me until he found me.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 1:18] The Lord grant that he may find mercy at the hands of the Lord on ‘that day.’ The many services that he rendered at Ephesus you have the best means of knowing.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:1] You must, then, my child, find strength in the help which comes from the union with Christ Jesus;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:2] and what you learnt from me, in the presence of many listeners, entrust to reliable people, who will be able in their turn to teach others.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:3] Share hardships with me, as a true soldier of Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:4] A soldier on active service, to please his superior officer, always avoids entangling himself in the affairs of ordinary life.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:5] No athlete is ever awarded the wreath of victory unless they have kept the rules.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:6] The labourer who does the work should be the first to receive a share of the fruits of the earth.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:7] Reflect on what I say; the Lord will always help you to understand.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:8] Keep before your mind Jesus Christ, raised from the dead, a descendant of David, as told in the good news entrusted to me;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:9] in the service of which I am suffering hardships, even to being put in fetters as a criminal. But the message of God is not fettered;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:10] and that is why I submit to anything for the sake of God’s people: so that they also may obtain the salvation which comes from union with Christ Jesus, and imperishable glory.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:11] How true this saying is — ​‘If we have shared his death, we will also share his life.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:12] If we continue to endure, we will also share his throne. If we should ever disown him, he, too, will disown us.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:13] If we lose our trust, he is still to be trusted, for he cannot be false to himself!’
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:14] Remind people of all this; tell them solemnly, as in the sight of God, to avoid controversy, a useless thing and the ruin of those who listen to it.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:15] Do your utmost to show yourself true to God, a worker with no reason to be ashamed, accurate in delivering the message of the truth.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:16] Avoid profane prattle. Those who indulge in it only get deeper into irreligious ways,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:17] and their teaching will spread like a cancer. Hymenaeus and Philetus are instances of this.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:18] They have gone completely astray as regards the truth; they say that a resurrection has already taken place, and so upset some people’s faith.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:19] Yet God’s firm foundation still stands unmoved, and it bears this inscription — ‘THE LORD KNOWS THOSE WHO ARE HIS’; and this — ‘LET ALL THOSE WHO USE THE NAME OF THE LORD TURN AWAY FROM WICKEDNESS.’
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:20] Now in a large house there are not only things of gold and silver, but also others of wood and earthenware, some for better and some for common use.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:21] If, then, a person has escaped from the pollution of such errors as I have mentioned, they will be like a thing kept for better use, set apart, serviceable to its owner, ready for any good purpose.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:22] Flee from the passions of youth, but pursue righteousness, faith, love, and peace, in the company of those who, with a pure heart, invoke the Lord.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:23] Shun foolish and ignorant discussions, for you know that they only breed quarrels;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:24] and a servant of the Lord should never quarrel. They ought, on the contrary, to be courteous to everyone, skilful teachers, and forbearing.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:25] They should instruct their opponents in a gentle spirit; for, possibly, God may give those opponents a repentance that will lead to a fuller knowledge of truth,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 2:26] and they may yet come to a sober mind, and escape from the devil's net, when captured by the Lord’s servant to do the will of God.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:1] Be sure of this, that in the last days difficult times will come.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:2] People will be selfish, mercenary, boastful, haughty, and blasphemous; disobedient to their parents, ungrateful, impure,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:3] incapable of affection, merciless, slanderous, wanting in self-control, brutal, careless of the right,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:4] treacherous, reckless, and puffed up with pride; they will love pleasure more than they love God;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:5] and while they retain the outward form of religion, they will not allow it to influence them. Turn your back on such people as these.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:6] For among them are to be found those who creep into homes and captivate weak women — women who, loaded with sins, and slaves to all kinds of passions,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:7] are always learning, and yet never able to attain to a real knowledge of the truth.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:8] Just as Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses, so do these people, in their turn, oppose the truth. Their minds are corrupted, and, as regards the faith, they are utterly worthless.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:9] They will not, however, make further progress; for their wicked folly will be plain to everyone, just as the folly Jannes and Jambres was.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:10] But you, Timothy, were a close observer of my teaching, my conduct, my purposes, my faith, my forbearance, my love, and my patient endurance,
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:11] as well as of my persecutions, and of the sufferings which I met with at Antioch, Iconium, and Lystra. You know what persecutions I underwent; and yet the Lord brought me safe out of all!
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:12] Yes, and all who aim at living a religious life in union with Christ Jesus will have to suffer persecution;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:13] but wicked people and impostors will go from bad to worse, deceiving others and deceived themselves.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:14] You, however, must stand by what you learnt and accepted as true. You know who they were from whom you learnt it;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:15] and that, from your childhood, you have known the sacred writings, which can give you the wisdom that, through belief in Christ Jesus, leads to salvation.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:16] All scripture is God-breathed: helpful for teaching, for refuting error, for giving guidance, and for training others in righteousness;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 3:17] so that God’s people may be capable and equipped for good work of every kind.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:1] I solemnly charge you, in the sight of God and of Christ Jesus, who will one day judge the living and the dead — I charge you by his appearing and by his kingdom: —
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:2] Proclaim the message, be ready in season and out of season, convince, rebuke, encourage, never failing to instruct with forbearance.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:3] For a time will come when people will not tolerate sound teaching. They will follow their own wishes, and, in their itching for novelty, procure themselves a crowd of teachers.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:4] They will turn a deaf ear to the truth, and give their attention to legends instead.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:5] But you, Timothy, must always be temperate. Face hardships; do the work of a missionary; discharge all the duties of your office.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:6] As for me, my life blood is already being poured out; the time of my departure is close at hand.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:7] I have run the great race; I have finished the course; I have kept the faith.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:8] And now the crown of righteousness awaits me, which the Lord, the just judge, will give me on ‘that day’ — and not only to me, but to all who have loved his appearing.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:9] Do your utmost to come to me soon;
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:10] for Demas, in his love for the world, has deserted me. He has gone to Thessalonica, Crescens to Galatia, and Titus to Dalmatia.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:11] There is no one but Luke with me. Pick up Mark on your way, and bring him with you, for he is useful to me in my work.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:12] I have sent Tychicus to Ephesus.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:13] Bring with you, when you come, the cloak which I left at Troas with Carpus, and the books, especially the parchments.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:14] Alexander, the coppersmith, showed much ill feeling towards me. ‘The Lord will give him what his actions deserve.’
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:15] You must also on your guard against him, for he is strongly opposed to our teaching.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:16] At my first trial no one stood by me. They all deserted me. May it never be counted against them!
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:17] But the Lord came to my help and strengthened me, in order that, through me, the proclamation should be made so widely that all the Gentiles should hear it; and I was rescued ‘out of the Lion’s mouth.’
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:18] The Lord will rescue me from all evil, and bring me safe into his Heavenly kingdom. All glory to him for ever and ever! Amen.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:19] Give my greeting to Prisca and Aquila, and to the household of Onesiphorus.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:20] Erastus remained at Corinth, and I left Thophimus ill at Miletus.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:21] Do your utmost to come before winter. Eubulus, Pudens, Linus and Claudia send you their greetings, and so do the rest of the Lord's followers.
[OEBcw - 2Tim 4:22] May the Lord be with your soul. God bless you all.
[OEBcw - Titus 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Titus 1:1] From Paul, a servant of God, and an apostle of Jesus Christ, charged to strengthen the faith of God’s chosen people, and their knowledge of that truth which makes for godliness
[OEBcw - Titus 1:2] and is based on the hope of eternal life, which God, who never lies, promised before the ages began,
[OEBcw - Titus 1:3] and has revealed at his own time in his message, with the proclamation of which I was entrusted by the command of God our Saviour.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:4] To Titus, my true child in our one faith: May God, the Father, and Christ Jesus, our Saviour, bless you and give you peace.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:5] My reason for leaving you in Crete was that you might put in order what had been left unsettled, and appoint officers of the church in the various towns, as I myself directed you.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:6] They are to be of irreproachable character, faithful to their partners, whose children are Christians and have never been charged with dissolute conduct or have been unruly.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:7] For a presiding officer, as God’s steward, ought to be of irreproachable character; not self-willed or quick-tempered, nor addicted to drink or to brawling or to questionable money-making.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:8] On the contrary, they should be hospitable, eager for the right, discreet, upright, people of holy life and capable of self-restraint,
[OEBcw - Titus 1:9] who hold doctrine that can be relied on as being in accordance with the accepted teaching; so that they may be able to encourage others by sound teaching, as well as to refute our opponents.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:10] There are, indeed, many unruly persons — great talkers who deceive themselves, principally converts from Judaism,
[OEBcw - Titus 1:11] whose mouths ought to be stopped; for they upset whole households by teaching what they ought not to teach, merely to make questionable gains.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:12] It was a Cretan — one of their own teachers — who said: ‘Cretans are always liars, base brutes, and gluttonous idlers’; and his statement is true.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:13] Therefore rebuke them sharply, so that they may be sound in the faith,
[OEBcw - Titus 1:14] and may pay no attention to Jewish legends, or to the directions of those who turn their backs on the truth.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:15] Everything is pure to the pure-minded, but to those whose minds are polluted and who are unbelievers nothing is pure. Their minds and consciences are alike polluted.
[OEBcw - Titus 1:16] They profess to know God, but by their actions they disown him. They are degraded and self-willed; and, as far as anything good is concerned, they are utterly worthless.
[OEBcw - Titus 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - Titus 2:1] You should, however, speak of such subjects as properly have a place in sound Christian teaching.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:2] Teach that the older men should be temperate, serious, and discreet; strong in faith, love, and endurance.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:3] So, too, that the older women should be reverent in their demeanour, and that they should avoid scandal, and beware of becoming slaves to drink;
[OEBcw - Titus 2:4] that they should teach what is right, so as to train the younger women to love their husbands and children,
[OEBcw - Titus 2:5] and to be discreet, pure-minded, domesticated, good women, respecting the authority of their husbands, in order that God’s message may not be maligned.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:6] And so again with the younger men — impress on them the need of discretion.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:7] Above all, set an example of doing good. Show sincerity in your teaching, and a serious spirit;
[OEBcw - Titus 2:8] let the instruction that you give be sound and above reproach, so that the enemy may be ashamed when he fails to find anything bad to say about us.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:9] Tell slaves to respect their owner's authority in all circumstances, and to try their best to please them.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:10] Teach them not to contradict or to pilfer, but to show such praiseworthy fidelity in everything, as to recommend the teaching about God our Saviour by all that they do.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:11] For the loving kindness of God has been revealed, bringing salvation for all;
[OEBcw - Titus 2:12] leading us to renounce irreligious ways and worldly ambitions, and to live discreet, upright, and religious lives here in this present world,
[OEBcw - Titus 2:13] while we are awaiting our blessed hope — the appearing in glory of our great God and Saviour, Christ Jesus.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:14] For he gave himself on our behalf, to deliver us from all wickedness, and to purify for himself a people who should be peculiarly his own and eager to do good.
[OEBcw - Titus 2:15] Speak of all this, and encourage and rebuke with all authority. Do not let anyone despise you.
[OEBcw - Titus 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - Titus 3:1] Remind your hearers to respect and obey the powers that be, to be ready for every kind of good work, to speak ill of no one, to avoid quarrelling,
[OEBcw - Titus 3:2] to be forbearing, and under all circumstances to show a gentle spirit in dealing with others, whoever they may be.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:3] There was, you remember, a time when we ourselves were foolish, disobedient, misled, slaves to all kinds of passions and vices, living in a spirit of malice and envy, detested ourselves and hating one another.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:4] But, when the kindness of God our Saviour and his love for humanity were revealed, he saved us,
[OEBcw - Titus 3:5] not as the result of any righteous actions that we had done, but in fulfilment of his merciful purposes. He saved us by that washing which was a new birth to us, and by the renewing power of the Holy Spirit,
[OEBcw - Titus 3:6] which he poured out on us abundantly through Jesus Christ our Saviour;
[OEBcw - Titus 3:7] that, having been pronounced righteous through his loving kindness, we might enter on our inheritance with the hope of eternal life.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:8] How true that saying is! And it is on these subjects that I desire you to lay especial stress, so that those who have learned to trust in God may be careful to devote themselves to doing good. Such subjects are excellent in themselves, and of real use to humanity.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:9] But have nothing to do with foolish discussions, or with genealogies, or with controversy, or disputes about the law. They are useless and futile.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:10] If someone is causing divisions among you, after warning them once or twice, have nothing more to say to them.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:11] You may be sure that such a person has forsaken the truth and is in the wrong; they stand self-condemned.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:12] As soon as I send Artemas or Tychicus to you, join me as quickly as possible at Nicopolis, for I have arranged to spend the winter there.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:13] Do your best to help Zenas, the teacher of the law, and Apollos, on their way, and see that they want for nothing.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:14] Let all our people learn to devote themselves to doing good, so as to meet the most pressing needs, and that their lives may not be unfruitful.
[OEBcw - Titus 3:15] All who are with me here send you their greeting. Give my greeting to our friends in the faith. God bless you all.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:1] From Paul, now a prisoner for Christ Jesus, and from Timothy, a fellow follower of the Lord.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:2] To our dear friend and fellow worker Philemon, to our sister Apphia, to our fellow soldier Archippus; and to the church that meets at Philemon’s house;
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:3] may God, our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ bless you and give you peace.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:4] I always mention you in my prayers and thank God for you,
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:5] because I hear of the love and the faith which you show, not only to the Lord Jesus, but also to all his people;
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:6] and I pray that your participation in the faith may result in action, as you come to a fuller realisation of everything that is good and Christlike in us.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:7] I have indeed found great joy and encouragement in your love, knowing, as I do, how the hearts of Christ’s People have been cheered, friend, by you.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:8] And so, though my union with Christ enables me, with all confidence, to dictate the course that you should adopt,
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:9] yet the claims of love make me prefer to plead with you — yes, even me, Paul, though I am an ambassador for Christ Jesus and, now a prisoner for him as well.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:10] I plead with you for this child of mine, Onesimus, to whom, in my prison, I have become a father.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:11] Once he was of little service to you, but now he has become of great service, not only to you, but to me as well;
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:12] and I am sending him back to you with this letter — though it is like tearing out of my ​heart.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:13] For my own sake I should like to keep him with me, so that, while I am in prison for the good news, he might attend to my wants on your behalf.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:14] But I do not wish to do anything without your consent, because I want your generosity to be voluntary and not, as it were, compulsory.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:15] It may be that he was separated from you for an hour, for this ​reason, so that you might have him back for ever,
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:16] no longer as a slave, but as something better — a dearly loved friend and follower of the Lord, especially dear to me, and how much more so to you, not only as a person, but as your fellow Christian!
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:17] If, then, you count me your friend, receive him as you would me.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:18] If he has caused you any loss, or owes you anything, charge it to me.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:19] I, Paul, put my own hand to it — I will repay you myself. I say nothing about your owing me your ​self.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:20] Yes, friend, let me gain something from you because of your union with the Lord. Cheer my heart by your Christlike spirit.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:21] Even as I write, I have such confidence in your compliance with my wishes, that I am sure that you will do even more than I am asking.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:22] Please also get a lodging ready for me, for I hope that I will be given back to you all in answer to your prayers.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:23] Epaphras, who is my fellow prisoner for Christ Jesus, sends you his greeting;
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:24] and Marcus, Aristarchus, Demas, and Luke, my fellow workers, send theirs.
[OEBcw - Phlm 1:25] May the blessing of the Lord Jesus Christ rest on your souls.
[OEBcw - Heb 1 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 1:1] God, who, of old, at many times and in many ways, spoke to our ancestors, by the prophets,
[OEBcw - Heb 1:2] has in these latter days spoken to us by the Son, whom he appointed the heir of all things, and through whom he made the universe.
[OEBcw - Heb 1:3] For he is the radiance of the glory of God and the ​expression of his being, upholding all creation by the power of his word; and, when he had made an expiation for the sins of humanity, he ‘took his seat at the right hand’ of God’s Majesty on high,
[OEBcw - Heb 1:4] having shown himself as much greater than the angels as the name that he has inherited surpasses theirs.
[OEBcw - Heb 1:5] For to which of the angels did God ever say — ‘You are my Son; this day I have become your Father’? or again — ‘I will be to him a Father, and he will be to me a Son’?
[OEBcw - Heb 1:6] And again, when God brought the first-born into the world, he said — ‘Let all the angels of God bow down before him.’
[OEBcw - Heb 1:7] Speaking of the angels, he said — ‘He makes the winds his angels And the flames of fire his servants’;
[OEBcw - Heb 1:8] while of the Son he said — ‘God is your throne for ever and ever; The sceptre of his kingdom is the sceptre of Justice;
[OEBcw - Heb 1:9] You love righteousness and hates iniquity; Therefore God, your God, has anointed you with the festal oil more abundantly than your peers.’
[OEBcw - Heb 1:10] Again — ‘You, Lord, in the beginning did lay the foundation of the earth, And the heavens are the work of your hands.
[OEBcw - Heb 1:11] They will perish, but you remain; As a garment they will all grow old;
[OEBcw - Heb 1:12] As a mantle you will fold them up, And as a garment they will be changed, But you are the same, and your years will know no end.’
[OEBcw - Heb 1:13] To which of the angels has God ever said — ‘Sit you at my right hand Until I put your enemies as a stool for your feet’?
[OEBcw - Heb 1:14] Are not all the angels spirits in the service of God, sent out to minister for the sake of those who are destined to obtain salvation?
[OEBcw - Heb 2 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 2:1] Therefore we must give still more heed to what we were taught, so we do not drift away.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:2] For, if the message which was delivered by angels had its authority confirmed, so that every offence against it, or neglect of it, met with a fitting requital,
[OEBcw - Heb 2:3] how can we, of all people, expect to escape, if we disregard so great a salvation? It was the Master who at the outset spoke of this salvation, and its authority was confirmed for us by those who heard him,
[OEBcw - Heb 2:4] while God himself added his testimony to it by signs, and marvels, and many different miracles, as well as by imparting the Holy Spirit as he saw fit.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:5] God has not given to angels the control of that future world of which we are speaking!
[OEBcw - Heb 2:6] No; a writer has declared somewhere — ‘What are mere mortals that you should remember them? Or human beings that you should care for them?
[OEBcw - Heb 2:7] You have made them, for a while, lower than angels; With glory and honour you have crowned them; You have set them over all that your hands have made;
[OEBcw - Heb 2:8] You have placed all things beneath their feet.’ This ‘placing of everything’ under humanity means that there was nothing which was not placed under them. As yet, however, we do not see everything placed under humanity.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:9] What our eyes do see is Jesus, who was made for a while lower than angels, now, because of his sufferings and death, crowned with glory and honour; so that his tasting the bitterness of death should, in God’s loving kindness, be on behalf of all humanity.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:10] It was, indeed, fitting that God, for whom and through whom all things exist, should, when leading many children to glory, make the author of their salvation perfect through suffering.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:11] For he who purifies, and those whom he purifies, all spring from One; and therefore he is not ashamed to call them his brothers and sisters.’
[OEBcw - Heb 2:12] He says — ‘I will tell of your name to my brothers and sisters, In the midst of the congregation I will sing your praise.’
[OEBcw - Heb 2:13] And again — ‘As for me, I will put my trust in God.’ And yet again — ‘See, here am I and the children whom God gave me.’
[OEBcw - Heb 2:14] Therefore, since human nature is the common heritage of ‘the children,’ Jesus also shared it, in order that by death he might render powerless him whose power lies in death — that is, the devil —
[OEBcw - Heb 2:15] and so might deliver all those who, from fear of death, had all their lives been living in slavery.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:16] It was not, surely, to the help of the angels that Jesus came, but ‘to the help of the descendants of Abraham.’
[OEBcw - Heb 2:17] And consequently it was necessary that he should in all points be made like ‘his brothers and sisters,’ in order that he might prove a merciful as well as a faithful high priest in humanity’s relations with God, for the purpose of expiating the sins of his people.
[OEBcw - Heb 2:18] The fact that he himself suffered under temptation enables him to help those who are tempted.
[OEBcw - Heb 3 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 3:1] Therefore, my Christian friends, you who, all alike, have received the call from heaven, fix your attention on Jesus, the apostle and high priest of our religion.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:2] See how faithful he was to the God who appointed him, as Moses was in the whole house of God.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:3] He has been deemed worthy of far higher honour than Moses, just as the founder of the house is held in greater regard than the house itself.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:4] For every house has its founder, and the founder of the universe is God.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:5] While the faithful service of Moses in the whole house of God was that of a servant, whose duty was to bear testimony to a message still to come,
[OEBcw - Heb 3:6] the faithfulness of Christ was that of a son set over the house of God. And we are his house — if only we retain, unshaken to the end, the courage and confidence inspired by our hope.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:7] Therefore, as the Holy Spirit says — ‘If today you hear God’s voice,
[OEBcw - Heb 3:8] harden not your hearts, as when Israel provoked me On the day when they tried my patience in the desert,
[OEBcw - Heb 3:9] Where your ancestors tried my forbearance, And saw my mighty deeds for forty years.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:10] Therefore I was sorely vexed with that generation, And I said — ​“Their hearts are always straying; They have never learned my ways”;
[OEBcw - Heb 3:11] While in my wrath I swore — “They will never enter upon my rest.”’
[OEBcw - Heb 3:12] Be careful, friends, that there is never found in anyone of you a wicked and faithless heart, shown by that person separating themselves from the living God.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:13] Rather encourage one another daily — while there is a ‘Today’ — to prevent anyone among you from being hardened by the deceitfulness of sin.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:14] For we now all share in the Christ, if indeed we retain, unshaken to the end, the confidence that we had at the first.
[OEBcw - Heb 3:15] To use the words of scripture — ‘If today you hear God’s voice, Harden not your hearts, as when Israel provoked me.’
[OEBcw - Heb 3:16] Who were they who heard God speak and yet provoked him? Were not they all those who left Egypt under the leadership of Moses?
[OEBcw - Heb 3:17] And with whom was it that God was sorely vexed for forty years? Was not it with those who had sinned, and who fell dead in the desert?
[OEBcw - Heb 3:18] And who were they to whom God swore that they should not enter upon his rest, if not those who had proved faithless?
[OEBcw - Heb 3:19] We see, then, that they failed to enter upon it because of their want of faith.
[OEBcw - Heb 4 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 4:1] We must, therefore, be very careful, though there is a promise still standing that we will enter upon God’s rest, that none of you even appear to have missed it.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:2] For we have had the good news told us just as they had. But the message which they heard did them no good, since they did not share the faith of those who were attentive to it.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:3] Upon that rest we who have believed are now entering. As God has said — ‘In my wrath I swore — “They will never enter upon my rest;”’ Although God’s work was finished at the creation of the world;
[OEBcw - Heb 4:4] for, in a passage referring to the seventh day, you will find these words — ‘God rested on the seventh day after all his work.’
[OEBcw - Heb 4:5] On the other hand, we read in that passage — ‘They will never enter upon my rest.’
[OEBcw - Heb 4:6] Since, then, there is still a promise that some will enter upon this rest, and since those who were first told the good news did not enter upon it, because of their disbelief,
[OEBcw - Heb 4:7] again God fixed a day. ‘Today,’ he said, speaking after a long interval through the mouth of David, in the passage already quoted — ‘If today you hear God’s voice Harden not your hearts.’
[OEBcw - Heb 4:8] Now if Joshua had given ‘rest’ to the people, God would not have spoken of another and later day.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:9] There is, then, a Sabbath rest still awaiting God’s people.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:10] For the person who enters upon God’s rest do themselves rest after their work, just as God did.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:11] Let us, therefore, make every effort to enter upon that rest, so that none of us fall through such disbelief as that of which we have had an example.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:12] God’s message is a living and active power, sharper than any two-edged sword, piercing its way until it penetrates soul and spirit — not the joints only but the ​marrow — and detecting the inmost thoughts and purposes of the mind.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:13] There is no created thing that can hide itself from the sight of God. Everything is exposed and laid bare before the eyes of him to whom we have to give account.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:14] We have, then , in Jesus, the Son of God, a great high priest who has passed into the highest heaven; let us, therefore, hold fast to the faith which we have professed.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:15] Our high priest is not one unable to sympathise with our weaknesses, but one who has in every way been tempted, exactly as we have been, but without sinning.
[OEBcw - Heb 4:16] Therefore, let us draw near boldly to the throne of love, to find pity and love for the hour of need.
[OEBcw - Heb 5 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 5:1] Every high priest, taken from among the people, is appointed as their representative in their relations with God, to offer both gifts and sacrifices in expiation of sins.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:2] And he is able to sympathise with the ignorant and deluded, since he is himself subject to weakness,
[OEBcw - Heb 5:3] and is therefore bound to offer sacrifices for sins, not only for the people, but equally so for himself.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:4] Nor does anyone take that high office on themselves, until they have been called to do so by God, as Aaron was.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:5] In the same way, even the Christ did not take the honour of the high priesthood on himself, but he was appointed by him who said to him — ‘You are my Son; this day I have become your Father’;
[OEBcw - Heb 5:6] and on another occasion also — ‘You are a priest for all time of the order of Melchizedek.’
[OEBcw - Heb 5:7] Jesus, in the days of his earthly life, offered prayers and supplications, with earnest cries and with tears, to him who was able to save him from death; and he was heard because of his devout submission.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:8] Son though he was, he learned obedience from his sufferings;
[OEBcw - Heb 5:9] and, being made perfect, he became to all those who obey him the source of eternal salvation,
[OEBcw - Heb 5:10] while God himself pronounced him a high priest of the order of Melchizedek.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:11] Now on this subject I have much to say, but it is difficult to explain it to you, because you have shown yourselves so slow to learn.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:12] For whereas, considering the time that has elapsed, you ought to be teaching others, you still need some one to teach you the ​alphabet of the divine revelation, and need again to be fed with ‘milk’ instead of with ‘solid food.’
[OEBcw - Heb 5:13] For everyone who still has to take ‘milk’ knows nothing of the teaching of righteousness; they are a mere infant.
[OEBcw - Heb 5:14] But ‘solid food’ is for Christians of mature faith — those whose faculties have been trained by practice to distinguish right from wrong.
[OEBcw - Heb 6 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 6:1] Therefore, let us leave behind the elementary teaching about the Christ and press on to perfection, not always laying over again a foundation of repentance for a lifeless formality, of faith in God —
[OEBcw - Heb 6:2] teaching concerning baptisms and the laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead and a final judgment.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:3] Yes and, with God’s help, we will.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:4] For if those who were once for all brought into the light, and learned to appreciate the gift from heaven, and came to share in the Holy Spirit,
[OEBcw - Heb 6:5] and learned to appreciate the beauty of the divine message, and the new powers of the coming age —
[OEBcw - Heb 6:6] if those, I say, fell away, it would be impossible to bring them again to repentance; they would be crucifying the Son of God over again for themselves, and exposing him to open contempt.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:7] Ground that drinks in the showers that from time to time fall on it, and produces vegetation useful to those for whom it is tilled, receives a blessing from God;
[OEBcw - Heb 6:8] but, if it ‘bears thorns and thistles,’ it is regarded as worthless, it is in danger of being ‘cursed,’ and its end will be the fire.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:9] But about you, dear friends, even though we speak in this way, we are confident of better things — of things that point to your salvation.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:10] For God is not unjust; he will not forget the work that you did, and the love that you showed for his name, in sending help to your fellow Christians — as you are still doing.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:11] But our great desire is that every one of you should be equally earnest to attain to a full conviction that our hope will be fulfilled, and that you should keep that hope to the end.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:12] Then you will not show yourselves slow to learn, but you will copy those who, through faith and patience, are now entering upon the enjoyment of God’s promises.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:13] When God gave his promise to Abraham, since there was no one greater by whom he could swear, he swore by himself.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:14] His words were — ‘I will assuredly bless you and increase your numbers.’
[OEBcw - Heb 6:15] And so, after patiently waiting, Abraham obtained the fulfilment of God’s promise.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:16] People, of course, swear by what is greater than themselves, and with them an oath is accepted as putting a matter beyond all dispute.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:17] And therefore God, in his desire to show, with unmistakable plainness, to those who were to enter on the enjoyment of what he had promised, the unchangeableness of his purpose, bound himself with an oath.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:18] For he intended us to find great encouragement in these two unchangeable things, which make it impossible for God to prove false — we, I mean, who fled for safety where we might lay hold on the hope set before us.
[OEBcw - Heb 6:19] This hope is an anchor for our souls, secure and strong, and it ‘reaches into the sanctuary that lies behind the curtain,’
[OEBcw - Heb 6:20] where Jesus, our forerunner, has entered on our behalf, after being made for all time a high priest of the order of Melchizedek.
[OEBcw - Heb 7 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 7:1] It was this Melchizedek, king of Salem and priest of the Most High God, who met Abraham returning from the slaughter of the kings, and gave him his blessing;
[OEBcw - Heb 7:2] and it was to him that Abraham allotted a tithe of all the spoil. The meaning of his name is ‘king of righteousness,’ and besides that, he was also king of Salem, which means ‘king of peace.’
[OEBcw - Heb 7:3] There is no record of his father, or mother, or lineage, nor again of any beginning of his days, or end of his life. In this he resembles the Son of God, and stands before us as a priest whose priesthood is continuous.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:4] Consider, then the importance of this Melchizedek, to whom even the patriarch Abraham himself gave a tithe of the choicest spoils.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:5] Those descendants of Levi, who are from time to time appointed to the priesthood, are directed to collect tithes from the people in accordance with the law — that is from their own kindred, although they also are descended from Abraham.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:6] But Melchizedek, although not of this lineage, received tithes from Abraham, and gave his blessing to the ​man who had God’s promises.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:7] Now no one can dispute that it is the superior who blesses the inferior.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:8] In the one case the tithes are received by people who are mortal; in the other case by one about whom there is the statement that his life still continues.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:9] Moreover, in a sense, even Levi, who is the receiver of the tithes, has, through Abraham, paid tithes;
[OEBcw - Heb 7:10] for Levi was still in the body of his ancestor when Melchizedek met Abraham.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:11] If, then, perfection had been attainable through the Levitical priesthood — and it was under this priesthood that the people received the law — why was it still necessary that a priest of a different order should appear, a priest of the order of Melchizedek and not of the order of Aaron?
[OEBcw - Heb 7:12] With the change of the priesthood a change of the law became a necessity.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:13] And he of whom all this is said belonged to quite a different tribe, no member of which has ever served at the altar.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:14] For it is plain that our Lord had sprung from the tribe of Judah, though of that tribe Moses said nothing about their being priests.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:15] All this becomes even yet plainer when we remember that a new priest has appeared, resembling Melchizedek,
[OEBcw - Heb 7:16] and that he was appointed, not under a law regulating only earthly matters, but by virtue of a life beyond the reach of death;
[OEBcw - Heb 7:17] for that is the meaning of the declaration — ‘You are for all time a priest of the order of Melchizedek.’
[OEBcw - Heb 7:18] On the one hand, we have the abolition of a previous regulation as being both inefficient and useless
[OEBcw - Heb 7:19] (for the law never brought anything to perfection); and, on the other hand, we have the introduction of a better hope, which enables us to draw near to God.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:20] Then again, the appointment of this new priest was ratified by an oath, which is not so with the Levitical priests,
[OEBcw - Heb 7:21] but his appointment was ratified by an oath, when God said to him — ‘The Lord has sworn, and will not change, “You are a priest for all time.”’
[OEBcw - Heb 7:22] And the oath shows the corresponding superiority of the covenant of which Jesus is appointed the surety.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:23] Again, new Levitical priests are continually being appointed, because death prevents their remaining in office;
[OEBcw - Heb 7:24] but Jesus remains for all time, and therefore the priesthood that he holds will never pass to another.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:25] And that is why he is able to save perfectly those who come to God through him, living for ever, as he does, to intercede of their behalf.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:26] This was the high priest that we needed — holy, innocent, spotless, withdrawn from sinners, exalted above the highest heaven,
[OEBcw - Heb 7:27] one who has no need to offer sacrifices daily as those high priests have, first for their own sins, and then for those of the people. For this he did once and for all, when he offered himself as the sacrifice.
[OEBcw - Heb 7:28] The law appoints as high priests men who are weak, but the words of God’s oath, which was later than the law, name the Son as, for all time, the perfect priest.
[OEBcw - Heb 8 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 8:1] To sum up what I have been saying: — Such is the high priest that we have, one who ‘has taken his seat at the right hand’ of the throne of God’s Majesty in heaven,
[OEBcw - Heb 8:2] where he ministers in the sanctuary, in that true tent set up by the Lord and not by man.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:3] Every high priest is appointed for the purpose of offering gifts and sacrifices to God; it follows, therefore, that this high priest must have some offering to make.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:4] If he were, however, still on earth, he would not even be a priest, since there are already priests who offer the gifts as the law directs.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:5] (These priests, it is true, are engaged in a service which is only a copy and shadow of the heavenly realities, as is shown by the directions given to Moses when he was about to construct the tent. ‘Look to it,’ are the words, ‘that you make every part in accordance with the pattern shown you on the mountain.’)
[OEBcw - Heb 8:6] But Jesus, as we see, has obtained a ministry as far excelling theirs, as the covenant of which he is the intermediary, based, as it is, on better promises, excels the former covenant.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:7] If that first covenant had been faultless, there would have been no occasion for a second.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:8] But, finding fault with the people, God says — ‘“A time is coming,” says the Lord, “When I will ratify a new covenant with the people of Israel and with the people of Judah —
[OEBcw - Heb 8:9] Not such a covenant as I made with their ancestors On the day when I took them by the hand to lead them out of the land of Egypt. For they did not abide by their covenant with me, And therefore I disregarded them,” says the Lord.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:10] “This is the covenant that I will make with the people of Israel After those days,” says the Lord. “I will impress my laws on their minds, And will inscribe them on their hearts; And I will be their God, And they will be my people.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:11] There will be no need for anyone to instruct their fellow citizen, Or for a person to say to their relatives ‘Learn to know the Lord’; For everyone will know me, From the lowest to the highest.
[OEBcw - Heb 8:12] For I will be merciful to their wrong-doings, And I will no longer remember their sins.”’
[OEBcw - Heb 8:13] By speaking of a ‘new’ covenant, God at once renders the former covenant obsolete; and whatever becomes obsolete and loses its force is virtually annulled.
[OEBcw - Heb 9 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 9:1] It is true that even the first covenant had its regulations for divine worship, and its sanctuary — though only a material one.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:2] For a tent was constructed, with an outer part which contained the stand for the lamps, and the table, and the consecrated bread. This is called the sanctuary.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:3] The part of the tent behind the second curtain is called the inner sanctuary.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:4] In it is the gold incense-altar, and the ark containing the covenant, completely covered with gold. In the ark is a gold casket containing the manna, Aaron’s rod that budded, and the tablets on which the covenant was written;
[OEBcw - Heb 9:5] while above it, and overshadowing the cover on which atonement was made, are the cherubim of the presence. Now is not the time to discuss these things in detail.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:6] Such, then, was the arrangement of the tent. Into the outer part priests are constantly going, in the discharge of their sacred duties;
[OEBcw - Heb 9:7] but into the inner only the high priest goes, and that but once a year, and never without taking the blood of a victim, which he offers on his own behalf, and on behalf of the errors of the people.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:8] By this the Holy Spirit is teaching that the way into the sanctuary was hidden, as long as the outer part of the tent still remained.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:9] For that was only a type, to continue down to the present time; and, in keeping with it, both gifts and sacrifices are offered, though incapable of satisfying the conscience of the worshiper;
[OEBcw - Heb 9:10] the whole system being concerned only with food and drink and various ablutions — external ceremonials imposed until the coming of the new order.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:11] But, when Christ came, he appeared as high priest of that better system which was established; and he entered through that nobler and more perfect ‘tent,’ not made by human hands — that is to say, not a part of this present creation.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:12] Nor was it with the blood of goats and calves, but with his own blood, that he entered, once and for all, into the sanctuary, and obtained our eternal deliverance.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:13] For, if the blood of goats and bulls, and the sprinkling of the ashes of a heifer, purify those who have been defiled (as far as ceremonial purification goes),
[OEBcw - Heb 9:14] how much more will the blood of the Christ, who, through his eternal Spirit, offered himself up to God, as a victim without blemish, purify our consciences from a lifeless formality, and fit us for the service of the living God!
[OEBcw - Heb 9:15] And that is why he is the intermediary of a new covenant; in order that, as a death has taken place to effect a deliverance from the offences committed under the first covenant, those who have received the call may obtain the eternal inheritance promised to them.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:16] Whenever such a covenant as a will is in question, the death of the testator must of necessity be alleged.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:17] For such a covenant takes effect only on death, it does not come into force as long as the testator is alive.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:18] This explains why even the first covenant was not ratified without the shedding of blood.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:19] For, when every command had been announced to all the people by Moses in accordance with the law, he took the blood of the calves and of the goats, with water, scarlet wool, and a bunch of hyssop, and sprinkled even the book of the law, as well as all the people,
[OEBcw - Heb 9:20] saying, as he did so — ​“This is the blood that renders valid the covenant which God has commanded to be made with you.”
[OEBcw - Heb 9:21] And in the same way he also sprinkled with the blood the tent and all the things that were used in public worship.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:22] Indeed, under the law, almost everything is purified with blood; and, unless blood is shed, no forgiveness is to be obtained.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:23] While, then, it was necessary for the copies of the heavenly realities to be purified by such means as these, the heavenly realities themselves required better sacrifices.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:24] For it was not into a sanctuary made by human hands, which merely foreshadowed the true one, that Christ entered, but into heaven itself, so that he might now appear in the presence of God on our behalf.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:25] Nor yet was it to offer himself may times, as year after year the high priest entered the sanctuary with an offering of blood — but not his own blood;
[OEBcw - Heb 9:26] for then Christ would have had to undergo death many times since the creation of the world. But now, once and for all, at the close of the age, he has appeared, in order to abolish sin by the sacrifice of himself.
[OEBcw - Heb 9:27] And, as it is ordained for people to die but once (death being followed by judgment),
[OEBcw - Heb 9:28] so it is with the Christ. He was offered up once and for all, to ‘bear away the sins of many’; and the second time he will appear — but without any burden of sin — to those who are waiting for him, to bring salvation.
[OEBcw - Heb 10 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 10:1] The law, though able to foreshadow the better system which was coming, never had its actual substance. Its priests, with those sacrifices which they offer continuously year after year, can never make those who come to worship perfect.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:2] Otherwise, would not the offering of these sacrifices have been abandoned, as the worshipers, having been once purified, would have had their consciences clear from sins?
[OEBcw - Heb 10:3] But, on the contrary, these sacrifices recall their sins to mind year after year.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:4] For the blood of bulls and goats is powerless to remove sins.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:5] That is why, when he was coming into the world, the Christ declared — ‘Sacrifice and offering you do not desire, but you ​provide for me a body;
[OEBcw - Heb 10:6] You ​take no pleasure in burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:7] So I said, “See, I have come’ (as is written of me in the pages of the book), “To do your will, God.”’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:8] First come the words — ​‘You do not desire, nor do you take pleasure in, sacrifices, offerings, burnt offerings, and sacrifices for sin’ (offerings regularly made under the law),
[OEBcw - Heb 10:9] and then there is added — ​‘See, I have come to do your will.’ The former sacrifices are set aside to be replaced by the latter.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:10] And it is in the fulfilment of the will of God that we have been purified by the sacrifice, once and for all, of the body of Jesus Christ.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:11] Every other priest stands day after day at his ministrations, and offers the same sacrifices over and over again — sacrifices that can never take sins away.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:12] But, this priest, after he had offered one sacrifice for sins, which should serve for all time, ‘took his seat at the right hand of God,’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:13] and has since then been waiting ‘for his enemies to be put as a stool for his feet.’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:14] By a single offering he has made perfect for all time those who are being purified.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:15] We have also the testimony of the Holy Spirit. For, after saying —
[OEBcw - Heb 10:16] ‘“This is the covenant that I will make with them After those days,” says the Lord; “I will impress my laws on their hearts, And will inscribe them on their minds,”’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:17] then we have — ‘And their sins and their iniquities I will no longer remember.’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:18] And, when these are forgiven, there is no further need of an offering for sin.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:19] Therefore, friends, since we may enter the sanctuary with confidence, in virtue of the blood of Jesus,
[OEBcw - Heb 10:20] by the way which he inaugurated for us — a new and living way, a way through the sanctuary curtain (that is, his human nature);
[OEBcw - Heb 10:21] and, since we have in him ‘a great priest set over the house of God,’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:22] let us draw near to God in all sincerity of heart and in perfect faith, with our hearts purified by the sprinkled blood from all consciousness of wrong, and with our bodies washed with pure water.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:23] Let us maintain the confession of our hope unshaken, for he who has given us his promise will not fail us.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:24] Let us vie with one another in a rivalry of love and noble actions.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:25] And let us not, as some do, cease to meet together; but, on the contrary, let us encourage one another, and all the more, now that you see the day drawing near.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:26] Remember, if we sin wilfully after we have gained a full knowledge of the truth, there can be no further sacrifice for sin;
[OEBcw - Heb 10:27] there is only a fearful anticipation of judgment, and a burning indignation which will destroy all opponents.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:28] When someone disregarded the law of Moses, they were, on the evidence of two or three witnesses, put to death without pity.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:29] How much worse then, think you, will be the punishment deserved by those who have trampled underfoot the Son of God, who have treated the blood that rendered the covenant valid — the ​blood by which they were purified — as if it were not holy, and who have outraged the Spirit of love?
[OEBcw - Heb 10:30] We know who it was that said — ‘It is for me to avenge, I will requite’; and again — ‘The Lord will judge his people.’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:31] It is a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:32] Call to mind those early days in which, after you had received the light, you patiently underwent a long and painful conflict.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:33] Sometimes, in consequence of the taunts and injuries heaped on you, you became a public spectacle; and sometimes you suffered through having shown yourselves to be the friends of people who were in the same position in which you had been.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:34] For you not only sympathised with those who were in prison, but you even took the confiscation of your possessions joyfully, knowing, as you did, that you had in yourselves a greater possession and a lasting one.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:35] Do not, therefore, abandon the confidence that you have gained, for it has a great reward awaiting it.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:36] You still have need of patient endurance, in order that, when you have done God’s will, you may obtain the fulfilment of his promise.
[OEBcw - Heb 10:37] ‘For there is indeed but a very little while Ere He who is coming will have come, without delay;
[OEBcw - Heb 10:38] And through faith the righteous ​will find ​life, But, if anyone draws back, my heart can find no pleasure in them.’
[OEBcw - Heb 10:39] But we do not belong to those who draw back, to their ruin, but to those who have faith, to the saving of their souls.
[OEBcw - Heb 11 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 11:1] Faith is the realisation of things hoped for — the proof of things not seen.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:2] And it was for faith that the people of old were renowned.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:3] Faith enables us to perceive that the universe was created at the bidding of God — so that we know that what we see was not made out of visible things.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:4] Faith made the sacrifice which Abel offered to God a better sacrifice than Cain’s, and won him renown as a righteous man, God himself establishing his renown by accepting his gifts; and it is by the example of his faith that Abel, though dead, still speaks.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:5] Faith led to Enoch’s removal from earth, so that he might not experience death. ‘He could not be found because God had removed him.’ For, before his removal, he was renowned as having pleased God;
[OEBcw - Heb 11:6] but without faith it is impossible to please him, for he who comes to God must believe that God exists, and that he rewards those who seek for him.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:7] It was faith that enabled Noah, after he had received the divine warning about what could not then be foreseen, to build, in reverent obedience, an ark in which to save his family. By his faith he condemned the world, and became possessed of that righteousness which follows on faith.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:8] It was faith that enabled Abraham to obey the call that he received, and to set out for the place which he was afterwards to obtain as his own; and he set out not knowing where he was going.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:9] It was faith that made him go to live as an emigrant in the promised land — as in a strange country — living there in tents with Isaac and Jacob, who shared the promise with him.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:10] For he was looking for the city with the sure foundations, whose architect and builder is God.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:11] Again, it was faith that enabled Sarah to conceive (though she was past the age for child-bearing), because she felt sure that he who had given her the promise would not fail her.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:12] And so from one man — and that when his powers were dead — there sprang a people as numerous ‘as the stars in the heavens or the countless grains of sand on the shore.’
[OEBcw - Heb 11:13] All these died sustained by faith. They did not obtain the promised blessings, but they saw them from a distance and welcomed the sight, and they acknowledged themselves to be only aliens and strangers on the earth.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:14] Those who speak like this show plainly that they are seeking their homeland.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:15] If they had been thinking of the land that they had left, they could have found opportunities to return.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:16] But no, they were longing for a better, a heavenly, land! And therefore God was not ashamed to be called their God; indeed he had already prepared them a city.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:17] It was faith that enabled Abraham, when put to the test, to offer Isaac as a sacrifice — he who had received the promises offering up his only son,
[OEBcw - Heb 11:18] of whom it had been said — ‘It is through Isaac that there will be descendants to bear your name.’
[OEBcw - Heb 11:19] For he argued that God was even able to raise a man from the dead — and indeed, figuratively speaking, Abraham did receive Isaac back from the dead.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:20] It was faith that enabled Isaac to bless Jacob and Esau, even with regard to the future.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:21] Faith enabled Jacob, when dying, to give his blessing to each of the sons of Joseph, and ‘to bow himself in worship as he leant on the top of his staff.’
[OEBcw - Heb 11:22] Faith caused Joseph, when his end was near, to speak of the future migration of the Israelites, and to give instructions with regard to his bones.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:23] Faith caused the parents of Moses to hide the child for three months after his birth, for they saw that he was a beautiful child; and they would not respect the king’s order.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:24] It was faith that caused Moses, when he was grown up, to refuse the title of ‘son of a daughter of Pharaoh.’
[OEBcw - Heb 11:25] He preferred sharing the hardships of God’s people to enjoying the short-lived pleasures of sin.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:26] For he counted ‘the reproaches that are heaped on the Christ’ of greater value than the treasures of Egypt, looking forward, as he did, to the reward awaiting him.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:27] Faith caused him to leave Egypt, though undaunted by the king’s anger, for he was strengthened in his endurance by the vision of the invisible God.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:28] Faith led him to institute the Passover and the sprinkling of the blood, so that the Destroyer might not touch the eldest children of the Israelites.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:29] Faith enabled the people to cross the Red Sea, as if it had been dry land, while the Egyptians, when they attempted to do so, were drowned.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:30] Faith caused the walls of Jericho to fall after being encircled for seven days.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:31] Faith saved Rahab, the prostitute, from perishing with the unbelievers, after she had entertained the spies with friendliness.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:32] Need I add anything more? Time would fail me if I attempted to relate the stories of Gideon, Barak, Samson, and Jephthah, and those of David, Samuel, and the prophets.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:33] By their faith they subdued kingdoms, ruled righteously, gained the fulfilment of God’s promises, ‘shut the mouths of lions,’
[OEBcw - Heb 11:34] quelled the fury of the flames, escaped the edge of the sword, found strength in the hour of weakness, displayed their prowess in war, and routed hostile armies.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:35] Women received back their dead raised to life. Some were tortured on the wheel, and refused release in order that they might rise to a better life.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:36] Others had to face taunts and blows, and even chains and imprisonment.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:37] They were stoned to death, they were tortured, they were swan asunder, they were put to the sword; they wandered about clothed in the skins of sheep or goats, destitute, persecuted, ill-used —
[OEBcw - Heb 11:38] people of whom the world was not worthy — roaming in lonely places, and on the mountains, and in caves and holes in the ground.
[OEBcw - Heb 11:39] Yet, though they all won renown by their faith, they did not obtain the final fulfilment of God’s promise;
[OEBcw - Heb 11:40] since God had in view some better thing for us, so that they would only reach perfection together with us.
[OEBcw - Heb 12 - start] 
[OEBcw - Heb 12:1] Seeing, therefore, that there is on every side of us such a throng of witnesses, let us also lay aside everything that hinders us, and the sin that clings about us, and run with patient endurance the race that lies before us,
[OEBcw - Heb 12:2] our eyes fixed on Jesus, the leader and perfect example of our faith, who, for the joy that lay before him, endured the cross, heedless of its shame, and now ‘has taken his seat at the right hand’ of the throne of God.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:3] Weigh well the example of him who had to endure such opposition from ‘people who were sinning against themselves,’ so that you should not grow weary or faint-hearted.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:4] You have not yet, in your struggle with sin, resisted to the death;
[OEBcw - Heb 12:5] and you have forgotten the encouraging words which are addressed to you as God’s children — ‘My child, think not lightly of the Lord’s discipline, Do not despond when he rebukes you;
[OEBcw - Heb 12:6] For it is him whom he loves that he disciplines, And he chastises every child whom he acknowledges.’
[OEBcw - Heb 12:7] It is for your discipline that you have to endure all this. God is dealing with you as his children. For where is there a child whom his father does not discipline?
[OEBcw - Heb 12:8] If you are left without that discipline, in which all children share, it shows that you are bastards, and not true children.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:9] Further, when our earthly fathers disciplined us, we respected them. Should we not, then, much rather yield submission to the Father of souls, and live?
[OEBcw - Heb 12:10] Our fathers disciplined us for only a short time and as seemed best to them; but God disciplines us for our true good, to enable us to share his holiness.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:11] No discipline is pleasant at the time; on the contrary, it is painful. But afterwards its fruit is seen in the peacefulness of a righteous life which is the lot of those who have been trained under it.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:12] Therefore ‘lift again the down-dropped hands and straighten the weakened knees;
[OEBcw - Heb 12:13] make straight paths for your feet,’ so that the lame limb may not be put out of joint, but rather be cured.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:14] Try earnestly to live at peace with everyone, and to attain to that purity without which no one will see the Lord.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:15] Take care that no one fails to use the loving help of God, ‘that no bitterness is allowed to take root and spring up, and cause trouble,’ and so poison the whole community.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:16] Take care that no one becomes immoral, or irreligious like Esau, who sold his birthright for a single meal.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:17] For you know that even afterwards, when he wished to claim his father’s blessing, he was rejected — for he never found an opportunity to repair his error — though he begged for the blessing with tears.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:18] It is not to tangible ‘flaming fire’ that you have drawn near, nor to ‘gloom, and darkness, and storm,
[OEBcw - Heb 12:19] and the blast of a trumpet, and an audible voice.’ Those who heard that voice entreated that they might hear no more,
[OEBcw - Heb 12:20] for they could not bear to think of the command — ​‘If even an animal touches the mountain, it is to be stoned to death;’
[OEBcw - Heb 12:21] and so fearful was the sight that Moses said — ​‘I tremble with fear.’
[OEBcw - Heb 12:22] No, but it is to Mount Zion that you have drawn near, the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, to countless hosts of angels,
[OEBcw - Heb 12:23] to the festal gathering and assemblage of God’s firstborn whose names are enrolled in heaven, to God the judge of all people, to the spirits of the righteous who have attained perfection,
[OEBcw - Heb 12:24] to Jesus, the intermediary of a new covenant, and to the sprinkled blood that tells of better things than the blood of Abel.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:25] Beware how you refuse to hear him who is speaking. For, if the Israelites did not escape punishment, when they refused to listen to him who taught them on earth the divine will, far worse will it be for us, if we turn away from him who is teaching us from heaven.
[OEBcw - Heb 12:26] Then his voice shook the earth, but now his declaration is — ‘Still once more I will cause not only the earth to tremble, but also the heavens.’
[OEBcw - Heb 12:27] And those words ‘still once more’ indicate the passing away of all that is shaken — that is, of all created things — in order that only what is unshaken may remain.
